TEXT: CHAPTER [I]_p0 [JONATHAN HARKER]_n'S0 JOURNAL 3 [May]_n1. [Bistritz]_n2. , [Left Munich]_n3 at 8:35 P. M. , on 1st May, arriving at Vienna early next morning should have arrived at 6:46, but train was an hour late. Buda-Pesth seems a wonderful place, from the glimpse which [I]_p1 got of [it]_p3 from the train and the little [I]_p2 could walk through the streets. [I]_p4 feared to go very far from the station, as [we]_p5 had arrived late and would start as near the correct time as possible. The impression [I]_p6 had was that [we]_p7 were leaving the West and entering the [East]_n4 the most western of splendid bridges over the Danube, which is here of noble width and depth, took [us]_p8 among the traditions of Turkish rule. [We]_p9 left in pretty good time, and came after nightfall to Klausenburgh. Here [I]_p10 stopped for the night at the [Hotel Royale]_n5.

[I]_p11 had for dinner, or rather supper, a chicken done up some way with red pepper, which was very good but thirsty. ([Mem]_n6. , get recipe for [Mina]_n7. ) [I]_p12 asked the waiter, and [he]_p14 said [it]_p15 was called "paprika hendl," and that, as [it]_p16 was a national dish, [I]_p13 should be able to get [it]_p16 anywhere along the Carpathians. [I]_p18 found [my]_p21 smattering of German very useful here indeed, [I]_p19 don't know how [I]_p19 should be able to get on without it. Having had some time at [my]_p22 disposal when in London, [I]_p23 had visited the [British]_n8 Museum, and made search among the books and maps in the library regarding [Transylvania]_n9 [it]_p24 had struck [me]_p25 that some foreknowledge of the country could hardly fail to have some importance in dealing with a nobleman of that country. [I]_p26 find that the district [he]_p27 named is in the extreme east of the country, just on the borders of three states, [Transylvania]_n,10 Moldavia and [Bukovina]_n,11 in the midst of the Carpathian mountains one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe. [I]_p28 was not able to light on any map or work giving the exact locality of the Castle Dracula, as there are no maps of this country as yet to compare with [our]_p30 own Ordnance Survey maps but [I]_p29 found that Bistritz, the post town named by [Count Dracula]_n,12 is a fairly well-known place. [I]_p31 shall enter here some of [my]_p33 notes, as [they]_p36 may refresh [my]_p34 memory when [I]_p32 talk over [my]_p34 travels with Mina. In the population of [Transylvania]_n13 there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with [them]_p37 the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the [East]_n14 and North.

[I]_p38 am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century [they]_p39 found the Huns settled in it. [I]_p40 read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if [it]_p41 were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool if so [my]_p42 stay may be very interesting. ([Mem]_n15. , [I]_p43 must ask the Count all about them. )  [I]_p44 did not sleep well, though [my]_p46 bed was comfortable enough, for [I]_p45 had all sorts of queer dreams. There was a dog howling all night under [my]_p47 window, which may have had something to do with [it]_p49 or [it]_p50 may have been the paprika, for [I]_p51 had to drink up all the water in [my]_p48 carafe, and was still thirsty. Towards morning [I]_p52 slept and was wakened by the continuous knocking at [my]_p55 door, so [I]_p53 guess [I]_p53 must have been sleeping soundly then. [I]_p56 had for breakfast more paprika, and a sort of porridge of maize flour which [they]_p57 said was "mamaliga," and egg-plant stuffed with forcemeat, a very excellent dish, which [they]_p58 call "impletata. " ([Mem]_n16.

, get recipe for this also. ) [I]_p59 had to hurry breakfast, for the train started a little before eight, or rather [it]_p61 ought to have done so, for after rushing to the station at 7:30 [I]_p60 had to sit in the carriage for more than an hour before [we]_p62 began to move. [It]_p63 seems to [me]_p64 that the further east [you]_p65 go the more unpunctual are the trains. What ought [they]_p66 to be in [China]_n?17 All day long [we]_p67 seemed to dawdle through a country which was full of beauty of every kind. Sometimes [we]_p68 saw little towns or castles on the top of steep hills such as [we]_p69 see in old missals sometimes [we]_p69 ran by rivers and streams which seemed from the wide stony margin on each side of [them]_p71 to be subject to great floods. [It]_p72 takes a lot of water, and running strong, to sweep the outside edge of a river clear. At every station there were groups of people, sometimes crowds, and in all sorts of attire. Some of [them]_p73 were just like the peasants at home or those [I]_p74 saw coming through France and Germany, with short jackets and round hats and home-made trousers but others were very picturesque. The women looked pretty, except when [you]_p75 got near them, but [they]_p76 were very clumsy about the waist. [They]_p77 had all full white sleeves of some kind or other, and most of [them]_p78 had big belts with a lot of strips of something fluttering from [them]_p79 like the dresses in a ballet, but of course there were petticoats under them.

The strangest figures [we]_p81 saw were the Slovaks, who were more barbarian than the rest, with [their]_p82 big cow-boy hats, great baggy dirty-white trousers, white linen shirts, and enormous heavy leather belts, nearly a foot wide, all studded over with brass nails. [They]_p83 wore high boots, with [their]_p84 trousers tucked into them, and had long black hair and heavy black moustaches. [They]_p85 are very picturesque, but do not look prepossessing. On the stage [they]_p86 would be set down at once as some old Oriental band of brigands. [They]_p87 are, however, [I]_p88 am told, very harmless and rather wanting in natural self-assertion. [It]_p89 was on the dark side of twilight when [we]_p90 got to [Bistritz]_n,18 which is a very interesting old place. Being practically on the frontier, for the [Borgo Pass]_n19 leads from [it]_p91 into [Bukovina]_n,20 [it]_p92 has had a very stormy existence, and [it]_p92 certainly shows marks of it. Fifty years ago a series of great fires took place, which made terrible havoc on five separate occasions. At the very beginning of the seventeenth century [it]_p95 underwent a siege of three weeks and lost 13,000 people, the casualties of war proper being assisted by famine and disease. [Count Dracula]_n21 had directed [me]_p96 to go to the [Golden Krone Hotel]_n,22 which [I]_p97 found, to [my]_p100 great delight, to be thoroughly old-fashioned, for of course [I]_p98 wanted to see all [I]_p98 could of the ways of the country.

[I]_p101 was evidently expected, for when [I]_p102 got near the door [I]_p102 faced a cheery-looking elderly woman in the usual peasant dress, white undergarment with long double apron, front, and back, of coloured stuff fitting almost too tight for modesty. When [I]_p104 came close [she]_p106 bowed and said, "The Herr Englishman?" "Yes," [I]_p105 said, "Jonathan Harker. " [She]_p107 smiled, and gave some message to an elderly man in white shirt-sleeves, who had followed [her]_p108 to the door. [He]_p109 went, but immediately returned with a letter:,   "My Friend. , Welcome to the Carpathians. [I]_p110 am anxiously expecting you. Sleep well [to-night]_n23. At three to-morrow the diligence will start for [Bukovina]_n24 a place on [it]_p111 is kept for you. At the [Borgo Pass]_n25 [my]_p112 carriage will await [you]_p113 and will bring [you]_p114 to me. [I]_p115 trust that [your]_p116 journey from London has been a happy one, and that [you]_p118 will enjoy [your]_p117 stay in [my]_p119 beautiful land.

"Your friend,  "DRACULA. " 4 [May]_n26. , [I]_p120 found that [my]_p121 landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing [him]_p123 to secure the best place on the coach for [me]_p124 but on making inquiries as to details [he]_p125 seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that [he]_p126 could not understand [my]_p122 German. This could not be true, because up to then [he]_p127 had understood [it]_p130 perfectly at least, [he]_p128 answered [my]_p131 questions exactly as if [he]_p128 did. [He]_p132 and [his]_p133 wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened sort of way. [He]_p134 mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all [he]_p135 knew. When [I]_p136 asked [him]_p137 if [he]_p138 knew [Count Dracula]_n,27 and could tell [me]_p140 anything of [his]_p141 castle, both [he]_p139 and [his]_p142 wife crossed themselves, and, saying that [they]_p143 knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. [It]_p144 was so near the time of starting that [I]_p145 had no time to ask any one else, for [it]_p146 was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting. Just before [I]_p147 was leaving, the old lady came up to [my]_p149 room and said in a very hysterical way: "Must [you]_p150 go? Oh! [young Herr]_n,28 must [you]_p151 go?" [She]_p152 was in such an excited state that [she]_p153 seemed to have lost [her]_p155 grip of what German [she]_p154 knew, and mixed [it]_p156 all up with some other language which [I]_p148 did not know at all. [I]_p157 was just able to follow [her]_p158 by asking many questions.

When [I]_p159 told [her]_p163 that [I]_p160 must go at once, and that [I]_p160 was engaged on important business, [she]_p164 asked again:  "Do [you]_p165 know what day [it]_p166 is?" [I]_p161 answered that [it]_p167 was the fourth of May. [She]_p168 shook [her]_p169 head as [she]_p170 said again: "Oh, yes! [I]_p172 know that! [I]_p173 know that, but do [you]_p175 know what day [it]_p176 is?" On [my]_p177 saying that [I]_p173 did not understand, [she]_p171 went on: "It is the eve of [St]_n29. [George]_n's30 [Day]_n31. Do [you]_p178 not know that [to-night]_n,32 when the clock strikes midnight, all the evil things in the world will have full sway? Do [you]_p179 know where [you]_p179 are going, and what [you]_p180 are going to?" [She]_p182 was in such evident distress that [I]_p183 tried to comfort her, but without effect. Finally [she]_p184 went down on [her]_p185 knees and implored [me]_p186 not to go at least to wait a day or two before starting. [It]_p187 was all very ridiculous but [I]_p188 did not feel comfortable. However, there was business to be done, and [I]_p189 could allow nothing to interfere with it. [I]_p190 therefore tried to raise [her]_p194 up, and said, as gravely as [I]_p191 could, that [I]_p191 thanked her, but [my]_p196 duty was imperative, and that [I]_p192 must go. [She]_p197 then rose and dried [her]_p198 eyes, and taking a crucifix from [her]_p199 neck offered [it]_p200 to me. [I]_p201 did not know what to do, for, as an [English Churchman]_n,33 [I]_p202 have been taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous, and yet [it]_p203 seemed so ungracious to refuse an old lady meaning so well and in such a state of mind.

[She]_p204 saw, [I]_p205 suppose, the doubt in [my]_p206 face, for [she]_p208 put the rosary round [my]_p207 neck, and said, "For [your]_p209 mother's sake," and went out of the room. [I]_p210 am writing up this part of the diary whilst [I]_p211 am waiting for the coach, which is, of course, late and the crucifix is still round [my]_p212 neck. Whether [it]_p213 is the old lady's fear, or the many ghostly traditions of this place, or the crucifix itself, [I]_p214 do not know, but [I]_p215 am not feeling nearly as easy in [my]_p216 mind as usual. If this book should ever reach [Mina]_n34 before [I]_p217 do, let [it]_p218 bring [my]_p219 good-bye. Here comes the coach! * * * * * 5 [May]_n35. The [Castle]_n36. , The grey of the morning has passed, and the sun is high over the distant horizon, which seems jagged, whether with trees or hills [I]_p220 know not, for [it]_p221 is so far off that big things and little are mixed. [I]_p222 am not sleepy, and, as [I]_p223 am not to be called till [I]_p223 awake, naturally [I]_p224 write till sleep comes. There are many odd things to put down, and, lest who reads [them]_p226 may fancy that [I]_p227 dined too well before [I]_p228 left [Bistritz]_n,37 let [me]_p229 put down [my]_p230 dinner exactly. [I]_p231 dined on what [they]_p232 called "robber steak", bits of bacon, onion, and beef, seasoned with red pepper, and strung on sticks and roasted over the fire, in the simple style of the London cat's meat! The wine was Golden Mediasch, which produces a queer sting on the tongue, which is, however, not disagreeable.

[I]_p233 had only a couple of glasses of this, and nothing else. When [I]_p234 got on the coach the driver had not taken [his]_p236 seat, and [I]_p235 saw [him]_p237 talking with the landlady. [They]_p238 were evidently talking of me, for every now and then [they]_p239 looked at me, and some of the people who were sitting on the bench outside the door, which [they]_p240 call by a name meaning "word-bearer", came and listened, and then looked at me, most of [them]_p241 pityingly. [I]_p242 could hear a lot of words often repeated, queer words, for there were many nationalities in the crowd so [I]_p243 quietly got [my]_p244 polyglot dictionary from [my]_p245 bag and looked [them]_p246 out. [I]_p247 must say [they]_p248 were not cheering to me, for amongst [them]_p249 were "Ordog", Satan, "pokol", hell, "stregoica", witch, "vrolok" and "vlkoslak", both of which mean the same thing, one being Slovak and the other Servian for something that is either were-wolf or vampire. ([Mem]_n38. , [I]_p250 must ask the Count about these superstitions)  When [we]_p251 started, the crowd round the inn door, which had by this time swelled to a considerable size, all made the sign of the cross and pointed two fingers towards me. With some difficulty [I]_p252 got a fellow-passenger to tell [me]_p254 what [they]_p255 meant [he]_p256 would not answer at first, but on learning that [I]_p253 was [English]_n,39 [he]_p257 explained that [it]_p258 was a charm or guard against the evil eye. This was not very pleasant for me, just starting for an unknown place to meet an unknown man but every one seemed so kind-hearted, and so sorrowful, and so sympathetic that [I]_p259 could not but be touched. [I]_p260 shall never forget the last glimpse which [I]_p261 had of the inn-yard and [its]_p262 crowd of picturesque figures, all crossing themselves, as [they]_p264 stood round the wide archway, with [its]_p263 background of rich foliage of oleander and orange trees in green tubs clustered in the centre of the yard.

Then [our]_p265 driver, whose wide linen drawers covered the whole front of the box-seat, "gotza" [they]_p267 call them, cracked [his]_p268 big whip over [his]_p269 four small horses, which ran abreast, and [we]_p270 set off on [our]_p266 journey. [I]_p271 soon lost sight and recollection of ghostly fears in the beauty of the scene as [we]_p274 drove along, although had [I]_p272 known the language, or rather languages, which [my]_p275 fellow-passengers were speaking, [I]_p272 might not have been able to throw [them]_p276 off so easily. Before [us]_p277 lay a green sloping land full of forests and woods, with here and there steep hills, crowned with clumps of trees or with farmhouses, the blank gable end to the road. There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossom, apple, plum, pear, cherry and as [we]_p278 drove by [I]_p279 could see the green grass under the trees spangled with the fallen petals. In and out amongst these green hills of what [they]_p280 call here the "Mittel [Land]_n"40 ran the road, losing [itself]_p281 as [it]_p282 swept round the grassy curve, or was shut out by the straggling ends of pine woods, which here and there ran down the hillsides like tongues of flame. The road was rugged, but still [we]_p283 seemed to fly over [it]_p284 with a feverish haste. [I]_p285 could not understand then what the haste meant, but the driver was evidently bent on losing no time in reaching [Borgo Prund]_n41. [I]_p286 was told that this road is in summertime excellent, but that [it]_p287 had not yet been put in order after the winter snows. In this respect [it]_p288 is different from the general run of roads in the Carpathians, for [it]_p289 is an old tradition that [they]_p290 are not to be kept in too good order. Of old the Hospadars would not repair them, lest the Turk should think that [they]_p291 were preparing to bring in foreign troops, and so hasten the war which was always really at loading point.

Beyond the green swelling hills of the Mittel [Land]_n42 rose mighty slopes of forest up to the lofty steeps of the Carpathians themselves. Right and left of [us]_p292 [they]_p293 towered, with the afternoon sun falling full upon [them]_p294 and bringing out all the glorious colours of this beautiful range, deep blue and purple in the shadows of the peaks, green and brown where grass and rock mingled, and an endless perspective of jagged rock and pointed crags, till these were [themselves]_p295 lost in the distance, where the snowy peaks rose grandly. Here and there seemed mighty rifts in the mountains, through which, as the sun began to sink, [we]_p296 saw now and again the white gleam of falling water. One of [my]_p297 companions touched [my]_p298 arm as [we]_p299 swept round the base of a hill and opened up the lofty, snow-covered peak of a mountain, which seemed, as [we]_p300 wound on [our]_p301 serpentine way, to be right before us:,   "Look! Isten szek!", "God's seat!", and [he]_p302 crossed [himself]_p303 reverently. As [we]_p304 wound on [our]_p305 endless way, and the sun sank lower and lower behind us, the shadows of the evening began to creep round us. This was emphasised by the fact that the snowy mountain-top still held the sunset, and seemed to glow out with a delicate cool pink. Here and there [we]_p306 passed Cszeks and Slovaks, all in picturesque attire, but [I]_p307 noticed that goitre was painfully prevalent. By the roadside were many crosses, and as [we]_p308 swept by, [my]_p309 companions all crossed themselves. Here and there was a peasant man or woman kneeling before a shrine, who did not even turn round as [we]_p310 approached, but seemed in the self-surrender of devotion to have neither eyes nor ears for the outer world. There were many things new to me: for instance, hay-ricks in the trees, and here and there very beautiful masses of weeping birch, [their]_p311 white stems shining like silver through the delicate green of the leaves.

Now and again [we]_p312 passed a leiter-wagon, the ordinary peasant's cart, with [its]_p313 long, snake-like vertebra, calculated to suit the inequalities of the road. On this were sure to be seated quite a group of home-coming peasants, the Cszeks with [their]_p314 white, and the Slovaks with [their]_p315 coloured, sheepskins, the latter carrying lance-fashion [their]_p315 long staves, with axe at end. As the evening fell [it]_p317 began to get very cold, and the growing twilight seemed to merge into one dark mistiness the gloom of the trees, oak, beech, and pine, though in the valleys which ran deep between the spurs of the hills, as [we]_p318 ascended through the Pass, the dark firs stood out here and there against the background of late-lying snow. Sometimes, as the road was cut through the pine woods that seemed in the darkness to be closing down upon us, great masses of greyness, which here and there bestrewed the trees, produced a peculiarly weird and solemn effect, which carried on the thoughts and grim fancies engendered earlier in the evening, when the falling sunset threw into strange relief the ghost-like clouds which amongst the Carpathians seem to wind ceaselessly through the valleys. Sometimes the hills were so steep that, despite [our]_p319 driver's haste, the horses could only go slowly. [I]_p320 wished to get down and walk up them, as [we]_p321 do at home, but the driver would not hear of it. "No, no," [he]_p322 said "you must not walk here the dogs are too fierce" and then [he]_p323 added, with what [he]_p323 evidently meant for grim pleasantry, for [he]_p324 looked round to catch the approving smile of the rest, "and [you]_p326 may have enough of such matters before [you]_p327 go to sleep. " The only stop [he]_p329 would make was a moment's pause to light [his]_p330 lamps. When [it]_p331 grew dark there seemed to be some excitement amongst the passengers, and [they]_p332 kept speaking to him, one after the other, as though urging [him]_p333 to further speed. [He]_p335 lashed the horses unmercifully with [his]_p336 long whip, and with wild cries of encouragement urged [them]_p337 on to further exertions.

Then through the darkness [I]_p338 could see a sort of patch of grey light ahead of us, as though there were a cleft in the hills. The excitement of the passengers grew greater the crazy coach rocked on [its]_p339 great leather springs, and swayed like a boat tossed on a stormy sea. [I]_p340 had to hold on. The road grew more level, and [we]_p341 appeared to fly along. Then the mountains seemed to come nearer to [us]_p342 on each side and to frown down upon [us]_p343 [we]_p344 were entering on the [Borgo Pass]_n43. One by one several of the passengers offered [me]_p345 gifts, which [they]_p347 pressed upon [me]_p346 with an earnestness which would take no denial these were certainly of an odd and varied kind, but each was given in simple good faith, with a kindly word, and a blessing, and that strange mixture of fear-meaning movements which [I]_p348 had seen outside the hotel at [Bistritz]_n,44 the sign of the cross and the guard against the evil eye. Then, as [we]_p349 flew along, the driver leaned forward, and on each side the passengers, craning over the edge of the coach, peered eagerly into the darkness. [It]_p350 was evident that something very exciting was either happening or expected, but though [I]_p351 asked each passenger, no one would give [me]_p352 the slightest explanation. This state of excitement kept on for some little time and at last [we]_p353 saw before [us]_p354 the Pass opening out on the eastern side. There were dark, rolling clouds overhead, and in the air the heavy, oppressive sense of thunder.

[It]_p355 seemed as though the mountain range had separated two atmospheres, and that now [we]_p356 had got into the thunderous one. [I]_p357 was now [myself]_p358 looking out for the conveyance which was to take [me]_p359 to the Count. Each moment [I]_p360 expected to see the glare of lamps through the blackness but all was dark. The only light was the flickering rays of [our]_p361 own lamps, in which the steam from [our]_p362 hard-driven horses rose in a white cloud. [We]_p363 could see now the sandy road lying white before us, but there was on [it]_p364 no sign of a vehicle. The passengers drew back with a sigh of gladness, which seemed to mock [my]_p365 own disappointment. [I]_p366 was already thinking what [I]_p367 had best do, when the driver, looking at [his]_p370 watch, said to the others something which [I]_p367 could hardly hear, [it]_p371 was spoken so quietly and in so low a tone [I]_p368 thought [it]_p372 was "An hour less than the time. " Then turning to me, [he]_p373 said in German worse than [my]_p374 own:,   "There is no carriage here. The [Herr]_n45 is not expected after all. [He]_p375 will now come on to [Bukovina]_n,46 and return to-morrow or the next day better the next day.

" Whilst [he]_p376 was speaking the horses began to neigh and snort and plunge wildly, so that the driver had to hold [them]_p377 up. Then, amongst a chorus of screams from the peasants and a universal crossing of themselves, a cal che, with four horses, drove up behind us, overtook us, and drew up beside the coach. [I]_p378 could see from the flash of [our]_p379 lamps, as the rays fell on them, that the horses were coal-black and splendid animals. [They]_p380 were driven by a tall man, with a long brown beard and a great black hat, which seemed to hide [his]_p381 face from us. [I]_p382 could only see the gleam of a pair of very bright eyes, which seemed red in the lamplight, as [he]_p383 turned to us. [He]_p384 said to the driver:, "You are early [to-night]_n,47 [my]_p385 friend. " The man stammered in reply:, "The [English Herr]_n48 was in a hurry," to which the stranger replied:, "That is why, [I]_p386 suppose, [you]_p387 wished [him]_p388 to go on to [Bukovina]_n49. [You]_p389 cannot deceive me, [my]_p390 friend [I]_p392 know too much, and [my]_p391 horses are swift. " As [he]_p393 spoke [he]_p394 smiled, and the lamplight fell on a hard-looking mouth, with very red lips and sharp-looking teeth, as white as ivory. One of [my]_p395 companions whispered to another the line from Burger's "Lenore":, "Denn die [Todten]_n50 reiten schnell", ("For the dead travel fast.

")  The strange driver evidently heard the words, for [he]_p396 looked up with a gleaming smile. The passenger turned [his]_p397 face away, at the same time putting out [his]_p398 two fingers and crossing himself. "Give [me]_p399 the [Herr]_n's51 luggage," said the driver and with exceeding alacrity [my]_p400 bags were handed out and put in the cal che. Then [I]_p401 descended from the side of the coach, as the cal che was close alongside, the driver helping [me]_p402 with a hand which caught [my]_p403 arm in a grip of steel [his]_p404 strength must have been prodigious. Without a word [he]_p405 shook [his]_p406 reins, the horses turned, and [we]_p407 swept into the darkness of the [Pass]_n52. As [I]_p408 looked back [I]_p409 saw the steam from the horses of the coach by the light of the lamps, and projected against [it]_p410 the figures of [my]_p411 late companions crossing themselves. Then the driver cracked [his]_p412 whip and called to [his]_p413 horses, and off [they]_p414 swept on [their]_p415 way to [Bukovina]_n53. As [they]_p416 sank into the darkness [I]_p417 felt a strange chill, and a lonely feeling came over [me]_p418 but a cloak was thrown over [my]_p420 shoulders, and a rug across [my]_p421 knees, and the driver said in excellent German:,   "The night is chill, mein Herr, and [my]_p421 master the Count bade [me]_p419 take all care of you. There is a flask of slivovitz (the plum brandy of the country) underneath the seat, if [you]_p423 should require it. " [I]_p424 did not take any, but [it]_p425 was a comfort to know [it]_p426 was there all the same.

[I]_p427 felt a little strangely, and not a little frightened. [I]_p428 think had there been any alternative [I]_p429 should have taken it, instead of prosecuting that unknown night journey. The carriage went at a hard pace straight along, then [we]_p430 made a complete turn and went along another straight road. [It]_p431 seemed to [me]_p432 that [we]_p433 were simply going over and over the same ground again and so [I]_p434 took note of some salient point, and found that this was so. [I]_p435 would have liked to have asked the driver what this all meant, but [I]_p436 really feared to do so, for [I]_p436 thought that, placed as [I]_p437 was, any protest would have had no effect in case there had been an intention to delay. By-and-by, however, as [I]_p439 was curious to know how time was passing, [I]_p440 struck a match, and by [its]_p441 flame looked at [my]_p442 watch [it]_p443 was within a few minutes of midnight. This gave [me]_p444 a sort of shock, for [I]_p445 suppose the general superstition about midnight was increased by [my]_p446 recent experiences. [I]_p447 waited with a sick feeling of suspense. Then a dog began to howl somewhere in a farmhouse far down the road, a long, agonised wailing, as if from fear. The sound was taken up by another dog, and then another and another, till, borne on the wind which now sighed softly through the Pass, a wild howling began, which seemed to come from all over the country, as far as the imagination could grasp [it]_p448 through the gloom of the night.

At the first howl the horses began to strain and rear, but the driver spoke to [them]_p449 soothingly, and [they]_p450 quieted down, but shivered and sweated as though after a runaway from sudden fright. Then, far off in the distance, from the mountains on each side of [us]_p451 began a louder and a sharper howling, that of wolves, which affected both the horses and [myself]_p452 in the same way, for [I]_p453 was minded to jump from the cal che and run, whilst [they]_p454 reared again and plunged madly, so that the driver had to use all [his]_p455 great strength to keep [them]_p456 from bolting. In a few minutes, however, [my]_p457 own ears got accustomed to the sound, and the horses so far became quiet that the driver was able to descend and to stand before them. [He]_p458 petted and soothed them, and whispered something in [their]_p459 ears, as [I]_p460 have heard of horse-tamers doing, and with extraordinary effect, for under [his]_p461 caresses [they]_p462 became quite manageable again, though [they]_p463 still trembled. The driver again took [his]_p464 seat, and shaking [his]_p465 reins, started off at a great pace. This time, after going to the far side of the Pass, [he]_p466 suddenly turned down a narrow roadway which ran sharply to the right. Soon [we]_p467 were hemmed in with trees, which in places arched right over the roadway till [we]_p468 passed as through a tunnel and again great frowning rocks guarded [us]_p469 boldly on either side. Though [we]_p470 were in shelter, [we]_p471 could hear the rising wind, for [it]_p473 moaned and whistled through the rocks, and the branches of the trees crashed together as [we]_p471 swept along. [It]_p474 grew colder and colder still, and fine, powdery snow began to fall, so that soon [we]_p475 and all around [us]_p476 were covered with a white blanket. The keen wind still carried the howling of the dogs, though this grew fainter as [we]_p477 went on [our]_p478 way.

The baying of the wolves sounded nearer and nearer, as though [they]_p479 were closing round on [us]_p480 from every side. [I]_p481 grew dreadfully afraid, and the horses shared [my]_p482 fear. The driver, however, was not in the least disturbed [he]_p483 kept turning [his]_p484 head to left and right, but [I]_p485 could not see anything through the darkness. Suddenly, away on [our]_p486 left, [I]_p487 saw a faint flickering blue flame. The driver saw [it]_p488 at the same moment [he]_p489 at once checked the horses, and, jumping to the ground, disappeared into the darkness. [I]_p490 did not know what to do, the less as the howling of the wolves grew closer but while [I]_p491 wondered the driver suddenly appeared again, and without a word took [his]_p492 seat, and [we]_p493 resumed [our]_p494 journey. [I]_p495 think [I]_p496 must have fallen asleep and kept dreaming of the incident, for [it]_p497 seemed to be repeated endlessly, and now looking back, [it]_p498 is like a sort of awful nightmare. Once the flame appeared so near the road, that even in the darkness around [us]_p499 [I]_p500 could watch the driver's motions. [He]_p501 went rapidly to where the blue flame arose, [it]_p502 must have been very faint, for [it]_p503 did not seem to illumine the place around [it]_p503 at all, and gathering a few stones, formed [them]_p505 into some device. Once there appeared a strange optical effect: when [he]_p506 stood between [me]_p508 and the flame [he]_p507 did not obstruct it, for [I]_p509 could see [its]_p510 ghostly flicker all the same.

This startled me, but as the effect was only momentary, [I]_p513 took [it]_p514 that [my]_p515 eyes deceived [me]_p511 straining through the darkness. Then for a time there were no blue flames, and [we]_p516 sped onwards through the gloom, with the howling of the wolves around us, as though [they]_p517 were following in a moving circle. At last there came a time when the driver went further afield than [he]_p518 had yet gone, and during [his]_p519 absence, the horses began to tremble worse than ever and to snort and scream with fright. [I]_p520 could not see any cause for it, for the howling of the wolves had ceased altogether but just then the moon, sailing through the black clouds, appeared behind the jagged crest of a beetling, pine-clad rock, and by [its]_p522 light [I]_p521 saw around [us]_p523 a ring of wolves, with white teeth and lolling red tongues, with long, sinewy limbs and shaggy hair. [They]_p524 were a hundred times more terrible in the grim silence which held [them]_p525 than even when [they]_p526 howled. For myself, [I]_p527 felt a sort of paralysis of fear. [It]_p528 is only when a man feels [himself]_p529 face to face with such horrors that [he]_p530 can understand [their]_p531 true import. All at once the wolves began to howl as though the moonlight had had some peculiar effect on them. The horses jumped about and reared, and looked helplessly round with eyes that rolled in a way painful to see  but the living ring of terror encompassed [them]_p532 on every side and [they]_p533 had perforce to remain within it. [I]_p534 called to the coachman to come, for [it]_p535 seemed to [me]_p536 that [our]_p537 only chance was to try to break out through the ring and to aid [his]_p538 approach.

[I]_p539 shouted and beat the side of the cal che, hoping by the noise to scare the wolves from that side, so as to give [him]_p540 a chance of reaching the trap. How [he]_p541 came there, [I]_p542 know not, but [I]_p543 heard [his]_p544 voice raised in a tone of imperious command, and looking towards the sound, saw [him]_p545 stand in the roadway. As [he]_p546 swept [his]_p547 long arms, as though brushing aside some impalpable obstacle, the wolves fell back and back further still. Just then a heavy cloud passed across the face of the moon, so that [we]_p548 were again in darkness. When [I]_p549 could see again the driver was climbing into the cal che, and the wolves had disappeared. This was all so strange and uncanny that a dreadful fear came upon me, and [I]_p550 was afraid to speak or move. The time seemed interminable as [we]_p551 swept on [our]_p552 way, now in almost complete darkness, for the rolling clouds obscured the moon. [We]_p553 kept on ascending, with occasional periods of quick descent, but in the main always ascending. Suddenly, [I]_p554 became conscious of the fact that the driver was in the act of pulling up the horses in the courtyard of a vast ruined castle, from whose tall black windows came no ray of light, and whose broken battlements showed a jagged line against the moonlit sky. CHAPTER II [JONATHAN HARKER]_n'S54 JOURNAL, continued 5 [May]_n55.

, [I]_p555 must have been asleep, for certainly if [I]_p556 had been fully awake [I]_p556 must have noticed the approach of such a remarkable place. In the gloom the courtyard looked of considerable size, and as several dark ways led from [it]_p558 under great round arches, [it]_p559 perhaps seemed bigger than [it]_p559 really is. [I]_p561 have not yet been able to see [it]_p562 by daylight. When the cal che stopped, the driver jumped down and held out [his]_p563 hand to assist [me]_p564 to alight. Again [I]_p565 could not but notice [his]_p566 prodigious strength. [His]_p567 hand actually seemed like a steel vice that could have crushed [mine]_p568 if [he]_p569 had chosen. Then [he]_p570 took out [my]_p571 traps, and placed [them]_p572 on the ground beside [me]_p573 as [I]_p574 stood close to a great door, old and studded with large iron nails, and set in a projecting doorway of massive stone. [I]_p575 could see even in the dim light that the stone was massively carved, but that the carving had been much worn by time and weather. As [I]_p576 stood, the driver jumped again into [his]_p577 seat and shook the reins the horses started forward, and trap and all disappeared down one of the dark openings. [I]_p578 stood in silence where [I]_p579 was, for [I]_p579 did not know what to do.

Of bell or knocker there was no sign through these frowning walls and dark window openings [it]_p581 was not likely that [my]_p582 voice could penetrate. The time [I]_p583 waited seemed endless, and [I]_p584 felt doubts and fears crowding upon me. What sort of place had [I]_p585 come to, and among what kind of people? What sort of grim adventure was [it]_p587 on which [I]_p586 had embarked? Was this a customary incident in the life of a solicitor's clerk sent out to explain the purchase of a London estate to a foreigner? Solicitor's clerk! Mina would not like that. Solicitor, for just before leaving [London]_n56 [I]_p588 got word that [my]_p592 examination was successful and [I]_p589 am now a full-blown solicitor! [I]_p589 began to rub [my]_p593 eyes and pinch [myself]_p594 to see if [I]_p590 were awake. [It]_p595 all seemed like a horrible nightmare to me, and [I]_p596 expected that [I]_p597 should suddenly awake, and find [myself]_p599 at home, with the dawn struggling in through the windows, as [I]_p597 had now and again felt in the morning after a day of overwork. But [my]_p600 flesh answered the pinching test, and [my]_p601 eyes were not to be deceived. [I]_p602 was indeed awake and among the Carpathians. All [I]_p603 could do now was to be patient, and to wait the coming of the morning. Just as [I]_p604 had come to this conclusion [I]_p605 heard a heavy step approaching behind the great door, and saw through the chinks the gleam of a coming light. Then there was the sound of rattling chains and the clanking of massive bolts drawn back.

A key was turned with the loud grating noise of long disuse, and the great door swung back. Within, stood a tall old man, clean shaven save for a long white moustache, and clad in black from head to foot, without a single speck of colour about [him]_p606 anywhere. [He]_p607 held in [his]_p608 hand an antique silver lamp, in which the flame burned without chimney or globe of any kind, throwing long quivering shadows as [it]_p609 flickered in the draught of the open door. The old man motioned [me]_p610 in with [his]_p612 right hand with a courtly gesture, saying in excellent [English]_n,57 but with a strange intonation:, "Welcome to [my]_p614 house! Enter freely and of [your]_p615 own will!" [He]_p616 made no motion of stepping to meet me, but stood like a statue, as though [his]_p613 gesture of welcome had fixed [him]_p617 into stone. The instant, however, that [I]_p618 had stepped over the threshold, [he]_p619 moved impulsively forward, and holding out [his]_p620 hand grasped mine with a strength which made [me]_p621 wince, an effect which was not lessened by the fact that [it]_p622 seemed as cold as ice, more like the hand of a dead than a living man. Again [he]_p623 said:,   "Welcome to [my]_p624 house. Come freely. Go safely and leave something of the happiness [you]_p625 bring!" The strength of the handshake was so much akin to that which [I]_p627 had noticed in the driver, whose face [I]_p628 had not seen, that for a moment [I]_p628 doubted if [it]_p634 were not the same person to whom [I]_p629 was speaking so to make sure, [I]_p629 said interrogatively:, "[Count Dracula]_n?"58 [He]_p635 bowed in a courtly way as [he]_p636 replied:, "I am Dracula and [I]_p629 bid [you]_p626 welcome, Mr Harker, to [my]_p637 house. Come in  the night air is chill, and [you]_p638 must need to eat and rest. " As [he]_p639 was speaking, [he]_p640 put the lamp on a bracket on the wall, and stepping out, took [my]_p642 luggage [he]_p640 had carried [it]_p643 in before [I]_p644 could forestall him.

[I]_p645 protested but [he]_p646 insisted:, "[Nay]_n,59 sir, [you]_p647 are [my]_p648 guest. [It]_p649 is late, and [my]_p650 people are not available. Let [me]_p651 see to [your]_p652 comfort myself. " [He]_p653 insisted on carrying [my]_p654 traps along the passage, and then up a great winding stair, and along another great passage, on whose stone floor [our]_p655 steps rang heavily. At the end of this [he]_p656 threw open a heavy door, and [I]_p657 rejoiced to see within a well-lit room in which a table was spread for supper, and on whose mighty hearth a great fire of logs, freshly replenished, flamed and flared. The Count halted, putting down [my]_p658 bags, closed the door, and crossing the room, opened another door, which led into a small octagonal room lit by a single lamp, and seemingly without a window of any sort. Passing through this, [he]_p659 opened another door, and motioned [me]_p660 to enter. [It]_p661 was a welcome sight for here was a great bedroom well lighted and warmed with another log fire,, also added to but lately, for the top logs were fresh, which sent a hollow roar up the wide chimney. The Count [himself]_p662 left [my]_p663 luggage inside and withdrew, saying, before [he]_p664 closed the door:,   "You will need, after [your]_p665 journey, to refresh [yourself]_p667 by making [your]_p666 toilet. [I]_p668 trust [you]_p669 will find all [you]_p670 wish.

When [you]_p671 are ready, come into the other room, where [you]_p672 will find [your]_p673 supper prepared. "  The light and warmth and the Count's courteous welcome seemed to have dissipated all [my]_p674 doubts and fears. Having then reached [my]_p675 normal state, [I]_p676 discovered that [I]_p677 was half famished with hunger so making a hasty toilet, [I]_p677 went into the other room. [I]_p679 found supper already laid out. [My]_p680 host, who stood on one side of the great fireplace, leaning against the stonework, made a graceful wave of [his]_p681 hand to the table, and said:,   "I pray you, be seated and sup how [you]_p682 please. [You]_p684 will, [I]_p685 trust, excuse [me]_p689 that [I]_p686 do not join [you]_p690 but [I]_p686 have dined already, and [I]_p687 do not sup. "  [I]_p691 handed to [him]_p692 the sealed letter which Mr Hawkins had entrusted to me. [He]_p693 opened [it]_p694 and read [it]_p695 gravely then, with a charming smile, [he]_p697 handed [it]_p695 to [me]_p698 to read. One passage of it, at least, gave [me]_p699 a thrill of pleasure. "I must regret that an attack of gout, from which malady [I]_p700 am a constant sufferer, forbids absolutely any travelling on [my]_p705 part for some time to come but [I]_p701 am happy to say [I]_p701 can send a sufficient substitute, one in whom [I]_p702 have every possible confidence.

[He]_p706 is a [young]_n60 man, full of energy and talent in [his]_p707 own way, and of a very faithful disposition. [He]_p708 is discreet and silent, and has grown into manhood in [my]_p709 service. [He]_p710 shall be ready to attend on [you]_p711 when [you]_p712 will during [his]_p713 stay, and shall take [your]_p714 instructions in all matters. "  The Count [himself]_p715 came forward and took off the cover of a dish, and [I]_p716 fell to at once on an excellent roast chicken. This, with some cheese and a salad and a bottle of old Tokay, of which [I]_p717 had two glasses, was [my]_p718 supper. During the time [I]_p719 was eating [it]_p722 the Count asked [me]_p723 many questions as to [my]_p724 journey, and [I]_p720 told [him]_p725 by degrees all [I]_p720 had experienced. By this time [I]_p726 had finished [my]_p727 supper, and by [my]_p728 host's desire had drawn up a chair by the fire and begun to smoke a cigar which [he]_p729 offered me, at the same time excusing [himself]_p731 that [he]_p730 did not smoke. [I]_p732 had now an opportunity of observing him, and found [him]_p733 of a very marked physiognomy. [His]_p735 face was a strong, a very strong, aquiline, with high bridge of the thin nose and peculiarly arched nostrils with lofty domed forehead, and hair growing scantily round the temples but profusely elsewhere. [His]_p736 eyebrows were very massive, almost meeting over the nose, and with bushy hair that seemed to curl in [its]_p737 own profusion.

The mouth, so far as [I]_p738 could see [it]_p739 under the heavy moustache, was fixed and rather cruel-looking, with peculiarly sharp white teeth these protruded over the lips, whose remarkable ruddiness showed astonishing vitality in a man of [his]_p740 years. For the [rest]_n,61 [his]_p741 ears were pale, and at the tops extremely pointed the chin was broad and strong, and the cheeks firm though thin. The general effect was one of extraordinary pallor. Hitherto [I]_p742 had noticed the backs of [his]_p744 hands as [they]_p746 lay on [his]_p745 knees in the firelight, and [they]_p747 had seemed rather white and fine but seeing [them]_p749 now close to me, [I]_p743 could not but notice that [they]_p747 were rather coarse, broad, with squat fingers. Strange to say, there were hairs in the centre of the palm. The nails were long and fine, and cut to a sharp point. As the Count leaned over [me]_p750 and [his]_p752 hands touched me, [I]_p753 could not repress a shudder. [It]_p754 may have been that [his]_p755 breath was rank, but a horrible feeling of nausea came over me, which, do what [I]_p756 would, [I]_p757 could not conceal. The Count, evidently noticing it, drew back and with a grim sort of smile, which showed more than [he]_p758 had yet done [his]_p759 protuberant teeth, sat [himself]_p761 down again on [his]_p760 own side of the fireplace. [We]_p762 were both silent for a while and as [I]_p763 looked towards the window [I]_p764 saw the first dim streak of the coming dawn.

There seemed a strange stillness over everything but as [I]_p765 listened [I]_p766 heard as if from down below in the valley the howling of many wolves. The Count's eyes gleamed, and [he]_p767 said:,   "Listen to them, the children of the night. What music [they]_p768 make!" Seeing, [I]_p769 suppose, some expression in [my]_p770 face strange to him, [he]_p771 added:,   "Ah, sir, [you]_p772 dwellers in the city cannot enter into the feelings of the hunter. " Then [he]_p773 rose and said:,   "But [you]_p774 must be tired. [Your]_p775 bedroom is all ready, and to-morrow [you]_p776 shall sleep as late as [you]_p777 will. [I]_p778 have to be away till the afternoon  so sleep well and dream well!" With a courteous bow, [he]_p780 opened for [me]_p781 [himself]_p782 the door to the octagonal room, and [I]_p779 entered [my]_p783 bedroom. [I]_p784 am all in a sea of wonders. [I]_p785 doubt [I]_p786 fear [I]_p786 think strange things, which [I]_p787 dare not confess to [my]_p789 own soul. God keep me, if only for the sake of those [dear]_n62 to me! * * * * * 7 May. , [It]_p790 is again early morning, but [I]_p791 have rested and enjoyed the last twenty-four hours.

[I]_p792 slept till late in the day, and awoke of [my]_p793 own accord. When [I]_p794 had dressed [myself]_p796 [I]_p795 went into the room where [we]_p797 had supped, and found a cold breakfast laid out, with coffee kept hot by the pot being placed on the hearth. There was a card on the table, on which was written:,   "I have to be absent for a while. Do not wait for me. , D. " [I]_p798 set to and enjoyed a hearty meal. When [I]_p799 had done, [I]_p800 looked for a bell, so that [I]_p800 might let the servants know [I]_p801 had finished but [I]_p801 could not find one. There are certainly odd deficiencies in the house, considering the extraordinary evidences of wealth which are round me. The table service is of gold, and so beautifully wrought that [it]_p804 must be of immense value. The curtains and upholstery of the chairs and sofas and the hangings of [my]_p805 bed are of the costliest and most beautiful fabrics, and must have been of fabulous value when [they]_p806 were made, for [they]_p807 are centuries old, though in excellent order.

[I]_p808 saw something like [them]_p809 in [Hampton Court]_n,63 but there [they]_p810 were worn and frayed and moth-eaten. But still in none of the rooms is there a mirror. There is not even a toilet glass on [my]_p811 table, and [I]_p814 had to get the little shaving glass from [my]_p812 bag before [I]_p815 could either shave or brush [my]_p812 hair. [I]_p816 have not yet seen a servant anywhere, or heard a sound near the castle except the howling of wolves. Some time after [I]_p817 had finished [my]_p823 meal, [I]_p818 do not know whether to call [it]_p824 breakfast or dinner, for [it]_p825 was between five and six o'clock when [I]_p818 had it, [I]_p819 looked about for something to read, for [I]_p819 did not like to go about the castle until [I]_p819 had asked the Count's permission. There was absolutely nothing in the room, book, newspaper, or even writing materials so [I]_p827 opened another door in the room and found a sort of library. The door opposite mine [I]_p828 tried, but found [it]_p829 locked. In the library [I]_p830 found, to [my]_p831 great delight, a vast number of [English]_n64 books, whole shelves full of them, and bound volumes of magazines and newspapers. A table in the centre was littered with [English]_n65 magazines and newspapers, though none of [them]_p832 were of very recent date. The books were of the most varied kind, history, geography, politics, political economy, botany, geology, law, all relating to England and [English]_n66 life and customs and manners.

There were even such books of reference as the London Directory, the "[Red]_n"67 and "Blue" books, Whitaker's Almanac, the Army and [Navy Lists]_n,68 and, [it]_p833 somehow gladdened [my]_p835 heart to see it, the Law List. Whilst [I]_p836 was looking at the books, the door opened, and the Count entered. [He]_p837 saluted [me]_p838 in a hearty way, and hoped that [I]_p839 had had a good night's [rest]_n69. Then [he]_p840 went on:,   "I am glad [you]_p843 found [your]_p845 way in here, for [I]_p841 am sure there is much that will interest you. These companions", and [he]_p846 laid [his]_p847 hand on some of the books, "have been good friends to me, and for some years past, ever since [I]_p850 had the idea of going to London, have given [me]_p848 many, many hours of pleasure. Through [them]_p851 [I]_p852 have come to know [your]_p853 great England and to know [her]_p854 is to love her. [I]_p856 long to go through the crowded streets of [your]_p857 mighty London, to be in the midst of the whirl and rush of humanity, to share [its]_p858 life, [its]_p859 change, [its]_p859 death, and all that makes [it]_p861 what [it]_p862 is. But alas! as yet [I]_p863 only know [your]_p864 tongue through books. To you, [my]_p865 friend, [I]_p866 look that [I]_p867 know [it]_p868 to speak. "  "But, Count," [I]_p869 said, "you know and speak English thoroughly!" [He]_p870 bowed gravely.

"I thank you, [my]_p875 friend, for [your]_p876 all too-flattering estimate, but yet [I]_p871 fear that [I]_p872 am but a little way on the road [I]_p872 would travel. True, [I]_p877 know the grammar and the words, but yet [I]_p878 know not how to speak them. "  "Indeed," [I]_p879 said, "you speak excellently. "  "Not so," [he]_p880 answered. "Well, [I]_p881 know that, did [I]_p882 move and speak in [your]_p883 [London]_n,70 none there are who would not know [me]_p884 for a stranger. That is not enough for me. Here [I]_p885 am noble [I]_p886 am boyar the common people know me, and [I]_p886 am master. But a stranger in a strange land, [he]_p888 is no one men know [him]_p889 not, and to know not is to care not for. [I]_p890 am content if [I]_p891 am like the rest, so that no man stops if [he]_p894 see me, or pause in [his]_p896 speaking if [he]_p895 hear [my]_p897 words, 'Ha, ha! a stranger!' [I]_p891 have been so long master that [I]_p892 would be master still, or at least that none other should be master of me. [You]_p898 come to [me]_p899 not alone as agent of [my]_p901 friend Peter Hawkins, of [Exeter]_n,71 to tell [me]_p900 all about [my]_p902 new estate in London.

[You]_p903 shall, [I]_p904 trust, rest here with [me]_p908 awhile, so that by [our]_p910 talking [I]_p905 may learn the [English]_n72 intonation and [I]_p905 would that [you]_p911 tell [me]_p909 when [I]_p906 make error, even of the smallest, in [my]_p912 speaking. [I]_p913 am sorry that [I]_p914 had to be away so long to-day but [you]_p916 will, [I]_p914 know, forgive one who has so many important affairs in hand. "  Of course [I]_p917 said all [I]_p918 could about being willing, and asked if [I]_p918 might come into that room when [I]_p919 chose. [He]_p921 answered: "Yes, certainly," and added:,   "You may go anywhere [you]_p922 wish in the castle, except where the doors are locked, where of course [you]_p923 will not wish to go. There is reason that all things are as [they]_p924 are, and did [you]_p925 see with [my]_p927 eyes and know with [my]_p928 knowledge, [you]_p926 would perhaps better understand. " [I]_p929 said [I]_p930 was sure of this, and then [he]_p931 went on:, "We are in [Transylvania]_n73 and [Transylvania]_n74 is not England. [Our]_p932 ways are not [your]_p933 ways, and there shall be to [you]_p934 many strange things. Nay, from what [you]_p935 have told [me]_p937 of [your]_p938 experiences already, [you]_p936 know something of what strange things there may be. "  This led to much conversation and as [it]_p939 was evident that [he]_p940 wanted to talk, if only for talking's sake, [I]_p941 asked [him]_p942 many questions regarding things that had already happened to [me]_p943 or come within [my]_p944 notice. Sometimes [he]_p945 sheered off the subject, or turned the conversation by pretending not to understand but generally [he]_p946 answered all [I]_p947 asked most frankly.

Then as time went on, and [I]_p948 had got somewhat bolder, [I]_p949 asked [him]_p950 of some of the strange things of the preceding night, as, for instance, why the coachman went to the places where [he]_p951 had seen the blue flames. [He]_p952 then explained to [me]_p953 that [it]_p954 was commonly believed that on a certain night of the year, last night, in fact, when all evil spirits are supposed to have unchecked sway, a blue flame is seen over any place where treasure has been concealed. "That treasure has been hidden," [he]_p955 went on, "in the region through which [you]_p956 came last night, there can be but little doubt for [it]_p957 was the ground fought over for centuries by the [Wallachian]_n,75 the Saxon, and the Turk. Why, there is hardly a foot of soil in all this region that has not been enriched by the blood of men, patriots or invaders. In old days there were stirring times, when the Austrian and the [Hungarian]_n76 came up in hordes, and the patriots went out to meet them, men and women, the aged and the children too, and waited [their]_p960 coming on the rocks above the passes, that [they]_p962 might sweep destruction on [them]_p958 with [their]_p961 artificial avalanches. When the invader was triumphant [he]_p963 found but little, for whatever there was had been sheltered in the friendly soil. "  "But how," said I, "can [it]_p964 have remained so long undiscovered, when there is a sure index to [it]_p965 if men will but take the trouble to look?" The Count smiled, and as [his]_p967 lips ran back over [his]_p968 gums, the long, sharp, canine teeth showed out strangely [he]_p970 answered:,   "Because [your]_p972 peasant is at heart a coward and a fool! Those flames only appear on one night and on that night no man of this land will, if [he]_p971 can help it, stir without [his]_p968 doors. And, [dear]_n77 sir, even if [he]_p973 did [he]_p974 would not know what to do. Why, even the peasant that [you]_p975 tell [me]_p976 of who marked the place of the flame would not know where to look in daylight even for [his]_p977 own work. Even [you]_p978 would not, [I]_p980 dare be sworn, be able to find these places again?"  "There [you]_p979 are right," [I]_p981 said.

"I know no more than the dead where even to look for them. " Then [we]_p982 drifted into other matters. "Come," [he]_p983 said at last, "tell [me]_p984 of London and of the house which [you]_p986 have procured for me. " With an apology for [my]_p987 remissness, [I]_p990 went into [my]_p988 own room to get the papers from [my]_p988 bag. Whilst [I]_p991 was placing [them]_p994 in order [I]_p992 heard a rattling of china and silver in the next room, and as [I]_p992 passed through, noticed that the table had been cleared and the lamp lit, for [it]_p995 was by this time deep into the dark. The lamps were also lit in the study or library, and [I]_p996 found the Count lying on the sofa, reading, of all things in the world, an English Bradshaw's Guide. When [I]_p997 came in [he]_p999 cleared the books and papers from the table and with [him]_p1000 [I]_p998 went into plans and deeds and figures of all sorts. [He]_p1001 was interested in everything, and asked [me]_p1002 a myriad questions about the place and [its]_p1003 surroundings. [He]_p1004 clearly had studied beforehand all [he]_p1005 could get on the subject of the neighbourhood, for [he]_p1006 evidently at the end knew very much more than [I]_p1007 did. When [I]_p1008 remarked this, [he]_p1013 answered:,   "Well, but, [my]_p1014 friend, is [it]_p1019 not needful that [I]_p1009 should? When [I]_p1009 go there [I]_p1010 shall be all alone, and [my]_p1015 friend Harker Jonathan, nay, pardon me, [I]_p1010 fall into [my]_p1015 country's habit of putting [your]_p1020 patronymic first, [my]_p1016 friend Jonathan Harker will not be by [my]_p1016 side to correct and aid me.

[He]_p1021 will be in [Exeter]_n,78 miles away, probably working at papers of the law with [my]_p1022 other friend, Peter Hawkins. So!"  [We]_p1023 went thoroughly into the business of the purchase of the estate at Purfleet. When [I]_p1024 had told [him]_p1026 the facts and got [his]_p1027 signature to the necessary papers, and had written a letter with [them]_p1028 ready to post to Mr Hawkins, [he]_p1029 began to ask [me]_p1030 how [I]_p1025 had come across so suitable a place. [I]_p1031 read to [him]_p1035 the notes which [I]_p1032 had made at the time, and which [I]_p1032 inscribe here:,   "At Purfleet, on a by-road, [I]_p1033 came across just such a place as seemed to be required, and where was displayed a dilapidated notice that the place was for sale. [It]_p1036 is surrounded by a high wall, of ancient structure, built of heavy stones, and has not been repaired for a large number of years. The closed gates are of heavy old oak and iron, all eaten with rust. "The estate is called Carfax, no doubt a corruption of the old [Quatre Face]_n,79 as the house is four-sided, agreeing with the cardinal points of the compass. [It]_p1037 contains in all some twenty acres, quite surrounded by the solid stone wall above mentioned. There are many trees on it, which make [it]_p1038 in places gloomy, and there is a deep, dark-looking pond or small lake, evidently fed by some springs, as the water is clear and flows away in a fair-sized stream. The house is very large and of all periods back, [I]_p1040 should say, to medi val times, for one part is of stone immensely thick, with only a few windows high up and heavily barred with iron.

[It]_p1041 looks like part of a keep, and is close to an old chapel or church. [I]_p1042 could not enter it, as [I]_p1043 had not the key of the door leading to [it]_p1045 from the house, but [I]_p1043 have taken with [my]_p1048 kodak views of [it]_p1046 from various points. The house has been added to, but in a very straggling way, and [I]_p1049 can only guess at the amount of ground [it]_p1050 covers, which must be very great. There are but few houses close at hand, one being a very large house only recently added to and formed into a private lunatic asylum. [It]_p1051 is not, however, visible from the grounds. "  When [I]_p1052 had finished, [he]_p1054 said:,   "I am glad that [it]_p1055 is old and big. [I]_p1056 [myself]_p1057 am of an old family, and to live in a new house would kill me. A house cannot be made habitable in a day and, after all, how few days go to make up a century. [I]_p1058 rejoice also that there is a chapel of old times. [We]_p1059 Transylvanian nobles love not to think that [our]_p1060 bones may lie amongst the common dead.

[I]_p1061 seek not gaiety nor mirth, not the bright voluptuousness of much sunshine and sparkling waters which please the [young]_n80 and [gay]_n81. [I]_p1062 am no longer [young]_n82 and [my]_p1063 heart, through weary years of mourning over the dead, is not attuned to mirth. Moreover, the walls of [my]_p1064 castle are broken the shadows are many, and the wind breathes cold through the broken battlements and casements. [I]_p1065 love the shade and the shadow, and would be alone with [my]_p1067 thoughts when [I]_p1066 may. " Somehow [his]_p1068 words and [his]_p1069 look did not seem to accord, or else [it]_p1072 was that [his]_p1069 cast of face made [his]_p1070 smile look malignant and saturnine. Presently, with an excuse, [he]_p1073 left me, asking [me]_p1074 to put all [my]_p1076 papers together. [He]_p1077 was some little time away, and [I]_p1078 began to look at some of the books around me. One was an atlas, which [I]_p1079 found opened naturally at England, as if that map had been much used. On looking at [it]_p1080 [I]_p1081 found in certain places little rings marked, and on examining these [I]_p1082 noticed that one was near London on the east side, manifestly where [his]_p1083 new estate was situated the other two were [Exeter]_n,83 and Whitby on the Yorkshire coast. [It]_p1084 was the better part of an hour when the Count returned.

"Aha!" [he]_p1085 said "still at [your]_p1086 books? [Good]_n!84 But [you]_p1087 must not work always. Come [I]_p1088 am informed that [your]_p1089 supper is ready. " [He]_p1090 took [my]_p1091 arm, and [we]_p1092 went into the next room, where [I]_p1093 found an excellent supper ready on the table. The Count again excused himself, as [he]_p1094 had dined out on [his]_p1095 being away from home. But [he]_p1096 sat as on the previous night, and chatted whilst [I]_p1097 ate. After supper [I]_p1098 smoked, as on the last evening, and the Count stayed with me, chatting and asking questions on every conceivable subject, hour after hour. [I]_p1099 felt that [it]_p1102 was getting very late indeed, but [I]_p1100 did not say anything, for [I]_p1100 felt under obligation to meet [my]_p1103 host's wishes in every way. [I]_p1104 was not sleepy, as the long sleep yesterday had fortified [me]_p1106 but [I]_p1105 could not help experiencing that chill which comes over one at the coming of the dawn, which is like, in [its]_p1107 way, the turn of the tide. [They]_p1108 say that people who are near death die generally at the change to the dawn or at the turn of the tide any one who has when tired, and tied as [it]_p1109 were to [his]_p1111 post, experienced this change in the atmosphere can well believe it. All at once [we]_p1112 heard the crow of a cock coming up with preternatural shrillness through the clear morning air [Count Dracula]_n,85 jumping to [his]_p1113 feet, said:, "Why, there is the morning again! How remiss [I]_p1114 am to let [you]_p1115 stay up so long.

[You]_p1116 must make [your]_p1117 conversation regarding [my]_p1118 [dear]_n86 new country of England less interesting, so that [I]_p1119 may not forget how time flies by us," and, with a courtly bow, [he]_p1120 quickly left me. [I]_p1121 went into [my]_p1123 own room and drew the curtains, but there was little to notice [my]_p1124 window opened into the courtyard, all [I]_p1122 could see was the warm grey of quickening sky. So [I]_p1125 pulled the curtains again, and have written of this day. * * * * * 8 [May]_n87. , [I]_p1126 began to fear as [I]_p1127 wrote in this book that [I]_p1127 was getting too diffuse but now [I]_p1128 am glad that [I]_p1128 went into detail from the first, for there is something so strange about this place and all in [it]_p1132 that [I]_p1128 cannot but feel uneasy. [I]_p1133 wish [I]_p1134 were safe out of it, or that [I]_p1134 had never come. [It]_p1136 may be that this strange night-existence is telling on [me]_p1137 but would that that were all! If there were any one to talk to [I]_p1138 could bear it, but there is no one. [I]_p1139 have only the Count to speak with, and he!, [I]_p1140 fear [I]_p1140 am [myself]_p1142 the only living soul within the place. Let [me]_p1143 be prosaic so far as facts can be [it]_p1146 will help [me]_p1144 to bear up, and imagination must not run riot with me. If [it]_p1147 does [I]_p1148 am lost.

Let [me]_p1149 say at once how [I]_p1150 stand, or seem to. [I]_p1151 only slept a few hours when [I]_p1152 went to bed, and feeling that [I]_p1152 could not sleep any more, got up. [I]_p1154 had hung [my]_p1155 shaving glass by the window, and was just beginning to shave. Suddenly [I]_p1156 felt a hand on [my]_p1157 shoulder, and heard the Count's voice saying to me, "Good-morning. " [I]_p1158 started, for [it]_p1160 amazed [me]_p1161 that [I]_p1159 had not seen him, since the reflection of the glass covered the whole room behind me. In starting [I]_p1163 had cut [myself]_p1164 slightly, but did not notice [it]_p1165 at the moment. Having answered the Count's salutation, [I]_p1166 turned to the glass again to see how [I]_p1167 had been mistaken. This time there could be no error, for the man was close to me, and [I]_p1168 could see [him]_p1169 over [my]_p1170 shoulder. But there was no reflection of [him]_p1171 in the mirror! The whole room behind [me]_p1172 was displayed but there was no sign of a man in it, except myself. This was startling, and, coming on the top of so many strange things, was beginning to increase that vague feeling of uneasiness which [I]_p1173 always have when the Count is near but at the instant [I]_p1174 saw that the cut had bled a little, and the blood was trickling over [my]_p1175 chin.

[I]_p1176 laid down the razor, turning as [I]_p1177 did so half round to look for some sticking plaster. When the Count saw [my]_p1178 face, [his]_p1180 eyes blazed with a sort of demoniac fury, and [he]_p1181 suddenly made a grab at [my]_p1179 throat. [I]_p1182 drew away, and [his]_p1183 hand touched the string of beads which held the crucifix. [It]_p1184 made an instant change in him, for the fury passed so quickly that [I]_p1185 could hardly believe that [it]_p1186 was ever there. "Take care," [he]_p1187 said, "take care how [you]_p1188 cut yourself. [It]_p1189 is more dangerous than [you]_p1190 think in this country. " Then seizing the shaving glass, [he]_p1191 went on: "And this is the wretched thing that has done the mischief. [It]_p1192 is a foul bauble of man's vanity. Away with it!" and opening the heavy window with one wrench of [his]_p1193 terrible hand, [he]_p1194 flung out the glass, which was shattered into a thousand pieces on the stones of the courtyard far below. Then [he]_p1195 withdrew without a word.

[It]_p1196 is very annoying, for [I]_p1197 do not see how [I]_p1198 am to shave, unless in [my]_p1199 watch-case or the bottom of the shaving-pot, which is fortunately of metal. When [I]_p1200 went into the dining-room, breakfast was prepared but [I]_p1201 could not find the Count anywhere. So [I]_p1202 breakfasted alone. [It]_p1203 is strange that as yet [I]_p1204 have not seen the Count eat or drink. [He]_p1205 must be a very peculiar man! After breakfast [I]_p1206 did a little exploring in the castle. [I]_p1207 went out on the stairs, and found a room looking towards the South. The view was magnificent, and from where [I]_p1208 stood there was every opportunity of seeing it. The castle is on the very edge of a terrible precipice. A stone falling from the window would fall a thousand feet without touching anything! As far as the eye can reach is a sea of green tree tops, with occasionally a deep rift where there is a chasm. Here and there are silver threads where the rivers wind in deep gorges through the forests.

But [I]_p1209 am not in heart to describe beauty, for when [I]_p1210 had seen the view [I]_p1210 explored further doors, doors, doors everywhere, and all locked and bolted. In no place save from the windows in the castle walls is there an available exit. The castle is a veritable prison, and [I]_p1212 am a prisoner! CHAPTER III JONATHAN [HARKER]_n'S88 JOURNAL, continued When [I]_p1213 found that [I]_p1213 was a prisoner a sort of wild feeling came over me. [I]_p1215 rushed up and down the stairs, trying every door and peering out of every window [I]_p1216 could find but after a little the conviction of [my]_p1217 helplessness overpowered all other feelings. When [I]_p1218 look back after a few hours [I]_p1219 think [I]_p1219 must have been mad for the time, for [I]_p1220 behaved much as a rat does in a trap. When, however, the conviction had come to [me]_p1222 that [I]_p1223 was helpless [I]_p1224 sat down quietly, as quietly as [I]_p1224 have ever done anything in [my]_p1226 life, and began to think over what was best to be done. [I]_p1227 am thinking still, and as yet have come to no definite conclusion. Of one thing only am [I]_p1228 certain that [it]_p1229 is no use making [my]_p1230 ideas known to the Count. [He]_p1231 knows well that [I]_p1232 am imprisoned and as [he]_p1234 has done [it]_p1236 himself, and has doubtless [his]_p1238 own motives for it, [he]_p1235 would only deceive [me]_p1239 if [I]_p1233 trusted [him]_p1240 fully with the facts. So far as [I]_p1241 can see, [my]_p1242 only plan will be to keep [my]_p1243 knowledge and [my]_p1243 fears to myself, and [my]_p1244 eyes open.

[I]_p1246 am, [I]_p1247 know, either being deceived, like a baby, by [my]_p1250 own fears, or else [I]_p1247 am in desperate straits and if the latter be so, [I]_p1248 need, and shall need, all [my]_p1251 brains to get through. [I]_p1252 had hardly come to this conclusion when [I]_p1253 heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. [He]_p1254 did not come at once into the library, so [I]_p1255 went cautiously to [my]_p1256 own room and found [him]_p1257 making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what [I]_p1258 had all along thought, that there were no servants in the house. When later [I]_p1259 saw [him]_p1261 through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, [I]_p1260 was assured of [it]_p1262 for if [he]_p1264 does [himself]_p1265 all these menial offices, surely [it]_p1263 is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave [me]_p1266 a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, [it]_p1268 must have been the Count [himself]_p1269 who was the driver of the coach that brought [me]_p1267 here. This is a terrible thought for if so, what does [it]_p1270 mean that [he]_p1271 could control the wolves, as [he]_p1272 did, by only holding up [his]_p1273 hand in silence. How was [it]_p1274 that all the people at [Bistritz]_n89 and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? [Bless]_n90 that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round [my]_p1279 neck! for [it]_p1275 is a comfort and a strength to [me]_p1277 whenever [I]_p1280 touch it. [It]_p1281 is odd that a thing which [I]_p1282 have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is [it]_p1283 that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that [it]_p1284 is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if [it]_p1284 may be, [I]_p1287 must examine this matter and try to make up [my]_p1288 mind about it.

In the meantime [I]_p1289 must find out all [I]_p1290 can about [Count Dracula]_n,91 as [it]_p1291 may help [me]_p1292 to understand. To-night [he]_p1293 may talk of himself, if [I]_p1294 turn the conversation that way. [I]_p1295 must be very careful, however, not to awake [his]_p1296 suspicion. * * * * *  Midnight. , [I]_p1297 have had a long talk with the Count. [I]_p1298 asked [him]_p1299 a few questions on [Transylvania]_n92 history, and [he]_p1300 warmed up to the subject wonderfully. In [his]_p1301 speaking of things and people, and especially of battles, [he]_p1302 spoke as if [he]_p1303 had been present at [them]_p1304 all. This [he]_p1305 afterwards explained by saying that to a boyar the pride of [his]_p1306 house and name is [his]_p1307 own pride, that [their]_p1310 glory is [his]_p1307 glory, that [their]_p1311 fate is [his]_p1308 fate. Whenever [he]_p1312 spoke of [his]_p1314 house [he]_p1313 always said "we," and spoke almost in the plural, like a king speaking. [I]_p1315 wish [I]_p1316 could put down all [he]_p1317 said exactly as [he]_p1318 said it, for to [me]_p1321 [it]_p1319 was most fascinating.

[It]_p1322 seemed to have in [it]_p1323 a whole history of the country. [He]_p1324 grew excited as [he]_p1325 spoke, and walked about the room pulling [his]_p1328 great white moustache and grasping anything on which [he]_p1326 laid [his]_p1329 hands as though [he]_p1326 would crush [it]_p1330 by main strength. One thing [he]_p1331 said which [I]_p1332 shall put down as nearly as [I]_p1333 can for [it]_p1334 tells in [its]_p1335 way the story of [his]_p1336 race:,   "We Szekelys have a right to be proud, for in [our]_p1337 veins flows the blood of many brave races who fought as the lion fights, for lordship. Here, in the whirlpool of European races, the Ugric tribe bore down from Iceland the fighting spirit which Thor and Wodin gave them, which [their]_p1338 Berserkers displayed to such fell intent on the seaboards of Europe, ay, and of Asia and Africa too, till the peoples thought that the were-wolves [themselves]_p1339 had come. Here, too, when [they]_p1340 came, [they]_p1341 found the Huns, whose warlike fury had swept the earth like a living flame, till the dying peoples held that in [their]_p1342 veins ran the blood of those old witches, who, expelled from Scythia had mated with the devils in the desert. Fools, fools! What devil or what witch was ever so great as Attila, whose blood is in these veins?" [He]_p1343 held up [his]_p1344 arms. "Is [it]_p1345 a wonder that [we]_p1347 were a conquering race that [we]_p1348 were proud that when the Magyar, the Lombard, the Avar, the Bulgar, or the Turk poured [his]_p1350 thousands on [our]_p1352 frontiers, [we]_p1348 drove [them]_p1353 back? Is [it]_p1346 strange that when Arpad and [his]_p1351 legions swept through the [Hungarian]_n93 fatherland [he]_p1354 found [us]_p1356 here when [he]_p1355 reached the frontier that the Honfoglalas was completed there? And when the [Hungarian]_n94 flood swept eastward, the Szekelys were claimed as kindred by the victorious Magyars, and to [us]_p1357 for centuries was trusted the guarding of the frontier of [[Turkey]_n]_n-land95 ay, and more than that, endless duty of the frontier guard, for, as the Turks say, 'water sleeps, and enemy is sleepless. ' Who more gladly than [we]_p1358 throughout the Four [Nations]_n96 received the 'bloody sword,' or at [its]_p1359 warlike call flocked quicker to the standard of the King? When was redeemed that great shame of [my]_p1360 nation, the shame of Cassova, when the flags of the Wallach and the Magyar went down beneath the Crescent? Who was [it]_p1362 but one of [my]_p1361 own race who as [Voivode]_n97 crossed the Danube and beat the Turk on [his]_p1365 own ground? This was a Dracula indeed! Woe was [it]_p1363 that [his]_p1366 own unworthy brother, when [he]_p1371 had fallen, sold [his]_p1366 people to the Turk and brought the shame of slavery on them! Was [it]_p1363 not this Dracula, indeed, who inspired that other of [his]_p1367 race who in a later age again and again brought [his]_p1367 forces over the great river into [Turkey]_n-land98 who, when [he]_p1372 was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though [he]_p1372 had to come alone from the bloody field where [his]_p1367 troops were being slaughtered, since [he]_p1373 knew that [he]_p1373 alone could ultimately triumph! [They]_p1377 said that [he]_p1373 thought only of himself. Bah! what good are peasants without a leader? Where ends the war without a brain and heart to conduct it? Again, when, after the battle of Moh cs, [we]_p1378 threw off the [Hungarian]_n99 yoke, [we]_p1379 of the Dracula blood were amongst [their]_p1381 leaders, for [our]_p1382 spirit would not brook that [we]_p1379 were not free. Ah, [young]_n100 sir, the Szekelys, and the [Dracula]_n101 as [their]_p1383 heart's blood, [their]_p1384 brains, and [their]_p1384 swords, can boast a record that mushroom growths like the Hapsburgs and the Romanoffs can never reach.

The warlike days are over. Blood is too precious a thing in these days of dishonourable peace and the glories of the great races are as a tale that is told. "  [It]_p1386 was by this time close on morning, and [we]_p1387 went to bed. ([Mem]_n102. , this diary seems horribly like the beginning of the "[Arabian Nights]_n,"103 for everything has to break off at cockcrow, or like the ghost of Hamlet's father. ) * * * * * 12 [May]_n104. , Let [me]_p1388 begin with facts, bare, meagre facts, verified by books and figures, and of which there can be no doubt. [I]_p1389 must not confuse [them]_p1390 with experiences which will have to rest on [my]_p1392 own observation, or [my]_p1393 memory of them. Last evening when the Count came from [his]_p1394 room [he]_p1395 began by asking [me]_p1396 questions on legal matters and on the doing of certain kinds of business. [I]_p1397 had spent the day wearily over books, and, simply to keep [my]_p1399 mind occupied, went over some of the matters [I]_p1398 had been examined in at Lincoln's Inn.

There was a certain method in the Count's inquiries, so [I]_p1400 shall try to put [them]_p1401 down in sequence the knowledge may somehow or some time be useful to me. First, [he]_p1402 asked if a man in England might have two solicitors or more. [I]_p1403 told [him]_p1404 [he]_p1405 might have a dozen if [he]_p1406 wished, but that [it]_p1407 would not be wise to have more than one solicitor engaged in one transaction, as only one could act at a time, and that to change would be certain to militate against [his]_p1408 interest. [He]_p1409 seemed thoroughly to understand, and went on to ask if there would be any practical difficulty in having one man to attend, say, to banking, and another to look after shipping, in case local help were needed in a place far from the home of the banking solicitor. [I]_p1410 asked [him]_p1413 to explain more fully, so that [I]_p1411 might not by any chance mislead him, so [he]_p1415 said:,   "I shall illustrate. [Your]_p1416 friend and mine, Mr Peter Hawkins, from under the shadow of [your]_p1417 beautiful cathedral at [Exeter]_n,105 which is far from London, buys for [me]_p1419 through [your]_p1418 good self [my]_p1420 place at London. Good! Now here let [me]_p1421 say frankly, lest [you]_p1422 should think [it]_p1423 strange that [I]_p1424 have sought the services of one so far off from London instead of some one resident there, that [my]_p1426 motive was that no local interest might be served save [my]_p1427 wish only and as one of London residence might, perhaps, have some purpose of [himself]_p1430 or friend to serve, [I]_p1425 went thus afield to seek [my]_p1427 agent, whose labours should be only to [my]_p1428 interest. Now, suppose I, who have much of affairs, wish to ship goods, say, to Newcastle, or Durham, or [Harwich]_n,106 or Dover, might [it]_p1433 not be that [it]_p1434 could with more ease be done by consigning to one in these ports?" [I]_p1431 answered that certainly [it]_p1434 would be most easy, but that [we]_p1436 solicitors had a system of agency one for the other, so that local work could be done locally on instruction from any solicitor, so that the client, simply placing [himself]_p1437 in the hands of one man, could have [his]_p1438 wishes carried out by [him]_p1439 without further trouble. "But," said he, "I could be at liberty to direct myself. Is [it]_p1440 not so?"
