"Of course," [I]_p1441 replied and "such is often done by men of business, who do not like the whole of [their]_p1442 affairs to be known by any one person.

"  "Good!" [he]_p1443 said, and then went on to ask about the means of making consignments and the forms to be gone through, and of all sorts of difficulties which might arise, but by forethought could be guarded against. [I]_p1444 explained all these things to [him]_p1445 to the best of [my]_p1446 ability, and [he]_p1447 certainly left [me]_p1450 under the impression that [he]_p1448 would have made a wonderful solicitor, for there was nothing that [he]_p1448 did not think of or foresee. For a man who was never in the country, and who did not evidently do much in the way of business, [his]_p1451 knowledge and acumen were wonderful. When [he]_p1452 had satisfied [himself]_p1455 on these points of which [he]_p1453 had spoken, and [I]_p1456 had verified all as well as [I]_p1457 could by the books available, [he]_p1453 suddenly stood up and said:,   "Have [you]_p1461 written since [your]_p1462 first letter to [our]_p1463 friend Mr Peter Hawkins, or to any other?" [It]_p1464 was with some bitterness in [my]_p1465 heart that [I]_p1457 answered that [I]_p1458 had not, that as yet [I]_p1458 had not seen any opportunity of sending letters to anybody. "Then write now, [my]_p1466 [young]_n107 friend," [he]_p1468 said, laying a heavy hand on [my]_p1467 shoulder: "write to [our]_p1469 friend and to any other and say, if [it]_p1470 will please you, that [you]_p1471 shall stay with [me]_p1473 until a month from now. "  "Do [you]_p1474 wish [me]_p1475 to stay so long?" [I]_p1476 asked, for [my]_p1477 heart grew cold at the thought. "I desire [it]_p1480 much nay, [I]_p1478 will take no refusal. When [your]_p1481 master, employer, what [you]_p1482 will, engaged that someone should come on [his]_p1483 behalf, [it]_p1484 was understood that [my]_p1485 needs only were to be consulted. [I]_p1486 have not stinted. Is [it]_p1487 not so?" What could [I]_p1489 do but bow acceptance? [It]_p1494 was Mr Hawkins's interest, not mine, and [I]_p1490 had to think of him, not [myself]_p1495 and besides, while [Count Dracula]_n108 was speaking, there was that in [his]_p1496 eyes and in [his]_p1497 bearing which made [me]_p1498 remember that [I]_p1490 was a prisoner, and that if [I]_p1491 wished [it]_p1488 [I]_p1491 could have no choice.

The Count saw [his]_p1499 victory in [my]_p1502 bow, and [his]_p1500 mastery in the trouble of [my]_p1503 face, for [he]_p1505 began at once to use them, but in [his]_p1500 own smooth, resistless way:, "I pray you, [my]_p1503 good [young]_n109 friend, that [you]_p1506 will not discourse of things other than business in [your]_p1508 letters. [It]_p1509 will doubtless please [your]_p1510 friends to know that [you]_p1511 are well, and that [you]_p1512 look forward to getting home to them. Is [it]_p1513 not so?" As [he]_p1514 spoke [he]_p1515 handed [me]_p1516 three sheets of note-paper and three envelopes. [They]_p1517 were all of the thinnest foreign post, and looking at them, then at him, and noticing [his]_p1518 quiet smile, with the sharp, canine teeth lying over the red underlip, [I]_p1519 understood as well as if [he]_p1522 had spoken that [I]_p1520 should be careful what [I]_p1520 wrote, for [he]_p1523 would be able to read it. So [I]_p1524 determined to write only formal notes now, but to write fully to Mr Hawkins in secret, and also to Mina, for to [her]_p1526 [I]_p1525 could write in shorthand, which would puzzle the Count, if [he]_p1527 did see it. When [I]_p1528 had written [my]_p1530 two letters [I]_p1529 sat quiet, reading a book whilst the Count wrote several notes, referring as [he]_p1531 wrote [them]_p1532 to some books on [his]_p1533 table. Then [he]_p1534 took up [my]_p1535 two and placed [them]_p1536 with [his]_p1537 own, and put by [his]_p1538 writing materials, after which, the instant the door had closed behind him, [I]_p1539 leaned over and looked at the letters, which were face down on the table. [I]_p1540 felt no compunction in doing so, for under the circumstances [I]_p1541 felt that [I]_p1541 should protect [myself]_p1544 in every way [I]_p1542 could. One of the letters was directed to [Samuel F]_n110. [Billington]_n,111 No.

7, The Crescent, Whitby, another to [Herr Leutner]_n,112 Varna the third was to Coutts & [Co]_n113. , London, and the fourth to [Herren Klopstock]_n114 & Billreuth, bankers, Buda-Pesth. The second and fourth were unsealed. [I]_p1545 was just about to look at [them]_p1547 when [I]_p1546 saw the door-handle move. [I]_p1548 sank back in [my]_p1549 seat, having just had time to replace the letters as [they]_p1551 had been and to resume [my]_p1550 book before the Count, holding still another letter in [his]_p1552 hand, entered the room. [He]_p1553 took up the letters on the table and stamped [them]_p1554 carefully, and then turning to me, said:,   "I trust [you]_p1557 will forgive me, but [I]_p1555 have much work to do in private this evening. [You]_p1558 will, [I]_p1559 hope, find all things as [you]_p1560 wish. " At the door [he]_p1561 turned, and after a moment's pause said:, "Let [me]_p1562 advise you, [my]_p1568 [dear]_n115 [young]_n116 friend, nay, let [me]_p1563 warn [you]_p1564 with all seriousness, that should [you]_p1565 leave these rooms [you]_p1565 will not by any chance go to sleep in any other part of the castle. [It]_p1569 is old, and has many memories, and there are bad dreams for those who sleep unwisely. Be warned! Should sleep now or ever overcome you, or be like to do, then haste to [your]_p1570 own chamber or to these rooms, for [your]_p1571 rest will then be safe.

But if [you]_p1572 be not careful in this respect, then", [He]_p1573 finished [his]_p1574 speech in a gruesome way, for [he]_p1576 motioned with [his]_p1575 hands as if [he]_p1577 were washing them. [I]_p1578 quite understood [my]_p1579 only doubt was as to whether any dream could be more terrible than the unnatural, horrible net of gloom and mystery which seemed closing around me. * * * * *  Later. , [I]_p1580 endorse the last words written, but this time there is no doubt in question. [I]_p1581 shall not fear to sleep in any place where [he]_p1582 is not. [I]_p1583 have placed the crucifix over the head of [my]_p1585 bed, [I]_p1584 imagine that [my]_p1586 [rest]_n117 is thus freer from dreams and there [it]_p1587 shall remain. When [he]_p1588 left [me]_p1589 [I]_p1590 went to [my]_p1591 room. After a little while, not hearing any sound, [I]_p1592 came out and went up the stone stair to where [I]_p1593 could look out towards the South. There was some sense of freedom in the vast expanse, inaccessible though [it]_p1594 was to me, as compared with the narrow darkness of the courtyard. Looking out on this, [I]_p1595 felt that [I]_p1596 was indeed in prison, and [I]_p1596 seemed to want a breath of fresh air, though [it]_p1598 were of the night.

[I]_p1599 am beginning to feel this nocturnal existence tell on me. [It]_p1600 is destroying [my]_p1601 nerve. [I]_p1602 start at [my]_p1603 own shadow, and am full of all sorts of horrible imaginings. God knows that there is ground for [my]_p1604 terrible fear in this accursed place! [I]_p1605 looked out over the beautiful expanse, bathed in soft yellow moonlight till [it]_p1606 was almost as light as day. In the soft light the distant hills became melted, and the shadows in the valleys and gorges of velvety blackness. The mere beauty seemed to cheer [me]_p1607 there was peace and comfort in every breath [I]_p1608 drew. As [I]_p1609 leaned from the window [my]_p1611 eye was caught by something moving a storey below me, and somewhat to [my]_p1612 left, where [I]_p1610 imagined, from the order of the rooms, that the windows of the Count's own room would look out. The window at which [I]_p1613 stood was tall and deep, stone-mullioned, and though weatherworn, was still complete but [it]_p1614 was evidently many a day since the case had been there. [I]_p1615 drew back behind the stonework, and looked carefully out. What [I]_p1616 saw was the Count's head coming out from the window.

[I]_p1617 did not see the face, but [I]_p1618 knew the man by the neck and the movement of [his]_p1619 back and arms. In any case [I]_p1620 could not mistake the hands which [I]_p1621 had had so many opportunities of studying. [I]_p1622 was at first interested and somewhat amused, for [it]_p1623 is wonderful how small a matter will interest and amuse a man when [he]_p1624 is a prisoner. But [my]_p1625 very feelings changed to repulsion and terror when [I]_p1626 saw the whole man slowly emerge from the window and begin to crawl down the castle wall over that dreadful abyss, face down with [his]_p1627 cloak spreading out around [him]_p1628 like great wings. At first [I]_p1629 could not believe [my]_p1630 eyes. [I]_p1631 thought [it]_p1633 was some trick of the moonlight, some weird effect of shadow but [I]_p1632 kept looking, and [it]_p1634 could be no delusion. [I]_p1635 saw the fingers and toes grasp the corners of the stones, worn clear of the mortar by the stress of years, and by thus using every projection and inequality move downwards with considerable speed, just as a lizard moves along a wall. What manner of man is this, or what manner of creature is [it]_p1636 in the semblance of man? [I]_p1637 feel the dread of this horrible place overpowering [me]_p1641 [I]_p1638 am in fear, in awful fear, and there is no escape for [me]_p1642 [I]_p1638 am encompassed about with terrors that [I]_p1639 dare not think of. * * * * * 15 [May]_n118. , Once more have [I]_p1643 seen the Count go out in [his]_p1644 lizard fashion.

[He]_p1645 moved downwards in a [sidelong]_n119 way, some hundred feet down, and a good deal to the left. [He]_p1646 vanished into some hole or window. When [his]_p1647 head had disappeared, [I]_p1648 leaned out to try and see more, but without avail, the distance was too great to allow a proper angle of sight. [I]_p1649 knew [he]_p1651 had left the castle now, and thought to use the opportunity to explore more than [I]_p1650 had dared to do as yet. [I]_p1652 went back to the room, and taking a lamp, tried all the doors. [They]_p1653 were all locked, as [I]_p1654 had expected, and the locks were comparatively new but [I]_p1655 went down the stone stairs to the hall where [I]_p1655 had entered originally. [I]_p1657 found [I]_p1658 could pull back the bolts easily enough and unhook the great chains but the door was locked, and the key was gone! That key must be in the Count's room [I]_p1658 must watch should [his]_p1661 door be unlocked, so that [I]_p1659 may get [it]_p1662 and escape. [I]_p1663 went on to make a thorough examination of the various stairs and passages, and to try the doors that opened from them. One or two small rooms near the hall were open, but there was nothing to see in [them]_p1664 except old furniture, dusty with age and moth-eaten. At last, however, [I]_p1665 found one door at the top of the stairway which, though [it]_p1666 seemed to be locked, gave a little under pressure.

[I]_p1667 tried [it]_p1668 harder, and found that [it]_p1669 was not really locked, but that the resistance came from the fact that the hinges had fallen somewhat, and the heavy door rested on the floor. Here was an opportunity which [I]_p1670 might not have again, so [I]_p1671 exerted myself, and with many efforts forced [it]_p1673 back so that [I]_p1671 could enter. [I]_p1674 was now in a wing of the castle further to the right than the rooms [I]_p1675 knew and a storey lower down. From the windows [I]_p1676 could see that the suite of rooms lay along to the south of the castle, the windows of the end room looking out both west and south. On the latter side, as well as to the former, there was a great precipice. The castle was built on the corner of a great rock, so that on three sides [it]_p1677 was quite impregnable, and great windows were placed here where sling, or bow, or culverin could not reach, and consequently light and comfort, impossible to a position which had to be guarded, were secured. To the west was a great valley, and then, rising far away, great jagged mountain fastnesses, rising peak on peak, the sheer rock studded with mountain ash and thorn, whose roots clung in cracks and crevices and crannies of the stone. This was evidently the portion of the castle occupied by the ladies in bygone days, for the furniture had more air of comfort than any [I]_p1678 had seen. The windows were curtainless, and the yellow moonlight, flooding in through the diamond panes, enabled one to see even colours, whilst [it]_p1679 softened the wealth of dust which lay over all and disguised in some measure the ravages of time and the moth. [My]_p1680 lamp seemed to be of little effect in the brilliant moonlight, but [I]_p1681 was glad to have [it]_p1682 with me, for there was a dread loneliness in the place which chilled [my]_p1683 heart and made [my]_p1684 nerves tremble.

Still, [it]_p1685 was better than living alone in the rooms which [I]_p1686 had come to hate from the presence of the Count, and after trying a little to school [my]_p1688 nerves, [I]_p1687 found a soft quietude come over me. Here [I]_p1689 am, sitting at a little oak table where in old times possibly some fair lady sat to pen, with much thought and many blushes, [her]_p1691 ill-spelt love-letter, and writing in [my]_p1692 diary in shorthand all that has happened since [I]_p1690 closed [it]_p1693 last. [It]_p1694 is nineteenth century up-to-date with a vengeance. And yet, unless [my]_p1695 senses deceive me, the old centuries had, and have, powers of [their]_p1696 own which mere "modernity" cannot kill. * * * * * Later: the Morning of 16 [May]_n120. , God preserve [my]_p1697 sanity, for to this [I]_p1698 am reduced. Safety and the assurance of safety are things of the past. Whilst [I]_p1699 live on here there is but one thing to hope for, that [I]_p1700 may not go mad, if, indeed, [I]_p1700 be not mad already. If [I]_p1702 be sane, then surely [it]_p1705 is maddening to think that of all the foul things that lurk in this hateful place the Count is the least dreadful to [me]_p1706 that to [him]_p1707 alone [I]_p1703 can look for safety, even though this be only whilst [I]_p1703 can serve [his]_p1708 purpose. Great God! merciful God! Let [me]_p1709 be calm, for out of that way lies madness indeed.

[I]_p1710 begin to get new lights on certain things which have puzzled me. Up to now [I]_p1711 never quite knew what Shakespeare meant when [he]_p1713 made Hamlet say:,   "My tablets! quick, [my]_p1714 tablets! 'Tis meet that [I]_p1712 put [it]_p1715 down," etc. ,  for now, feeling as though [my]_p1716 own brain were unhinged or as if the shock had come which must end in [its]_p1718 undoing, [I]_p1719 turn to [my]_p1717 diary for repose. The habit of entering accurately must help to soothe me. The Count's mysterious warning frightened [me]_p1720 at the time [it]_p1723 frightens [me]_p1721 more now when [I]_p1725 think of it, for in future [he]_p1726 has a fearful hold upon me. [I]_p1727 shall fear to doubt what [he]_p1730 may say!  When [I]_p1728 had written in [my]_p1731 diary and had fortunately replaced the book and pen in [my]_p1732 pocket [I]_p1728 felt sleepy. The Count's warning came into [my]_p1733 mind, but [I]_p1734 took a pleasure in disobeying it. The sense of sleep was upon me, and with [it]_p1735 the obstinacy which sleep brings as outrider. The soft moonlight soothed, and the wide expanse without gave a sense of freedom which refreshed me. [I]_p1736 determined not to return [to-night]_n121 to the gloom-haunted rooms, but to sleep here, where, of old, ladies had sat and sung and lived sweet lives whilst [their]_p1737 gentle breasts were sad for [their]_p1738 menfolk away in the midst of remorseless wars.

[I]_p1739 drew a great couch out of [its]_p1742 place near the corner, so that as [I]_p1740 lay, [I]_p1740 could look at the lovely view to east and south, and unthinking of and uncaring for the dust, composed [myself]_p1743 for sleep. [I]_p1744 suppose [I]_p1745 must have fallen asleep [I]_p1745 hope so, but [I]_p1746 fear, for all that followed was startlingly real, so real that now sitting here in the broad, full sunlight of the morning, [I]_p1746 cannot in the least believe that [it]_p1749 was all sleep. [I]_p1750 was not alone. The room was the same, unchanged in any way since [I]_p1751 came into [it]_p1754 [I]_p1752 could see along the floor, in the brilliant moonlight, [my]_p1755 own footsteps marked where [I]_p1752 had disturbed the long accumulation of dust. In the moonlight opposite [me]_p1756 were three [young]_n122 women, ladies by [their]_p1757 dress and manner. [I]_p1758 thought at the time that [I]_p1759 must be dreaming when [I]_p1759 saw them, for, though the moonlight was behind them, [they]_p1761 threw no shadow on the floor. [They]_p1762 came close to me, and looked at [me]_p1763 for some time, and then whispered together. Two were dark, and had high aquiline noses, like the Count, and great dark, piercing eyes that seemed to be almost red when contrasted with the pale yellow moon. The other was fair, as fair as can be, with great wavy masses of golden hair and eyes like pale sapphires. [I]_p1765 seemed somehow to know [her]_p1767 face, and to know [it]_p1768 in connection with some dreamy fear, but [I]_p1766 could not recollect at the moment how or where.

All three had brilliant white teeth that shone like pearls against the ruby of [their]_p1769 voluptuous lips. There was something about [them]_p1770 that made [me]_p1771 uneasy, some longing and at the same time some deadly fear. [I]_p1772 felt in [my]_p1773 heart a wicked, burning desire that [they]_p1774 would kiss [me]_p1775 with those red lips. [It]_p1776 is not good to note this down, lest some day [it]_p1777 should meet [Mina]_n's123 eyes and cause [her]_p1779 pain but [it]_p1778 is the truth. [They]_p1780 whispered together, and then [they]_p1781 all three laughed, such a silvery, musical laugh, but as hard as though the sound never could have come through the softness of human lips. [It]_p1782 was like the intolerable, tingling sweetness of water-glasses when played on by a cunning hand. The fair girl shook [her]_p1783 head coquettishly, and the other two urged [her]_p1784 on. One said:,   "Go on! [You]_p1785 are first, and [we]_p1786 shall follow [yours]_p1787 is the right to begin. " The other added:, "He is [young]_n124 and strong there are kisses for [us]_p1788 all. " [I]_p1789 lay quiet, looking out under [my]_p1790 eyelashes in an agony of delightful anticipation.

The fair girl advanced and bent over [me]_p1791 till [I]_p1793 could feel the movement of [her]_p1794 breath upon me. Sweet [it]_p1795 was in one sense, honey-sweet, and sent the same tingling through the nerves as [her]_p1796 voice, but with a bitter underlying the sweet, a bitter offensiveness, as one smells in blood. [I]_p1797 was afraid to raise [my]_p1798 eyelids, but looked out and saw perfectly under the lashes. The girl went on [her]_p1799 knees, and bent over me, simply gloating. There was a deliberate voluptuousness which was both thrilling and repulsive, and as [she]_p1800 arched [her]_p1802 neck [she]_p1801 actually licked [her]_p1803 lips like an animal, till [I]_p1804 could see in the moonlight the moisture shining on the scarlet lips and on the red tongue as [it]_p1805 lapped the white sharp teeth. Lower and lower went [her]_p1806 head as the lips went below the range of [my]_p1807 mouth and chin and seemed about to fasten on [my]_p1808 throat. Then [she]_p1809 paused, and [I]_p1810 could hear the churning sound of [her]_p1811 tongue as [it]_p1813 licked [her]_p1812 teeth and lips, and could feel the hot breath on [my]_p1814 neck. Then the skin of [my]_p1815 throat began to tingle as one's flesh does when the hand that is to tickle [it]_p1816 approaches nearer, nearer. [I]_p1817 could feel the soft, shivering touch of the lips on the super-sensitive skin of [my]_p1818 throat, and the hard dents of two sharp teeth, just touching and pausing there. [I]_p1819 closed [my]_p1820 eyes in a languorous ecstasy and waited, waited with beating heart.

But at that instant, another sensation swept through [me]_p1821 as quick as lightning. [I]_p1822 was conscious of the presence of the Count, and of [his]_p1823 being as if lapped in a storm of fury. As [my]_p1824 eyes opened involuntarily [I]_p1825 saw [his]_p1826 strong hand grasp the slender neck of the fair woman and with giant's power draw [it]_p1827 back, the blue eyes transformed with fury, the white teeth champing with rage, and the fair cheeks blazing red with passion. But the Count! Never did [I]_p1828 imagine such wrath and fury, even to the demons of the pit. [His]_p1829 eyes were positively blazing. The red light in [them]_p1830 was lurid, as if the flames of hell-fire blazed behind them. [His]_p1832 face was deathly pale, and the lines of [it]_p1833 were hard like drawn wires  the thick eyebrows that met over the nose now seemed like a heaving bar of white-hot metal. With a fierce sweep of [his]_p1834 arm, [he]_p1835 hurled the woman from him, and then motioned to the others, as though [he]_p1836 were beating [them]_p1837 back [it]_p1838 was the same imperious gesture that [I]_p1839 had seen used to the wolves. In a voice which, though low and almost in a whisper seemed to cut through the air and then ring round the room [he]_p1840 said:,   "How dare [you]_p1841 touch him, any of you? How dare [you]_p1842 cast eyes on [him]_p1847 when [I]_p1850 had forbidden it? Back, [I]_p1851 tell [you]_p1842 all! This man belongs to me! Beware how [you]_p1843 meddle with him, or you'll have to deal with me. " The fair girl, with a laugh of ribald coquetry, turned to answer him:,   "You [yourself]_p1852 never loved [you]_p1853 never love!" On this the other women joined, and such a mirthless, hard, soulless laughter rang through the room that [it]_p1854 almost made [me]_p1856 faint to hear [it]_p1855 seemed like the pleasure of fiends.

Then the Count turned, after looking at [my]_p1857 face attentively, and said in a soft whisper:,   "Yes, [I]_p1858 too can love [you]_p1859 yourselves can tell [it]_p1860 from the past. Is [it]_p1861 not so? Well, now [I]_p1862 promise [you]_p1864 that when [I]_p1863 am done with [him]_p1866 [you]_p1865 shall kiss [him]_p1867 at [your]_p1868 will. Now go! go! [I]_p1869 must awaken him, for there is work to be done. " "Are [we]_p1870 to have nothing [to-night]_n?"125 said one of them, with a low laugh, as [she]_p1871 pointed to the bag which [he]_p1872 had thrown upon the floor, and which moved as though there were some living thing within it. For answer [he]_p1873 nodded [his]_p1874 head. One of the women jumped forward and opened it. If [my]_p1875 ears did not deceive [me]_p1876 there was a gasp and a low wail, as of a half-smothered child. The women closed round, whilst [I]_p1877 was aghast with horror but as [I]_p1878 looked [they]_p1879 disappeared, and with [them]_p1880 the dreadful bag. There was no door near them, and [they]_p1881 could not have passed [me]_p1882 without [my]_p1883 noticing. [They]_p1884 simply seemed to fade into the rays of the moonlight and pass out through the window, for [I]_p1885 could see outside the dim, shadowy forms for a moment before [they]_p1886 entirely faded away.

Then the horror overcame me, and [I]_p1887 sank down unconscious. CHAPTER IV [JONATHAN HARKER]_n'S126 JOURNAL, continued [I]_p1888 awoke in [my]_p1889 own bed. If [it]_p1890 be that [I]_p1891 had not dreamt, the Count must have carried [me]_p1892 here. [I]_p1893 tried to satisfy [myself]_p1894 on the subject, but could not arrive at any unquestionable result. To be sure, there were certain small evidences, such as that [my]_p1895 clothes were folded and laid by in a manner which was not [my]_p1896 habit. [My]_p1897 watch was still unwound, and [I]_p1898 am rigorously accustomed to wind [it]_p1899 the last thing before going to bed, and many such details. But these things are no proof, for [they]_p1900 may have been evidences that [my]_p1901 mind was not as usual, and, from some cause or another, [I]_p1902 had certainly been much upset. [I]_p1903 must watch for proof. Of one thing [I]_p1904 am glad: if [it]_p1905 was that the Count carried [me]_p1906 here and undressed me, [he]_p1908 must have been hurried in [his]_p1909 task, for [my]_p1910 pockets are intact. [He]_p1914 would have taken or destroyed it. As [I]_p1915 look round this room, although [it]_p1916 has been to [me]_p1918 so full of fear, [it]_p1917 is now a sort of sanctuary, for nothing can be more dreadful than those awful women, who were, who are, waiting to suck [my]_p1919 blood. * * * * * 18 [May]_n127. , [I]_p1920 have been down to look at that room again in daylight, for [I]_p1921 must know the truth. When [I]_p1922 got to the doorway at the top of the stairs [I]_p1923 found [it]_p1924 closed. [It]_p1925 had been so forcibly driven against the jamb that part of the woodwork was splintered. [I]_p1926 could see that the bolt of the lock had not been shot, but the door is fastened from the inside. [I]_p1927 fear [it]_p1928 was no dream, and must act on this surmise. * * * * * 19 [May]_n128. , [I]_p1929 am surely in the toils.

Last night the Count asked [me]_p1930 in the suavest tones to write three letters, one saying that [my]_p1931 work here was nearly done, and that [I]_p1932 should start for home within a few days, another that [I]_p1933 was starting on the next morning from the time of the letter, and the third that [I]_p1933 had left the castle and arrived at Bistritz. [I]_p1935 would fain have rebelled, but felt that in the present state of things [it]_p1937 would be madness to quarrel openly with the Count whilst [I]_p1936 am so absolutely in [his]_p1938 power and to refuse would be to excite [his]_p1939 suspicion and to arouse [his]_p1939 anger. [He]_p1941 knows that [I]_p1942 know too much, and that [I]_p1943 must not live, lest [I]_p1943 be dangerous to [him]_p1945 [my]_p1946 only chance is to prolong [my]_p1947 opportunities. Something may occur which will give [me]_p1948 a chance to escape. [I]_p1949 saw in [his]_p1950 eyes something of that gathering wrath which was manifest when [he]_p1951 hurled that fair woman from him. [He]_p1952 explained to [me]_p1953 that posts were few and uncertain, and that [my]_p1955 writing now would ensure ease of mind to [my]_p1956 friends and [he]_p1959 assured [me]_p1954 with so much impressiveness that [he]_p1960 would countermand the later letters, which would be held over at [Bistritz]_n129 until due time in case chance would admit of [my]_p1956 prolonging [my]_p1957 stay, that to oppose [him]_p1961 would have been to create new suspicion. [I]_p1962 therefore pretended to fall in with [his]_p1964 views, and asked [him]_p1965 what dates [I]_p1963 should put on the letters. [He]_p1966 calculated a minute, and then said:,   "The first should be June 12, the second June 19, and the third June 29. "  [I]_p1967 know now the span of [my]_p1968 life. God help me! * * * * * 28 [May]_n130.

, There is a chance of escape, or at any rate of being able to send word home. A band of Szgany have come to the castle, and are encamped in the courtyard. These Szgany are gipsies [I]_p1969 have notes of [them]_p1970 in [my]_p1971 book. [They]_p1972 are peculiar to this part of the world, though allied to the ordinary gipsies all the world over. There are thousands of [them]_p1973 in Hungary and [Transylvania]_n,131 who are almost outside all law. [They]_p1974 attach [themselves]_p1975 as a rule to some great noble or boyar, and call [themselves]_p1976 by [his]_p1977 name. [They]_p1978 are fearless and without religion, save superstition, and [they]_p1979 talk only [their]_p1980 own varieties of the [Romany]_n132 tongue. [I]_p1981 shall write some letters home, and shall try to get [them]_p1982 to have [them]_p1983 posted. [I]_p1984 have already spoken [them]_p1985 through [my]_p1986 window to begin acquaintanceship. [They]_p1987 took [their]_p1988 hats off and made obeisance and many signs, which, however, [I]_p1990 could not understand any more than [I]_p1991 could [their]_p1989 spoken language.

* * * * *  [I]_p1992 have written the letters. Mina's is in shorthand, and [I]_p1993 simply ask [Mr Hawkins]_n133 to communicate with her. To [her]_p1994 [I]_p1995 have explained [my]_p1997 situation, but without the horrors which [I]_p1996 may only surmise. [It]_p1998 would shock and frighten [her]_p1999 to death were [I]_p2001 to expose [my]_p2002 heart to her. Should the letters not carry, then the Count shall not yet know [my]_p2003 secret or the extent of [my]_p2004 knowledge. * * * * *  [I]_p2005 have given the letters [I]_p2006 threw [them]_p2008 through the bars of [my]_p2010 window with a gold piece, and made what signs [I]_p2006 could to have [them]_p2009 posted. The man who took [them]_p2011 pressed [them]_p2012 to [his]_p2014 heart and bowed, and then put [them]_p2012 in [his]_p2015 cap. [I]_p2016 could do no more. [I]_p2017 stole back to the study, and began to read. As the Count did not come in, [I]_p2018 have written here.

* * * * *  The Count has come. [He]_p2019 sat down beside me, and said in [his]_p2022 smoothest voice as [he]_p2023 opened two letters:,   "The Szgany has given [me]_p2020 these, of which, though [I]_p2024 know not whence [they]_p2026 come, [I]_p2025 shall, of course, take care. See!", [he]_p2027 must have looked at it, "one is from you, and to [my]_p2030 friend Peter Hawkins the other", here [he]_p2028 caught sight of the strange symbols as [he]_p2028 opened the envelope, and the dark look came into [his]_p2031 face, and [his]_p2032 eyes blazed wickedly, "the other is a vile thing, an outrage upon friendship and hospitality! [It]_p2033 is not signed. Well! so [it]_p2034 cannot matter to us. " And [he]_p2035 calmly held letter and envelope in the flame of the lamp till [they]_p2036 were consumed. Then [he]_p2037 went on:,   "The letter to Hawkins, that [I]_p2038 shall, of course, send on, since [it]_p2039 is yours. [Your]_p2040 letters are sacred to me. [Your]_p2041 pardon, [my]_p2042 friend, that unknowingly [I]_p2043 did break the seal. Will [you]_p2044 not cover [it]_p2045 again?" [He]_p2046 held out the letter to me, and with a courteous bow handed [me]_p2047 a clean envelope. [I]_p2049 could only redirect [it]_p2050 and hand [it]_p2051 to [him]_p2052 in silence.

When [he]_p2053 went out of the room [I]_p2054 could hear the key turn softly. A minute later [I]_p2055 went over and tried it, and the door was locked. When, an hour or two after, the Count came quietly into the room, [his]_p2056 coming awakened me, for [I]_p2057 had gone to sleep on the sofa. [He]_p2058 was very courteous and very cheery in [his]_p2059 manner, and seeing that [I]_p2060 had been sleeping, [he]_p2061 said:,   "So, [my]_p2062 friend, [you]_p2063 are tired? Get to bed. There is the surest [rest]_n134. [I]_p2064 may not have the pleasure to talk [to-night]_n,135 since there are many labours to [me]_p2066 but [you]_p2067 will sleep, [I]_p2065 pray. " [I]_p2068 passed to [my]_p2069 room and went to bed, and, strange to say, slept without dreaming. Despair has [its]_p2070 own calms. * * * * * 31 [May]_n136. , This morning when [I]_p2071 woke [I]_p2072 thought [I]_p2072 would provide [myself]_p2077 with some paper and envelopes from [my]_p2078 bag and keep [them]_p2083 in [my]_p2079 pocket, so that [I]_p2073 might write in case [I]_p2073 should get an opportunity, but again a surprise, again a shock!  Every scrap of paper was gone, and with [it]_p2084 all [my]_p2079 notes, [my]_p2080 memoranda, relating to railways and travel, [my]_p2080 letter of credit, in fact all that might be useful to [me]_p2085 were [I]_p2073 once outside the castle.

[I]_p2086 sat and pondered awhile, and then some thought occurred to me, and [I]_p2087 made search of [my]_p2089 portmanteau and in the wardrobe where [I]_p2087 had placed [my]_p2090 clothes. The suit in which [I]_p2091 had travelled was gone, and also [my]_p2093 overcoat and rug [I]_p2092 could find no trace of [them]_p2094 anywhere. This looked like some new scheme of villainy. * * * * *  17 June. , This morning, as [I]_p2095 was sitting on the edge of [my]_p2097 bed cudgelling [my]_p2098 brains, [I]_p2096 heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses' feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard. With joy [I]_p2099 hurried to the window, and saw drive into the yard two great leiter-wagons, each drawn by eight sturdy horses, and at the head of each pair a Slovak, with [his]_p2100 wide hat, great nail-studded belt, dirty sheepskin, and high boots. [They]_p2101 had also [their]_p2102 long staves in hand. [I]_p2103 ran to the door, intending to descend and try and join [them]_p2105 through the main hall, as [I]_p2104 thought that way might be opened for them. Again a shock: [my]_p2107 door was fastened on the outside. Then [I]_p2108 ran to the window and cried to them.

[They]_p2109 looked up at [me]_p2110 stupidly and pointed, but just then the "hetman" of the Szgany came out, and seeing [them]_p2111 pointing to [my]_p2112 window, said something, at which [they]_p2113 laughed. Henceforth no effort of mine, no piteous cry or agonised entreaty, would make [them]_p2114 even look at me. [They]_p2115 resolutely turned away. The leiter-wagons contained great, square boxes, with handles of thick rope these were evidently empty by the ease with which the Slovaks handled them, and by [their]_p2116 resonance as [they]_p2117 were roughly moved. When [they]_p2118 were all unloaded and packed in a great heap in one corner of the yard, the Slovaks were given some money by the Szgany, and spitting on [it]_p2119 for luck, lazily went each to [his]_p2120 horse's head. Shortly afterwards, [I]_p2121 heard the cracking of [their]_p2122 whips die away in the distance. * * * * *  24 June, before morning. , Last night the Count left [me]_p2123 early, and locked [himself]_p2124 into [his]_p2125 own room. As soon as [I]_p2126 dared [I]_p2127 ran up the winding stair, and looked out of the window, which opened south. [I]_p2128 thought [I]_p2129 would watch for the Count, for there is something going on.

The Szgany are quartered somewhere in the castle and are doing work of some kind. [I]_p2130 know it, for now and then [I]_p2131 hear a far-away muffled sound as of mattock and spade, and, whatever [it]_p2132 is, [it]_p2133 must be the end of some ruthless villainy. [I]_p2135 had been at the window somewhat less than half an hour, when [I]_p2136 saw something coming out of the Count's window. [I]_p2137 drew back and watched carefully, and saw the whole man emerge. [It]_p2138 was a new shock to [me]_p2139 to find that [he]_p2140 had on the suit of clothes which [I]_p2141 had worn whilst travelling here, and slung over [his]_p2143 shoulder the terrible bag which [I]_p2142 had seen the women take away. There could be no doubt as to [his]_p2144 quest, and in [my]_p2146 garb, too! This, then, is [his]_p2145 new scheme of evil: that [he]_p2148 will allow others to see me, as [they]_p2151 think, so that [he]_p2149 may both leave evidence that [I]_p2152 have been seen in the towns or villages posting [my]_p2147 own letters, and that any wickedness which [he]_p2149 may do shall by the local people be attributed to me. [It]_p2153 makes [me]_p2154 rage to think that this can go on, and whilst [I]_p2155 am shut up here, a veritable prisoner, but without that protection of the law which is even a criminal's right and consolation. [I]_p2156 thought [I]_p2157 would watch for the Count's return, and for a long time sat doggedly at the window. Then [I]_p2158 began to notice that there were some quaint little specks floating in the rays of the moonlight. [They]_p2159 were like the tiniest grains of dust, and [they]_p2160 whirled round and gathered in clusters in a nebulous sort of way.

[I]_p2161 watched [them]_p2162 with a sense of soothing, and a sort of calm stole over me. [I]_p2163 leaned back in the embrasure in a more comfortable position, so that [I]_p2164 could enjoy more fully the a rial gambolling. Something made [me]_p2165 start up, a low, piteous howling of dogs somewhere far below in the valley, which was hidden from [my]_p2166 sight. Louder [it]_p2167 seemed to ring in [my]_p2168 ears, and the floating motes of dust to take new shapes to the sound as [they]_p2169 danced in the moonlight. [I]_p2170 felt [myself]_p2171 struggling to awake to some call of [my]_p2172 instincts nay, [my]_p2173 very soul was struggling, and [my]_p2173 half-remembered sensibilities were striving to answer the call. [I]_p2175 was becoming hypnotised! Quicker and quicker danced the dust the moonbeams seemed to quiver as [they]_p2176 went by [me]_p2177 into the mass of gloom beyond. More and more [they]_p2178 gathered till [they]_p2179 seemed to take dim phantom shapes. And then [I]_p2180 started, broad awake and in full possession of [my]_p2181 senses, and ran screaming from the place. The phantom shapes, which were becoming gradually materialised from the moonbeams, were those of the three ghostly women to whom [I]_p2182 was doomed. [I]_p2183 fled, and felt somewhat safer in [my]_p2184 own room, where there was no moonlight and where the lamp was burning brightly.

When a couple of hours had passed [I]_p2185 heard something stirring in the Count's room, something like a sharp wail quickly suppressed and then there was silence, deep, awful silence, which chilled me. With a beating heart, [I]_p2186 tried the door but [I]_p2187 was locked in [my]_p2188 prison, and could do nothing. [I]_p2189 sat down and simply cried. As [I]_p2190 sat [I]_p2191 heard a sound in the courtyard without, the agonised cry of a woman. [I]_p2192 rushed to the window, and throwing [it]_p2193 up, peered out between the bars. There, indeed, was a woman with dishevelled hair, holding [her]_p2194 hands over [her]_p2195 heart as one distressed with running. [She]_p2196 was leaning against a corner of the gateway. When [she]_p2197 saw [my]_p2199 face at the window [she]_p2198 threw [herself]_p2202 forward, and shouted in a voice laden with menace:,   "Monster, give [me]_p2204 [my]_p2200 child!"  [She]_p2205 threw [herself]_p2203 on [her]_p2206 knees, and raising up [her]_p2207 hands, cried the same words in tones which wrung [my]_p2200 heart. Then [she]_p2208 tore [her]_p2209 hair and beat [her]_p2210 breast, and abandoned [herself]_p2211 to all the violences of extravagant emotion. Finally, [she]_p2212 threw [herself]_p2213 forward, and, though [I]_p2214 could not see her, [I]_p2215 could hear the beating of [her]_p2216 naked hands against the door.

Somewhere high overhead, probably on the tower, [I]_p2218 heard the voice of the Count calling in [his]_p2219 harsh, metallic whisper. [His]_p2220 call seemed to be answered from far and wide by the howling of wolves. Before many minutes had passed a pack of [them]_p2221 poured, like a pent-up dam when liberated, through the wide entrance into the courtyard. There was no cry from the woman, and the howling of the wolves was but short. Before long [they]_p2222 streamed away singly, licking [their]_p2223 lips. [I]_p2224 could not pity her, for [I]_p2225 knew now what had become of [her]_p2226 child, and [she]_p2228 was better dead. What shall [I]_p2229 do? what can [I]_p2230 do? How can [I]_p2230 escape from this dreadful thing of night and gloom and fear?  * * * * *  25 June, morning. , No man knows till [he]_p2232 has suffered from the night how sweet and how [dear]_n137 to [his]_p2233 heart and eye the morning can be. When the sun grew so high this morning that [it]_p2234 struck the top of the great gateway opposite [my]_p2236 window, the high spot which [it]_p2235 touched seemed to [me]_p2237 as if the dove from the ark had lighted there. [My]_p2238 fear fell from [me]_p2239 as if [it]_p2240 had been a vaporous garment which dissolved in the warmth.

[I]_p2241 must take action of some sort whilst the courage of the day is upon me. Last night one of [my]_p2242 post-dated letters went to post, the first of that fatal series which is to blot out the very traces of [my]_p2243 existence from the earth. Let [me]_p2244 not think of it. Action!  [It]_p2245 has always been at night-time that [I]_p2246 have been molested or threatened, or in some way in danger or in fear. [I]_p2247 have not yet seen the Count in the daylight. Can [it]_p2248 be that [he]_p2249 sleeps when others wake, that [he]_p2250 may be awake whilst [they]_p2251 sleep? If [I]_p2252 could only get into [his]_p2253 room! But there is no possible way. The door is always locked, no way for me. Yes, there is a way, if one dares to take it. Where [his]_p2254 body has gone why may not another body go? [I]_p2256 have seen [him]_p2257 [myself]_p2258 crawl from [his]_p2255 window. Why should not [I]_p2259 imitate him, and go in by [his]_p2260 window? The chances are desperate, but [my]_p2261 need is more desperate still.

[I]_p2262 shall risk it. At the worst [it]_p2263 can only be death and a man's death is not a calf's, and the dreaded Hereafter may still be open to me. God help [me]_p2264 in [my]_p2265 task! Good-bye, Mina, if [I]_p2267 fail good-bye, [my]_p2266 faithful friend and second father good-bye, all, and last of all Mina!  * * * * *  Same day, later. , [I]_p2268 have made the effort, and God, helping me, have come safely back to this room. [I]_p2269 must put down every detail in order. [I]_p2270 went whilst [my]_p2271 courage was fresh straight to the window on the south side, and at once got outside on the narrow ledge of stone which runs around the building on this side. The stones are big and roughly cut, and the mortar has by process of time been washed away between them. [I]_p2272 took off [my]_p2273 boots, and ventured out on the desperate way. [I]_p2274 looked down once, so as to make sure that a sudden glimpse of the awful depth would not overcome me, but after that kept [my]_p2275 eyes away from it. [I]_p2276 knew pretty well the direction and distance of the Count's window, and made for [it]_p2278 as well as [I]_p2277 could, having regard to the opportunities available.

[I]_p2279 did not feel dizzy, [I]_p2280 suppose [I]_p2280 was too excited, and the time seemed ridiculously short till [I]_p2281 found [myself]_p2283 standing on the window-sill and trying to raise up the sash. [I]_p2284 was filled with agitation, however, when [I]_p2285 bent down and slid feet foremost in through the window. Then [I]_p2286 looked around for the Count, but, with surprise and gladness, made a discovery. The room was empty! [It]_p2287 was barely furnished with odd things, which seemed to have never been used the furniture was something the same style as that in the south rooms, and was covered with dust. [I]_p2288 looked for the key, but [it]_p2290 was not in the lock, and [I]_p2289 could not find [it]_p2291 anywhere. The only thing [I]_p2292 found was a great heap of gold in one corner, gold of all kinds, Roman, and British, and Austrian, and [Hungarian]_n,138 and Greek and Turkish money, covered with a film of dust, as though [it]_p2293 had lain long in the ground. None of [it]_p2294 that [I]_p2295 noticed was less than three hundred years old. There were also chains and ornaments, some jewelled, but all of [them]_p2296 old and stained. At one corner of the room was a heavy door. [I]_p2297 tried it, for, since [I]_p2298 could not find the key of the room or the key of the outer door, which was the main object of [my]_p2300 search, [I]_p2298 must make further examination, or all [my]_p2301 efforts would be in vain.

[It]_p2302 was open, and led through a stone passage to a circular stairway, which went steeply down. [I]_p2303 descended, minding carefully where [I]_p2304 went, for the stairs were dark, being only lit by loopholes in the heavy masonry. At the bottom there was a dark, tunnel-like passage, through which came a deathly, sickly odour, the odour of old earth newly turned. As [I]_p2305 went through the passage the smell grew closer and heavier. At last [I]_p2306 pulled open a heavy door which stood ajar, and found [myself]_p2307 in an old, ruined chapel, which had evidently been used as a graveyard. The roof was broken, and in two places were steps leading to vaults, but the ground had recently been dug over, and the earth placed in great wooden boxes, manifestly those which had been brought by the Slovaks. There was nobody about, and [I]_p2308 made search for any further outlet, but there was none. Then [I]_p2309 went over every inch of the ground, so as not to lose a chance. [I]_p2310 went down even into the vaults, where the dim light struggled, although to do so was a dread to [my]_p2311 very soul. Into two of these [I]_p2312 went, but saw nothing except fragments of old coffins and piles of dust in the third, however, [I]_p2313 made a discovery.

There, in one of the great boxes, of which there were fifty in all, on a pile of newly dug earth, lay the Count! [He]_p2314 was either dead or asleep, [I]_p2315 could not say which, for the eyes were open and stony, but without the glassiness of death, and the cheeks had the warmth of life through all [their]_p2316 pallor the lips were as red as ever. But there was no sign of movement, no pulse, no breath, no beating of the heart. [I]_p2317 bent over him, and tried to find any sign of life, but in vain. [He]_p2318 could not have lain there long, for the earthy smell would have passed away in a few hours. By the side of the box was [its]_p2319 cover, pierced with holes here and there. [I]_p2320 thought [he]_p2324 might have the keys on him, but when [I]_p2321 went to search [I]_p2321 saw the dead eyes, and in them, dead though [they]_p2325 were, such a look of hate, though unconscious of [me]_p2326 or [my]_p2327 presence, that [I]_p2322 fled from the place, and leaving the Count's room by the window, crawled again up the castle wall. Regaining [my]_p2328 room, [I]_p2329 threw [myself]_p2330 panting upon the bed and tried to think. * * * * *  29 June. , To-day is the date of [my]_p2331 last letter, and the Count has taken steps to prove that [it]_p2333 was genuine, for again [I]_p2334 saw [him]_p2335 leave the castle by the same window, and in [my]_p2332 clothes. As [he]_p2336 went down the wall, lizard fashion, [I]_p2337 wished [I]_p2338 had a gun or some lethal weapon, that [I]_p2338 might destroy [him]_p2341 but [I]_p2339 fear that no weapon wrought alone by man's hand would have any effect on him.

[I]_p2343 dared not wait to see [him]_p2345 return, for [I]_p2344 feared to see those weird sisters. [I]_p2346 came back to the library, and read there till [I]_p2347 fell asleep. [I]_p2348 was awakened by the Count, who looked at [me]_p2349 as grimly as a man can look as [he]_p2350 said:,   "To-morrow, [my]_p2351 friend, [we]_p2352 must part. [You]_p2353 return to [your]_p2354 beautiful England, [I]_p2355 to some work which may have such an end that [we]_p2356 may never meet. [Your]_p2357 letter home has been despatched to-morrow [I]_p2358 shall not be here, but all shall be ready for [your]_p2359 journey. In the morning come the Szgany, who have some labours of [their]_p2360 own here, and also come some [Slovaks]_n139. When [they]_p2361 have gone, [my]_p2362 carriage shall come for you, and shall bear [you]_p2363 to the [Borgo Pass]_n140 to meet the diligence from [Bukovina]_n141 to [Bistritz]_n142. But [I]_p2365 am in hopes that [I]_p2366 shall see more of [you]_p2367 at [Castle Dracula]_n143. " [I]_p2368 suspected him, and determined to test [his]_p2369 sincerity. Sincerity! [It]_p2370 seems like a profanation of the word to write [it]_p2371 in connection with such a monster, so asked [him]_p2372 point-blank:, "Why may [I]_p2373 not go [to-night]_n?"144 "Because, [dear]_n145 sir, [my]_p2374 coachman and horses are away on a mission.

"  "But [I]_p2375 would walk with pleasure. [I]_p2376 want to get away at once. " [He]_p2377 smiled, such a soft, smooth, diabolical smile that [I]_p2378 knew there was some trick behind [his]_p2379 smoothness. [He]_p2380 said:,   "And [your]_p2381 baggage?"  "I do not care about it. [I]_p2382 can send for [it]_p2383 some other time. "  The Count stood up, and said, with a sweet courtesy which made [me]_p2384 rub [my]_p2385 eyes, [it]_p2387 seemed so real:,   "You English have a saying which is close to [my]_p2386 heart, for [its]_p2388 spirit is that which rules [our]_p2389 boyars: 'Welcome the coming speed the parting guest. ' Come with me, [my]_p2390 [dear]_n146 [young]_n147 friend. Not an hour shall [you]_p2391 wait in [my]_p2393 house against [your]_p2394 will, though sad am [I]_p2396 at [your]_p2395 going, and that [you]_p2392 so suddenly desire it. Come!" With a stately gravity, he, with the lamp, preceded [me]_p2397 down the stairs and along the hall. Suddenly [he]_p2398 stopped.

"[Hark]_n!"148 Close at hand came the howling of many wolves. [It]_p2399 was almost as if the sound sprang up at the rising of [his]_p2400 hand, just as the music of a great orchestra seems to leap under the b ton of the conductor. After a pause of a moment, [he]_p2401 proceeded, in [his]_p2402 stately way, to the door, drew back the ponderous bolts, unhooked the heavy chains, and began to draw [it]_p2403 open. To [my]_p2404 intense astonishment [I]_p2405 saw that [it]_p2406 was unlocked. Suspiciously, [I]_p2407 looked all round, but could see no key of any kind. As the door began to open, the howling of the wolves without grew louder and angrier [their]_p2408 red jaws, with champing teeth, and [their]_p2409 blunt-clawed feet as [they]_p2410 leaped, came in through the opening door. [I]_p2411 knew then that to struggle at the moment against the Count was useless. With such allies as these at [his]_p2412 command, [I]_p2413 could do nothing. But still the door continued slowly to open, and only the Count's body stood in the gap. Suddenly [it]_p2414 struck [me]_p2415 that this might be the moment and means of [my]_p2416 doom [I]_p2418 was to be given to the wolves, and at [my]_p2417 own instigation.

There was a diabolical wickedness in the idea great enough for the Count, and as a last chance [I]_p2419 cried out:,   "Shut the door [I]_p2420 shall wait till morning!" and covered [my]_p2421 face with [my]_p2422 hands to hide [my]_p2422 tears of bitter disappointment. With one sweep of [his]_p2424 powerful arm, the Count threw the door shut, and the great bolts clanged and echoed through the hall as [they]_p2425 shot back into [their]_p2426 places. In silence [we]_p2427 returned to the library, and after a minute or two [I]_p2428 went to [my]_p2429 own room. The last [I]_p2430 saw of [Count Dracula]_n149 was [his]_p2431 kissing [his]_p2432 hand to [me]_p2434 with a red light of triumph in [his]_p2432 eyes, and with a smile that Judas in hell might be proud of. When [I]_p2435 was in [my]_p2438 room and about to lie down, [I]_p2436 thought [I]_p2436 heard a whispering at [my]_p2439 door. [I]_p2440 went to [it]_p2441 softly and listened. Unless [my]_p2442 ears deceived me, [I]_p2443 heard the voice of the Count:,   "Back, back, to [your]_p2444 own place! [Your]_p2445 time is not yet come. Wait! Have patience! To-night is mine. To-morrow night is yours!" There was a low, sweet ripple of laughter, and in a rage [I]_p2446 threw open the door, and saw without the three terrible women licking [their]_p2447 lips. As [I]_p2448 appeared [they]_p2449 all joined in a horrible laugh, and ran away.

[I]_p2450 came back to [my]_p2451 room and threw [myself]_p2453 on [my]_p2452 knees. [It]_p2454 is then so near the end? To-morrow! to-morrow! [Lord]_n,150 help me, and those to whom [I]_p2455 am [dear]_n!151 * * * * * 30 June, morning. , These may be the last words [I]_p2456 ever write in this diary. [I]_p2457 slept till just before the dawn, and when [I]_p2458 woke threw [myself]_p2460 on [my]_p2461 knees, for [I]_p2458 determined that if Death came [he]_p2462 should find [me]_p2463 ready. At last [I]_p2464 felt that subtle change in the air, and knew that the morning had come. Then came the welcome cock-crow, and [I]_p2465 felt that [I]_p2466 was safe. With a glad heart, [I]_p2467 opened [my]_p2468 door and ran down to the hall. [I]_p2469 had seen that the door was unlocked, and now escape was before me. With hands that trembled with eagerness, [I]_p2470 unhooked the chains and drew back the massive bolts. But the door would not move.

Despair seized me. [I]_p2471 pulled, and pulled, at the door, and shook [it]_p2472 till, massive as [it]_p2473 was, [it]_p2473 rattled in [its]_p2475 casement. [I]_p2476 could see the bolt shot. [It]_p2477 had been locked after [I]_p2478 left the Count. Then a wild desire took [me]_p2479 to obtain that key at any risk, and [I]_p2480 determined then and there to scale the wall again and gain the Count's room. [He]_p2481 might kill me, but death now seemed the happier choice of evils. Without a pause [I]_p2482 rushed up to the east window, and scrambled down the wall, as before, into the Count's room. [It]_p2483 was empty, but that was as [I]_p2484 expected. [I]_p2485 could not see a key anywhere, but the heap of gold remained. [I]_p2486 went through the door in the corner and down the winding stair and along the dark passage to the old chapel.

[I]_p2487 knew now well enough where to find the monster [I]_p2488 sought. The great box was in the same place, close against the wall, but the lid was laid on it, not fastened down, but with the nails ready in [their]_p2489 places to be hammered home. [I]_p2490 knew [I]_p2491 must reach the body for the key, so [I]_p2491 raised the lid, and laid [it]_p2494 back against the wall and then [I]_p2492 saw something which filled [my]_p2495 very soul with horror. There lay the Count, but looking as if [his]_p2496 youth had been half renewed, for the white hair and moustache were changed to dark iron-grey the cheeks were fuller, and the white skin seemed ruby-red underneath the mouth was redder than ever, for on the lips were gouts of fresh blood, which trickled from the corners of the mouth and ran over the chin and neck. Even the deep, burning eyes seemed set amongst swollen flesh, for the lids and pouches underneath were bloated. [It]_p2497 seemed as if the whole awful creature were simply gorged with blood. [He]_p2498 lay like a filthy leech, exhausted with [his]_p2499 repletion. [Hark]_n!152 in the courtyard and down the rocky way the roll of heavy wheels, the crack of whips, and the chorus of the Szgany as [they]_p2550 pass into the distance. [I]_p2551 am alone in the castle with those awful women. Faugh! [Mina]_n153 is a woman, and there is nought in common. [They]_p2552 are devils of the Pit!  [I]_p2553 shall not remain alone with [them]_p2556 [I]_p2554 shall try to scale the castle wall farther than [I]_p2554 have yet attempted. [I]_p2557 shall take some of the gold with me, lest [I]_p2558 want [it]_p2559 later. [I]_p2560 may find a way from this dreadful place. And then away for home! away to the quickest and nearest train! away from this cursed spot, from this cursed land, where the devil and [his]_p2561 children still walk with earthly feet!  At least God's mercy is better than that of these monsters, and the precipice is steep and high.

At [its]_p2562 foot a man may sleep, as a man. Good-bye, all! Mina! CHAPTER V Letter from Miss [Mina Murray]_n154 to Miss Lucy Westenra. "9 [May]_n155. "My dearest Lucy,,   "Forgive [my]_p2563 long delay in writing, but [I]_p2564 have been simply overwhelmed with work. The life of an assistant schoolmistress is sometimes trying. [Good-bye]_n159. "Your loving "[MINA]_n160. "Tell [me]_p2614 all the news when [you]_p2615 write. [You]_p2616 have not told [me]_p2617 anything for a long time. As [I]_p3047 knew that the only cure for this sort of thing was work, [I]_p3048 went down amongst the patients. [I]_p3049 picked out one who has afforded [me]_p3050 a study of much interest.

[He]_p3051 is so quaint that [I]_p3052 am determined to understand [him]_p3054 as well as [I]_p3053 can. [To-day]_n216 [I]_p3055 seemed to get nearer than ever before to the heart of [his]_p3056 mystery. [I]_p3057 questioned [him]_p3059 more fully than [I]_p3058 had ever done, with a view to making [myself]_p3060 master of the facts of [his]_p3061 hallucination. In [my]_p3062 manner of doing [it]_p3063 there was, [I]_p3064 now see, something of cruelty. [I]_p3065 seemed to wish to keep [him]_p3068 to the point of [his]_p3069 madness, a thing which [I]_p3066 avoid with the patients as [I]_p3066 would the mouth of hell. ([Mem]_n217. , under what circumstances would [I]_p3070 not avoid the pit of hell?) Omnia Rom venalia sunt. Hell has [its]_p3071 price! verb. sap. If there be anything behind this instinct [it]_p3072 will be valuable to trace [it]_p3073 afterwards accurately, so [I]_p3074 had better commence to do so, therefore,   R.

M. Renfield, tat 59. , Sanguine temperament great physical strength  morbidly excitable periods of gloom, ending in some fixed idea which [I]_p3075 cannot make out. [I]_p3076 presume that the sanguine temperament [itself]_p3077 and the disturbing influence end in a mentally-accomplished finish a possibly dangerous man, probably dangerous if unselfish. In selfish men caution is as secure an armour for [their]_p3078 foes as for themselves. What [I]_p3079 think of on this point is, when self is the fixed point the centripetal force is balanced with the centrifugal when duty, a cause, etc. , is the fixed point, the latter force is paramount, and only accident or a series of accidents can balance it. [Letter]_n,218 [Quincey]_n219 P. [Morris]_n220 to [Hon]_n221. [Arthur]_n222 [Holmwood]_n223.

"25 [May]_n224. "My [dear]_n225 Art,, "We've told yarns by the camp-fire in the prairies and dressed one another's wounds after trying a landing at the Marquesas and drunk healths on the shore of Titicaca. There are more yarns to be told, and other wounds to be healed, and another health to be drunk. Won't [you]_p3080 let this be at [my]_p3083 camp-fire to-morrow night? [I]_p3084 have no hesitation in asking you, as [I]_p3085 know a certain lady is engaged to a certain dinner-party, and that [you]_p3081 are free. There will only be one other, [our]_p3086 old pal at the Korea, [Jack]_n226 [Seward]_n227. He's coming, too, and [we]_p3087 both want to mingle [our]_p3088 weeps over the wine-cup, and to drink a health with all [our]_p3089 hearts to the happiest man in all the wide world, who has won the noblest heart that God has made and the best worth winning. [We]_p3090 promise [you]_p3091 a hearty welcome, and a loving greeting, and a health as true as [your]_p3092 own right hand. [We]_p3093 shall both swear to leave [you]_p3094 at home if [you]_p3095 drink too deep to a certain pair of eyes. Come!  "Yours, as ever and always,  "QUINCEY P. MORRIS.

" Telegram from [Arthur]_n228 [Holmwood]_n229 to [Quincey]_n230 P. [Morris]_n231. "26 [May]_n232. "Count [me]_p3096 in every time. [I]_p3097 bear messages which will make both [your]_p3098 ears tingle. "[ART]_n233. " CHAPTER VI [MINA MURRAY]_n'S234 JOURNAL 24 July. [Whitby]_n235. , Lucy met [me]_p3099 at the station, looking sweeter and lovelier than ever, and [we]_p3100 drove up to the house at the Crescent in which [they]_p3101 have rooms. This is a lovely place.

The little river, the Esk, runs through a deep valley, which broadens out as [it]_p3102 comes near the harbour. A great viaduct runs across, with high piers, through which the view seems somehow further away than [it]_p3103 really is. The valley is beautifully green, and [it]_p3104 is so steep that when [you]_p3106 are on the high land on either side [you]_p3107 look right across it, unless [you]_p3107 are near enough to see down. The houses of the old town, the side away from us, are all red-roofed, and seem piled up one over the other anyhow, like the pictures [we]_p3109 see of Nuremberg. Right over the town is the ruin of Whitby [Abbey]_n,236 which was sacked by the Danes, and which is the scene of part of "Marmion," where the girl was built up in the wall. [It]_p3110 is a most noble ruin, of immense size, and full of beautiful and romantic bits there is a legend that a white lady is seen in one of the windows. Between [it]_p3111 and the town there is another church, the parish one, round which is a big graveyard, all full of tombstones. This is to [my]_p3112 mind the nicest spot in Whitby, for [it]_p3113 lies right over the town, and has a full view of the harbour and all up the bay to where the headland called [Kettleness]_n237 stretches out into the sea. [It]_p3114 descends so steeply over the harbour that part of the bank has fallen away, and some of the graves have been destroyed. In one place part of the stonework of the graves stretches out over the sandy pathway far below.

There are walks, with seats beside them, through the churchyard and people go and sit there all day long looking at the beautiful view and enjoying the breeze. [I]_p3115 shall come and sit here very often [myself]_p3116 and work. Indeed, [I]_p3117 am writing now, with [my]_p3118 book on [my]_p3119 knee, and listening to the talk of three old men who are sitting beside me. [They]_p3120 seem to do nothing all day but sit up here and talk. The harbour lies below me, with, on the far side, one long granite wall stretching out into the sea, with a curve outwards at the end of it, in the middle of which is a lighthouse. A heavy sea-wall runs along outside of it. On the near side, the sea-wall makes an elbow crooked inversely, and [its]_p3121 end too has a lighthouse. Between the two piers there is a narrow opening into the harbour, which then suddenly widens. [It]_p3122 is nice at high water but when the tide is out [it]_p3123 shoals away to nothing, and there is merely the stream of the Esk, running between banks of sand, with rocks here and there. Outside the harbour on this side there rises for about half a mile a great reef, the sharp edge of which runs straight out from behind the south lighthouse.

At the end of [it]_p3124 is a buoy with a bell, which swings in bad weather, and sends in a mournful sound on the wind. [They]_p3125 have a legend here that when a ship is lost bells are heard out at sea. [I]_p3126 must ask the old man about this [he]_p3127 is coming this way. [He]_p3128 is a funny old man. [He]_p3129 must be awfully old, for [his]_p3130 face is all gnarled and twisted like the bark of a tree. [He]_p3131 tells [me]_p3132 that [he]_p3133 is nearly a hundred, and that [he]_p3134 was a sailor in the Greenland fishing fleet when Waterloo was fought. [He]_p3135 is, [I]_p3136 am afraid, a very sceptical person, for when [I]_p3137 asked [him]_p3139 about the bells at sea and the [White]_n238 Lady at the abbey [he]_p3140 said very brusquely:, "I wouldn't fash masel' about them, miss. [Them]_p3141 things be all wore out. Mind, [I]_p3142 don't say that [they]_p3144 never was, but [I]_p3143 do say that [they]_p3145 wasn't in [my]_p3146 time. [They]_p3147 be all very well for comers and trippers, an' the like, but not for a nice [young]_n239 lady like you.

[Them]_p3148 feet-folks from [York]_n240 and Leeds that be always eatin' cured herrin's an' drinkin' tea an' lookin' out to buy cheap jet would creed aught. [I]_p3149 wonder masel' who'd be bothered tellin' lies to them, even the newspapers, which is full of fool-talk. " [I]_p3150 thought [he]_p3152 would be a good person to learn interesting things from, so [I]_p3151 asked [him]_p3154 if [he]_p3153 would mind telling [me]_p3155 something about the whale-fishing in the old days. [He]_p3156 was just settling [himself]_p3157 to begin when the clock struck six, whereupon [he]_p3158 laboured to get up, and said:,   "I must gang ageeanwards home now, miss. [My]_p3159 grand-daughter doesn't like to be kept waitin' when the tea is ready, for [it]_p3160 takes [me]_p3161 time to crammle aboon the grees, for there be a many of 'em an', miss, [I]_p3162 lack belly-timber sairly by the clock. "  [He]_p3163 hobbled away, and [I]_p3164 could see [him]_p3165 hurrying, as well as [he]_p3166 could, down the steps. The steps are a great feature on the place. [They]_p3167 lead from the town up to the church, there are hundreds of them, [I]_p3168 do not know how many, and [they]_p3169 wind up in a delicate curve the slope is so gentle that a horse could easily walk up and down them. [I]_p3170 think [they]_p3171 must originally have had something to do with the abbey. [I]_p3172 shall go home too.

Lucy went out visiting with [her]_p3173 mother, and as [they]_p3174 were only duty calls, [I]_p3175 did not go. [They]_p3176 will be home by this. * * * * *  1 August. , [I]_p3177 came up here an hour ago with Lucy, and [we]_p3178 had a most interesting talk with [my]_p3179 old friend and the two others who always come and join him. [He]_p3180 is evidently the [Sir Oracle]_n241 of them, and [I]_p3181 should think must have been in [his]_p3182 time a most dictatorial person. [He]_p3183 will not admit anything, and downfaces everybody. If [he]_p3184 can't out-argue [them]_p3186 [he]_p3185 bullies them, and then takes [their]_p3188 silence for agreement with [his]_p3189 views. Lucy was looking sweetly pretty in [her]_p3190 white lawn frock [she]_p3191 has got a beautiful colour since [she]_p3192 has been here. [I]_p3193 noticed that the old men did not lose any time in coming up and sitting near [her]_p3194 when [we]_p3195 sat down. [She]_p3196 is so sweet with old people [I]_p3197 think [they]_p3198 all fell in love with [her]_p3199 on the spot.

Even [my]_p3200 old man succumbed and did not contradict her, but gave [me]_p3201 double share instead. [I]_p3202 got [him]_p3203 on the subject of the legends, and [he]_p3204 went off at once into a sort of sermon. [I]_p3205 must try to remember [it]_p3206 and put [it]_p3207 down:,   "It be all fool-talk, lock, stock, and barrel that's what [it]_p3207 be, an' nowt else. These bans an' wafts an' boh-ghosts an' barguests an' bogles an' all anent [them]_p3209 is only fit to set bairns an' dizzy women a-belderin'. [They]_p3210 be nowt but air-blebs. They, an' all grims an' signs an' warnin's, be all invented by parsons an' illsome beuk-bodies an' railway touters to skeer an' scunner hafflin's, an' to get folks to do somethin' that [they]_p3211 don't other incline to. [It]_p3212 makes [me]_p3213 ireful to think o' them. Why, it's [them]_p3214 that, not content with printin' lies on paper an' preachin' [them]_p3215 out of pulpits, does want to be cuttin' [them]_p3215 on the tombstones. Look here all around [you]_p3217 in what airt [ye]_p3218 will all [them]_p3219 steans, holdin' up [their]_p3224 heads as well as [they]_p3226 can out of [their]_p3225 pride, is acant, simply tumblin' down with the weight o' the lies wrote on them, 'Here lies the body' or '[Sacred]_n242 to the memory' wrote on all of them, an' yet in nigh half of [them]_p3220 there bean't no bodies at all an' the memories of [them]_p3220 bean't cared a pinch of snuff about, much less sacred. Lies all of them, nothin' but lies of one kind or another! [My]_p3231 gog, but it'll be a quare scowderment at the [Day]_n243 of Judgment when [they]_p3232 come tumblin' up in [their]_p3235 death-sarks, all jouped together an' tryin' to drag [their]_p3236 tombsteans with [them]_p3227 to prove how good [they]_p3233 was some of [them]_p3228 trimmlin' and ditherin', with [their]_p3236 hands that dozzened an' slippy from lyin' in the sea that [they]_p3233 can't even keep [their]_p3237 grup o' them.

"  [I]_p3239 could see from the old fellow's self-satisfied air and the way in which [he]_p3241 looked round for the approval of [his]_p3243 cronies that [he]_p3242 was "showing off," so [I]_p3240 put in a word to keep [him]_p3244 going:,   "Oh, Mr Swales, [you]_p3245 can't be serious. Surely these tombstones are not all wrong?"  "Yabblins! There may be a poorish few not wrong, savin' where [they]_p3246 make out the people too good for there be folk that do think a balm-bowl be like the sea, if only [it]_p3247 be [their]_p3248 own. The whole thing be only lies. Now look [you]_p3249 here [you]_p3250 come here a stranger, an' [you]_p3250 see this kirk-garth. " [I]_p3252 nodded, for [I]_p3253 thought [it]_p3255 better to assent, though [I]_p3253 did not quite understand [his]_p3256 dialect. [I]_p3257 knew [it]_p3258 had something to do with the church. [He]_p3259 went on: "And [you]_p3260 consate that all these steans be aboon folk that be happed here, snod an' snog?" [I]_p3261 assented again. "Then that be just where the lie comes in. Why, there be scores of these lay-beds that be toom as old Dun's 'bacca-box on [Friday]_n244 night. " [He]_p3262 nudged one of [his]_p3263 companions, and [they]_p3264 all laughed.

"And [my]_p3265 gog! how could [they]_p3266 be otherwise? Look at that one, the aftest abaft the bier-bank: read it!" [I]_p3267 went over and read:,   "Edward Spencelagh, master mariner, murdered by pirates off the coast of Andres, April, 1854, t. 30. " When [I]_p3268 came back Mr Swales went on:,   "Who brought [him]_p3271 home, [I]_p3269 wonder, to hap [him]_p3272 here? Murdered off the coast of Andres! an' [you]_p3273 consated [his]_p3274 body lay under! Why, [I]_p3269 could name [ye]_p3275 a dozen whose bones lie in the Greenland seas above", [he]_p3276 pointed northwards, "or where the currents may have drifted them. There be the steans around ye. Ye can, with [your]_p3277 [young]_n245 eyes, read the small-print of the lies from here. This [Braithwaite]_n246 Lowrey, [I]_p3278 knew [his]_p3279 father, lost in the Lively off Greenland in '20 or Andrew Woodhouse, drowned in the same seas in 1777 or John Paxton, drowned off Cape Farewell a year later or old John Rawlings, whose grandfather sailed with me, drowned in the Gulf of Finland in '50. Do [ye]_p3280 think that all these men will have to make a rush to Whitby when the trumpet sounds? [I]_p3282 have [me]_p3284 antherums aboot it! [I]_p3283 tell [ye]_p3281 that when [they]_p3287 got here they'd be jommlin' an' jostlin' one another that way that [it]_p3285 'ud be like a fight up on the ice in the old days, when we'd be at one another from daylight to dark, an' tryin' to tie up [our]_p3289 cuts by the light of the aurora borealis. " This was evidently local pleasantry, for the old man cackled over it, and [his]_p3290 cronies joined in with gusto. "But," [I]_p3291 said, "surely [you]_p3292 are not quite correct, for [you]_p3293 start on the assumption that all the poor people, or [their]_p3294 spirits, will have to take [their]_p3295 tombstones with [them]_p3296 on the [Day]_n247 of Judgment. Do [you]_p3297 think that will be really necessary?"  "Well, what else be [they]_p3298 tombstones for? Answer [me]_p3299 that, miss!"  "To please [their]_p3300 relatives, [I]_p3301 suppose.

"  "To please [their]_p3302 relatives, [you]_p3303 suppose!" This [he]_p3304 said with intense scorn. "How will [it]_p3305 pleasure [their]_p3306 relatives to know that lies is wrote over them, and that everybody in the place knows that [they]_p3307 be lies?" [He]_p3308 pointed to a stone at [our]_p3309 feet which had been laid down as a slab, on which the seat was rested, close to the edge of the cliff. "Read the lies on that thruff-stean," [he]_p3310 said. The letters were upside down to [me]_p3311 from where [I]_p3312 sat, but Lucy was more opposite to them, so [she]_p3313 leant over and read:, "Sacred to the memory of George [Canon]_n,248 who died, in the hope of a glorious resurrection, on July, 29, 1873, falling from the rocks at [Kettleness]_n249. This tomb was erected by [his]_p3314 sorrowing mother to [her]_p3315 dearly beloved son. 'He was the only son of [his]_p3316 mother, and [she]_p3317 was a widow. ' Really, Mr Swales, [I]_p3318 don't see anything very funny in that!" [She]_p3319 spoke [her]_p3320 comment very gravely and somewhat severely. "Ye don't see aught funny! Ha! ha! But that's because [ye]_p3321 don't gawm the sorrowin' mother was a hell-cat that hated [him]_p3322 because [he]_p3323 was acrewk'd, a regular lamiter [he]_p3324 was, an' [he]_p3324 hated [her]_p3327 so that [he]_p3325 committed suicide in order that [she]_p3328 mightn't get an insurance [she]_p3329 put on [his]_p3330 life. [He]_p3331 blew nigh the top of [his]_p3332 head off with an old musket that [they]_p3333 had for scarin' the crows with. 'Twarn't for crows then, for [it]_p3334 brought the clegs and the dowps to him.

That's the way [he]_p3335 fell off the rocks. And, as to hopes of a glorious resurrection, I've often heard [him]_p3336 say masel' that [he]_p3337 hoped he'd go to hell, for [his]_p3340 mother was so pious that she'd be sure to go to heaven, an' [he]_p3338 didn't want to addle where [she]_p3341 was. Now isn't that stean at any rate", [he]_p3343 hammered [it]_p3345 with [his]_p3349 stick as [he]_p3344 spoke, "a pack of lies? and won't [it]_p3346 make Gabriel keckle when Geordie comes pantin' up the grees with the tombstean balanced on [his]_p3350 hump, and asks [it]_p3346 to be took as evidence!"  [I]_p3351 did not know what to say, but Lucy turned the conversation as [she]_p3355 said, rising up:,   "Oh, why did [you]_p3356 tell [us]_p3357 of this? [It]_p3358 is [my]_p3359 favourite seat, and [I]_p3352 cannot leave [it]_p3347 and now [I]_p3352 find [I]_p3353 must go on sitting over the grave of a suicide. " "That won't harm ye, [my]_p3360 pretty an' [it]_p3361 may make [poor]_n250 Geordie gladsome to have so trim a lass sittin' on [his]_p3362 lap. That won't hurt ye. Why, I've sat here off an' on for nigh twenty years past, an' [it]_p3363 hasn't done [me]_p3364 no harm. Don't [ye]_p3365 fash about [them]_p3369 as lies under ye, or that doesn' lie there either! It'll be time for [ye]_p3366 to be getting scart when [ye]_p3366 see the tombsteans all run away with, and the place as bare as a stubble-field. There's the clock, an' [I]_p3370 must gang. [My]_p3371 service to ye, ladies!" And off [he]_p3372 hobbled. [Lucy]_n251 and [I]_p3373 sat awhile, and [it]_p3374 was all so beautiful before [us]_p3375 that [we]_p3376 took hands as [we]_p3377 sat and [she]_p3378 told [me]_p3379 all over again about [Arthur]_n252 and [their]_p3380 coming marriage.

That made [me]_p3381 just a little heart-sick, for [I]_p3382 haven't heard from Jonathan for a whole month. * * * * *  The same day. [I]_p3383 came up here alone, for [I]_p3384 am very sad. There was no letter for me. [I]_p3385 hope there cannot be anything the matter with Jonathan. The clock has just struck nine. [I]_p3386 see the lights scattered all over the town, sometimes in rows where the streets are, and sometimes singly  [they]_p3387 run right up the Esk and die away in the curve of the valley. To [my]_p3388 left the view is cut off by a black line of roof of the old house next the abbey. The sheep and lambs are bleating in the fields away behind me, and there is a clatter of a donkey's hoofs up the paved road below. The band on the pier is playing a harsh waltz in good time, and further along the quay there is a [Salvation Army]_n253 meeting in a back street.

Neither of the bands hears the other, but up here [I]_p3389 hear and see [them]_p3390 both. [I]_p3391 wonder where Jonathan is and if [he]_p3393 is thinking of me! [I]_p3392 wish [he]_p3394 were here. [Dr Seward]_n's254 [Diary]_n255. 5 June. , The case of Renfield grows more interesting the more [I]_p3395 get to understand the man. [He]_p3396 has certain qualities very largely developed  selfishness, secrecy, and purpose. [I]_p3397 wish [I]_p3398 could get at what is the object of the latter. [He]_p3399 seems to have some settled scheme of [his]_p3400 own, but what [it]_p3401 is [I]_p3402 do not yet know. [His]_p3403 redeeming quality is a love of animals, though, indeed, [he]_p3404 has such curious turns in [it]_p3406 that [I]_p3407 sometimes imagine [he]_p3405 is only abnormally cruel. [His]_p3408 pets are of odd sorts.

Just now [his]_p3409 hobby is catching flies. [He]_p3410 has at present such a quantity that [I]_p3411 have had [myself]_p3412 to expostulate. To [my]_p3413 astonishment, [he]_p3414 did not break out into a fury, as [I]_p3415 expected, but took the matter in simple seriousness. [He]_p3416 thought for a moment, and then said: "May [I]_p3417 have three days? [I]_p3418 shall clear [them]_p3419 away. " Of course, [I]_p3420 said that would do. [I]_p3421 must watch him. * * * * *  18 June. , [He]_p3422 has turned [his]_p3423 mind now to spiders, and has got several very big fellows in a box. [He]_p3424 keeps feeding [them]_p3425 with [his]_p3426 flies, and the number of the latter is becoming sensibly diminished, although [he]_p3429 has used half [his]_p3427 food in attracting more flies from outside to [his]_p3427 room. * * * * *  1 July.

, [His]_p3430 spiders are now becoming as great a nuisance as [his]_p3431 flies, and to-day [I]_p3432 told [him]_p3433 that [he]_p3434 must get rid of them. [He]_p3435 looked very sad at this, so [I]_p3436 said that [he]_p3437 must clear out some of them, at all events. [He]_p3438 cheerfully acquiesced in this, and [I]_p3439 gave [him]_p3440 the same time as before for reduction. [He]_p3441 disgusted [me]_p3442 much while with him, for when a horrid blow-fly, bloated with some carrion food, buzzed into the room, [he]_p3443 caught it, held [it]_p3445 exultantly for a few moments between [his]_p3449 finger and thumb, and, before [I]_p3451 knew what [he]_p3444 was going to do, put [it]_p3446 in [his]_p3450 mouth and ate it. [I]_p3452 scolded [him]_p3453 for it, but [he]_p3458 argued quietly that [it]_p3455 was very good and very wholesome that [it]_p3456 was life, strong life, and gave life to him. This gave [me]_p3459 an idea, or the rudiment of one. [I]_p3460 must watch how [he]_p3461 gets rid of [his]_p3462 spiders. [He]_p3463 has evidently some deep problem in [his]_p3464 mind, for [he]_p3465 keeps a little note-book in which [he]_p3466 is always jotting down something. Whole pages of [it]_p3467 are filled with masses of figures, generally single numbers added up in batches, and then the totals added in batches again, as though [he]_p3469 were "focussing" some account, as the auditors put it. * * * * *  8 July.

, There is a method in [his]_p3470 madness, and the rudimentary idea in [my]_p3471 mind is growing. [It]_p3472 will be a whole idea soon, and then, oh, unconscious cerebration! [you]_p3473 will have to give the wall to [your]_p3474 conscious brother. [I]_p3475 kept away from [my]_p3477 friend for a few days, so that [I]_p3476 might notice if there were any change. Things remain as [they]_p3478 were except that [he]_p3479 has parted with some of [his]_p3480 pets and got a new one. [He]_p3481 has managed to get a sparrow, and has already partially tamed it. [His]_p3482 means of taming is simple, for already the spiders have diminished. Those that do remain, however, are well fed, for [he]_p3483 still brings in the flies by tempting [them]_p3484 with [his]_p3485 food. * * * * *  19 July. , [We]_p3486 are progressing. [My]_p3487 friend has now a whole colony of sparrows, and [his]_p3488 flies and spiders are almost obliterated.

When [I]_p3489 came in [he]_p3490 ran to [me]_p3494 and said [he]_p3491 wanted to ask [me]_p3495 a great favour, a very, very great favour and as [he]_p3491 spoke [he]_p3492 fawned on [me]_p3495 like a dog. [I]_p3497 asked [him]_p3504 what [it]_p3506 was, and [he]_p3508 said, with a sort of rapture in [his]_p3510 voice and bearing:,   "A kitten, a nice little, sleek playful kitten, that [I]_p3498 can play with, and teach, and feed, and feed, and feed!"
