[I]_p3498 was not unprepared for this request, for [I]_p3499 had noticed how [his]_p3511 pets went on increasing in size and vivacity, but [I]_p3499 did not care that [his]_p3511 pretty family of tame sparrows should be wiped out in the same manner as the flies and the spiders so [I]_p3499 said [I]_p3500 would see about it, and asked [him]_p3505 if [he]_p3509 would not rather have a cat than a kitten. [His]_p3513 eagerness betrayed [him]_p3514 as [he]_p3515 answered:,   "Oh, yes, [I]_p3516 would like a cat! [I]_p3517 only asked for a kitten lest [you]_p3518 should refuse [me]_p3519 a cat. No one would refuse [me]_p3520 a kitten, would they?" [I]_p3521 shook [my]_p3524 head, and said that at present [I]_p3522 feared [it]_p3525 would not be possible, but that [I]_p3522 would see about it. [His]_p3527 face fell, and [I]_p3528 could see a warning of danger in it, for there was a sudden fierce, [sidelong]_n256 look which meant killing. The man is an undeveloped homicidal maniac. [I]_p3529 shall test [him]_p3531 with [his]_p3532 present craving and see how [it]_p3533 will work out then [I]_p3530 shall know more. * * * * *  10 p. m. , [I]_p3534 have visited [him]_p3535 again and found [him]_p3536 sitting in a corner brooding.

When [I]_p3537 came in [he]_p3538 threw [himself]_p3539 on [his]_p3540 knees before [me]_p3542 and implored [me]_p3543 to let [him]_p3544 have a cat that [his]_p3541 salvation depended upon it. [I]_p3545 was firm, however, and told [him]_p3547 that [he]_p3549 could not have it, whereupon [he]_p3550 went without a word, and sat down, gnawing [his]_p3551 fingers, in the corner where [I]_p3546 had found him. [I]_p3552 shall see [him]_p3553 in the morning early. * * * * *  20 July. , [Visited]_n257 Renfield very early, before the attendant went [his]_p3554 rounds. [Found]_n258 [him]_p3555 up and humming a tune. [He]_p3556 was spreading out [his]_p3557 sugar, which [he]_p3559 had saved, in the window, and was manifestly beginning [his]_p3558 fly-catching again and beginning [it]_p3560 cheerfully and with a good grace. [I]_p3561 looked around for [his]_p3562 birds, and not seeing them, asked [him]_p3563 where [they]_p3564 were. [He]_p3565 replied, without turning round, that [they]_p3566 had all flown away. There were a few feathers about the room and on [his]_p3567 pillow a drop of blood.

[I]_p3568 said nothing, but went and told the keeper to report to [me]_p3569 if there were anything odd about [him]_p3570 during the day. * * * * *  11 a. m. , The attendant has just been to [me]_p3571 to say that Renfield has been very sick and has disgorged a whole lot of feathers. "My belief is, doctor," [he]_p3572 said, "that [he]_p3573 has eaten [his]_p3575 birds, and that [he]_p3573 just took and ate [them]_p3576 raw!"  * * * * *  11 p. m. , [I]_p3577 gave Renfield a strong opiate [to-night]_n,259 enough to make even [him]_p3578 sleep, and took away [his]_p3579 pocket-book to look at it. The thought that has been buzzing about [my]_p3580 brain lately is complete, and the theory proved. [My]_p3581 homicidal maniac is of a peculiar kind. [I]_p3582 shall have to invent a new classification for him, and call [him]_p3583 a zo phagous (life-eating) maniac what [he]_p3585 desires is to absorb as many lives as [he]_p3586 can, and [he]_p3586 has laid [himself]_p3588 out to achieve [it]_p3589 in a cumulative way.

[He]_p3590 gave many flies to one spider and many spiders to one bird, and then wanted a cat to eat the many birds. What would have been [his]_p3591 later steps? [It]_p3592 would almost be worth while to complete the experiment. [It]_p3593 might be done if there were only a sufficient cause. Men sneered at vivisection, and yet look at [its]_p3594 results to-day! Why not advance science in [its]_p3595 most difficult and vital aspect, the knowledge of the brain? Had [I]_p3596 even the secret of one such mind, did [I]_p3597 hold the key to the fancy of even one lunatic, [I]_p3597 might advance [my]_p3599 own branch of science to a pitch compared with which Burdon-Sanderson's physiology or Ferrier's brain-knowledge would be as nothing. If only there were a sufficient cause! [I]_p3600 must not think too much of this, or [I]_p3601 may be tempted a good cause might turn the scale with me, for may not [I]_p3601 too be of an exceptional brain, congenitally?  How well the man reasoned lunatics always do within [their]_p3603 own scope. [I]_p3604 wonder at how many lives [he]_p3605 values a man, or if at only one. [He]_p3606 has closed the account most accurately, and [to-day]_n260 begun a new record. How many of [us]_p3607 begin a new record with each day of [our]_p3608 lives?  To [me]_p3609 [it]_p3610 seems only yesterday that [my]_p3611 whole life ended with [my]_p3612 new hope, and that truly [I]_p3613 began a new record. So [it]_p3614 will be until the Great [Recorder]_n261 sums [me]_p3615 up and closes [my]_p3616 ledger account with a balance to profit or loss. Oh, Lucy, Lucy, [I]_p3617 cannot be angry with you, nor can [I]_p3618 be angry with [my]_p3620 friend whose happiness is [yours]_p3621 but [I]_p3618 must only wait on hopeless and work.

Work! work!  If [I]_p3622 only could have as strong a cause as [my]_p3623 poor mad friend there, a good, unselfish cause to make [me]_p3624 work, that would be indeed happiness. [Mina Murray]_n's262 [Journal]_n263. 26 July. , [I]_p3625 am anxious, and [it]_p3626 soothes [me]_p3628 to express [myself]_p3629 here [it]_p3627 is like whispering to one's self and listening at the same time. And there is also something about the shorthand symbols that makes [it]_p3630 different from writing. [I]_p3631 am unhappy about [Lucy]_n264 and about [Jonathan]_n265. [I]_p3632 had not heard from Jonathan for some time, and was very concerned but yesterday [dear]_n266 Mr Hawkins, who is always so kind, sent [me]_p3633 a letter from him. [I]_p3634 had written asking [him]_p3635 if [he]_p3636 had heard, and [he]_p3637 said the enclosed had just been received. [It]_p3638 is only a line dated from [Castle Dracula]_n,267 and says that [he]_p3639 is just starting for home. That is not like Jonathan  [I]_p3640 do not understand it, and [it]_p3641 makes [me]_p3643 uneasy.

Then, too, Lucy, although [she]_p3644 is so well, has lately taken to [her]_p3645 old habit of walking in [her]_p3646 sleep. [Her]_p3647 mother has spoken to [me]_p3648 about it, and [we]_p3649 have decided that [I]_p3650 am to lock the door of [our]_p3651 room every night. Mrs Westenra has got an idea that sleep-walkers always go out on roofs of houses and along the edges of cliffs and then get suddenly wakened and fall over with a despairing cry that echoes all over the place. [Poor]_n268 [dear]_n,269 [she]_p3652 is naturally anxious about [Lucy]_n,270 and [she]_p3653 tells [me]_p3654 that [her]_p3655 husband, [Lucy]_n's271 father, had the same habit that [he]_p3656 would get up in the night and dress [himself]_p3658 and go out, if [he]_p3657 were not stopped. [Lucy]_n272 is to be married in the autumn, and [she]_p3659 is already planning out [her]_p3660 dresses and how [her]_p3661 house is to be arranged. [I]_p3662 sympathise with her, for [I]_p3663 do the same, only Jonathan and [I]_p3663 will start in life in a very simple way, and shall have to try to make both ends meet. [Mr Holmwood]_n,273 [he]_p3665 is the [Hon]_n274. [Arthur]_n275 Holmwood, only son of [Lord]_n276 [Godalming]_n,277 is coming up here very shortly, as soon as [he]_p3666 can leave town, for [his]_p3668 father is not very well, and [I]_p3669 think [dear]_n278 Lucy is counting the moments till [he]_p3667 comes. [She]_p3670 wants to take [him]_p3671 up to the seat on the churchyard cliff and show [him]_p3672 the beauty of [Whitby]_n279. [I]_p3673 daresay [it]_p3674 is the waiting which disturbs [her]_p3675 [she]_p3676 will be all right when [he]_p3677 arrives.

* * * * *  27 July. , No news from [Jonathan]_n280. [I]_p3678 am getting quite uneasy about him, though why [I]_p3679 should [I]_p3679 do not know but [I]_p3680 do wish that [he]_p3682 would write, if [it]_p3683 were only a single line. Lucy walks more than ever, and each night [I]_p3684 am awakened by [her]_p3685 moving about the room. Fortunately, the weather is so hot that [she]_p3686 cannot get cold but still the anxiety and the perpetually being wakened is beginning to tell on me, and [I]_p3687 am getting nervous and wakeful myself. Thank God, [Lucy]_n's281 health keeps up. Mr Holmwood has been suddenly called to Ring to see [his]_p3688 father, who has been taken seriously ill. Lucy frets at the postponement of seeing him, but [it]_p3689 does not touch [her]_p3690 looks [she]_p3692 is a trifle stouter, and [her]_p3691 cheeks are a lovely rose-pink. [She]_p3693 has lost that an mic look which [she]_p3694 had. [I]_p3695 pray [it]_p3696 will all last.

* * * * *  3 August. , Another week gone, and no news from Jonathan, not even to Mr Hawkins, from whom [I]_p3697 have heard. Oh, [I]_p3698 do hope [he]_p3699 is not ill. [He]_p3700 surely would have written. [I]_p3701 look at that last letter of his, but somehow [it]_p3702 does not satisfy me. [It]_p3703 does not read like him, and yet [it]_p3704 is [his]_p3705 writing. There is no mistake of that. Lucy has not walked much in [her]_p3706 sleep the last week, but there is an odd concentration about [her]_p3707 which [I]_p3709 do not understand even in [her]_p3707 sleep [she]_p3710 seems to be watching me. [She]_p3711 tries the door, and finding [it]_p3712 locked, goes about the room searching for the key. 6 August.

, Another three days, and no news. This suspense is getting dreadful. If [I]_p3713 only knew where to write to or where to go to, [I]_p3714 should feel easier but no one has heard a word of [Jonathan]_n282 since that last letter. [I]_p3715 must only pray to God for patience. [Lucy]_n283 is more excitable than ever, but is otherwise well. Last night was very threatening, and the fishermen say that [we]_p3716 are in for a storm. [I]_p3717 must try to watch [it]_p3718 and learn the weather signs. To-day is a grey day, and the sun as [I]_p3719 write is hidden in thick clouds, high over [Kettleness]_n284. Everything is grey, except the green grass, which seems like emerald amongst [it]_p3720 grey earthy rock  grey clouds, tinged with the sunburst at the far edge, hang over the grey sea, into which the sand-points stretch like grey fingers. The sea is tumbling in over the shallows and the sandy flats with a roar, muffled in the sea-mists drifting inland.

The horizon is lost in a grey mist. All is vastness the clouds are piled up like giant rocks, and there is a "brool" over the sea that sounds like some presage of doom. Dark figures are on the beach here and there, sometimes half shrouded in the mist, and seem "men like trees walking. " The fishing-boats are racing for home, and rise and dip in the ground swell as [they]_p3721 sweep into the harbour, bending to the scuppers. Here comes old Mr Swales. [He]_p3722 is making straight for me, and [I]_p3723 can see, by the way [he]_p3724 lifts [his]_p3726 hat, that [he]_p3725 wants to talk. [I]_p3727 have been quite touched by the change in the poor old man. When [he]_p3728 sat down beside me, [he]_p3729 said in a very gentle way:,   "I want to say something to you, miss. " [I]_p3730 could see [he]_p3738 was not at ease, so [I]_p3731 took [his]_p3740 poor old wrinkled hand in mine and asked [him]_p3742 to speak fully so [he]_p3739 said, leaving [his]_p3741 hand in mine:,   "I'm afraid, [my]_p3743 deary, that [I]_p3731 must have shocked [you]_p3744 by all the wicked things I've been sayin' about the dead, and such like, for weeks past  but [I]_p3732 didn't mean them, and [I]_p3732 want [ye]_p3745 to remember that when I'm gone. [We]_p3746 aud folks that be daffled, and with one foot abaft the krok-hooal, don't altogether like to think of it, and [we]_p3750 don't want to feel scart of [it]_p3747  an' that's why I've took to makin' light of it, so that I'd cheer up [my]_p3751 own heart a bit.

But, [Lord]_n285 love ye, miss, [I]_p3752 ain't afraid of dyin', not a bit only [I]_p3753 don't want to die if [I]_p3753 can help it. [My]_p3755 time must be nigh at hand now, for [I]_p3756 be aud, and a hundred years is too much for any man to expect and I'm so nigh [it]_p3758 that the [Aud Man]_n286 is already whettin' [his]_p3759 scythe. Ye see, [I]_p3760 can't get out o' the habit of caffin' about [it]_p3761 all at once the chafts will wag as [they]_p3762 be used to. Some day soon the Angel of Death will sound [his]_p3763 trumpet for me. But don't [ye]_p3764 dooal an' greet, [my]_p3765 deary!", for [he]_p3766 saw that [I]_p3768 was crying, "if [he]_p3767 should come this very night I'd not refuse to answer [his]_p3770 call. For life be, after all, only a waitin' for somethin' else than what we're doin' and death be all that [we]_p3771 can rightly depend on. But I'm content, for it's comin' to me, [my]_p3773 deary, and comin' quick. [It]_p3774 may be comin' while [we]_p3775 be lookin' and wonderin'. Maybe it's in that wind out over the sea that's bringin' with [it]_p3776 loss and wreck, and sore distress, and sad hearts. Look! look!" [he]_p3778 cried suddenly.

"There's something in that wind and in the hoast beyont that sounds, and looks, and tastes, and smells like death. It's in the air [I]_p3779 feel [it]_p3780 comin'. [Lord]_n,287 make [me]_p3781 answer cheerful when [my]_p3782 call comes!" [He]_p3783 held up [his]_p3784 arms devoutly, and raised [his]_p3785 hat. [His]_p3786 mouth moved as though [he]_p3787 were praying. After a few minutes' silence, [he]_p3788 got up, shook hands with me, and blessed me, and said good-bye, and hobbled off. [It]_p3789 all touched me, and upset [me]_p3790 very much. [I]_p3792 was glad when the coastguard came along, with [his]_p3793 spy-glass under [his]_p3794 arm. [He]_p3795 stopped to talk with me, as [he]_p3796 always does, but all the time kept looking at a strange ship. "I can't make [her]_p3797 out," [he]_p3799 said "she's a Russian, by the look of [her]_p3798  but she's knocking about in the queerest way. [She]_p3800 doesn't know [her]_p3801 mind a bit [she]_p3802 seems to see the storm coming, but can't decide whether to run up north in the open, or to put in here.

Look there again! [She]_p3803 is steered mighty strangely, for [she]_p3804 doesn't mind the hand on the wheel  changes about with every puff of wind. We'll hear more of [her]_p3805 before this time [to-morrow]_n288. " CHAPTER VII CUTTING FROM "THE DAILYGRAPH," 8 AUGUST (Pasted in [Mina Murray]_n's289 [Journal]_n290. )  From a Correspondent. [Whitby]_n291. One of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been experienced here, with results both strange and unique. The weather had been somewhat sultry, but not to any degree uncommon in the month of August. Saturday evening was as fine as was ever known, and the great body of holiday-makers laid out yesterday for visits to [Mulgrave]_n292 Woods, Robin Hood's Bay, Rig Mill, Runswick, Staithes, and the various trips in the neighbourhood of Whitby. The steamers Emma and Scarborough made trips up and down the coast, and there was an unusual amount of "tripping" both to and from [Whitby]_n293. The day was unusually fine till the afternoon, when some of the gossips who frequent the [East Cliff]_n294 churchyard, and from that commanding eminence watch the wide sweep of sea visible to the north and east, called attention to a sudden show of "mares'-tails" high in the sky to the north-west.

The wind was then blowing from the south-west in the mild degree which in barometrical language is ranked "No. 2: light breeze. " The coastguard on duty at once made report, and one old fisherman, who for more than half a century has kept watch on weather signs from the [East Cliff]_n,295 foretold in an emphatic manner the coming of a sudden storm. The approach of sunset was so very beautiful, so grand in [its]_p3806 masses of splendidly-coloured clouds, that there was quite an assemblage on the walk along the cliff in the old churchyard to enjoy the beauty. Before the sun dipped below the black mass of [Kettleness]_n,296 standing boldly athwart the western sky, [its]_p3807 downward way was marked by myriad clouds of every sunset-colour, flame, purple, pink, green, violet, and all the tints of gold with here and there masses not large, but of seemingly absolute blackness, in all sorts of shapes, as well outlined as colossal silhouettes. The experience was not lost on the painters, and doubtless some of the sketches of the "Prelude to the Great Storm" will grace the R. A. and R. I. walls in May next.

More than one captain made up [his]_p3808 mind then and there that [his]_p3809 "cobble" or [his]_p3809 "mule," as [they]_p3811 term the different classes of boats, would remain in the harbour till the storm had passed. The wind fell away entirely during the evening, and at midnight there was a dead calm, a sultry heat, and that prevailing intensity which, on the approach of thunder, affects persons of a sensitive nature. There were but few lights in sight at sea, for even the coasting steamers, which usually "hug" the shore so closely, kept well to seaward, and but few fishing-boats were in sight. The only sail noticeable was a foreign schooner with all sails set, which was seemingly going westwards. The foolhardiness or ignorance of [her]_p3812 officers was a prolific theme for comment whilst [she]_p3815 remained in sight, and efforts were made to signal [her]_p3813 to reduce sail in face of [her]_p3813 danger. Before the night shut down [she]_p3816 was seen with sails idly flapping as [she]_p3817 gently rolled on the undulating swell of the sea,  "As idle as a painted ship upon a painted ocean. "  Shortly before ten o'clock the stillness of the air grew quite oppressive, and the silence was so marked that the bleating of a sheep inland or the barking of a dog in the town was distinctly heard, and the band on the pier, with [its]_p3818 lively French air, was like a discord in the great harmony of nature's silence. A little after midnight came a strange sound from over the sea, and high overhead the air began to carry a strange, faint, hollow booming. Then without warning the tempest broke. With a rapidity which, at the time, seemed incredible, and even afterwards is impossible to realize, the whole aspect of nature at once became convulsed.

The waves rose in growing fury, each overtopping [its]_p3819 fellow, till in a very few minutes the lately glassy sea was like a roaring and devouring monster. [White]_n-crested297 waves beat madly on the level sands and rushed up the shelving cliffs others broke over the piers, and with [their]_p3820 spume swept the lanthorns of the lighthouses which rise from the end of either pier of Whitby Harbour. The wind roared like thunder, and blew with such force that [it]_p3821 was with difficulty that even strong men kept [their]_p3822 feet, or clung with grim clasp to the iron stanchions. [It]_p3823 was found necessary to clear the entire piers from the mass of onlookers, or else the fatalities of the night would have been increased manifold. To add to the difficulties and dangers of the time, masses of sea-fog came drifting inland, white, wet clouds, which swept by in ghostly fashion, so dank and damp and cold that [it]_p3824 needed but little effort of imagination to think that the spirits of those lost at sea were touching [their]_p3825 living brethren with the clammy hands of death, and many a one shuddered as the wreaths of sea-mist swept by. At times the mist cleared, and the sea for some distance could be seen in the glare of the lightning, which now came thick and fast, followed by such sudden peals of thunder that the whole sky overhead seemed trembling under the shock of the footsteps of the storm. Some of the scenes thus revealed were of immeasurable grandeur and of absorbing interest, the sea, running mountains high, threw skywards with each wave mighty masses of white foam, which the tempest seemed to snatch at and whirl away into space here and there a fishing-boat, with a rag of sail, running madly for shelter before the blast now and again the white wings of a storm-tossed sea-bird. On the summit of the [East Cliff]_n298 the new searchlight was ready for experiment, but had not yet been tried. The officers in charge of [it]_p3826 got [it]_p3827 into working order, and in the pauses of the inrushing mist swept with [it]_p3827 the surface of the sea. Once or twice [its]_p3829 service was most effective, as when a fishing-boat, with gunwale under water, rushed into the harbour, able, by the guidance of the sheltering light, to avoid the danger of dashing against the piers.

As each boat achieved the safety of the port there was a shout of joy from the mass of people on shore, a shout which for a moment seemed to cleave the gale and was then swept away in [its]_p3830 rush. Before long the searchlight discovered some distance away a schooner with all sails set, apparently the same vessel which had been noticed earlier in the evening. The wind had by this time backed to the east, and there was a shudder amongst the watchers on the cliff as [they]_p3831 realized the terrible danger in which [she]_p3832 now was. Between [her]_p3833 and the port lay the great flat reef on which so many good ships have from time to time suffered, and, with the wind blowing from [its]_p3834 present quarter, [it]_p3835 would be quite impossible that [she]_p3836 should fetch the entrance of the harbour. [It]_p3837 was now nearly the hour of high tide, but the waves were so great that in [their]_p3838 troughs the shallows of the shore were almost visible, and the schooner, with all sails set, was rushing with such speed that, in the words of one old salt, "she must fetch up somewhere, if [it]_p3839 was only in hell. " Then came another rush of sea-fog, greater than any hitherto, a mass of dank mist, which seemed to close on all things like a grey pall, and left available to men only the organ of hearing, for the roar of the tempest, and the crash of the thunder, and the booming of the mighty billows came through the damp oblivion even louder than before. The rays of the searchlight were kept fixed on the harbour mouth across the [East]_n299 Pier, where the shock was expected, and men waited breathless. The wind suddenly shifted to the north-east, and the remnant of the sea-fog melted in the blast and then, mirabile dictu, between the piers, leaping from wave to wave as [it]_p3840 rushed at headlong speed, swept the strange schooner before the blast, with all sail set, and gained the safety of the harbour. The searchlight followed her, and a shudder ran through all who saw her, for lashed to the helm was a corpse, with drooping head, which swung horribly to and fro at each motion of the ship. No other form could be seen on deck at all.

A great awe came on all as [they]_p3841 realised that the ship, as if by a miracle, had found the harbour, unsteered save by the hand of a dead man! However, all took place more quickly than [it]_p3842 takes to write these words. The schooner paused not, but rushing across the harbour, pitched [herself]_p3843 on that accumulation of sand and gravel washed by many tides and many storms into the south-east corner of the pier jutting under the [East Cliff]_n,300 known locally as Tate [Hill]_n301 [Pier]_n302. There was of course a considerable concussion as the vessel drove up on the sand heap. Every spar, rope, and stay was strained, and some of the "top-hammer" came crashing down. But, strangest of all, the very instant the shore was touched, an immense dog sprang up on deck from below, as if shot up by the concussion, and running forward, jumped from the bow on the sand. Making straight for the steep cliff, where the churchyard hangs over the laneway to the [East]_n303 Pier so steeply that some of the flat tombstones, "thruff-steans" or "through-stones," as [they]_p3844 call [them]_p3845 in the Whitby vernacular, actually project over where the sustaining cliff has fallen away, [it]_p3846 disappeared in the darkness, which seemed intensified just beyond the focus of the searchlight. [It]_p3847 so happened that there was no one at the moment on Tate Hill Pier, as all those whose houses are in close proximity were either in bed or were out on the heights above. Thus the coastguard on duty on the eastern side of the harbour, who at once ran down to the little pier, was the first to climb on board. The men working the searchlight, after scouring the entrance of the harbour without seeing anything, then turned the light on the derelict and kept [it]_p3848 there. The coastguard ran aft, and when [he]_p3849 came beside the wheel, bent over to examine it, and recoiled at once as though under some sudden emotion.

This seemed to pique general curiosity, and quite a number of people began to run. [It]_p3850 is a good way round from the West [Cliff]_n304 by the [Drawbridge]_n305 to Tate Hill Pier, but [your]_p3851 correspondent is a fairly good runner, and came well ahead of the crowd. When [I]_p3852 arrived, however, [I]_p3853 found already assembled on the pier a crowd, whom the coastguard and police refused to allow to come on board. By the courtesy of the chief boatman, [I]_p3854 was, as [your]_p3855 correspondent, permitted to climb on deck, and was one of a small group who saw the dead seaman whilst actually lashed to the wheel. [It]_p3856 was no wonder that the coastguard was surprised, or even awed, for not often can such a sight have been seen. The man was simply fastened by [his]_p3857 hands, tied one over the other, to a spoke of the wheel. Between the inner hand and the wood was a crucifix, the set of beads on which [it]_p3858 was fastened being around both wrists and wheel, and all kept fast by the binding cords. The poor fellow may have been seated at one time, but the flapping and buffeting of the sails had worked through the rudder of the wheel and dragged [him]_p3859 to and fro, so that the cords with which [he]_p3860 was tied had cut the flesh to the bone. Accurate note was made of the state of things, and a doctor, [Surgeon J]_n306. M.

Caffyn, of 33, [East Elliot Place]_n,307 who came immediately after me, declared, after making examination, that the man must have been dead for quite two days. In [his]_p3861 pocket was a bottle, carefully corked, empty save for a little roll of paper, which proved to be the addendum to the log. The coastguard said the man must have tied up [his]_p3862 own hands, fastening the knots with [his]_p3863 teeth. The fact that a coastguard was the first on board may save some complications, later on, in the Admiralty Court for coastguards cannot claim the salvage which is the right of the first civilian entering on a derelict. Already, however, the legal tongues are wagging, and one [young]_n308 law student is loudly asserting that the rights of the owner are already completely sacrificed, [his]_p3864 property being held in contravention of the statutes of mortmain, since the tiller, as emblemship, if not proof, of delegated possession, is held in a dead hand. [It]_p3865 is needless to say that the dead steersman has been reverently removed from the place where [he]_p3866 held [his]_p3867 honourable watch and ward till death, a steadfastness as noble as that of the [young]_n309 Casabianca, and placed in the mortuary to await inquest. Already the sudden storm is passing, and [its]_p3868 fierceness is abating  crowds are scattering homeward, and the sky is beginning to redden over the Yorkshire wolds. [I]_p3869 shall send, in time for [your]_p3870 next issue, further details of the derelict ship which found [her]_p3871 way so miraculously into harbour in the storm. [Whitby]_n310 9 August. , The sequel to the strange arrival of the derelict in the storm last night is almost more startling than the thing itself.

[It]_p3872 turns out that the schooner is a Russian from [Varna]_n,311 and is called the Demeter. [She]_p3873 is almost entirely in ballast of silver sand, with only a small amount of cargo, a number of great wooden boxes filled with mould. This cargo was consigned to a [Whitby]_n312 solicitor, [Mr S]_n313. F. [Billington]_n,314 of 7, The Crescent, who this morning went aboard and formally took possession of the goods consigned to him. The Russian consul, too, acting for the charter-party, took formal possession of the ship, and paid all harbour dues, etc. Nothing is talked about here to-day except the strange coincidence the officials of the Board of Trade have been most exacting in seeing that every compliance has been made with existing regulations. As the matter is to be a "nine days' wonder," [they]_p3874 are evidently determined that there shall be no cause of after complaint. A good deal of interest was abroad concerning the dog which landed when the ship struck, and more than a few of the members of the S. P.

C. A. , which is very strong in Whitby, have tried to befriend the animal. To the general disappointment, however, [it]_p3875 was not to be found  [it]_p3876 seems to have disappeared entirely from the town. [It]_p3877 may be that [it]_p3878 was frightened and made [its]_p3880 way on to the moors, where [it]_p3879 is still hiding in terror. There are some who look with dread on such a possibility, lest later on [it]_p3881 should in [itself]_p3883 become a danger, for [it]_p3882 is evidently a fierce brute. Early this morning a large dog, a half-bred mastiff belonging to a coal merchant close to Tate [Hill]_n315 [Pier]_n,316 was found dead in the roadway opposite to [its]_p3884 master's yard. [It]_p3885 had been fighting, and manifestly had had a savage opponent, for [its]_p3886 throat was torn away, and [its]_p3887 belly was slit open as if with a savage claw. * * * * *  Later. , By the kindness of the Board of Trade inspector, [I]_p3888 have been permitted to look over the log-book of the Demeter, which was in order up to within three days, but contained nothing of special interest except as to facts of missing men.

The greatest interest, however, is with regard to the paper found in the bottle, which was to-day produced at the inquest and a more strange narrative than the two between [them]_p3889 unfold [it]_p3890 has not been [my]_p3891 lot to come across. As there is no motive for concealment, [I]_p3892 am permitted to use them, and accordingly send [you]_p3893 a rescript, simply omitting technical details of seamanship and supercargo. [It]_p3894 almost seems as though the captain had been seized with some kind of mania before [he]_p3895 had got well into blue water, and that this had developed persistently throughout the voyage. Of course [my]_p3896 statement must be taken cum grano, since [I]_p3897 am writing from the dictation of a clerk of the Russian consul, who kindly translated for me, time being short. LOG OF THE "DEMETER. " [Varna]_n317 to [Whitby]_n318. Written 18 July, things so strange happening, that [I]_p3898 shall keep accurate note henceforth till [we]_p3899 land. * * * * *  On 6 July [we]_p3900 finished taking in cargo, silver sand and boxes of earth. At noon set sail. [East]_n319 wind, fresh.

Crew, five hands. two mates, cook, and [myself]_p3901 (captain). * * * * *  On 11 July at dawn entered Bosphorus. Boarded by Turkish Customs officers. Backsheesh. All correct. Under way at 4 p. m. * * * * *  On 12 July through Dardanelles. More Customs officers and flagboat of guarding squadron.

Backsheesh again. Work of officers thorough, but quick. Want [us]_p3902 off soon. At dark passed into Archipelago. * * * * * On 13 July passed [Cape Matapan]_n320. Crew dissatisfied about something. Seemed scared, but would not speak out. * * * * *  On 14 July was somewhat anxious about crew. Men all steady fellows, who sailed with [me]_p3903 before. Mate could not make out what was wrong [they]_p3904 only told [him]_p3905 there was something, and crossed themselves.

Mate lost temper with one of [them]_p3906 that day and struck him. Expected fierce quarrel, but all was quiet. * * * * * On 16 July mate reported in the morning that one of crew, [Petrofsky]_n,321 was missing. Could not account for it. Took larboard watch eight bells last night was relieved by Abramoff, but did not go to bunk. Men more downcast than ever. All said [they]_p3907 expected something of the kind, but would not say more than there was something aboard. Mate getting very impatient with [them]_p3908 feared some trouble ahead. * * * * *  On 17 July, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to [my]_p3909 cabin, and in an awestruck way confided to [me]_p3910 that [he]_p3911 thought there was a strange man aboard the ship. [He]_p3912 said that in [his]_p3913 watch [he]_p3914 had been sheltering behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when [he]_p3915 saw a tall, thin man, who was not like any of the crew, come up the companion-way, and go along the deck forward, and disappear.

[He]_p3916 followed cautiously, but when [he]_p3917 got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed. [He]_p3918 was in a panic of superstitious fear, and [I]_p3919 am afraid the panic may spread. To allay it, [I]_p3920 shall to-day search entire ship carefully from stem to stern. * * * * *  Later in the day [I]_p3921 got together the whole crew, and told them, as [they]_p3922 evidently thought there was some one in the ship, [we]_p3923 would search from stem to stern. First mate angry said [it]_p3924 was folly, and to yield to such foolish ideas would demoralise the men said [he]_p3925 would engage to keep [them]_p3926 out of trouble with a handspike. [I]_p3927 let [him]_p3928 take the helm, while the rest began thorough search, all keeping abreast, with lanterns: [we]_p3929 left no corner unsearched. As there were only the big wooden boxes, there were no odd corners where a man could hide. Men much relieved when search over, and went back to work cheerfully. First mate scowled, but said nothing. * * * * *  22 July.

, Rough weather last three days, and all hands busy with sails, no time to be frightened. Men seem to have forgotten [their]_p3930 dread. Mate cheerful again, and all on good terms. Praised men for work in bad weather. Passed Gibralter and out through Straits. All well. * * * * *  24 July. , There seems some doom over this ship. Already a hand short, and entering on the [Bay]_n322 of [Biscay]_n323 with wild weather ahead, and yet last night another man lost, disappeared. Like the first, [he]_p3931 came off [his]_p3932 watch and was not seen again.

Men all in a panic of fear sent a round robin, asking to have double watch, as [they]_p3933 fear to be alone. Mate angry. Fear there will be some trouble, as either [he]_p3934 or the men will do some violence. * * * * *  28 July. , [Four]_n324 days in hell, knocking about in a sort of maelstrom, and the wind a tempest. No sleep for any one. Men all worn out. Hardly know how to set a watch, since no one fit to go on. Second mate volunteered to steer and watch, and let men snatch a few hours' sleep. [Wind]_n325 abating seas still terrific, but feel [them]_p3935 less, as ship is steadier.

* * * * *  29 July. , Another tragedy. Had single watch [to-night]_n,326 as crew too tired to double. When morning watch came on deck could find no one except steersman. Raised outcry, and all came on deck. Thorough search, but no one found. Are now without second mate, and crew in a panic. Mate and [I]_p3936 agreed to go armed henceforth and wait for any sign of cause. * * * * *  30 July. , Last night.

Rejoiced [we]_p3937 are nearing England. Weather fine, all sails set. Retired worn out slept soundly awaked by mate telling [me]_p3938 that both man of watch and steersman missing. Only self and mate and two hands left to work ship. * * * * *  1 August. , Two days of fog, and not a sail sighted. Had hoped when in the [English Channel]_n327 to be able to signal for help or get in somewhere. Not having power to work sails, have to run before wind. Dare not lower, as could not raise [them]_p3939 again. [We]_p3940 seem to be drifting to some terrible doom.

Mate now more demoralised than either of men. [His]_p3941 stronger nature seems to have worked inwardly against himself. Men are beyond fear, working stolidly and patiently, with minds made up to worst. [They]_p3942 are Russian, [he]_p3943 Roumanian. * * * * *  2 August, midnight. , Woke up from few minutes' sleep by hearing a cry, seemingly outside [my]_p3944 port. Could see nothing in fog. Rushed on deck, and ran against mate. Tells [me]_p3945 heard cry and ran, but no sign of man on watch. One more gone.

Lord, help us! Mate says [we]_p3946 must be past Straits of Dover, as in a moment of fog lifting [he]_p3947 saw North Foreland, just as [he]_p3948 heard the man cry out. If so [we]_p3949 are now off in the [North Sea]_n,328 and only God can guide [us]_p3950 in the fog, which seems to move with [us]_p3951 and God seems to have deserted us. * * * * *  3 August. , At midnight [I]_p3953 went to relieve the man at the wheel, and when [I]_p3954 got to [it]_p3955 found no one there. The wind was steady, and as [we]_p3956 ran before [it]_p3957 there was no yawing. [I]_p3958 dared not leave it, so shouted for the mate. After a few seconds [he]_p3959 rushed up on deck in [his]_p3960 flannels. [He]_p3961 looked wild-eyed and haggard, and [I]_p3962 greatly fear [his]_p3963 reason has given way. [He]_p3964 came close to [me]_p3965 and whispered hoarsely, with [his]_p3966 mouth to [my]_p3967 ear, as though fearing the very air might hear: "It is here [I]_p3968 know it, now. On the watch last night [I]_p3969 saw It, like a man, tall and thin, and ghastly pale.

[It]_p3970 was in the bows, and looking out. [I]_p3971 crept behind It, and gave [It]_p3972 [my]_p3975 knife but the knife went through It, empty as the air. " And as [he]_p3976 spoke [he]_p3977 took [his]_p3978 knife and drove [it]_p3979 savagely into space. Then [he]_p3980 went on: "But [It]_p3981 is here, and I'll find It. [It]_p3983 is in the hold, perhaps in one of those boxes. I'll unscrew [them]_p3984 one by one and see. [You]_p3985 work the helm. " And, with a warning look and [his]_p3986 finger on [his]_p3987 lip, [he]_p3988 went below. There was springing up a choppy wind, and [I]_p3989 could not leave the helm. [I]_p3990 saw [him]_p3991 come out on deck again with a tool-chest and a lantern, and go down the forward hatchway.

[He]_p3992 is mad, stark, raving mad, and it's no use [my]_p3993 trying to stop him. [He]_p3994 can't hurt those big boxes: [they]_p3995 are invoiced as "clay," and to pull [them]_p3996 about is as harmless a thing as [he]_p3997 can do. So here [I]_p3998 stay, and mind the helm, and write these notes. [I]_p3999 can only trust in God and wait till the fog clears. Then, if [I]_p4000 can't steer to any harbour with the wind that is, [I]_p4001 shall cut down sails and lie by, and signal for help. * * * * *  [It]_p4002 is nearly all over now. Just as [I]_p4003 was beginning to hope that the mate would come out calmer, for [I]_p4004 heard [him]_p4005 knocking away at something in the hold, and work is good for him, there came up the hatchway a sudden, startled scream, which made [my]_p4007 blood run cold, and up on the deck [he]_p4008 came as if shot from a gun, a raging madman, with [his]_p4009 eyes rolling and [his]_p4010 face convulsed with fear. "Save me! save me!" [he]_p4011 cried, and then looked round on the blanket of fog. [His]_p4012 horror turned to despair, and in a steady voice [he]_p4013 said: "You had better come too, captain, before [it]_p4014 is too late. [He]_p4015 is there.

[I]_p4016 know the secret now. The sea will save [me]_p4017 from [Him]_n,329 and [it]_p4018 is all that is left!" Before [I]_p4019 could say a word, or move forward to seize him, [he]_p4020 sprang on the bulwark and deliberately threw [himself]_p4021 into the sea. [I]_p4022 suppose [I]_p4023 know the secret too, now. [It]_p4024 was this madman who had got rid of the men one by one, and now [he]_p4025 has followed [them]_p4026 himself. God help me! How am [I]_p4027 to account for all these horrors when [I]_p4028 get to port? When [I]_p4028 get to port! Will that ever be?  * * * * *  4 August. , Still fog, which the sunrise cannot pierce. [I]_p4030 know there is sunrise because [I]_p4031 am a sailor, why else [I]_p4031 know not. [I]_p4033 dared not go below, [I]_p4034 dared not leave the helm so here all night [I]_p4034 stayed, and in the dimness of the night [I]_p4035 saw It, [Him]_n!330 God forgive me, but the mate was right to jump overboard. [It]_p4037 was better to die like a man to die like a sailor in blue water no man can object. But [I]_p4038 am captain, and [I]_p4039 must not leave [my]_p4040 ship.

But [I]_p4041 shall baffle this fiend or monster, for [I]_p4042 shall tie [my]_p4045 hands to the wheel when [my]_p4046 strength begins to fail, and along with [them]_p4049 [I]_p4042 shall tie that which He, It!, dare not touch and then, come good wind or foul, [I]_p4043 shall save [my]_p4046 soul, and [my]_p4047 honour as a captain. [I]_p4050 am growing weaker, and the night is coming on. If [He]_p4051 can look [me]_p4052 in the face again, [I]_p4053 may not have time to act. If [we]_p4054 are wrecked, mayhap this bottle may be found, and those who find [it]_p4055 may understand if not,. well, then all men shall know that [I]_p4056 have been true to [my]_p4057 trust. God and the Blessed Virgin and the saints help a poor ignorant soul trying to do [his]_p4058 duty. * * * * *  Of course the verdict was an open one. There is no evidence to adduce  and whether or not the man [himself]_p4059 committed the murders there is now none to say. The folk here hold almost universally that the captain is simply a hero, and [he]_p4060 is to be given a public funeral. Already [it]_p4061 is arranged that [his]_p4062 body is to be taken with a train of boats up the Esk for a piece and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and up the abbey steps for [he]_p4063 is to be buried in the churchyard on the cliff.

The owners of more than a hundred boats have already given in [their]_p4064 names as wishing to follow [him]_p4065 to the grave. No trace has ever been found of the great dog at which there is much mourning, for, with public opinion in [its]_p4066 present state, [he]_p4067 would, [I]_p4068 believe, be adopted by the town. To-morrow will see the funeral and so will end this one more "mystery of the sea. " [Mina Murray]_n's331 [Journal]_n332. 8 August. , [Lucy]_n333 was very restless all night, and I, too, could not sleep. The storm was fearful, and as [it]_p4069 boomed loudly among the chimney-pots, [it]_p4070 made [me]_p4071 shudder. When a sharp puff came [it]_p4072 seemed to be like a distant gun. Strangely enough, Lucy did not wake but [she]_p4073 got up twice and dressed herself. Fortunately, each time [I]_p4074 awoke in time and managed to undress [her]_p4075 without waking her, and got [her]_p4076 back to bed.

[It]_p4078 is a very strange thing, this sleep-walking, for as soon as [her]_p4079 will is thwarted in any physical way, [her]_p4080 intention, if there be any, disappears, and [she]_p4082 yields [herself]_p4083 almost exactly to the routine of [her]_p4080 life. Early in the morning [we]_p4084 both got up and went down to the harbour to see if anything had happened in the night. There were very few people about, and though the sun was bright, and the air clear and fresh, the big, grim-looking waves, that seemed dark [themselves]_p4085 because the foam that topped [them]_p4087 was like snow, forced [themselves]_p4086 in through the narrow mouth of the harbour, like a bullying man going through a crowd. Somehow [I]_p4088 felt glad that [Jonathan]_n334 was not on the sea last night, but on land. But, oh, is [he]_p4089 on land or sea? Where is he, and how? [I]_p4091 am getting fearfully anxious about him. If [I]_p4092 only knew what to do, and could do anything!  * * * * *  10 August. , The funeral of the poor sea-captain to-day was most touching. Every boat in the harbour seemed to be there, and the coffin was carried by captains all the way from [Tate Hill Pier]_n335 up to the churchyard. Lucy came with me, and [we]_p4093 went early to [our]_p4094 old seat, whilst the cort ge of boats went up the river to the Viaduct and came down again. [We]_p4095 had a lovely view, and saw the procession nearly all the way.

The poor fellow was laid to rest quite near [our]_p4096 seat so that [we]_p4097 stood on [it]_p4098 when the time came and saw everything. [Poor Lucy]_n336 seemed much upset. [She]_p4099 was restless and uneasy all the time, and [I]_p4100 cannot but think that [her]_p4101 dreaming at night is telling on her. [She]_p4103 is quite odd in one thing: [she]_p4104 will not admit to [me]_p4106 that there is any cause for restlessness or if there be, [she]_p4105 does not understand [it]_p4107 herself. There is an additional cause in that poor old Mr Swales was found dead this morning on [our]_p4108 seat, [his]_p4109 neck being broken. [He]_p4110 had evidently, as the doctor said, fallen back in the seat in some sort of fright, for there was a look of fear and horror on [his]_p4111 face that the men said made [them]_p4112 shudder. [Poor]_n337 [dear]_n338 old man! Perhaps [he]_p4113 had seen Death with [his]_p4114 dying eyes! Lucy is so sweet and sensitive that [she]_p4115 feels influences more acutely than other people do. Just now [she]_p4116 was quite upset by a little thing which [I]_p4117 did not much heed, though [I]_p4118 am [myself]_p4119 very fond of animals. One of the men who came up here often to look for the boats was followed by [his]_p4120 dog. The dog is always with him.

[They]_p4121 are both quiet persons, and [I]_p4122 never saw the man angry, nor heard the dog bark. During the service the dog would not come to [its]_p4123 master, who was on the seat with us, but kept a few yards off, barking and howling. [Its]_p4124 master spoke to [it]_p4125 gently, and then harshly, and then angrily but [it]_p4126 would neither come nor cease to make a noise. [It]_p4127 was in a sort of fury, with [its]_p4128 eyes savage, and all [its]_p4129 hairs bristling out like a cat's tail when puss is on the war-path. Finally the man, too, got angry, and jumped down and kicked the dog, and then took [it]_p4130 by the scruff of the neck and half dragged and half threw [it]_p4131 on the tombstone on which the seat is fixed. The moment [it]_p4132 touched the stone the poor thing became quiet and fell all into a tremble. [It]_p4133 did not try to get away, but crouched down, quivering and cowering, and was in such a pitiable state of terror that [I]_p4134 tried, though without effect, to comfort it. [Lucy]_n339 was full of pity, too, but [she]_p4135 did not attempt to touch the dog, but looked at [it]_p4136 in an agonised sort of way. [I]_p4137 greatly fear that [she]_p4138 is of too super-sensitive a nature to go through the world without trouble. [She]_p4139 will be dreaming of this [to-night]_n,340 [I]_p4140 am sure.

The whole agglomeration of things, the ship steered into port by a dead man [his]_p4141 attitude, tied to the wheel with a crucifix and beads the touching funeral the dog, now furious and now in terror, will all afford material for [her]_p4142 dreams. [I]_p4143 think [it]_p4145 will be best for [her]_p4146 to go to bed tired out physically, so [I]_p4144 shall take [her]_p4147 for a long walk by the cliffs to [Robin Hood]_n's341 [Bay]_n342 and back. [She]_p4148 ought not to have much inclination for sleep-walking then. CHAPTER VIII  MINA MURRAY'S JOURNAL   Same day, 11 o'clock p. m. , Oh, but [I]_p4149 am tired! If [it]_p4152 were not that [I]_p4150 had made [my]_p4154 diary a duty [I]_p4150 should not open [it]_p4153 [to-night]_n343. [We]_p4155 had a lovely walk. Lucy, after a while, was in gay spirits, owing, [I]_p4156 think, to some [dear]_n344 cows who came nosing towards [us]_p4157 in a field close to the lighthouse, and frightened the wits out of us. [I]_p4159 believe [we]_p4160 forgot everything except, of course, personal fear, and [it]_p4161 seemed to wipe the slate clean and give [us]_p4162 a fresh start. [We]_p4163 had a capital "severe tea" at [Robin Hood]_n's345 [Bay]_n346 in a sweet little old-fashioned inn, with a bow-window right over the seaweed-covered rocks of the strand.

[I]_p4164 believe [we]_p4165 should have shocked the "[New Woman]_n"347 with [our]_p4166 appetites. Men are more tolerant, bless them! Then [we]_p4167 walked home with some, or rather many, stoppages to rest, and with [our]_p4168 hearts full of a constant dread of wild bulls. Lucy was really tired, and [we]_p4169 intended to creep off to bed as soon as [we]_p4170 could. The [young]_n348 curate came in, however, and Mrs Westenra asked [him]_p4171 to stay for supper. [Lucy]_n349 and [I]_p4172 had both a fight for [it]_p4175 with the dusty miller [I]_p4173 know [it]_p4176 was a hard fight on [my]_p4177 part, and [I]_p4173 am quite heroic. [I]_p4178 think that some day the bishops must get together and see about breeding up a new class of curates, who don't take supper, no matter how [they]_p4179 may be pressed to, and who will know when girls are tired. [Lucy]_n350 is asleep and breathing softly. [She]_p4180 has more colour in [her]_p4181 cheeks than usual, and looks, oh, so sweet. If [Mr Holmwood]_n351 fell in love with [her]_p4182 seeing [her]_p4183 only in the drawing-room, [I]_p4185 wonder what [he]_p4186 would say if [he]_p4187 saw [her]_p4183 now. Some of the "[New Women]_n"352 writers will some day start an idea that men and women should be allowed to see each other asleep before proposing or accepting.

But [I]_p4188 suppose the New Woman won't condescend in future to accept [she]_p4189 will do the proposing herself. And a nice job [she]_p4190 will make of it, too! There's some consolation in that. [I]_p4191 am so happy [to-night]_n,353 because [dear]_n354 [Lucy]_n355 seems better. [I]_p4192 really believe [she]_p4193 has turned the corner, and that [we]_p4194 are over [her]_p4195 troubles with dreaming. [I]_p4196 should be quite happy if [I]_p4197 only knew if [Jonathan]_n356. God bless and keep him. * * * * *  11 August, 3 a. m. , [Diary]_n357 again. No sleep now, so [I]_p4198 may as well write.

[I]_p4199 am too agitated to sleep. [We]_p4200 have had such an adventure, such an agonising experience. [I]_p4201 fell asleep as soon as [I]_p4202 had closed [my]_p4203 diary. Suddenly [I]_p4204 became broad awake, and sat up, with a horrible sense of fear upon me, and of some feeling of emptiness around me. The room was dark, so [I]_p4205 could not see [Lucy]_n's358 bed [I]_p4206 stole across and felt for her. The bed was empty. [I]_p4207 lit a match and found that [she]_p4208 was not in the room. The door was shut, but not locked, as [I]_p4209 had left it. [I]_p4210 feared to wake [her]_p4211 mother, who has been more than usually ill lately, so threw on some clothes and got ready to look for her. As [I]_p4213 was leaving the room [it]_p4214 struck [me]_p4215 that the clothes [she]_p4217 wore might give [me]_p4216 some clue to [her]_p4218 dreaming intention.

Dressing-gown would mean house dress, outside. Dressing-gown and dress were both in [their]_p4219 places. "Thank God," [I]_p4220 said to myself, "she cannot be far, as [she]_p4221 is only in [her]_p4223 nightdress. " [I]_p4224 ran downstairs and looked in the sitting-room. Not there! Then [I]_p4225 looked in all the other open rooms of the house, with an ever-growing fear chilling [my]_p4226 heart. Finally [I]_p4227 came to the hall door and found [it]_p4228 open. [It]_p4229 was not wide open, but the catch of the lock had not caught. The people of the house are careful to lock the door every night, so [I]_p4230 feared that [Lucy]_n359 must have gone out as [she]_p4231 was. There was no time to think of what might happen a vague, overmastering fear obscured all details. [I]_p4232 took a big, heavy shawl and ran out.

The clock was striking one as [I]_p4233 was in the Crescent, and there was not a soul in sight. [I]_p4234 ran along the [North Terrace]_n,360 but could see no sign of the white figure which [I]_p4235 expected. At the edge of the [West Cliff]_n361 above the pier [I]_p4236 looked across the harbour to the [East Cliff]_n,362 in the hope or fear, [I]_p4237 don't know which, of seeing [Lucy]_n363 in [our]_p4238 favourite seat. There was a bright full moon, with heavy black, driving clouds, which threw the whole scene into a fleeting diorama of light and shade as [they]_p4239 sailed across. For a moment or two [I]_p4240 could see nothing, as the shadow of a cloud obscured [St]_n364. Mary's Church and all around it. Then as the cloud passed [I]_p4241 could see the ruins of the abbey coming into view and as the edge of a narrow band of light as sharp as a sword-cut moved along, the church and the churchyard became gradually visible. Whatever [my]_p4242 expectation was, [it]_p4243 was not disappointed, for there, on [our]_p4244 favourite seat, the silver light of the moon struck a half-reclining figure, snowy white. The coming of the cloud was too quick for [me]_p4245 to see much, for shadow shut down on light almost immediately but [it]_p4247 seemed to [me]_p4246 as though something dark stood behind the seat where the white figure shone, and bent over it. What [it]_p4249 was, whether man or beast, [I]_p4250 could not tell [I]_p4251 did not wait to catch another glance, but flew down the steep steps to the pier and along by the fish-market to the bridge, which was the only way to reach the [East Cliff]_n365.

The town seemed as dead, for not a soul did [I]_p4252 see [I]_p4253 rejoiced that [it]_p4255 was so, for [I]_p4253 wanted no witness of [poor Lucy]_n's366 condition. The time and distance seemed endless, and [my]_p4256 knees trembled and [my]_p4257 breath came laboured as [I]_p4258 toiled up the endless steps to the abbey. [I]_p4259 must have gone fast, and yet [it]_p4260 seemed to [me]_p4261 as if [my]_p4262 feet were weighted with lead, and as though every joint in [my]_p4263 body were rusty. When [I]_p4264 got almost to the top [I]_p4265 could see the seat and the white figure, for [I]_p4265 was now close enough to distinguish [it]_p4267 even through the spells of shadow. There was undoubtedly something, long and black, bending over the half-reclining white figure. [I]_p4268 called in fright, "[Lucy]_n!367 [Lucy]_n!"368 and something raised a head, and from where [I]_p4269 was [I]_p4269 could see a white face and red, gleaming eyes. Lucy did not answer, and [I]_p4271 ran on to the entrance of the churchyard. As [I]_p4272 entered, the church was between [me]_p4274 and the seat, and for a minute or so [I]_p4273 lost sight of her. When [I]_p4275 came in view again the cloud had passed, and the moonlight struck so brilliantly that [I]_p4276 could see Lucy half reclining with [her]_p4277 head lying over the back of the seat. [She]_p4278 was quite alone, and there was not a sign of any living thing about.

When [I]_p4279 bent over [her]_p4281 [I]_p4280 could see that [she]_p4282 was still asleep. [Her]_p4283 lips were parted, and [she]_p4284 was breathing, not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get [her]_p4285 lungs full at every breath. As [I]_p4287 came close, [she]_p4288 put up [her]_p4289 hand in [her]_p4290 sleep and pulled the collar of [her]_p4290 nightdress close around [her]_p4291 throat. Whilst [she]_p4293 did so there came a little shudder through her, as though [she]_p4294 felt the cold. [I]_p4295 flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round [her]_p4297 neck, for [I]_p4296 dreaded lest [she]_p4299 should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as [she]_p4300 was. [I]_p4301 feared to wake [her]_p4305 all at once, so, in order to have [my]_p4312 hands free that [I]_p4302 might help her, [I]_p4302 fastened the shawl at [her]_p4306 throat with a big safety-pin but [I]_p4303 must have been clumsy in [my]_p4313 anxiety and pinched or pricked [her]_p4306 with it, for by-and-by, when [her]_p4307 breathing became quieter, [she]_p4314 put [her]_p4307 hand to [her]_p4307 throat again and moaned. When [I]_p4315 had [her]_p4317 carefully wrapped up [I]_p4316 put [my]_p4320 shoes on [her]_p4318 feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first [she]_p4321 did not respond but gradually [she]_p4322 became more and more uneasy in [her]_p4323 sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, [I]_p4324 wished to get [her]_p4326 home at once, [I]_p4325 shook [her]_p4327 more forcibly, till finally [she]_p4329 opened [her]_p4327 eyes and awoke. [She]_p4330 did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, [she]_p4331 did not realise all at once where [she]_p4332 was.

Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when [her]_p4333 body must have been chilled with cold, and [her]_p4334 mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, [she]_p4336 did not lose [her]_p4334 grace. [She]_p4337 trembled a little, and clung to [me]_p4338 when [I]_p4340 told [her]_p4341 to come at once with [me]_p4339 home [she]_p4342 rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As [we]_p4343 passed along, the gravel hurt [my]_p4344 feet, and [Lucy]_n369 noticed [me]_p4345 wince. [She]_p4346 stopped and wanted to insist upon [my]_p4347 taking [my]_p4348 shoes but [I]_p4349 would not. However, when [we]_p4350 got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, [I]_p4353 daubed [my]_p4354 feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as [we]_p4351 went home, no one, in case [we]_p4351 should meet any one, should notice [my]_p4355 bare feet. Fortune favoured us, and [we]_p4356 got home without meeting a soul. Once [we]_p4357 saw a man, who seemed not quite sober, passing along a street in front of [us]_p4359 but [we]_p4358 hid in a door till [he]_p4360 had disappeared up an opening such as there are here, steep little closes, or "wynds," as [they]_p4361 call [them]_p4362 in Scotland. [My]_p4363 heart beat so loud all the time that sometimes [I]_p4364 thought [I]_p4365 should faint. [I]_p4366 was filled with anxiety about [Lucy]_n,370 not only for [her]_p4367 health, lest [she]_p4369 should suffer from the exposure, but for [her]_p4368 reputation in case the story should get wind. When [we]_p4370 got in, and had washed [our]_p4371 feet, and had said a prayer of thankfulness together, [I]_p4372 tucked [her]_p4373 into bed.

Before falling asleep [she]_p4374 asked, even implored, [me]_p4375 not to say a word to any one, even [her]_p4376 mother, about [her]_p4377 sleep-walking adventure. [I]_p4378 hesitated at first to promise but on thinking of the state of [her]_p4380 mother's health, and how the knowledge of such a thing would fret her, and thinking, too, of how such a story might become distorted, nay, infallibly would, in case [it]_p4382 should leak out, [I]_p4379 thought [it]_p4383 wiser to do so. [I]_p4384 hope [I]_p4385 did right. [I]_p4386 have locked the door, and the key is tied to [my]_p4388 wrist, so perhaps [I]_p4387 shall not be again disturbed. [Lucy]_n371 is sleeping soundly the reflex of the dawn is high and far over the sea. * * * * *  Same day, noon. , All goes well. Lucy slept till [I]_p4389 woke [her]_p4390 and seemed not to have even changed [her]_p4391 side. The adventure of the night does not seem to have harmed [her]_p4392 on the contrary, [it]_p4394 has benefited her, for [she]_p4395 looks better this morning than [she]_p4396 has done for weeks. [I]_p4397 was sorry to notice that [my]_p4398 clumsiness with the safety-pin hurt her.

Indeed, [it]_p4399 might have been serious, for the skin of [her]_p4400 throat was pierced. [I]_p4401 must have pinched up a piece of loose skin and have transfixed it, for there are two little red points like pin-pricks, and on the band of [her]_p4402 nightdress was a drop of blood. When [I]_p4403 apologised and was concerned about it, [she]_p4404 laughed and petted me, and said [she]_p4405 did not even feel it. Fortunately [it]_p4406 cannot leave a scar, as [it]_p4407 is so tiny. * * * * *  Same day, night. , [We]_p4408 passed a happy day. The air was clear, and the sun bright, and there was a cool breeze. [We]_p4409 took [our]_p4410 lunch to [Mulgrave]_n372 Woods, Mrs Westenra driving by the road and Lucy and [I]_p4411 walking by the cliff-path and joining [her]_p4412 at the gate. [I]_p4413 felt a little sad myself, for [I]_p4414 could not but feel how absolutely happy [it]_p4415 would have been had Jonathan been with me. But there! [I]_p4416 must only be patient.

In the evening [we]_p4417 strolled in the [Casino Terrace]_n,373 and heard some good music by Spohr and Mackenzie, and went to bed early. Lucy seems more restful than [she]_p4418 has been for some time, and fell asleep at once. [I]_p4419 shall lock the door and secure the key the same as before, though [I]_p4420 do not expect any trouble [to-night]_n374. * * * * *  12 August. , [My]_p4421 expectations were wrong, for twice during the night [I]_p4422 was wakened by Lucy trying to get out. [She]_p4423 seemed, even in [her]_p4424 sleep, to be a little impatient at finding the door shut, and went back to bed under a sort of protest. [I]_p4425 woke with the dawn, and heard the birds chirping outside of the window. Lucy woke, too, and, [I]_p4426 was glad to see, was even better than on the previous morning. All [her]_p4427 old gaiety of manner seemed to have come back, and [she]_p4428 came and snuggled in beside [me]_p4429 and told [me]_p4430 all about [Arthur]_n375. [I]_p4431 told [her]_p4433 how anxious [I]_p4432 was about Jonathan, and then [she]_p4434 tried to comfort me.

Well, [she]_p4435 succeeded somewhat, for, though sympathy can't alter facts, [it]_p4436 can help to make [them]_p4437 more bearable. * * * * *  13 August. , Another quiet day, and to bed with the key on [my]_p4438 wrist as before. Again [I]_p4439 awoke in the night, and found [Lucy]_n376 sitting up in bed, still asleep, pointing to the window. [I]_p4440 got up quietly, and pulling aside the blind, looked out. [It]_p4441 was brilliant moonlight, and the soft effect of the light over the sea and sky, merged together in one great, silent mystery, was beautiful beyond words. Between [me]_p4442 and the moonlight flitted a great bat, coming and going in great whirling circles. Once or twice [it]_p4443 came quite close, but was, [I]_p4444 suppose, frightened at seeing me, and flitted away across the harbour towards the abbey. When [I]_p4445 came back from the window Lucy had lain down again, and was sleeping peacefully. [She]_p4446 did not stir again all night.

* * * * *  14 August. , On the [East Cliff]_n,377 reading and writing all day. Lucy seems to have become as much in love with the spot as [I]_p4447 am, and [it]_p4448 is hard to get [her]_p4451 away from [it]_p4449 when [it]_p4449 is time to come home for lunch or tea or dinner. This afternoon [she]_p4452 made a funny remark. [We]_p4453 were coming home for dinner, and had come to the top of the steps up from the [West Pier]_n378 and stopped to look at the view, as [we]_p4454 generally do. The setting sun, low down in the sky, was just dropping behind [Kettleness]_n379 the red light was thrown over on the [East Cliff]_n380 and the old abbey, and seemed to bathe everything in a beautiful rosy glow. [We]_p4455 were silent for a while, and suddenly Lucy murmured as if to herself:,   "His red eyes again! [They]_p4456 are just the same. " [It]_p4457 was such an odd expression, coming apropos of nothing, that [it]_p4458 quite startled me. [I]_p4459 slewed round a little, so as to see [Lucy]_n381 well without seeming to stare at her, and saw that [she]_p4465 was in a half-dreamy state, with an odd look on [her]_p4462 face that [I]_p4460 could not quite make out so [I]_p4460 said nothing, but followed [her]_p4463 eyes. [She]_p4466 appeared to be looking over at [our]_p4467 own seat, whereon was a dark figure seated alone.

[I]_p4468 was a little startled myself, for [it]_p4469 seemed for an instant as if the stranger had great eyes like burning flames but a second look dispelled the illusion. The red sunlight was shining on the windows of [St]_n382. Mary's Church behind [our]_p4470 seat, and as the sun dipped there was just sufficient change in the refraction and reflection to make [it]_p4471 appear as if the light moved. [I]_p4472 called Lucy's attention to the peculiar effect, and [she]_p4473 became [herself]_p4476 with a start, but [she]_p4474 looked sad all the same [it]_p4477 may have been that [she]_p4474 was thinking of that terrible night up there. [We]_p4478 never refer to [it]_p4479 so [I]_p4480 said nothing, and [we]_p4481 went home to dinner. Lucy had a headache and went early to bed. [I]_p4482 saw [her]_p4485 asleep, and went out for a little stroll [myself]_p4486  [I]_p4483 walked along the cliffs to the westward, and was full of sweet sadness, for [I]_p4483 was thinking of Jonathan. When coming home, [it]_p4487 was then bright moonlight, so bright that, though the front of [our]_p4488 part of the Crescent was in shadow, everything could be well seen, [I]_p4490 threw a glance up at [our]_p4489 window, and saw Lucy's head leaning out. [I]_p4491 thought that perhaps [she]_p4493 was looking out for me, so [I]_p4492 opened [my]_p4494 handkerchief and waved it. [She]_p4495 did not notice or make any movement whatever.

Just then, the moonlight crept round an angle of the building, and the light fell on the window. There distinctly was [Lucy]_n383 with [her]_p4496 head lying up against the side of the window-sill and [her]_p4497 eyes shut. [She]_p4498 was fast asleep, and by her, seated on the window-sill, was something that looked like a good-sized bird. [I]_p4499 was afraid [she]_p4502 might get a chill, so [I]_p4500 ran upstairs, but as [I]_p4500 came into the room [she]_p4503 was moving back to [her]_p4505 bed, fast asleep, and breathing heavily [she]_p4503 was holding [her]_p4506 hand to [her]_p4506 throat, as though to protect [it]_p4508 from cold. [I]_p4509 did not wake her, but tucked [her]_p4511 up warmly [I]_p4510 have taken care that the door is locked and the window securely fastened. [She]_p4513 looks so sweet as [she]_p4514 sleeps but [she]_p4515 is paler than is [her]_p4516 wont, and there is a drawn, haggard look under [her]_p4517 eyes which [I]_p4518 do not like. [I]_p4519 fear [she]_p4520 is fretting about something. [I]_p4521 wish [I]_p4522 could find out what [it]_p4523 is. * * * * *  15 August. , Rose later than usual.

Lucy was languid and tired, and slept on after [we]_p4524 had been called. [We]_p4525 had a happy surprise at breakfast. [Arthur]_n's384 father is better, and wants the marriage to come off soon. [Lucy]_n385 is full of quiet joy, and [her]_p4526 mother is glad and sorry at once. Later on in the day [she]_p4527 told [me]_p4528 the cause. [She]_p4529 is grieved to lose [Lucy]_n386 as [her]_p4530 very own, but [she]_p4532 is rejoiced that [she]_p4533 is soon to have some one to protect her. [Poor]_n387 [dear]_n,388 sweet lady! [She]_p4534 confided to [me]_p4535 that [she]_p4536 has got [her]_p4537 death-warrant. [She]_p4538 has not told Lucy, and made [me]_p4539 promise secrecy  [her]_p4540 doctor told [her]_p4541 that within a few months, at most, [she]_p4543 must die, for [her]_p4541 heart is weakening. At any time, even now, a sudden shock would be almost sure to kill her. Ah, [we]_p4544 were wise to keep from [her]_p4545 the affair of the dreadful night of [Lucy]_n's389 sleep-walking.

* * * * *  17 August. , No diary for two whole days. [I]_p4546 have not had the heart to write. Some sort of shadowy pall seems to be coming over [our]_p4547 happiness. No news from Jonathan, and [Lucy]_n390 seems to be growing weaker, whilst [her]_p4548 mother's hours are numbering to a close. [I]_p4549 do not understand [Lucy]_n's391 fading away as [she]_p4550 is doing. [She]_p4551 eats well and sleeps well, and enjoys the fresh air but all the time the roses in [her]_p4552 cheeks are fading, and [she]_p4554 gets weaker and more languid day by day at night [I]_p4555 hear [her]_p4553 gasping as if for air. [I]_p4556 keep the key of [our]_p4557 door always fastened to [my]_p4558 wrist at night, but [she]_p4559 gets up and walks about the room, and sits at the open window. Last night [I]_p4560 found [her]_p4564 leaning out when [I]_p4561 woke up, and when [I]_p4561 tried to wake [her]_p4565 [I]_p4562 could not [she]_p4566 was in a faint. When [I]_p4567 managed to restore [her]_p4568 [she]_p4569 was as weak as water, and cried silently between long, painful struggles for breath.

When [I]_p4570 asked [her]_p4571 how [she]_p4573 came to be at the window [she]_p4574 shook [her]_p4572 head and turned away. [I]_p4575 trust [her]_p4576 feeling ill may not be from that unlucky prick of the safety-pin. [I]_p4577 looked at [her]_p4578 throat just now as [she]_p4579 lay asleep, and the tiny wounds seem not to have healed. [They]_p4580 are still open, and, if anything, larger than before, and the edges of [them]_p4581 are faintly white. [They]_p4582 are like little white dots with red centres. Unless [they]_p4583 heal within a day or two, [I]_p4584 shall insist on the doctor seeing about them. Letter, [Samuel F]_n392. [Billington]_n393 & Son, Solicitors, [Whitby]_n,394 to Messrs. [Carter]_n,395 [Paterson]_n396 & [Co]_n397. , [London]_n398.

"17 August. "Dear Sirs,, "Herewith please receive invoice of goods sent by Great [Northern]_n399 Railway. Same are to be delivered at Carfax, near Purfleet, immediately on receipt at goods station King's Cross. The house is at present empty, but enclosed please find keys, all of which are labelled. "You will please deposit the boxes, fifty in number, which form the consignment, in the partially ruined building forming part of the house and marked 'A' on rough diagram enclosed. [Your]_p4585 agent will easily recognise the locality, as [it]_p4586 is the ancient chapel of the mansion. The goods leave by the train at 9:30 [to-night]_n,400 and will be due at [King]_n's401 Cross at 4:30 to-morrow afternoon. As [our]_p4587 client wishes the delivery made as soon as possible, [we]_p4588 shall be obliged by [your]_p4589 having teams ready at King's Cross at the time named and [forthwith]_n402 conveying the goods to destination. In order to obviate any delays possible through any routine requirements as to payment in [your]_p4590 departments, [we]_p4591 enclose cheque herewith for ten pounds ( 10), receipt of which please acknowledge. Should the charge be less than this amount, [you]_p4592 can return balance if greater, [we]_p4594 shall at once send cheque for difference on hearing from you.

[You]_p4595 are to leave the keys on coming away in the main hall of the house, where the proprietor may get [them]_p4596 on [his]_p4597 entering the house by means of [his]_p4598 duplicate key. "Pray do not take [us]_p4599 as exceeding the bounds of business courtesy in pressing [you]_p4600 in all ways to use the utmost expedition. "We are, [dear]_n403 [Sirs]_n,404 "Faithfully yours, "[SAMUEL F]_n405. BILLINGTON & [SON]_n406. " [Letter]_n,407 Messrs. [Carter]_n,408 [Paterson]_n409 & [Co]_n410. , [London]_n,411 to Messrs. [Billington]_n412 & Son, [Whitby]_n413. "21 August. "[Dear Sirs]_n,,414 "We beg to acknowledge 10 received and to return cheque 1 17s.

9d, amount of overplus, as shown in receipted account herewith. Goods are delivered in exact accordance with instructions, and keys left in parcel in main hall, as directed. "We are, [dear]_n415 [Sirs]_n,416 "Yours respectfully. "[Pro CARTER]_n,417 PATERSON & CO. " [Mina Murray]_n's418 [Journal]_n419. 18 August. , [I]_p4601 am happy [to-day]_n,420 and write sitting on the seat in the churchyard. [Lucy]_n421 is ever so much better. Last night [she]_p4602 slept well all night, and did not disturb [me]_p4603 once. The roses seem coming back already to [her]_p4604 cheeks, though [she]_p4605 is still sadly pale and wan-looking.

If [she]_p4606 were in any way an mic [I]_p4608 could understand it, but [she]_p4607 is not. [She]_p4609 is in [gay]_n422 spirits and full of life and cheerfulness. All the morbid reticence seems to have passed from her, and [she]_p4612 has just reminded me, as if [I]_p4613 needed any reminding, of that night, and that [it]_p4615 was here, on this very seat, [I]_p4614 found [her]_p4610 asleep. As [she]_p4616 told [me]_p4618 [she]_p4617 tapped playfully with the heel of [her]_p4620 boot on the stone slab and said:,   "My poor little feet didn't make much noise then! [I]_p4621 daresay poor old Mr Swales would have told [me]_p4619 that [it]_p4623 was because [I]_p4622 didn't want to wake up Geordie. " As [she]_p4624 was in such a communicative humour, [I]_p4626 asked [her]_p4627 if [she]_p4625 had dreamed at all that night. Before [she]_p4628 answered, that sweet, puckered look came into [her]_p4629 forehead, which [Arthur]_n,423 [I]_p4631 call [him]_p4633 [Arthur]_n424 from [her]_p4630 habit, says [he]_p4634 loves and, indeed, [I]_p4632 don't wonder that [he]_p4635 does. Then [she]_p4636 went on in a half-dreaming kind of way, as if trying to recall [it]_p4637 to herself:,   "I didn't quite dream but [it]_p4638 all seemed to be real. [I]_p4639 only wanted to be here in this spot, [I]_p4640 don't know why, for [I]_p4640 was afraid of something, [I]_p4641 don't know what. [I]_p4643 remember, though [I]_p4644 suppose [I]_p4644 was asleep, passing through the streets and over the bridge. A fish leaped as [I]_p4646 went by, and [I]_p4647 leaned over to look at it, and [I]_p4647 heard a lot of dogs howling, the whole town seemed as if [it]_p4650 must be full of dogs all howling at once, as [I]_p4648 went up the steps.

Then [I]_p4652 had a vague memory of something long and dark with red eyes, just as [we]_p4655 saw in the sunset, and something very sweet and very bitter all around [me]_p4656 at once and then [I]_p4653 seemed sinking into deep green water, and there was a singing in [my]_p4658 ears, as [I]_p4653 have heard there is to drowning men and then everything seemed passing away from [me]_p4657 [my]_p4659 soul seemed to go out from [my]_p4659 body and float about the air. [I]_p4661 seem to remember that once the West Lighthouse was right under me, and then there was a sort of agonising feeling, as if [I]_p4662 were in an earthquake, and [I]_p4662 came back and found [you]_p4664 shaking [my]_p4665 body. [I]_p4666 saw [you]_p4668 do [it]_p4670 before [I]_p4667 felt you. "  Then [she]_p4671 began to laugh. [It]_p4672 seemed a little uncanny to me, and [I]_p4673 listened to [her]_p4674 breathlessly. [I]_p4675 did not quite like it, and thought [it]_p4676 better not to keep [her]_p4678 mind on the subject, so [we]_p4680 drifted on to other subjects, and [Lucy]_n425 was like [her]_p4679 old self again. When [we]_p4681 got home the fresh breeze had braced [her]_p4682 up, and [her]_p4683 pale cheeks were really more rosy. [Her]_p4684 mother rejoiced when [she]_p4685 saw her, and [we]_p4686 all spent a very happy evening together. * * * * *  19 August. , Joy, joy, joy! although not all joy.

At last, news of [Jonathan]_n426. The [dear]_n427 fellow has been ill that is why [he]_p4687 did not write. [I]_p4688 am not afraid to think [it]_p4690 or say it, now that [I]_p4689 know. Mr Hawkins sent [me]_p4692 on the letter, and wrote himself, oh, so kindly. [I]_p4693 am to leave in the morning and go over to [Jonathan]_n,428 and to help to nurse [him]_p4694 if necessary, and to bring [him]_p4695 home. [Mr Hawkins]_n429 says [it]_p4696 would not be a bad thing if [we]_p4697 were to be married out there. [I]_p4698 have cried over the good [Sister]_n's430 letter till [I]_p4699 can feel [it]_p4700 wet against [my]_p4702 bosom, where [it]_p4701 lies. [It]_p4703 is of [Jonathan]_n,431 and must be next [my]_p4704 heart, for [he]_p4706 is in [my]_p4705 heart. [My]_p4707 journey is all mapped out, and [my]_p4708 luggage ready. [I]_p4709 am only taking one change of dress Lucy will bring [my]_p4711 trunk to London and keep [it]_p4712 till [I]_p4710 send for it, for [it]_p4713 may be that.

[I]_p4715 must write no more [I]_p4716 must keep [it]_p4717 to say to [Jonathan]_n,432 [my]_p4718 husband. The letter that [he]_p4719 has seen and touched must comfort [me]_p4720 till [we]_p4721 meet. [Letter]_n,433 [Sister Agatha]_n,434 [Hospital]_n435 of [St]_n436. Joseph and [Ste]_n437. Mary, [Buda-Pesth]_n,438 to [Miss Wilhelmina Murray]_n439. "12 August. "Dear [Madam]_n,,440 "I write by desire of Mr Jonathan Harker, who is [himself]_p4722 not strong enough to write, though progressing well, thanks to God and [St]_n441. Joseph and [Ste]_n442. Mary. [He]_p4723 has been under [our]_p4724 care for nearly six weeks, suffering from a violent brain fever.

[He]_p4725 wishes [me]_p4726 to convey [his]_p4727 love, and to say that by this post [I]_p4731 write for [him]_p4732 to Mr [Peter]_n443 Hawkins, [Exeter]_n,444 to say, with [his]_p4728 dutiful respects, that [he]_p4733 is sorry for [his]_p4728 delay, and that all of [his]_p4729 work is completed. [He]_p4734 will require some few weeks' rest in [our]_p4735 sanatorium in the hills, but will then return. [He]_p4736 wishes [me]_p4737 to say that [he]_p4738 has not sufficient money with him, and that [he]_p4739 would like to pay for [his]_p4740 staying here, so that others who need shall not be wanting for help. "Believe me,  "Yours, with sympathy and all blessings,  "SISTER AGATHA. "P. S. , [My]_p4741 patient being asleep, [I]_p4742 open this to let [you]_p4743 know something more. [He]_p4744 has told [me]_p4745 all about you, and that [you]_p4746 are shortly to be [his]_p4748 wife. All blessings to [you]_p4749 both! [He]_p4750 has had some fearful shock, so says [our]_p4751 doctor, and in [his]_p4752 delirium [his]_p4753 ravings have been dreadful of wolves and poison and blood of ghosts and demons and [I]_p4754 fear to say of what. Be careful with [him]_p4755 always that there may be nothing to excite [him]_p4756 of this kind for a long time to come the traces of such an illness as [his]_p4757 do not lightly die away.

[We]_p4758 should have written long ago, but [we]_p4759 knew nothing of [his]_p4760 friends, and there was on [him]_p4761 nothing that any one could understand. [He]_p4762 came in the train from Klausenburg, and the guard was told by the station-master there that [he]_p4763 rushed into the station shouting for a ticket for home. Seeing from [his]_p4764 violent demeanour that [he]_p4765 was [English]_n,445 [they]_p4766 gave [him]_p4767 a ticket for the furthest station on the way thither that the train reached. "Be assured that [he]_p4768 is well cared for. [He]_p4769 has won all hearts by [his]_p4770 sweetness and gentleness. [He]_p4771 is truly getting on well, and [I]_p4772 have no doubt will in a few weeks be all himself. But be careful of [him]_p4773 for safety's sake. There are, [I]_p4774 pray God and [St]_n446. Joseph and [Ste]_n447. Mary, many, many, happy years for [you]_p4775 both.

" [Dr Seward]_n's448 [Diary]_n449. 19 August. , Strange and sudden change in Renfield last night. About eight o'clock [he]_p4776 began to get excited and sniff about as a dog does when setting. The attendant was struck by [his]_p4777 manner, and knowing [my]_p4778 interest in him, encouraged [him]_p4779 to talk. [He]_p4781 is usually respectful to the attendant and at times servile but [to-night]_n,450 the man tells me, [he]_p4782 was quite haughty. Would not condescend to talk with [him]_p4783 at all.
