All [he]_p4784 would say was:, "I don't want to talk to you: [you]_p4785 don't count now the [Master]_n451 is at hand. "  The attendant thinks [it]_p4787 is some sudden form of religious mania which has seized him. If so, [we]_p4788 must look out for squalls, for a strong man with homicidal and religious mania at once might be dangerous.

The combination is a dreadful one. At nine o'clock [I]_p4789 visited [him]_p4790 myself. [His]_p4791 attitude to [me]_p4792 was the same as that to the attendant in [his]_p4793 sublime self-feeling the difference between [myself]_p4794 and attendant seemed to [him]_p4795 as nothing. [It]_p4796 looks like religious mania, and [he]_p4797 will soon think that [he]_p4798 [himself]_p4799 is God. These infinitesimal distinctions between man and man are too paltry for an [Omnipotent]_n452 Being. How these madmen give [themselves]_p4800 away! The real God taketh heed lest a sparrow fall but the God created from human vanity sees no difference between an eagle and a sparrow. Oh, if men only knew!  For half an hour or more Renfield kept getting excited in greater and greater degree. [I]_p4801 did not pretend to be watching him, but [I]_p4802 kept strict observation all the same. All at once that shifty look came into [his]_p4803 eyes which [we]_p4804 always see when a madman has seized an idea, and with [it]_p4805 the shifty movement of the head and back which asylum attendants come to know so well. [He]_p4806 became quite quiet, and went and sat on the edge of [his]_p4807 bed resignedly, and looked into space with lack-lustre eyes.

[I]_p4808 thought [I]_p4809 would find out if [his]_p4810 apathy were real or only assumed, and tried to lead [him]_p4813 to talk of [his]_p4811 pets, a theme which had never failed to excite [his]_p4811 attention. At first [he]_p4814 made no reply, but at length said testily:,   "Bother [them]_p4815 all! [I]_p4817 don't care a pin about them. "  "What?" [I]_p4818 said. "You don't mean to tell [me]_p4819 [you]_p4820 don't care about spiders?" (Spiders at present are [his]_p4821 hobby and the note-book is filling up with columns of small figures. ) To this [he]_p4822 answered enigmatically:,   "The bride-maidens rejoice the eyes that wait the coming of the bride  but when the bride draweth nigh, then the maidens shine not to the eyes that are filled. "  [He]_p4823 would not explain himself, but remained obstinately seated on [his]_p4824 bed all the time [I]_p4825 remained with him. [I]_p4826 am weary [to-night]_n453 and low in spirits. [I]_p4827 cannot but think of Lucy, and how different things might have been. If [I]_p4828 don't sleep at once, chloral, the modern Morpheus, C{2}HCl{3}O. H{2}O! [I]_p4829 must be careful not to let [it]_p4830 grow into a habit.

No, [I]_p4831 shall take none [to-night]_n!454 [I]_p4832 have thought of [Lucy]_n,455 and [I]_p4832 shall not dishonour [her]_p4834 by mixing the two. If need be, [to-night]_n456 shall be sleepless. * * * * *  Later. , Glad [I]_p4835 made the resolution gladder that [I]_p4836 kept to it. [I]_p4837 had lain tossing about, and had heard the clock strike only twice, when the night-watchman came to me, sent up from the ward, to say that Renfield had escaped. [I]_p4838 threw on [my]_p4839 clothes and ran down at once [my]_p4840 patient is too dangerous a person to be roaming about. Those ideas of [his]_p4841 might work out dangerously with strangers. The attendant was waiting for me. [He]_p4842 said [he]_p4843 had seen [him]_p4845 not ten minutes before, seemingly asleep in [his]_p4846 bed, when [he]_p4844 had looked through the observation-trap in the door. [His]_p4847 attention was called by the sound of the window being wrenched out.

[He]_p4848 ran back and saw [his]_p4849 feet disappear through the window, and had at once sent up for me. [He]_p4850 was only in [his]_p4851 night-gear, and cannot be far off. The attendant thought [it]_p4852 would be more useful to watch where [he]_p4853 should go than to follow him, as [he]_p4854 might lose sight of [him]_p4855 whilst getting out of the building by the door. [He]_p4857 is a bulky man, and couldn't get through the window. [I]_p4858 am thin, so, with [his]_p4860 aid, [I]_p4859 got out, but feet foremost, and, as [we]_p4861 were only a few feet above ground, landed unhurt. The attendant told [me]_p4862 the patient had gone to the left, and had taken a straight line, so [I]_p4863 ran as quickly as [I]_p4864 could. As [I]_p4865 got through the belt of trees [I]_p4866 saw a white figure scale the high wall which separates [our]_p4867 grounds from those of the deserted house. [I]_p4868 ran back at once, told the watchman to get three or four men immediately and follow [me]_p4869 into the grounds of Carfax, in case [our]_p4870 friend might be dangerous. [I]_p4871 got a ladder myself, and crossing the wall, dropped down on the other side. [I]_p4872 could see Renfield's figure just disappearing behind the angle of the house, so [I]_p4873 ran after him.

On the far side of the house [I]_p4874 found [him]_p4875 pressed close against the old ironbound oak door of the chapel. [He]_p4876 was talking, apparently to some one, but [I]_p4877 was afraid to go near enough to hear what [he]_p4879 was saying, lest [I]_p4878 might frighten him, and [he]_p4880 should run off. Chasing an errant swarm of bees is nothing to following a naked lunatic, when the fit of escaping is upon him! After a few minutes, however, [I]_p4885 could see that [he]_p4886 did not take note of anything around him, and so ventured to draw nearer to him, the more so as [my]_p4887 men had now crossed the wall and were closing [him]_p4881 in. [I]_p4888 heard [him]_p4890 say:, "I am here to do [Your]_p4891 bidding, [Master]_n457. [I]_p4892 am [Your]_p4894 slave, and [You]_p4895 will reward me, for [I]_p4893 shall be faithful. [I]_p4896 have worshipped [You]_p4897 long and afar off. Now that [You]_p4898 are near, [I]_p4901 await [Your]_p4902 commands, and [You]_p4899 will not pass [me]_p4904 by, will You, [dear]_n458 Master, in [Your]_p4903 distribution of good things?" [He]_p4905 is a selfish old beggar anyhow. [He]_p4906 thinks of the loaves and fishes even when [he]_p4907 believes [he]_p4908 is in a Real Presence. [His]_p4909 manias make a startling combination. When [we]_p4910 closed in on [him]_p4911 [he]_p4912 fought like a tiger.

[He]_p4913 is immensely strong, for [he]_p4914 was more like a wild beast than a man. [I]_p4915 never saw a lunatic in such a paroxysm of rage before and [I]_p4916 hope [I]_p4916 shall not again. [It]_p4918 is a mercy that [we]_p4919 have found out [his]_p4920 strength and [his]_p4921 danger in good time. With strength and determination like his, [he]_p4922 might have done wild work before [he]_p4923 was caged. [He]_p4924 is safe now at any rate. [Jack]_n459 [Sheppard]_n460 [himself]_p4925 couldn't get free from the strait-waistcoat that keeps [him]_p4926 restrained, and he's chained to the wall in the padded room. [His]_p4927 cries are at times awful, but the silences that follow are more deadly still, for [he]_p4928 means murder in every turn and movement. Just now [he]_p4929 spoke coherent words for the first time:,   "I shall be patient, Master. [It]_p4930 is coming, coming, coming!"  So [I]_p4931 took the hint, and came too. [I]_p4932 was too excited to sleep, but this diary has quieted me, and [I]_p4933 feel [I]_p4933 shall get some sleep [to-night]_n461.

CHAPTER IX   Letter, Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra. "[Buda-Pesth]_n,462 24 August. "My dearest Lucy,,   "I know [you]_p4935 will be anxious to hear all that has happened since [we]_p4936 parted at the railway station at Whitby. Well, [my]_p4937 [dear]_n,463 [I]_p4938 got to Hull all right, and caught the boat to Hamburg, and then the train on here. [I]_p4939 feel that [I]_p4940 can hardly recall anything of the journey, except that [I]_p4940 knew [I]_p4941 was coming to [Jonathan]_n,464 and, that as [I]_p4941 should have to do some nursing, [I]_p4941 had better get all the sleep [I]_p4942 could. [I]_p4946 found [my]_p4947 [dear]_n465 one, oh, so thin and pale and weak-looking. All the resolution has gone out of [his]_p4948 [dear]_n466 eyes, and that quiet dignity which [I]_p4950 told [you]_p4951 was in [his]_p4949 face has vanished. [He]_p4952 is only a wreck of himself, and [he]_p4953 does not remember anything that has happened to [him]_p4954 for a long time past. At least, [he]_p4955 wants [me]_p4956 to believe so, and [I]_p4957 shall never ask. [He]_p4958 has had some terrible shock, and [I]_p4959 fear [it]_p4960 might tax [his]_p4962 poor brain if [he]_p4963 were to try to recall it.

[Sister Agatha]_n,467 who is a good creature and a born nurse, tells [me]_p4964 that [he]_p4965 raved of dreadful things whilst [he]_p4966 was off [his]_p4967 head. [I]_p4968 wanted [her]_p4969 to tell [me]_p4972 what [they]_p4973 were but [she]_p4974 would only cross herself, and say [she]_p4975 would never tell that the ravings of the sick were the secrets of God, and that if a nurse through [her]_p4970 vocation should hear them, [she]_p4975 should respect [her]_p4970 trust. [She]_p4977 is a sweet, good soul, and the next day, when [she]_p4978 saw [I]_p4981 was troubled, [she]_p4979 opened up the subject again, and after saying that [she]_p4979 could never mention what [my]_p4983 poor [dear]_n468 raved about, added: 'I can tell [you]_p4985 this much, [my]_p4984 [dear]_n:469 that [it]_p4987 was not about anything which [he]_p4988 has done wrong [himself]_p4989 and you, as [his]_p4990 wife to be, have no cause to be concerned. [He]_p4991 has not forgotten [you]_p4992 or what [he]_p4994 owes to you. [His]_p4995 fear was of great and terrible things, which no mortal can treat of. ' [I]_p4996 do believe the [dear]_n470 soul thought [I]_p4997 might be jealous lest [my]_p4998 poor [dear]_n471 should have fallen in love with any other girl. The idea of [my]_p4999 being jealous about Jonathan! And yet, [my]_p5000 [dear]_n,472 let [me]_p5001 whisper, [I]_p5003 felt a thrill of joy through [me]_p5002 when [I]_p5004 knew that no other woman was a cause of trouble. [I]_p5005 am now sitting by [his]_p5007 bedside, where [I]_p5006 can see [his]_p5008 face while [he]_p5009 sleeps. [He]_p5010 is waking!. "When [he]_p5011 woke [he]_p5012 asked [me]_p5014 for [his]_p5015 coat, as [he]_p5012 wanted to get something from the pocket [I]_p5017 asked [Sister Agatha]_n,473 and [she]_p5018 brought all [his]_p5016 things.

[I]_p5019 saw that amongst [them]_p5023 was [his]_p5024 note-book, and was going to ask [him]_p5026 to let [me]_p5027 look at it, for [I]_p5020 knew then that [I]_p5020 might find some clue to [his]_p5025 trouble, but [I]_p5021 suppose [he]_p5029 must have seen [my]_p5032 wish in [my]_p5033 eyes, for [he]_p5030 sent [me]_p5028 over to the window, saying [he]_p5030 wanted to be quite alone for a moment. Then [he]_p5034 called [me]_p5040 back, and when [I]_p5044 came [he]_p5035 had [his]_p5046 hand over the note-book, and [he]_p5035 said to [me]_p5041 very solemnly:, "'[Wilhelmina]_n',474 [I]_p5045 knew then that [he]_p5036 was in deadly earnest, for [he]_p5036 has never called [me]_p5041 by that name since [he]_p5036 asked [me]_p5042 to marry him, 'you know, [dear]_n,475 [my]_p5047 ideas of the trust between husband and wife: there should be no secret, no concealment. [I]_p5048 have had a great shock, and when [I]_p5049 try to think of what [it]_p5052 is [I]_p5049 feel [my]_p5054 head spin round, and [I]_p5050 do not know if [it]_p5053 was all real or the dreaming of a madman. [You]_p5055 know [I]_p5056 have had brain fever, and that is to be mad. The secret is here, and [I]_p5057 do not want to know it. [I]_p5058 want to take up [my]_p5059 life here, with [our]_p5060 marriage. ' For, [my]_p5061 [dear]_n,476 [we]_p5062 had decided to be married as soon as the formalities are complete. 'Are [you]_p5063 willing, [Wilhelmina]_n,477 to share [my]_p5064 ignorance? Here is the book. Take [it]_p5065 and keep it, read [it]_p5066 if [you]_p5068 will, but never let [me]_p5069 know unless, indeed, some solemn duty should come upon [me]_p5070 to go back to the bitter hours, asleep or awake, sane or mad, recorded here. ' [He]_p5071 fell back exhausted, and [I]_p5072 put the book under [his]_p5073 pillow, and kissed him.

[I]_p5074 have asked [Sister Agatha]_n478 to beg the Superior to let [our]_p5075 wedding be this afternoon, and am waiting [her]_p5076 reply. * * * * * "She has come and told [me]_p5077 that the chaplain of the [English]_n479 mission church has been sent for. [We]_p5078 are to be married in an hour, or as soon after as [Jonathan]_n480 awakes. * * * * * "[Lucy]_n,481 the time has come and gone. [I]_p5079 feel very solemn, but very, very happy. Jonathan woke a little after the hour, and all was ready, and [he]_p5080 sat up in bed, propped up with pillows. [He]_p5081 answered [his]_p5082 'I will' firmly and strongly. [I]_p5083 could hardly speak [my]_p5084 heart was so full that even those words seemed to choke me. The [dear]_n482 sisters were so kind. Please God, [I]_p5085 shall never, never forget them, nor the grave and sweet responsibilities [I]_p5086 have taken upon me.

[I]_p5087 must tell [you]_p5088 of [my]_p5089 wedding present. When the chaplain and the sisters had left [me]_p5090 alone with [my]_p5092 husband, oh, Lucy, [it]_p5098 is the first time [I]_p5102 have written the words 'my husband', left [me]_p5091 alone with [my]_p5093 husband, [I]_p5103 took the book from under [his]_p5105 pillow, and wrapped [it]_p5099 up in white paper, and tied [it]_p5099 with a little bit of pale blue ribbon which was round [my]_p5093 neck, and sealed [it]_p5100 over the knot with sealing-wax, and for [my]_p5094 seal [I]_p5103 used [my]_p5094 wedding ring. Then [I]_p5106 kissed [it]_p5109 and showed [it]_p5110 to [my]_p5115 husband, and told [him]_p5116 that [I]_p5107 would keep [it]_p5110 so, and then [it]_p5111 would be an outward and visible sign for [us]_p5117 all [our]_p5118 lives that [we]_p5119 trusted each other that [I]_p5107 would never open [it]_p5111 unless [it]_p5111 were for [his]_p5120 own [dear]_n483 sake or for the sake of some stern duty. Then [he]_p5121 took [my]_p5124 hand in his, and oh, Lucy, [it]_p5127 was the first time [he]_p5122 took [his]_p5125 wife's hand, and said that [it]_p5128 was the dearest thing in all the wide world, and that [he]_p5122 would go through all the past again to win it, if need be. The poor [dear]_n484 meant to have said a part of the past, but [he]_p5130 cannot think of time yet, and [I]_p5132 shall not wonder if at first [he]_p5131 mixes up not only the month, but the year. "Well, [my]_p5133 [dear]_n,485 what could [I]_p5138 say? [I]_p5139 could only tell [him]_p5142 that [I]_p5139 was the happiest woman in all the wide world, and that [I]_p5140 had nothing to give [him]_p5143 except myself, [my]_p5134 life, and [my]_p5134 trust, and that with these went [my]_p5135 love and duty for all the days of [my]_p5135 life. And, [my]_p5144 [dear]_n,486 when [he]_p5145 kissed me, and drew [me]_p5146 to [him]_p5148 with [his]_p5149 poor weak hands, [it]_p5150 was like a very solemn pledge between us. "Lucy [dear]_n,487 do [you]_p5151 know why [I]_p5154 tell [you]_p5152 all this? [It]_p5155 is not only because [it]_p5156 is all sweet to me, but because [you]_p5152 have been, and are, very [dear]_n488 to me. [It]_p5157 was [my]_p5158 privilege to be [your]_p5159 friend and guide when [you]_p5160 came from the schoolroom to prepare for the world of life. [I]_p5161 want [you]_p5163 to see now, and with the eyes of a very happy wife, whither duty has led [me]_p5165 so that in [your]_p5166 own married life [you]_p5164 too may be all happy as [I]_p5162 am.

[My]_p5167 [dear]_n,489 please [Almighty God]_n,490 [your]_p5168 life may be all [it]_p5169 promises: a long day of sunshine, with no harsh wind, no forgetting duty, no distrust. [I]_p5170 must not wish [you]_p5173 no pain, for that can never be but [I]_p5171 do hope [you]_p5174 will be always as happy as [I]_p5171 am now. Good-bye, [my]_p5175 [dear]_n491. [I]_p5176 shall post this at once, and, perhaps, write [you]_p5177 very soon again. [I]_p5178 must stop, for Jonathan is waking, [I]_p5179 must attend to [my]_p5180 husband! "Your ever-loving "MINA [HARKER]_n492. "   Letter, Lucy Westenra to Mina Harker. "[Whitby]_n,493 30 August. "My dearest Mina,,   "Oceans of love and millions of kisses, and may [you]_p5181 soon be in [your]_p5182 own home with [your]_p5183 husband. [I]_p5184 wish [you]_p5185 could be coming home soon enough to stay with [us]_p5186 here. The strong air would soon restore Jonathan [it]_p5187 has quite restored me.

[I]_p5188 have an appetite like a cormorant, am full of life, and sleep well. [You]_p5189 will be glad to know that [I]_p5190 have quite given up walking in [my]_p5191 sleep. [I]_p5192 think [I]_p5193 have not stirred out of [my]_p5195 bed for a week, that is when [I]_p5193 once got into [it]_p5196 at night. [Arthur]_n494 says [I]_p5197 am getting fat. By the way, [I]_p5198 forgot to tell [you]_p5199 that [Arthur]_n495 is here. [We]_p5200 have such walks and drives, and rides, and rowing, and tennis, and fishing together and [I]_p5201 love [him]_p5202 more than ever. [He]_p5203 tells [me]_p5204 that [he]_p5208 loves [me]_p5205 more, but [I]_p5212 doubt that, for at first [he]_p5209 told [me]_p5205 that [he]_p5209 couldn't love [me]_p5206 more than [he]_p5210 did then. But this is nonsense. There [he]_p5213 is, calling to me. So no more just at present from [your]_p5214 loving  "LUCY.
"P. S. , [Mother]_n496 sends [her]_p5215 love. [She]_p5216 seems better, poor [dear]_n497. "P. P. S. , [We]_p5217 are to be married on 28 September. " [Dr Seward]_n's498 [Diary]_n499. 20 August.

, The case of Renfield grows even more interesting. [He]_p5218 has now so far quieted that there are spells of cessation from [his]_p5219 passion. For the first week after [his]_p5220 attack [he]_p5221 was perpetually violent. Then one night, just as the moon rose, [he]_p5222 grew quiet, and kept murmuring to himself: "Now [I]_p5223 can wait now [I]_p5224 can wait. " The attendant came to tell me, so [I]_p5225 ran down at once to have a look at him. [He]_p5226 was still in the strait-waistcoat and in the padded room, but the suffused look had gone from [his]_p5227 face, and [his]_p5228 eyes had something of [their]_p5229 old pleading, [I]_p5230 might almost say, "cringing", softness. [I]_p5231 was satisfied with [his]_p5232 present condition, and directed [him]_p5233 to be relieved. The attendants hesitated, but finally carried out [my]_p5234 wishes without protest. [It]_p5235 was a strange thing that the patient had humour enough to see [their]_p5237 distrust, for, coming close to me, [he]_p5240 said in a whisper, all the while looking furtively at them:,   "They think [I]_p5241 could hurt you! Fancy [me]_p5238 hurting you! The fools!"  [It]_p5236 was soothing, somehow, to the feelings to find [myself]_p5243 dissociated even in the mind of this poor madman from the others but all the same [I]_p5242 do not follow [his]_p5244 thought. Am [I]_p5245 to take [it]_p5248 that [I]_p5246 have anything in common with him, so that [we]_p5250 are, as [it]_p5249 were, to stand together or has [he]_p5251 to gain from [me]_p5252 some good so stupendous that [my]_p5253 well-being is needful to him? [I]_p5246 must find out later on.

To-night [he]_p5254 will not speak. Even the offer of a kitten or even a full-grown cat will not tempt him. [He]_p5255 will only say: "I don't take any stock in cats. [I]_p5256 have more to think of now, and [I]_p5257 can wait [I]_p5257 can wait. "  After a while [I]_p5259 left him. The attendant tells [me]_p5260 that [he]_p5261 was quiet until just before dawn, and that then [he]_p5262 began to get uneasy, and at length violent, until at last [he]_p5262 fell into a paroxysm which exhausted [him]_p5265 so that [he]_p5263 swooned into a sort of coma. * * * * *. Three nights has the same thing happened, violent all day then quiet from moonrise to sunrise. [I]_p5266 wish [I]_p5267 could get some clue to the cause. [It]_p5268 would almost seem as if there was some influence which came and went.

Happy thought! [We]_p5269 shall [to-night]_n500 play sane wits against mad ones. [He]_p5270 escaped before without [our]_p5271 help [to-night]_n501 [he]_p5272 shall escape with it. [We]_p5273 shall give [him]_p5274 a chance, and have the men ready to follow in case [they]_p5275 are required. * * * * *  23 August. , "The unexpected always happens. " How well Disraeli knew life. [Our]_p5276 bird when [he]_p5277 found the cage open would not fly, so all [our]_p5278 subtle arrangements were for nought. At any rate, [we]_p5279 have proved one thing that the spells of quietness last a reasonable time. [We]_p5280 shall in future be able to ease [his]_p5281 bonds for a few hours each day. [I]_p5282 have given orders to the night attendant merely to shut [him]_p5283 in the padded room, when once [he]_p5284 is quiet, until an hour before sunrise.

The poor soul's body will enjoy the relief even if [his]_p5285 mind cannot appreciate it. Hark! The unexpected again! [I]_p5286 am called the patient has once more escaped. * * * * *  Later. , Another night adventure. Renfield artfully waited until the attendant was entering the room to inspect. Then [he]_p5287 dashed out past [him]_p5288 and flew down the passage. [I]_p5289 sent word for the attendants to follow. Again [he]_p5290 went into the grounds of the deserted house, and [we]_p5291 found [him]_p5292 in the same place, pressed against the old chapel door. When [he]_p5293 saw [me]_p5296 [he]_p5294 became furious, and had not the attendants seized [him]_p5298 in time, [he]_p5294 would have tried to kill me. As [we]_p5299 were holding [him]_p5300 a strange thing happened.

[He]_p5301 suddenly redoubled [his]_p5302 efforts, and then as suddenly grew calm. [I]_p5303 looked round instinctively, but could see nothing. Then [I]_p5304 caught the patient's eye and followed it, but could trace nothing as [it]_p5305 looked into the moonlit sky except a big bat, which was flapping [its]_p5307 silent and ghostly way to the west. Bats usually wheel and flit about, but this one seemed to go straight on, as if [it]_p5308 knew where [it]_p5309 was bound for or had some intention of [its]_p5310 own. The patient grew calmer every instant, and presently said:,   "You needn't tie [me]_p5311 [I]_p5312 shall go quietly!" Without trouble [we]_p5313 came back to the house. [I]_p5314 feel there is something ominous in [his]_p5315 calm, and shall not forget this night. Lucy Westenra's Diary [Hillingham]_n,502 24 August. , [I]_p5316 must imitate [Mina]_n,503 and keep writing things down. Then [we]_p5317 can have long talks when [we]_p5318 do meet. [I]_p5319 wonder when [it]_p5320 will be.

[I]_p5321 wish [she]_p5323 were with [me]_p5324 again, for [I]_p5322 feel so unhappy. Last night [I]_p5325 seemed to be dreaming again just as [I]_p5326 was at [Whitby]_n504. Perhaps [it]_p5327 is the change of air, or getting home again. [It]_p5328 is all dark and horrid to me, for [I]_p5329 can remember nothing but [I]_p5330 am full of vague fear, and [I]_p5330 feel so weak and worn out. When [Arthur]_n505 came to lunch [he]_p5332 looked quite grieved when [he]_p5333 saw me, and [I]_p5334 hadn't the spirit to try to be cheerful. [I]_p5335 wonder if [I]_p5336 could sleep in mother's room [to-night]_n506. [I]_p5337 shall make an excuse and try. * * * * *  25 August. , Another bad night. [Mother]_n507 did not seem to take to [my]_p5338 proposal.

[She]_p5339 seems not too well herself, and doubtless [she]_p5340 fears to worry me. [I]_p5341 tried to keep awake, and succeeded for a while but when the clock struck twelve [it]_p5343 waked [me]_p5344 from a doze, so [I]_p5342 must have been falling asleep. There was a sort of scratching or flapping at the window, but [I]_p5345 did not mind it, and as [I]_p5346 remember no more, [I]_p5346 suppose [I]_p5347 must then have fallen asleep. More bad dreams. [I]_p5349 wish [I]_p5350 could remember them. This morning [I]_p5351 am horribly weak. [My]_p5352 face is ghastly pale, and [my]_p5353 throat pains me. [It]_p5354 must be something wrong with [my]_p5355 lungs, for [I]_p5356 don't seem ever to get air enough. [I]_p5357 shall try to cheer up when [Arthur]_n508 comes, or else [I]_p5358 know [he]_p5359 will be miserable to see [me]_p5360 so. [Letter]_n,509 [Arthur]_n510 [Holmwood]_n511 to [Dr Seward]_n512.

"[Albemarle]_n513 Hotel, 31 August. "My [dear]_n514 [Jack]_n,,515 "I want [you]_p5361 to do [me]_p5362 a favour. [Lucy]_n516 is ill that is, [she]_p5363 has no special disease, but [she]_p5364 looks awful, and is getting worse every day. [I]_p5365 have asked [her]_p5367 if there is any cause [I]_p5366 do not dare to ask [her]_p5368 mother, for to disturb the poor lady's mind about [her]_p5368 daughter in [her]_p5369 present state of health would be fatal. Mrs Westenra has confided to [me]_p5371 that [her]_p5372 doom is spoken, disease of the heart, though poor Lucy does not know [it]_p5373 yet. [I]_p5374 am sure that there is something preying on [my]_p5375 [dear]_n517 girl's mind. [I]_p5376 am almost distracted when [I]_p5377 think of [her]_p5378 to look at [her]_p5379 gives [me]_p5380 a pang. [I]_p5381 told [her]_p5384 [I]_p5382 should ask [you]_p5386 to see her, and though [she]_p5387 demurred at first, [I]_p5382 know why, old fellow, [she]_p5388 finally consented. [It]_p5389 will be a painful task for you, [I]_p5392 know, old friend, but [it]_p5394 is for [her]_p5395 sake, and [I]_p5393 must not hesitate to ask, or [you]_p5390 to act. [You]_p5396 are to come to lunch at [Hillingham]_n518 to-morrow, two o'clock, so as not to arouse any suspicion in Mrs Westenra, and after lunch Lucy will take an opportunity of being alone with you.

[I]_p5397 shall come in for tea, and [we]_p5400 can go away together [I]_p5398 am filled with anxiety, and want to consult with [you]_p5401 alone as soon as [I]_p5398 can after [you]_p5402 have seen her. Do not fail!  "ARTHUR. " Telegram, [Arthur]_n519 [Holmwood]_n520 to [Seward]_n521. "1 September. "Am summoned to see [my]_p5403 father, who is worse. Am writing. Write [me]_p5404 fully by [to-night]_n's522 post to Ring. Wire [me]_p5405 if necessary. " [Letter]_n523 from [Dr Seward]_n524 to [Arthur]_n525 [Holmwood]_n526. "2 September.

"My [dear]_n527 old fellow,, "With regard to Miss Westenra's health [I]_p5406 hasten to let [you]_p5408 know at once that in [my]_p5409 opinion there is not any functional disturbance or any malady that [I]_p5407 know of. At the same time, [I]_p5410 am not by any means satisfied with [her]_p5412 appearance [she]_p5414 is woefully different from what [she]_p5415 was when [I]_p5411 saw [her]_p5413 last. Of course [you]_p5416 must bear in mind that [I]_p5417 did not have full opportunity of examination such as [I]_p5418 should wish [our]_p5419 very friendship makes a little difficulty which not even medical science or custom can bridge over. [I]_p5420 had better tell [you]_p5421 exactly what happened, leaving [you]_p5422 to draw, in a measure, [your]_p5423 own conclusions. [I]_p5424 shall then say what [I]_p5425 have done and propose doing. "I found Miss Westenra in seemingly gay spirits. [Her]_p5426 mother was present, and in a few seconds [I]_p5427 made up [my]_p5428 mind that [she]_p5429 was trying all [she]_p5430 knew to mislead [her]_p5431 mother and prevent [her]_p5432 from being anxious. [I]_p5433 have no doubt [she]_p5434 guesses, if [she]_p5435 does not know, what need of caution there is. [We]_p5436 lunched alone, and as [we]_p5437 all exerted [ourselves]_p5439 to be cheerful, [we]_p5438 got, as some kind of reward for [our]_p5440 labours, some real cheerfulness amongst us. Then Mrs Westenra went to lie down, and Lucy was left with me.

[We]_p5441 went into [her]_p5442 boudoir, and till [we]_p5444 got there [her]_p5443 gaiety remained, for the servants were coming and going. As soon as the door was closed, however, the mask fell from [her]_p5445 face, and [she]_p5448 sank down into a chair with a great sigh, and hid [her]_p5446 eyes with [her]_p5446 hand. When [I]_p5449 saw that [her]_p5451 high spirits had failed, [I]_p5450 at once took advantage of [her]_p5452 reaction to make a diagnosis. [She]_p5453 said to [me]_p5454 very sweetly:,   "'I cannot tell [you]_p5455 how [I]_p5456 loathe talking about myself. ' [I]_p5458 reminded [her]_p5459 that a doctor's confidence was sacred, but that [you]_p5461 were grievously anxious about her. [She]_p5462 caught on to [my]_p5463 meaning at once, and settled that matter in a word. 'Tell [Arthur]_n528 everything [you]_p5464 choose. [I]_p5465 do not care for myself, but all for him!' So [I]_p5466 am quite free. "I could easily see that [she]_p5470 is somewhat bloodless, but [I]_p5467 could not see the usual an mic signs, and by a chance [I]_p5468 was actually able to test the quality of [her]_p5472 blood, for in opening a window which was stiff a cord gave way, and [she]_p5471 cut [her]_p5473 hand slightly with broken glass. [It]_p5474 was a slight matter in itself, but [it]_p5475 gave [me]_p5476 an evident chance, and [I]_p5477 secured a few drops of the blood and have analysed them.

The qualitative analysis gives a quite normal condition, and shows, [I]_p5478 should infer, in [itself]_p5479 a vigorous state of health. In other physical matters [I]_p5480 was quite satisfied that there is no need for anxiety but as there must be a cause somewhere, [I]_p5481 have come to the conclusion that [it]_p5482 must be something mental. [She]_p5483 complains of difficulty in breathing satisfactorily at times, and of heavy, lethargic sleep, with dreams that frighten her, but regarding which [she]_p5484 can remember nothing. [She]_p5485 says that as a child [she]_p5486 used to walk in [her]_p5489 sleep, and that when in Whitby the habit came back, and that once [she]_p5487 walked out in the night and went to [East Cliff]_n,529 where Miss Murray found [her]_p5490 but [she]_p5487 assures [me]_p5491 that of late the habit has not returned. [I]_p5492 am in doubt, and so have done the best thing [I]_p5493 know of [I]_p5493 have written to [my]_p5495 old friend and master, [Professor]_n530 [Van Helsing]_n,531 of Amsterdam, who knows as much about obscure diseases as any one in the world. [I]_p5496 have asked [him]_p5498 to come over, and as [you]_p5500 told [me]_p5502 that all things were to be at [your]_p5503 charge, [I]_p5497 have mentioned to [him]_p5499 who [you]_p5501 are and [your]_p5504 relations to Miss Westenra. This, [my]_p5505 [dear]_n532 fellow, is in obedience to [your]_p5506 wishes, for [I]_p5507 am only too proud and happy to do anything [I]_p5508 can for her. [Van Helsing]_n533 would, [I]_p5509 know, do anything for [me]_p5510 for a personal reason, so, no matter on what ground [he]_p5511 comes, [we]_p5512 must accept [his]_p5513 wishes. [He]_p5514 is a seemingly arbitrary man, but this is because [he]_p5515 knows what [he]_p5516 is talking about better than any one else. [He]_p5517 is a philosopher and a metaphysician, and one of the most advanced scientists of [his]_p5518 day  and [he]_p5519 has, [I]_p5520 believe, an absolutely open mind.

This, with an iron nerve, a temper of the ice-brook, an indomitable resolution, self-command, and toleration exalted from virtues to blessings, and the kindliest and truest heart that beats, these form [his]_p5521 equipment for the noble work that [he]_p5524 is doing for mankind, work both in theory and practice, for [his]_p5522 views are as wide as [his]_p5522 all-embracing sympathy. [I]_p5525 tell [you]_p5527 these facts that [you]_p5528 may know why [I]_p5526 have such confidence in him. [I]_p5529 have asked [him]_p5530 to come at once. [I]_p5531 shall see Miss Westenra to-morrow again. [She]_p5532 is to meet [me]_p5533 at the Stores, so that [I]_p5534 may not alarm [her]_p5535 mother by too early a repetition of [my]_p5536 call. "Yours always,  "JOHN SEWARD. " [Letter]_n,534 [Abraham Van Helsing]_n,535 M. D. , D. Ph.

, D. Lit. , etc. , etc. , to [Dr Seward]_n536. "2 September. "My good Friend,,   "When [I]_p5537 have received [your]_p5539 letter [I]_p5538 am already coming to you. By good fortune [I]_p5540 can leave just at once, without wrong to any of those who have trusted me. Were fortune other, then [it]_p5541 were bad for those who have trusted, for [I]_p5542 come to [my]_p5543 friend when [he]_p5544 call [me]_p5546 to aid those [he]_p5545 holds [dear]_n537. Tell [your]_p5547 friend that when that time [you]_p5548 suck from [my]_p5551 wound so swiftly the poison of the gangrene from that knife that [our]_p5553 other friend, too nervous, let slip, [you]_p5549 did more for [him]_p5554 when [he]_p5555 wants [my]_p5552 aids and [you]_p5549 call for [them]_p5556 than all [his]_p5557 great fortune could do.

But [it]_p5558 is pleasure added to do for him, [your]_p5560 friend [it]_p5559 is to [you]_p5561 that [I]_p5562 come. Have then rooms for [me]_p5563 at the Great Eastern Hotel, so that [I]_p5564 may be near to hand, and please [it]_p5566 so arrange that [we]_p5568 may see the [young]_n538 lady not too late on to-morrow, for [it]_p5567 is likely that [I]_p5565 may have to return here that night. But if need be [I]_p5569 shall come again in three days, and stay longer if [it]_p5570 must. Till then good-bye, [my]_p5571 friend John. "[VAN]_n539 HELSING. " [Letter]_n,540 [Dr Seward]_n541 to [Hon]_n542. [Arthur]_n543 [Holmwood]_n544. "3 September. "My [dear]_n545 Art,, "[Van Helsing]_n546 has come and gone. [He]_p5572 came on with [me]_p5573 to [Hillingham]_n,547 and found that, by [Lucy]_n's548 discretion, [her]_p5574 mother was lunching out, so that [we]_p5576 were alone with her.

[Van Helsing]_n549 made a very careful examination of the patient. [He]_p5577 is to report to me, and [I]_p5578 shall advise you, for of course [I]_p5579 was not present all the time. [He]_p5580 is, [I]_p5581 fear, much concerned, but says [he]_p5582 must think. When [I]_p5583 told [him]_p5584 of [our]_p5586 friendship and how [you]_p5587 trust to [me]_p5589 in the matter, [he]_p5590 said: 'You must tell [him]_p5585 all [you]_p5588 think. Tell [him]_p5591 what [I]_p5592 think, if [you]_p5593 can guess it, if [you]_p5594 will. [Nay]_n,550 [I]_p5595 am not jesting. This is no jest, but life and death, perhaps more. ' [I]_p5596 asked what [he]_p5597 meant by that, for [he]_p5598 was very serious. This was when [we]_p5599 had come back to town, and [he]_p5600 was having a cup of tea before starting on [his]_p5601 return to Amsterdam. [He]_p5602 would not give [me]_p5603 any further clue.

[You]_p5604 must not be angry with me, Art, because [his]_p5605 very reticence means that all [his]_p5606 brains are working for [her]_p5607 good. [He]_p5608 will speak plainly enough when the time comes, be sure. So [I]_p5609 told [him]_p5612 [I]_p5610 would simply write an account of [our]_p5613 visit, just as if [I]_p5610 were doing a descriptive special article for The Daily Telegraph. [He]_p5614 seemed not to notice, but remarked that the smuts in London were not quite so bad as [they]_p5615 used to be when [he]_p5616 was a student here. [I]_p5617 am to get [his]_p5618 report [to-morrow]_n551 if [he]_p5619 can possibly make it. In any case [I]_p5620 am to have a letter. "Well, as to the visit. [Lucy]_n552 was more cheerful than on the day [I]_p5621 first saw her, and certainly looked better. [She]_p5622 had lost something of the ghastly look that so upset you, and [her]_p5623 breathing was normal. [She]_p5624 was very sweet to the professor (as [she]_p5625 always is), and tried to make [him]_p5626 feel at ease though [I]_p5627 could see that the poor girl was making a hard struggle for it.

[I]_p5628 believe [Van Helsing]_n553 saw it, too, for [I]_p5629 saw the quick look under [his]_p5631 bushy brows that [I]_p5629 knew of old. Then [he]_p5632 began to chat of all things except [ourselves]_p5633 and diseases and with such an infinite geniality that [I]_p5634 could see poor Lucy's pretense of animation merge into reality. Then, without any seeming change, [he]_p5635 brought the conversation gently round to [his]_p5636 visit, and suavely said:, "'My [dear]_n554 [young]_n555 miss, [I]_p5637 have the so great pleasure because [you]_p5638 are so much beloved. That is much, [my]_p5639 [dear]_n,556 ever were there that which [I]_p5640 do not see. [They]_p5641 told [me]_p5642 [you]_p5643 were down in the spirit, and that [you]_p5644 were of a ghastly pale. To [them]_p5645 [I]_p5647 say: "Pouf!"' And [he]_p5649 snapped [his]_p5650 fingers at [me]_p5651 and went on: 'But [you]_p5652 and [I]_p5648 shall show [them]_p5646 how wrong [they]_p5653 are. How can he', and [he]_p5654 pointed at [me]_p5658 with the same look and gesture as that with which once [he]_p5655 pointed [me]_p5659 out to [his]_p5661 class, on, or rather after, a particular occasion which [he]_p5655 never fails to remind [me]_p5659 of, 'know anything of a [young]_n557 ladies? [He]_p5663 has [his]_p5662 madams to play with, and to bring [them]_p5664 back to happiness, and to those that love them. [It]_p5666 is much to do, and, oh, but there are rewards, in that [we]_p5667 can bestow such happiness. But the [young]_n558 ladies! [He]_p5668 has no wife nor daughter, and the [young]_n559 do not tell [themselves]_p5669 to [the y]_noung,560 but to the old, like me, who have known so many sorrows and the causes of them. So, [my]_p5670 [dear]_n,561 [we]_p5671 will send [him]_p5672 away to smoke the cigarette in the garden, whiles [you]_p5673 and [I]_p5674 have little talk all to ourselves.

' [I]_p5675 took the hint, and strolled about, and presently the professor came to the window and called [me]_p5676 in. [He]_p5677 looked grave, but said: 'I have made careful examination, but there is no functional cause. With [you]_p5678 [I]_p5679 agree that there has been much blood lost [it]_p5680 has been, but is not. But the conditions of [her]_p5681 are in no way an mic. [I]_p5682 have asked [her]_p5685 to send [me]_p5687 [her]_p5686 maid, that [I]_p5683 may ask just one or two question, that so [I]_p5683 may not chance to miss nothing. [I]_p5688 know well what [she]_p5689 will say. And yet there is cause there is always cause for everything. [I]_p5690 must go back home and think. [You]_p5691 must send to [me]_p5692 the telegram every day and if there be cause [I]_p5693 shall come again. The disease, for not to be all well is a disease, interest me, and the sweet [young]_n562 [dear]_n,563 [she]_p5696 interest [me]_p5694 too.

[She]_p5697 charm me, and for her, if not for [you]_p5698 or disease, [I]_p5699 come. '  "As [I]_p5700 tell you, [he]_p5701 would not say a word more, even when [we]_p5702 were alone. And so now, [Art]_n,564 [you]_p5703 know all [I]_p5704 know. [I]_p5705 shall keep stern watch. [I]_p5706 trust [your]_p5707 poor father is rallying. [It]_p5708 must be a terrible thing to you, [my]_p5709 [dear]_n565 old fellow, to be placed in such a position between two people who are both so [dear]_n566 to you. [I]_p5710 know [your]_p5712 idea of duty to [your]_p5713 father, and [you]_p5714 are right to stick to [it]_p5717 but, if need be, [I]_p5711 shall send [you]_p5715 word to come at once to Lucy so do not be over-anxious unless [you]_p5715 hear from me. " [Dr Seward]_n's567 [Diary]_n568. 4 September. , Zo phagous patient still keeps up [our]_p5718 interest in him.

[He]_p5719 had only one outburst and that was yesterday at an unusual time. Just before the stroke of noon [he]_p5720 began to grow restless. The attendant knew the symptoms, and at once summoned aid. Fortunately the men came at a run, and were just in time, for at the stroke of noon [he]_p5721 became so violent that [it]_p5722 took all [their]_p5723 strength to hold him. In about five minutes, however, [he]_p5724 began to get more and more quiet, and finally sank into a sort of melancholy, in which state [he]_p5725 has remained up to now. The attendant tells [me]_p5726 that [his]_p5727 screams whilst in the paroxysm were really appalling [I]_p5728 found [my]_p5730 hands full when [I]_p5729 got in, attending to some of the other patients who were frightened by him. Indeed, [I]_p5731 can quite understand the effect, for the sounds disturbed even me, though [I]_p5732 was some distance away. [It]_p5733 is now after the dinner-hour of the asylum, and as yet [my]_p5734 patient sits in a corner brooding, with a dull, sullen, woe-begone look in [his]_p5735 face, which seems rather to indicate than to show something directly. [I]_p5736 cannot quite understand it. * * * * *  Later.

, Another change in [my]_p5737 patient. At five o'clock [I]_p5738 looked in on him, and found [him]_p5739 seemingly as happy and contented as [he]_p5741 used to be. [He]_p5742 was catching flies and eating them, and was keeping note of [his]_p5743 capture by making nail-marks on the edge of the door between the ridges of padding. When [he]_p5744 saw me, [he]_p5745 came over and apologised for [his]_p5748 bad conduct, and asked [me]_p5746 in a very humble, cringing way to be led back to [his]_p5749 own room and to have [his]_p5749 note-book again. [I]_p5751 thought [it]_p5752 well to humour him: so [he]_p5753 is back in [his]_p5754 room with the window open. [He]_p5755 has the sugar of [his]_p5756 tea spread out on the window-sill, and is reaping quite a harvest of flies. [He]_p5757 is not now eating them, but putting [them]_p5758 into a box, as of old, and is already examining the corners of [his]_p5760 room to find a spider. [I]_p5761 tried to get [him]_p5762 to talk about the past few days, for any clue to [his]_p5763 thoughts would be of immense help to [me]_p5764 but [he]_p5765 would not rise. For a moment or two [he]_p5766 looked very sad, and said in a sort of far-away voice, as though saying [it]_p5767 rather to [himself]_p5768 than to me:,   "All over! all over! [He]_p5769 has deserted me. No hope for [me]_p5770 now unless [I]_p5775 do [it]_p5777 for myself!" Then suddenly turning to [me]_p5771 in a resolute way, [he]_p5779 said: "Doctor, won't [you]_p5780 be very good to [me]_p5771 and let [me]_p5772 have a little more sugar? [I]_p5776 think [it]_p5778 would be good for me.

"  "And the flies?" [I]_p5781 said. "Yes! The flies like it, too, and [I]_p5782 like the flies therefore [I]_p5783 like it. " And there are people who know so little as to think that madmen do not argue. [I]_p5784 procured [him]_p5786 a double supply, and left [him]_p5787 as happy a man as, [I]_p5785 suppose, any in the world. [I]_p5788 wish [I]_p5789 could fathom [his]_p5790 mind. * * * * *  Midnight. , Another change in him. [I]_p5791 had been to see Miss Westenra, whom [I]_p5792 found much better, and had just returned, and was standing at [our]_p5794 own gate looking at the sunset, when once more [I]_p5792 heard [him]_p5795 yelling. As [his]_p5796 room is on this side of the house, [I]_p5797 could hear [it]_p5798 better than in the morning. [It]_p5799 was a shock to [me]_p5800 to turn from the wonderful smoky beauty of a sunset over London, with [its]_p5801 lurid lights and inky shadows and all the marvellous tints that come on foul clouds even as on foul water, and to realise all the grim sternness of [my]_p5803 own cold stone building, with [its]_p5802 wealth of breathing misery, and [my]_p5804 own desolate heart to endure [it]_p5805 all.

[I]_p5806 reached [him]_p5807 just as the sun was going down, and from [his]_p5808 window saw the red disc sink. As [it]_p5809 sank [he]_p5811 became less and less frenzied and just as [it]_p5810 dipped [he]_p5812 slid from the hands that held him, an inert mass, on the floor. [It]_p5813 is wonderful, however, what intellectual recuperative power lunatics have, for within a few minutes [he]_p5814 stood up quite calmly and looked around him. [I]_p5815 signalled to the attendants not to hold him, for [I]_p5816 was anxious to see what [he]_p5817 would do. [He]_p5818 went straight over to the window and brushed out the crumbs of sugar then [he]_p5819 took [his]_p5821 fly-box, and emptied [it]_p5823 outside, and threw away the box then [he]_p5820 shut the window, and crossing over, sat down on [his]_p5822 bed. All this surprised me, so [I]_p5824 asked him: "Are [you]_p5826 not going to keep flies any more?"  "No," said [he]_p5827 "I am sick of all that rubbish!" [He]_p5828 certainly is a wonderfully interesting study. [I]_p5829 wish [I]_p5830 could get some glimpse of [his]_p5831 mind or of the cause of [his]_p5832 sudden passion. Stop there may be a clue after all, if [we]_p5833 can find why to-day [his]_p5834 paroxysms came on at high noon and at sunset. "4 September. , [Patient]_n573 still better to-day. " Telegram, [Seward]_n,574 [London]_n,575 to [Van Helsing]_n,576 [Amsterdam]_n577. "5 September. , [Patient]_n578 greatly improved. [Good]_n579 appetite sleeps naturally good spirits colour coming back. " Telegram, [Seward]_n,580 [London]_n,581 to [Van Helsing]_n,582 [Amsterdam]_n583. "6 September. , Terrible change for the worse. Come at once do not lose an hour.

[I]_p5837 hold over telegram to Holmwood till have seen you. " CHAPTER X [Letter]_n,584 [Dr Seward]_n585 to [Hon]_n586. [Arthur]_n587 [Holmwood]_n588. "6 September. "My [dear]_n589 Art,, "My news to-day is not so good. [Lucy]_n590 this morning had gone back a bit. There is, however, one good thing which has arisen from [it]_p5838 Mrs Westenra was naturally anxious concerning Lucy, and has consulted [me]_p5839 professionally about her. [I]_p5840 took advantage of the opportunity, and told [her]_p5842 that [my]_p5847 old master, [Van Helsing]_n,591 the great specialist, was coming to stay with me, and that [I]_p5841 would put [her]_p5843 in [his]_p5848 charge conjointly with [myself]_p5849 so now [we]_p5850 can come and go without alarming [her]_p5843 unduly, for a shock to [her]_p5844 would mean sudden death, and this, in Lucy's weak condition, might be disastrous to her. [We]_p5851 are hedged in with difficulties, all of us, [my]_p5852 poor old fellow but, please God, [we]_p5853 shall come through [them]_p5854 all right. If any need [I]_p5855 shall write, so that, if [you]_p5857 do not hear from me, take [it]_p5858 for granted that [I]_p5856 am simply waiting for news.

In haste  Yours ever,  "JOHN SEWARD. " [Dr Seward]_n's592 [Diary]_n593. 7 September. , The first thing [Van Helsing]_n594 said to [me]_p5859 when [we]_p5860 met at [Liverpool Street]_n595 was:, "Have [you]_p5861 said anything to [our]_p5862 [young]_n596 friend the lover of her?" [I]_p5868 wrote [him]_p5870 a letter simply telling [him]_p5871 that [you]_p5873 were coming, as Miss Westenra was not so well, and that [I]_p5869 should let [him]_p5871 know if need be. "  "Right, [my]_p5874 friend," [he]_p5875 said, "quite right! Better [he]_p5876 not know as yet  perhaps [he]_p5876 shall never know. [I]_p5878 pray so but if [it]_p5879 be needed, then [he]_p5880 shall know all. And, [my]_p5881 good friend John, let [me]_p5882 caution you. [You]_p5883 deal with the madmen.

All men are mad in some way or the other and inasmuch as [you]_p5884 deal discreetly with [your]_p5885 madmen, so deal with God's madmen, too, the rest of the world. [You]_p5886 tell not [your]_p5887 madmen what [you]_p5888 do nor why [you]_p5889 do [it]_p5892 [you]_p5889 tell [them]_p5893 not what [you]_p5890 think. So [you]_p5894 shall keep knowledge in [its]_p5895 place, where [it]_p5897 may [rest]_n,597 where [it]_p5898 may gather [its]_p5896 kind around [it]_p5898 and breed. [You]_p5900 and [I]_p5901 shall keep as yet what [we]_p5902 know here, and here. " [He]_p5903 touched [me]_p5904 on the heart and on the forehead, and then touched [himself]_p5905 the same way. "I have for [myself]_p5906 thoughts at the present. Later [I]_p5907 shall unfold to you. "  "Why not now?" [I]_p5908 asked. "It may do some good [we]_p5909 may arrive at some decision. '" [I]_p5921 did not see the application, and told [him]_p5922 so. " To which [he]_p6435 smiled a sad sort of smile as [he]_p6436 replied:,   "He is [her]_p6437 lover, [her]_p6438 fianc. [Van Helsing]_n688 returned in a couple of hours, and presently said to me: "Now [you]_p6513 go home, and eat much and drink enough. Make [yourself]_p6514 strong. [I]_p6520 have grave reasons. No, do not ask [them]_p6521 think what [you]_p6522 will. Do not fear to think even the most not-probable. [Good-night]_n690. "  In the hall two of the maids came to me, and asked if [they]_p6523 or either of [them]_p6524 might not sit up with Miss Lucy. " [I]_p6534 was much touched by [their]_p6535 kindness. Perhaps [it]_p6536 is because [I]_p6538 am weak at present, and perhaps because [it]_p6537 was on Lucy's account, that [their]_p6540 devotion was manifested for over and over again have [I]_p6539 seen similar instances of woman's kindness. [I]_p6541 got back here in time for a late dinner went [my]_p6542 rounds, all well and set this down whilst waiting for sleep. [It]_p6543 is coming. * * * * *  11 September. , This afternoon [I]_p6544 went over to [Hillingham]_n692. [Found Van Helsing]_n693 in excellent spirits, and Lucy much better. CHAPTER XI  Lucy Westenra's Diary. 12 September. , How good [they]_p6660 all are to me. [I]_p6661 quite love that [dear]_n708 Dr [Van Helsing]_n709.

[I]_p6662 wonder why [he]_p6663 was so anxious about these flowers. [He]_p6664 positively frightened me, [he]_p6665 was so fierce. 13 September. , Called at the [Berkeley]_n715 and found [Van Helsing]_n,716 as usual, up to time. The carriage ordered from the hotel was waiting. Oh, how [we]_p6754 are beset! How are all the powers of the devils against us!" Suddenly [he]_p6755 jumped to [his]_p6756 feet. "Come," [he]_p6757 said, "come, [we]_p6758 must see and act. Presently [he]_p6787 took an opportunity of telling Mrs Westenra that [she]_p6788 must not remove anything from Lucy's room without consulting [him]_p6789 that the flowers were of medicinal value, and that the breathing of [their]_p6790 odour was a part of the system of cure. After another hour [Lucy]_n732 waked from [her]_p6794 sleep, fresh and bright and seemingly not much the worse for [her]_p6795 terrible ordeal. What does [it]_p6796 all mean? [I]_p6797 am beginning to wonder if [my]_p6798 long habit of life amongst the insane is beginning to tell upon [my]_p6799 own brain. Lucy Westenra's Diary. 17 September. , [Four]_n733 days and nights of peace. [I]_p6800 am getting so strong again that [I]_p6801 hardly know myself. [It]_p6802 is as if [I]_p6803 had passed through some long nightmare, and had just awakened to see the beautiful sunshine and feel the fresh air of the morning around me. [I]_p6804 have a dim half-remembrance of long, anxious times of waiting and fearing darkness in which there was not even the pain of hope to make present distress more poignant: and then long spells of oblivion, and the rising back to life as a diver coming up through a great press of water.

Since, however, Dr [Van Helsing]_n734 has been with me, all this bad dreaming seems to have passed away the noises that used to frighten [me]_p6805 out of [my]_p6809 wits, the flapping against the windows, the distant voices which seemed so close to me, the harsh sounds that came from [I]_p6810 know not where and commanded [me]_p6806 to do [I]_p6811 know not what, have all ceased. [I]_p6812 go to bed now without any fear of sleep. [I]_p6813 do not even try to keep awake. [I]_p6814 have grown quite fond of the garlic, and a boxful arrives for [me]_p6815 every day from Haarlem. Thank God for mother's sake, and [dear]_n737 [Arthur]_n's,738 and for all [our]_p6819 friends who have been so kind! [PERILOUS ADVENTURE]_n741 OF OUR INTERVIEWER. Interview with the Keeper in the Zo logical Gardens. After many inquiries and almost as many refusals, and perpetually using the words "[Pall Mall Gazette]_n"742 as a sort of talisman, [I]_p6826 managed to find the keeper of the section of the Zo logical Gardens in which the wolf department is included. [Thomas Bilder]_n743 lives in one of the cottages in the enclosure behind the elephant-house, and was just sitting down to [his]_p6827 tea when [I]_p6828 found him. [Thomas]_n744 and [his]_p6829 wife are hospitable folk, elderly, and without children, and if the specimen [I]_p6830 enjoyed of [their]_p6831 hospitality be of the average kind, [their]_p6832 lives must be pretty comfortable. Then when the table was cleared, and [he]_p6835 had lit [his]_p6837 pipe, [he]_p6836 said:,   "Now, sir, [you]_p6838 can go on and arsk [me]_p6840 what [you]_p6839 want. You'll excoose [me]_p6841 refoosin' to talk of perfeshunal subjects afore meals. [I]_p6842 gives the wolves and the jackals and the hyenas in all [our]_p6844 section [their]_p6845 tea afore [I]_p6843 begins to arsk [them]_p6846 questions. "  "How do [you]_p6847 mean, ask [them]_p6848 questions?" [I]_p6849 queried, wishful to get [him]_p6850 into a talkative humour.

"'Ittin' of [them]_p6851 over the 'ead with a pole is one way scratchin' of [their]_p6852 hears is another, when gents as is flush wants a bit of a show-orf to [their]_p6853 gals. [I]_p6854 don't so much mind the fust, the 'ittin' with a pole afore [I]_p6855 chucks in [their]_p6858 dinner but [I]_p6855 waits till they've 'ad [their]_p6859 sherry and kawffee, so to speak, afore [I]_p6856 tries on with the ear-scratchin'. Mind you," [he]_p6860 added philosophically, "there's a deal of the same nature in [us]_p6861 as in [them]_p6862 theer animiles. Here's [you]_p6863 a-comin' and arskin' of [me]_p6865 questions about [my]_p6866 business, and [I]_p6867 that grumpy-like that only for [your]_p6870 bloomin' 'arf-quid I'd 'a' seen [you]_p6864 blowed fust 'fore I'd answer. Not even when [you]_p6871 arsked [me]_p6874 sarcastic-like if I'd like [you]_p6872 to arsk the Superintendent if [you]_p6872 might arsk [me]_p6875 questions. Without offence did [I]_p6876 tell yer to go to 'ell?"  "You did. "  "An' when [you]_p6877 said you'd report [me]_p6879 for usin' of obscene language that was 'ittin' [me]_p6880 over the 'ead but the 'arf-quid made that all right. [I]_p6881 weren't a-goin' to fight, so [I]_p6882 waited for the food, and did with [my]_p6883 'owl as the wolves, and lions, and tigers does. But, Lor' love yer 'art, now that the old 'ooman has stuck a chunk of [her]_p6884 tea-cake in me, an' rinsed [me]_p6886 out with [her]_p6885 bloomin' old teapot, and I've lit hup, [you]_p6889 may scratch [my]_p6891 ears for all you're worth, and won't git even a growl out of me. [I]_p6893 know what yer a-comin' at, that 'ere escaped wolf. "  "Exactly. [I]_p6894 want [you]_p6895 to give [me]_p6896 [your]_p6897 view of it. Just tell [me]_p6898 how [it]_p6899 happened and when [I]_p6901 know the facts I'll get [you]_p6903 to say what [you]_p6904 consider was the cause of it, and how [you]_p6904 think the whole affair will end. "  "All right, guv'nor. This 'ere is about the '[ole]_n745 story. That 'ere wolf what [we]_p6906 called [Bersicker]_n746 was one of three grey ones that came from [Norway]_n747 to Jamrach's, which [we]_p6907 bought off [him]_p6908 four years ago. [He]_p6909 was a nice well-behaved wolf, that never gave no trouble to talk of. I'm more surprised at 'im for wantin' to get out nor any other animile in the place.
