" "Don't [you]_p6911 mind him, sir!" broke in Mrs [Tom]_n,748 with a cheery laugh. "'E's got mindin' the animiles so long that blest if [he]_p6912 ain't like a old wolf 'isself! But there ain't no 'arm in 'im. "  "Well, sir, [it]_p6913 was about two hours after feedin' yesterday when [I]_p6914 first hear [my]_p6915 disturbance. [I]_p6916 was makin' up a litter in the monkey-house for a [young]_n749 puma which is ill but when [I]_p6917 heard the yelpin' and 'owlin' [I]_p6917 kem away straight. There was [Bersicker a-tearin]_n'750 like a mad thing at the bars as if [he]_p6919 wanted to get out. There wasn't much people about that day, and close at hand was only one man, a tall, thin chap, with a 'ook nose and a pointed beard, with a few white hairs runnin' through it. [He]_p6920 had a 'ard, cold look and red eyes, and [I]_p6921 took a sort of mislike to him, for [it]_p6922 seemed as if [it]_p6923 was 'im as [they]_p6924 was hirritated at. [He]_p6925 'ad white kid gloves on 'is 'ands, and [he]_p6926 pointed out the animiles to [me]_p6927 and says: 'Keeper, these wolves seem upset at something. '  "'Maybe it's you,' says I, for [I]_p6928 did not like the airs as [he]_p6930 give 'isself. [He]_p6931 didn't git angry, as [I]_p6932 'oped [he]_p6933 would, but [he]_p6934 smiled a kind of insolent smile, with a mouth full of white, sharp teeth.

'Oh no, [they]_p6935 wouldn't like me,' 'e says. "'Ow yes, [they]_p6936 would,' says I, a-imitatin' of him. 'They always likes a bone or two to clean [their]_p6937 teeth on about tea-time, which [you]_p6938 'as a bagful. ' "Well, [it]_p6939 was a odd thing, but when the animiles see [us]_p6940 a-talkin' [they]_p6941 lay down, and when [I]_p6942 went over to [Bersicker]_n751 [he]_p6943 let [me]_p6944 stroke [his]_p6945 ears same as ever. That there man kem over, and blessed but if [he]_p6946 didn't put in [his]_p6947 hand and stroke the old wolf's ears too!  "'Tyke care,' says I. '[Bersicker]_n752 is quick. '  "'Never mind,' [he]_p6948 says. 'I'm used to 'em!'  "'Are [you]_p6949 in the business yourself?' [I]_p6950 says, tyking off [my]_p6952 'at, for a man what trades in wolves, anceterer, is a good friend to keepers. "'No' says he, 'not exactly in the business, but [I]_p6953 'ave made pets of several. ' And with that [he]_p6954 lifts [his]_p6955 'at as perlite as a lord, and walks away.

Old [Bersicker]_n753 kep' a-lookin' arter 'im till 'e was out of sight, and then went and lay down in a corner and wouldn't come hout the 'ole hevening. Well, larst night, so soon as the moon was hup, the wolves here all began a-'owling. There warn't nothing for [them]_p6956 to 'owl at. There warn't no one near, except some one that was evidently a-callin' a dog somewheres out back of the gardings in the Park road. Once or twice [I]_p6957 went out to see that all was right, and [it]_p6958 was, and then the 'owling stopped. Just before twelve o'clock [I]_p6959 just took a look round afore turnin' in, an', bust me, but when [I]_p6960 kem opposite to old [Bersicker]_n's754 cage [I]_p6960 see the rails broken and twisted about and the cage empty. And that's all [I]_p6962 know for certing. "  "Did any one else see anything?"  "One of [our]_p6963 gard'ners was a-comin' 'ome about that time from a 'armony, when [he]_p6964 sees a big grey dog comin' out through the garding 'edges. At least, so [he]_p6965 says, but [I]_p6968 don't give much for [it]_p6969 myself, for if [he]_p6966 did 'e never said a word about [it]_p6970 to [his]_p6972 missis when 'e got 'ome, and [it]_p6970 was only after the escape of the wolf was made known, and [we]_p6973 had been up all night-a-huntin' of the Park for [Bersicker]_n,755 that [he]_p6966 remembered seein' anything. [My]_p6974 own belief was that the 'armony 'ad got into [his]_p6975 'ead.

" "Now, [Mr Bilder]_n,756 can [you]_p6976 account in any way for the escape of the wolf?" "Well, sir," [he]_p6978 said, with a suspicious sort of modesty, "I think [I]_p6979 can but [I]_p6980 don't know as 'ow you'd be satisfied with the theory. "  "Certainly [I]_p6982 shall. If a man like you, who knows the animals from experience, can't hazard a good guess at any rate, who is even to try?"  "Well then, sir, [I]_p6983 accounts for [it]_p6984 this way [it]_p6985 seems to [me]_p6986 that 'ere wolf escaped, simply because [he]_p6987 wanted to get out. " From the hearty way that both [Thomas]_n757 and [his]_p6988 wife laughed at the joke [I]_p6989 could see that [it]_p6990 had done service before, and that the whole explanation was simply an elaborate sell. [I]_p6991 couldn't cope in badinage with the worthy [Thomas]_n,758 but [I]_p6992 thought [I]_p6992 knew a surer way to [his]_p6995 heart, so [I]_p6993 said:, "Now, [Mr Bilder]_n,759 we'll consider that first half-sovereign worked off, and this brother of [his]_p6996 is waiting to be claimed when you've told [me]_p6999 what [you]_p6997 think will happen. "  "Right y'are, sir," [he]_p7000 said briskly. "Ye'll excoose me, [I]_p7004 know, for a-chaffin' of ye, but the old woman here winked at me, which was as much as telling [me]_p7001 to go on. "  "Well, [I]_p7005 never!" said the old lady. "My opinion is this: that 'ere wolf is a-'idin' of, somewheres. The gard'ner wot didn't remember said [he]_p7006 was a-gallopin' northward faster than a horse could go but [I]_p7007 don't believe him, for, [yer]_p7008 see, sir, wolves don't gallop no more nor dogs does, [they]_p7009 not [bein]_n'760 built that way.

Wolves is fine things in a storybook, and [I]_p7010 dessay when [they]_p7011 gets in packs and does be chivyin' somethin' that's more afeared than [they]_p7012 is [they]_p7012 can make a devil of a noise and chop [it]_p7014 up, whatever [it]_p7015 is. But, [Lor]_n'761 bless you, in real life a wolf is only a low creature, not half so clever or bold as a good dog and not half a quarter so much fight in 'im. This one ain't been used to fightin' or even to providin' for hisself, and more like he's somewhere round the Park a-'idin' an' a-shiverin' of, and, if [he]_p7016 thinks at all, wonderin' where [he]_p7017 is to get [his]_p7020 breakfast from or maybe he's got down some area and is in a coal-cellar. [My]_p7021 eye, won't some cook get a rum start when [she]_p7022 sees [his]_p7023 green eyes a-shining at [her]_p7024 out of the dark! If [he]_p7025 can't get food he's bound to look for it, and mayhap [he]_p7026 may chance to light on a butcher's shop in time. If [he]_p7028 doesn't, and some nursemaid goes a-walkin' orf with a soldier, leavin' of the hinfant in the perambulator, well, then [I]_p7029 shouldn't be surprised if the census is one babby the less. That's all. " [I]_p7030 was handing [him]_p7031 the half-sovereign, when something came bobbing up against the window, and [Mr Bilder]_n's762 face doubled [its]_p7032 natural length with surprise. "God bless me!" [he]_p7033 said. "If there ain't old [Bersicker]_n763 come back by 'isself!" [He]_p7034 went to the door and opened [it]_p7035 a most unnecessary proceeding [it]_p7036 seemed to me. [I]_p7037 have always thought that a wild animal never looks so well as when some obstacle of pronounced durability is between [us]_p7038 a personal experience has intensified rather than diminished that idea.

After all, however, there is nothing like custom, for neither [Bilder]_n764 nor [his]_p7039 wife thought any more of the wolf than [I]_p7040 should of a dog. The animal [itself]_p7041 was as peaceful and well-behaved as that father of all picture-wolves, [Red]_n765 Riding Hood's quondam friend, whilst moving [her]_p7042 confidence in masquerade. The whole scene was an unutterable mixture of comedy and pathos. The wicked wolf that for half a day had paralysed London and set all the children in the town shivering in [their]_p7043 shoes, was there in a sort of penitent mood, and was received and petted like a sort of vulpine prodigal son. Old [Bilder]_n766 examined [him]_p7044 all over with most tender solicitude, and when [he]_p7045 had finished with [his]_p7046 penitent said:, "There, [I]_p7048 knew the poor old chap would get into some kind of trouble didn't [I]_p7049 say [it]_p7050 all along? Here's [his]_p7047 head all cut and full of broken glass. 'E's been a-gettin' over some bloomin' wall or other. It's a shyme that people are allowed to top [their]_p7051 walls with broken bottles. This 'ere's what comes of it. Come along, Bersicker. "  [He]_p7052 took the wolf and locked [him]_p7053 up in a cage, with a piece of meat that satisfied, in quantity at any rate, the elementary conditions of the fatted calf, and went off to report.

[I]_p7054 came off, too, to report the only exclusive information that is given to-day regarding the strange escapade at the Zoo. [Dr Seward]_n's767 [Diary]_n768. 17 September. , [I]_p7055 was engaged after dinner in [my]_p7056 study posting up [my]_p7057 books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed [my]_p7058 patient, with [his]_p7059 face distorted with passion. [I]_p7060 was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of [his]_p7061 own accord into the Superintendent's study is almost unknown. Without an instant's pause [he]_p7062 made straight at me. [He]_p7063 had a dinner-knife in [his]_p7064 hand, and, as [I]_p7065 saw [he]_p7067 was dangerous, [I]_p7066 tried to keep the table between us. [He]_p7068 was too quick and too strong for me, however for before [I]_p7071 could get [my]_p7072 balance [he]_p7074 had struck at [me]_p7069 and cut [my]_p7073 left wrist rather severely. Before [he]_p7075 could strike again, however, [I]_p7077 got in [my]_p7078 right and [he]_p7076 was sprawling on [his]_p7079 back on the floor.

[My]_p7080 wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. [I]_p7081 saw that [my]_p7082 friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied [myself]_p7084 binding up [my]_p7083 wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and [we]_p7085 turned [our]_p7086 attention to him, [his]_p7087 employment positively sickened me. [He]_p7088 was lying on [his]_p7089 belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from [my]_p7090 wounded wrist. [He]_p7091 was easily secured, and, to [my]_p7092 surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: "The blood is the life! The blood is the life!"  [I]_p7094 cannot afford to lose blood just at present [I]_p7095 have lost too much of late for [my]_p7093 physical good, and then the prolonged strain of Lucy's illness and [its]_p7096 horrible phases is telling on me. [I]_p7097 am over-excited and weary, and [I]_p7098 need [rest]_n,769 [rest][_n, ]_nrest770. [Happily]_n771 [Van Helsing]_n772 has not summoned me, so [I]_p7099 need not forego [my]_p7101 sleep [to-night]_n773 [I]_p7100 could not well do without it. Telegram, [Van Helsing]_n,774 Antwerp, to [Seward]_n,775 Carfax. (Sent to Carfax, Sussex, as no county given delivered late by twenty-two hours. )  "17 September.

, Do not fail to be at [Hillingham]_n776 [to-night]_n777. If not watching all the time frequently, visit and see that flowers are as placed very important do not fail. Shall be with [you]_p7102 as soon as possible after arrival. " [Dr Seward]_n's778 [Diary]_n779. 18 September. , Just off for train to [London]_n780. The arrival of [Van Helsing]_n's781 telegram filled [me]_p7103 with dismay. A whole night lost, and [I]_p7104 know by bitter experience what may happen in a night. Of course [it]_p7105 is possible that all may be well, but what may have happened? Surely there is some horrible doom hanging over [us]_p7106 that every possible accident should thwart [us]_p7107 in all [we]_p7108 try to do. [I]_p7109 shall take this cylinder with me, and then [I]_p7110 can complete [my]_p7111 entry on Lucy's phonograph.

Memorandum left by Lucy Westenra. 17 September. Night. , [I]_p7112 write this and leave [it]_p7113 to be seen, so that no one may by any chance get into trouble through me. This is an exact record of what took place [to-night]_n782. [I]_p7114 feel [I]_p7115 am dying of weakness, and have barely strength to write, but [it]_p7117 must be done if [I]_p7115 die in the doing. [I]_p7118 went to bed as usual, taking care that the flowers were placed as Dr [Van Helsing]_n783 directed, and soon fell asleep. [I]_p7119 was waked by the flapping at the window, which had begun after that sleep-walking on the cliff at Whitby when Mina saved me, and which now [I]_p7120 know so well. [I]_p7121 was not afraid, but [I]_p7122 did wish that [Dr Seward]_n784 was in the next room, as Dr [Van Helsing]_n785 said [he]_p7124 would be, so that [I]_p7122 might have called him. [I]_p7125 tried to go to sleep, but could not.

Then there came to [me]_p7126 the old fear of sleep, and [I]_p7127 determined to keep awake. Perversely sleep would try to come then when [I]_p7128 did not want [it]_p7131 so, as [I]_p7129 feared to be alone, [I]_p7129 opened [my]_p7132 door and called out: "Is there anybody there?" There was no answer. [I]_p7133 was afraid to wake mother, and so closed [my]_p7134 door again. Then outside in the shrubbery [I]_p7135 heard a sort of howl like a dog's, but more fierce and deeper. [I]_p7136 went to the window and looked out, but could see nothing, except a big bat, which had evidently been buffeting [its]_p7137 wings against the window. So [I]_p7138 went back to bed again, but determined not to go to sleep. Presently the door opened, and mother looked in  seeing by [my]_p7139 moving that [I]_p7140 was not asleep, came in, and sat by me. [She]_p7141 said to [me]_p7142 even more sweetly and softly than [her]_p7143 wont:,   "I was uneasy about you, darling, and came in to see that [you]_p7144 were all right. "  [I]_p7146 feared [she]_p7147 might catch cold sitting there, and asked [her]_p7152 to come in and sleep with me, so [she]_p7148 came into bed, and lay down beside [me]_p7155 [she]_p7148 did not take off [her]_p7153 dressing gown, for [she]_p7149 said [she]_p7149 would only stay a while and then go back to [her]_p7153 own bed. As [she]_p7157 lay there in [my]_p7158 arms, and [I]_p7159 in hers, the flapping and buffeting came to the window again.

[She]_p7160 was startled and a little frightened, and cried out: "What is that?" [I]_p7161 tried to pacify her, and at last succeeded, and [she]_p7165 lay quiet but [I]_p7162 could hear [her]_p7163 poor [dear]_n786 heart still beating terribly. After a while there was the low howl again out in the shrubbery, and shortly after there was a crash at the window, and a lot of broken glass was hurled on the floor. The window blind blew back with the wind that rushed in, and in the aperture of the broken panes there was the head of a great, gaunt grey wolf. [Mother]_n787 cried out in a fright, and struggled up into a sitting posture, and clutched wildly at anything that would help her. Amongst other things, [she]_p7166 clutched the wreath of flowers that [Dr Van Helsing]_n788 insisted on [my]_p7167 wearing round [my]_p7168 neck, and tore [it]_p7169 away from me. For a second or two [she]_p7170 sat up, pointing at the wolf, and there was a strange and horrible gurgling in [her]_p7172 throat then [she]_p7171 fell over, as if struck with lightning, and [her]_p7173 head hit [my]_p7174 forehead and made [me]_p7175 dizzy for a moment or two. The room and all round seemed to spin round. [I]_p7176 kept [my]_p7177 eyes fixed on the window, but the wolf drew [his]_p7178 head back, and a whole myriad of little specks seemed to come blowing in through the broken window, and wheeling and circling round like the pillar of dust that travellers describe when there is a simoon in the desert. [I]_p7179 tried to stir, but there was some spell upon me, and [dear]_n789 mother's poor body, which seemed to grow cold already, for [her]_p7183 [dear]_n790 heart had ceased to beat, weighed [me]_p7181 down and [I]_p7180 remembered no more for a while. The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till [I]_p7184 recovered consciousness again.

Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling and in [our]_p7185 shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. [I]_p7186 was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of [my]_p7187 dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for [I]_p7188 could hear [their]_p7189 bare feet pattering outside [my]_p7190 door. [I]_p7191 called to them, and [they]_p7192 came in, and when [they]_p7193 saw what had happened, and what [it]_p7195 was that lay over [me]_p7196 on the bed, [they]_p7193 screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. [They]_p7197 lifted off the body of [my]_p7198 [dear]_n791 mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after [I]_p7199 had got up. [They]_p7200 were all so frightened and nervous that [I]_p7201 directed [them]_p7202 to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room and [I]_p7203 laid what flowers [I]_p7204 had on [my]_p7205 [dear]_n792 mother's breast. When [they]_p7206 were there [I]_p7207 remembered what Dr [Van Helsing]_n793 had told me, but [I]_p7208 didn't like to remove them, and, besides, [I]_p7208 would have some of the servants to sit up with [me]_p7210 now.

[I]_p7212 was surprised that the maids did not come back. [I]_p7213 called them, but got no answer, so [I]_p7214 went to the dining-room to look for them. [My]_p7215 heart sank when [I]_p7216 saw what had happened. [They]_p7217 all four lay helpless on the floor, breathing heavily. The decanter of sherry was on the table half full, but there was a queer, acrid smell about. [I]_p7218 was suspicious, and examined the decanter. [It]_p7219 smelt of laudanum, and looking on the sideboard, [I]_p7220 found that the bottle which mother's doctor uses for her, oh! did use, was empty. What am [I]_p7221 to do? what am [I]_p7222 to do? [I]_p7222 am back in the room with mother. [I]_p7224 cannot leave her, and [I]_p7225 am alone, [save]_n794 for the sleeping servants, whom some one has drugged. Alone with the dead! [I]_p7226 dare not go out, for [I]_p7227 can hear the low howl of the wolf through the broken window.

The air seems full of specks, floating and circling in the draught from the window, and the lights burn blue and dim. What am [I]_p7228 to do? God shield [me]_p7230 from harm this night! [I]_p7229 shall hide this paper in [my]_p7232 breast, where [they]_p7233 shall find [it]_p7235 when [they]_p7234 come to lay [me]_p7231 out. [My]_p7236 [dear]_n795 mother gone! [It]_p7237 is time that [I]_p7238 go too. Good-bye, [dear]_n796 [Arthur]_n,797 if [I]_p7239 should not survive this night. God keep you, [dear]_n,798 and God help me! CHAPTER XII [DR]_n799. SEWARD'S [DIARY]_n800 18 September. , [I]_p7240 drove at once to [Hillingham]_n801 and arrived early. Keeping [my]_p7241 cab at the gate, [I]_p7242 went up the avenue alone. [I]_p7243 knocked gently and rang as quietly as possible, for [I]_p7244 feared to disturb Lucy or [her]_p7245 mother, and hoped to only bring a servant to the door. After a while, finding no response, [I]_p7246 knocked and rang again still no answer.

[I]_p7247 cursed the laziness of the servants that [they]_p7248 should lie abed at such an hour, for [it]_p7249 was now ten o'clock, and so rang and knocked again, but more impatiently, but still without response. Hitherto [I]_p7250 had blamed only the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me. Was this desolation but another link in the chain of doom which seemed drawing tight around us? Was [it]_p7251 indeed a house of death to which [I]_p7252 had come, too late? [I]_p7253 knew that minutes, even seconds of delay, might mean hours of danger to Lucy, if [she]_p7256 had had again one of those frightful relapses  and [I]_p7253 went round the house to try if [I]_p7254 could find by chance an entry anywhere. [I]_p7257 could find no means of ingress. Every window and door was fastened and locked, and [I]_p7258 returned baffled to the porch. As [I]_p7259 did so, [I]_p7260 heard the rapid pit-pat of a swiftly driven horse's feet. [They]_p7261 stopped at the gate, and a few seconds later [I]_p7262 met [Van Helsing]_n802 running up the avenue. When [he]_p7263 saw me, [he]_p7264 gasped out:,   "Then [it]_p7265 was you, and just arrived. How is she? Are [we]_p7266 too late? Did [you]_p7267 not get [my]_p7268 telegram?"  [I]_p7269 answered as quickly and coherently as [I]_p7270 could that [I]_p7270 had only got [his]_p7273 telegram early in the morning, and had not lost a minute in coming here, and that [I]_p7271 could not make any one in the house hear me. [He]_p7274 paused and raised [his]_p7275 hat as [he]_p7276 said solemnly:,   "Then [I]_p7277 fear [we]_p7278 are too late.

God's will be done!" With [his]_p7279 usual recuperative energy, [he]_p7280 went on: "Come. If there be no way open to get in, [we]_p7281 must make one. Time is all in all to [us]_p7282 now. "  [We]_p7283 went round to the back of the house, where there was a kitchen window. The [Professor]_n803 took a small surgical saw from [his]_p7284 case, and handing [it]_p7285 to me, pointed to the iron bars which guarded the window. [I]_p7286 attacked [them]_p7287 at once and had very soon cut through three of them. Then with a long, thin knife [we]_p7289 pushed back the fastening of the sashes and opened the window. [I]_p7290 helped the [Professor]_n804 in, and followed him. There was no one in the kitchen or in the servants' rooms, which were close at hand. [We]_p7291 tried all the rooms as [we]_p7292 went along, and in the dining-room, dimly lit by rays of light through the shutters, found four servant-women lying on the floor.

There was no need to think [them]_p7293 dead, for [their]_p7294 stertorous breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the room left no doubt as to [their]_p7295 condition. [Van Helsing]_n805 and [I]_p7296 looked at each other, and as [we]_p7297 moved away [he]_p7298 said: "We can attend to [them]_p7299 later. " Then [we]_p7300 ascended to Lucy's room. For an instant or two [we]_p7301 paused at the door to listen, but there was no sound that [we]_p7302 could hear. With white faces and trembling hands, [we]_p7303 opened the door gently, and entered the room. How shall [I]_p7304 describe what [we]_p7305 saw? On the bed lay two women, Lucy and [her]_p7306 mother. The latter lay farthest in, and [she]_p7307 was covered with a white sheet, the edge of which had been blown back by the draught through the broken window, showing the drawn, white face, with a look of terror fixed upon it. By [her]_p7308 side lay [Lucy]_n,806 with face white and still more drawn. The flowers which had been round [her]_p7309 neck [we]_p7312 found upon [her]_p7310 mother's bosom, and [her]_p7310 throat was bare, showing the two little wounds which [we]_p7313 had noticed before, but looking horribly white and mangled. Without a word the [Professor]_n807 bent over the bed, [his]_p7314 head almost touching poor Lucy's breast then [he]_p7317 gave a quick turn of [his]_p7315 head, as of one who listens, and leaping to [his]_p7315 feet, [he]_p7318 cried out to me:, "It is not yet too late! Quick! quick! Bring the brandy!" [I]_p7319 flew downstairs and returned with it, taking care to smell and taste it, lest it, too, were drugged like the decanter of sherry which [I]_p7320 found on the table.

The maids were still breathing, but more restlessly, and [I]_p7321 fancied that the narcotic was wearing off. [I]_p7322 did not stay to make sure, but returned to [Van Helsing]_n808. [He]_p7323 rubbed the brandy, as on another occasion, on [her]_p7324 lips and gums and on [her]_p7325 wrists and the palms of [her]_p7325 hands. [He]_p7327 said to me:,   "I can do this, all that can be at the present. [You]_p7328 go wake those maids. Flick [them]_p7329 in the face with a wet towel, and flick [them]_p7330 hard. Make [them]_p7331 get heat and fire and a warm bath. This poor soul is nearly as cold as that beside her. [She]_p7332 will need be heated before [we]_p7333 can do anything more. "  [I]_p7334 went at once, and found little difficulty in waking three of the women.

The fourth was only a [young]_n809 girl, and the drug had evidently affected [her]_p7335 more strongly, so [I]_p7338 lifted [her]_p7336 on the sofa and let [her]_p7336 sleep. The others were dazed at first, but as remembrance came back to [them]_p7339 [they]_p7340 cried and sobbed in a hysterical manner. [I]_p7341 was stern with them, however, and would not let [them]_p7342 talk. [I]_p7344 told [them]_p7345 that one life was bad enough to lose, and that if [they]_p7346 delayed [they]_p7347 would sacrifice Miss Lucy. So, sobbing and crying, [they]_p7348 went about [their]_p7350 way, half clad as [they]_p7349 were, and prepared fire and water. Fortunately, the kitchen and boiler fires were still alive, and there was no lack of hot water. [We]_p7351 got a bath and carried [Lucy]_n810 out as [she]_p7352 was and placed [her]_p7353 in it. Whilst [we]_p7354 were busy chafing [her]_p7355 limbs there was a knock at the hall door. One of the maids ran off, hurried on some more clothes, and opened it. Then [she]_p7356 returned and whispered to [us]_p7357 that there was a gentleman who had come with a message from Mr Holmwood.

[I]_p7358 bade [her]_p7359 simply tell [him]_p7360 that [he]_p7361 must wait, for [we]_p7362 could see no one now. [She]_p7363 went away with the message, and, engrossed with [our]_p7364 work, [I]_p7365 clean forgot all about him. [I]_p7366 never saw in all [my]_p7367 experience the [Professor]_n811 work in such deadly earnest. [I]_p7368 knew, as [he]_p7369 knew, that [it]_p7370 was a stand-up fight with death, and in a pause told [him]_p7371 so. [He]_p7372 answered [me]_p7373 in a way that [I]_p7374 did not understand, but with the sternest look that [his]_p7377 face could wear:,   "If that were all, [I]_p7375 would stop here where [we]_p7378 are now, and let [her]_p7379 fade away into peace, for [I]_p7375 see no light in life over [her]_p7380 horizon. " [He]_p7381 went on with [his]_p7382 work with, if possible, renewed and more frenzied vigour. Presently [we]_p7383 both began to be conscious that the heat was beginning to be of some effect. Lucy's heart beat a trifle more audibly to the stethoscope, and [her]_p7384 lungs had a perceptible movement. [Van Helsing]_n's812 face almost beamed, and as [we]_p7385 lifted [her]_p7386 from the bath and rolled [her]_p7387 in a hot sheet to dry [her]_p7387 [he]_p7391 said to me:, "The first gain is ours! Check to the King!" [We]_p7392 took Lucy into another room, which had by now been prepared, and laid [her]_p7388 in bed and forced a few drops of brandy down [her]_p7388 throat. [I]_p7393 noticed that [Van Helsing]_n813 tied a soft silk handkerchief round [her]_p7394 throat.

[She]_p7395 was still unconscious, and was quite as bad as, if not worse than, [we]_p7396 had ever seen her. [Van Helsing]_n814 called in one of the women, and told [her]_p7397 to stay with [her]_p7398 and not to take [her]_p7398 eyes off [her]_p7399 till [we]_p7401 returned, and then beckoned [me]_p7402 out of the room. "We must consult as to what is to be done," [he]_p7403 said as [we]_p7404 descended the stairs. In the hall [he]_p7405 opened the dining-room door, and [we]_p7407 passed in, [he]_p7406 closing the door carefully behind him. The shutters had been opened, but the blinds were already down, with that obedience to the etiquette of death which the [British]_n815 woman of the lower classes always rigidly observes. The room was, therefore, dimly dark. [It]_p7408 was, however, light enough for [our]_p7409 purposes. [Van Helsing]_n's816 sternness was somewhat relieved by a look of perplexity. [He]_p7410 was evidently torturing [his]_p7411 mind about something, so [I]_p7412 waited for an instant, and [he]_p7413 spoke:,   "What are [we]_p7414 to do now? Where are [we]_p7415 to turn for help? [We]_p7416 must have another transfusion of blood, and that soon, or that poor girl's life won't be worth an hour's purchase. [You]_p7417 are exhausted already [I]_p7418 am exhausted too.

[I]_p7419 fear to trust those women, even if [they]_p7420 would have courage to submit. What are [we]_p7421 to do for some one who will open [his]_p7422 veins for her?" "What's the matter with me, anyhow?" The voice came from the sofa across the room, and [its]_p7423 tones brought relief and joy to [my]_p7424 heart, for [they]_p7425 were those of [Quincey]_n817 Morris. [Van Helsing]_n818 started angrily at the first sound, but [his]_p7426 face softened and a glad look came into [his]_p7427 eyes as [I]_p7428 cried out: "[Quincey]_n819 Morris!" and rushed towards [him]_p7429 with outstretched hands. "What brought [you]_p7430 here?" [I]_p7431 cried as [our]_p7432 hands met. "I guess [Art]_n820 is the cause. " [He]_p7433 handed [me]_p7434 a telegram:, "Have not heard from [Seward]_n821 for three days, and am terribly anxious. Cannot leave. Father still in same condition. Send [me]_p7435 word how Lucy is. Do not delay.

, HOLMWOOD. "  "I think [I]_p7436 came just in the nick of time. [You]_p7438 know [you]_p7439 have only to tell [me]_p7440 what to do. " [Van Helsing]_n822 strode forward, and took [his]_p7441 hand, looking [him]_p7442 straight in the eyes as [he]_p7443 said:, "A brave man's blood is the best thing on this earth when a woman is in trouble. You're a man and no mistake. Well, the devil may work against [us]_p7444 for all he's worth, but God sends [us]_p7445 men when [we]_p7446 want them. "  Once again [we]_p7447 went through that ghastly operation. [I]_p7448 have not the heart to go through with the details. Lucy had got a terrible shock and [it]_p7449 told on [her]_p7450 more than before, for though plenty of blood went into [her]_p7451 veins, [her]_p7451 body did not respond to the treatment as well as on the other occasions. [Her]_p7453 struggle back into life was something frightful to see and hear.

However, the action of both heart and lungs improved, and [Van Helsing]_n823 made a subcutaneous injection of morphia, as before, and with good effect. [Her]_p7454 faint became a profound slumber. The [Professor]_n824 watched whilst [I]_p7455 went downstairs with [Quincey]_n825 Morris, and sent one of the maids to pay off one of the cabmen who were waiting. [I]_p7456 left [Quincey]_n826 lying down after having a glass of wine, and told the cook to get ready a good breakfast. Then a thought struck me, and [I]_p7457 went back to the room where Lucy now was. When [I]_p7458 came softly in, [I]_p7459 found [Van Helsing]_n827 with a sheet or two of note-paper in [his]_p7460 hand. [He]_p7461 had evidently read it, and was thinking [it]_p7462 over as [he]_p7464 sat with [his]_p7465 hand to [his]_p7466 brow. There was a look of grim satisfaction in [his]_p7467 face, as of one who has had a doubt solved. [He]_p7468 handed [me]_p7469 the paper saying only: "It dropped from Lucy's breast when [we]_p7470 carried [her]_p7471 to the bath. " When [I]_p7472 had read it, [I]_p7473 stood looking at the [Professor]_n,828 and after a pause asked him: "In God's name, what does [it]_p7476 all mean? Was she, or is she, mad or what sort of horrible danger is it?" [I]_p7473 was so bewildered that [I]_p7474 did not know what to say more.

[Van Helsing]_n829 put out [his]_p7479 hand and took the paper, saying:, "Do not trouble about [it]_p7480 now. Forget [it]_p7481 for the present. [You]_p7482 shall know and understand [it]_p7483 all in good time but [it]_p7484 will be later. And now what is [it]_p7485 that [you]_p7486 came to [me]_p7487 to say?" This brought [me]_p7488 back to fact, and [I]_p7489 was all [myself]_p7490 again. "I came to speak about the certificate of death. If [we]_p7491 do not act properly and wisely, there may be an inquest, and that paper would have to be produced. [I]_p7492 am in hopes that [we]_p7493 need have no inquest, for if [we]_p7494 had [it]_p7495 would surely kill [poor Lucy]_n,830 if nothing else did. [I]_p7496 know, and [you]_p7497 know, and the other doctor who attended [her]_p7498 knows, that Mrs Westenra had disease of the heart, and [we]_p7499 can certify that [she]_p7500 died of it. Let [us]_p7501 fill up the certificate at once, and [I]_p7502 shall take [it]_p7503 [myself]_p7504 to the registrar and go on to the undertaker. " "Good, oh [my]_p7505 friend John! Well thought of! [Truly]_n831 Miss Lucy, if [she]_p7506 be sad in the foes that beset her, is at least happy in the friends that love her.

One, two, three, all open [their]_p7507 veins for her, besides one old man. Ah yes, [I]_p7508 know, friend John [I]_p7509 am not blind! [I]_p7509 love [you]_p7511 all the more for it! Now go. " In the hall [I]_p7512 met [Quincey]_n832 Morris, with a telegram for [Arthur]_n833 telling [him]_p7514 that Mrs Westenra was dead that Lucy also had been ill, but was now going on better and that [Van Helsing]_n834 and [I]_p7513 were with her. [I]_p7515 told [him]_p7520 where [I]_p7516 was going, and [he]_p7521 hurried [me]_p7522 out, but as [I]_p7516 was going said:, "When [you]_p7523 come back, [Jack]_n,835 may [I]_p7517 have two words with [you]_p7524 all to ourselves?" [I]_p7517 nodded in reply and went out. [I]_p7525 found no difficulty about the registration, and arranged with the local undertaker to come up in the evening to measure for the coffin and to make arrangements. When [I]_p7526 got back [Quincey]_n836 was waiting for me. [I]_p7527 told [him]_p7530 [I]_p7528 would see [him]_p7531 as soon as [I]_p7528 knew about Lucy, and went up to [her]_p7532 room. [She]_p7533 was still sleeping, and the [Professor]_n837 seemingly had not moved from [his]_p7534 seat at [her]_p7535 side. From [his]_p7536 putting [his]_p7537 finger to [his]_p7537 lips, [I]_p7539 gathered that [he]_p7540 expected [her]_p7541 to wake before long and was afraid of forestalling nature. So [I]_p7542 went down to [Quincey]_n838 and took [him]_p7543 into the breakfast-room, where the blinds were not drawn down, and which was a little more cheerful, or rather less cheerless, than the other rooms.

When [we]_p7544 were alone, [he]_p7545 said to me:, "[Jack]_n839 [Seward]_n,840 [I]_p7546 don't want to shove [myself]_p7548 in anywhere where I've no right to be but this is no ordinary case. [You]_p7549 know [I]_p7550 loved that girl and wanted to marry [her]_p7552 but, although that's all past and gone, [I]_p7551 can't help feeling anxious about [her]_p7553 all the same. What is [it]_p7554 that's wrong with her? The Dutchman, and a fine old fellow [he]_p7555 is [I]_p7557 can see that, said, that time [you]_p7558 two came into the room, that [you]_p7559 must have another transfusion of blood, and that both [you]_p7559 and [he]_p7556 were exhausted. Now [I]_p7561 know well that [you]_p7562 medical men speak in camera, and that a man must not expect to know what [they]_p7563 consult about in private. But this is no common matter, and, whatever [it]_p7564 is, [I]_p7565 have done [my]_p7566 part. Is not that so?" "That's so," [I]_p7567 said, and [he]_p7570 went on:, "I take [it]_p7571 that both [you]_p7572 and [Van Helsing]_n841 had done already what [I]_p7568 did to-day. Is not that so?"  "That's so. " "And [I]_p7573 guess [Art]_n842 was in [it]_p7574 too. When [I]_p7575 saw [him]_p7576 four days ago down at [his]_p7577 own place [he]_p7578 looked queer. [I]_p7579 have not seen anything pulled down so quick since [I]_p7580 was on the Pampas and had a mare that [I]_p7580 was fond of go to grass all in a night.

One of those big bats that [they]_p7582 call vampires had got at [her]_p7583 in the night, and what with [his]_p7587 gorge and the vein left open, there wasn't enough blood in [her]_p7584 to let [her]_p7584 stand up, and [I]_p7588 had to put a bullet through [her]_p7585 as [she]_p7589 lay. [Jack]_n,843 if [you]_p7590 may tell [me]_p7591 without betraying confidence, [Arthur]_n844 was the first, is not that so?" As [he]_p7592 spoke the poor fellow looked terribly anxious. [He]_p7593 was in a torture of suspense regarding the woman [he]_p7594 loved, and [his]_p7595 utter ignorance of the terrible mystery which seemed to surround [her]_p7597 intensified [his]_p7596 pain. [His]_p7598 very heart was bleeding, and [it]_p7599 took all the manhood of him, and there was a royal lot of it, too, to keep [him]_p7601 from breaking down. [I]_p7603 paused before answering, for [I]_p7604 felt that [I]_p7604 must not betray anything which the [Professor]_n845 wished kept secret but already [he]_p7607 knew so much, and guessed so much, that there could be no reason for not answering, so [I]_p7605 answered in the same phrase: "That's so. "  "And how long has this been going on?"  "About ten days. " "Ten days! Then [I]_p7608 guess, [Jack]_n846 [Seward]_n,847 that that poor pretty creature that [we]_p7609 all love has had put into [her]_p7610 veins within that time the blood of four strong men. Man alive, [her]_p7611 whole body wouldn't hold it. " Then, coming close to me, [he]_p7612 spoke in a fierce half-whisper: "What took [it]_p7613 out?"  [I]_p7614 shook [my]_p7615 head. "That," [I]_p7616 said, "is the crux.

[Van Helsing]_n848 is simply frantic about it, and [I]_p7617 am at [my]_p7618 wits' end. [I]_p7619 can't even hazard a guess. There has been a series of little circumstances which have thrown out all [our]_p7620 calculations as to Lucy being properly watched. But these shall not occur again. Here [we]_p7621 stay until all be well, or ill. " [Quincey]_n849 held out [his]_p7622 hand. "Count [me]_p7623 in," [he]_p7624 said. "You and the Dutchman will tell [me]_p7625 what to do, and I'll do it. " When [she]_p7626 woke late in the afternoon, Lucy's first movement was to feel in [her]_p7627 breast, and, to [my]_p7628 surprise, produced the paper which [Van Helsing]_n850 had given [me]_p7629 to read. The careful [Professor]_n851 had replaced [it]_p7630 where [it]_p7631 had come from, lest on waking [she]_p7632 should be alarmed.

[Her]_p7633 eye then lit on [Van Helsing]_n852 and on [me]_p7634 too, and gladdened. Then [she]_p7635 looked around the room, and seeing where [she]_p7636 was, shuddered [she]_p7636 gave a loud cry, and put [her]_p7638 poor thin hands before [her]_p7639 pale face. [We]_p7640 both understood what that meant, that [she]_p7641 had realised to the full [her]_p7642 mother's death so [we]_p7644 tried what [we]_p7645 could to comfort her. Doubtless sympathy eased [her]_p7646 somewhat, but [she]_p7647 was very low in thought and spirit, and wept silently and weakly for a long time. [We]_p7648 told [her]_p7649 that either or both of [us]_p7652 would now remain with [her]_p7650 all the time, and that seemed to comfort her. Towards dusk [she]_p7653 fell into a doze. Here a very odd thing occurred. Whilst still asleep [she]_p7654 took the paper from [her]_p7655 breast and tore [it]_p7656 in two. [Van Helsing]_n853 stepped over and took the pieces from her. All the same, however, [she]_p7657 went on with the action of tearing, as though the material were still in [her]_p7659 hands finally [she]_p7658 lifted [her]_p7660 hands and opened [them]_p7661 as though scattering the fragments.

[Van Helsing]_n854 seemed surprised, and [his]_p7662 brows gathered as if in thought, but [he]_p7663 said nothing. * * * * *  19 September. , All last night [she]_p7664 slept fitfully, being always afraid to sleep, and something weaker when [she]_p7665 woke from it. The [Professor]_n855 and [I]_p7666 took [it]_p7667 in turns to watch, and [we]_p7668 never left [her]_p7669 for a moment unattended. [Quincey]_n856 Morris said nothing about [his]_p7670 intention, but [I]_p7671 knew that all night long [he]_p7672 patrolled round and round the house. When the day came, [its]_p7673 searching light showed the ravages in poor Lucy's strength. [She]_p7674 was hardly able to turn [her]_p7675 head, and the little nourishment which [she]_p7677 could take seemed to do [her]_p7676 no good. At times [she]_p7678 slept, and both [Van Helsing]_n857 and [I]_p7679 noticed the difference in her, between sleeping and waking. Whilst asleep [she]_p7680 looked stronger, although more haggard, and [her]_p7683 breathing was softer [her]_p7684 open mouth showed the pale gums drawn back from the teeth, which thus looked positively longer and sharper than usual when [she]_p7681 woke the softness of [her]_p7684 eyes evidently changed the expression, for [she]_p7681 looked [her]_p7685 own self, although a dying one. In the afternoon [she]_p7687 asked for [Arthur]_n,858 and [we]_p7688 telegraphed for him.

[Quincey]_n859 went off to meet [him]_p7689 at the station. When [he]_p7690 arrived [it]_p7691 was nearly six o'clock, and the sun was setting full and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks. When [he]_p7692 saw her, [Arthur]_n860 was simply choking with emotion, and none of [us]_p7693 could speak. In the hours that had passed, the fits of sleep, or the comatose condition that passed for it, had grown more frequent, so that the pauses when conversation was possible were shortened. [Arthur]_n's861 presence, however, seemed to act as a stimulant [she]_p7694 rallied a little, and spoke to [him]_p7696 more brightly than [she]_p7695 had done since [we]_p7697 arrived. [He]_p7698 too pulled [himself]_p7699 together, and spoke as cheerily as [he]_p7700 could, so that the best was made of everything. [It]_p7701 was now nearly one o'clock, and [he]_p7702 and [Van Helsing]_n862 are sitting with her. [I]_p7703 am to relieve [them]_p7705 in a quarter of an hour, and [I]_p7704 am entering this on Lucy's phonograph. Until six o'clock [they]_p7706 are to try to [rest]_n863. [I]_p7707 fear that to-morrow will end [our]_p7708 watching, for the shock has been too great the poor child cannot rally.

God help [us]_p7709 all. Letter, Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra. (Unopened by her. )  "17 September. "My dearest Lucy,,   "It seems an age since [I]_p7710 heard from you, or indeed since [I]_p7711 wrote. [You]_p7712 will pardon me, [I]_p7713 know, for all [my]_p7714 faults when [you]_p7716 have read all [my]_p7715 budget of news. Well, [I]_p7717 got [my]_p7718 husband back all right when [we]_p7719 arrived at [Exeter]_n864 there was a carriage waiting for us, and in it, though [he]_p7720 had an attack of gout, Mr Hawkins. [He]_p7721 took [us]_p7722 to [his]_p7724 house, where there were rooms for [us]_p7723 all nice and comfortable, and [we]_p7725 dined together. After dinner Mr Hawkins said:,   "'My dears, [I]_p7726 want to drink [your]_p7727 health and prosperity and may every blessing attend [you]_p7728 both. [I]_p7729 know [you]_p7730 both from children, and have, with love and pride, seen [you]_p7731 grow up.

Now [I]_p7732 want [you]_p7733 to make [your]_p7734 home here with me. [I]_p7735 have left to [me]_p7737 neither chick nor child all are gone, and in [my]_p7738 will [I]_p7736 have left [you]_p7739 everything. ' [I]_p7740 cried, [Lucy]_n865 [dear]_n,866 as Jonathan and the old man clasped hands. [Our]_p7741 evening was a very, very happy one. "So here [we]_p7742 are, installed in this beautiful old house, and from both [my]_p7743 bedroom and the drawing-room [I]_p7744 can see the great elms of the cathedral close, with [their]_p7746 great black stems standing out against the old yellow stone of the cathedral and [I]_p7745 can hear the rooks overhead cawing and cawing and chattering and gossiping all day, after the manner of rooks, and humans. [I]_p7747 am busy, [I]_p7748 need not tell you, arranging things and housekeeping. Jonathan and Mr Hawkins are busy all day for, now that Jonathan is a partner, Mr Hawkins wants to tell [him]_p7749 all about the clients. "How is [your]_p7750 [dear]_n867 mother getting on? [I]_p7751 wish [I]_p7752 could run up to town for a day or two to see you, [dear]_n,868 but [I]_p7752 dare not go yet, with so much on [my]_p7754 shoulders and Jonathan wants looking after still. [He]_p7755 is beginning to put some flesh on [his]_p7756 bones again, but [he]_p7759 was terribly weakened by the long illness even now [he]_p7760 sometimes starts out of [his]_p7757 sleep in a sudden way and awakes all trembling until [I]_p7761 can coax [him]_p7762 back to [his]_p7757 usual placidity. However, thank God, these occasions grow less frequent as the days go on, and [they]_p7763 will in time pass away altogether, [I]_p7764 trust.

And now [I]_p7765 have told [you]_p7766 [my]_p7767 news, let [me]_p7768 ask yours. When are [you]_p7769 to be married, and where, and who is to perform the ceremony, and what are [you]_p7770 to wear, and is [it]_p7772 to be a public or a private wedding? Tell [me]_p7774 all about it, [dear]_n869 tell [me]_p7775 all about everything, for there is nothing which interests [you]_p7770 which will not be [dear]_n870 to me. Jonathan asks [me]_p7777 to send [his]_p7780 'respectful duty,' but [I]_p7782 do not think that is good enough from the junior partner of the important firm Hawkins & Harker and so, as [you]_p7785 love me, and [he]_p7788 loves me, and [I]_p7783 love [you]_p7786 with all the moods and tenses of the verb, [I]_p7783 send [you]_p7786 simply [his]_p7781 'love' instead. Good-bye, [my]_p7789 dearest Lucy, and all blessings on you. "Yours, "[MINA HARKER]_n871. "   Report from Patrick Hennessey, M. D. , M. R. C.
S. L. K. Q. C. P. I. , etc. , etc. , to [John Seward]_n,872 M.

D. "20 September. "My [dear]_n873 Sir,, "In accordance with [your]_p7790 wishes, [I]_p7791 enclose report of the conditions of everything left in [my]_p7792 charge. With regard to patient, Renfield, there is more to say. [He]_p7793 has had another outbreak, which might have had a dreadful ending, but which, as [it]_p7794 fortunately happened, was unattended with any unhappy results. This afternoon a carrier's cart with two men made a call at the empty house whose grounds abut on ours, the house to which, [you]_p7795 will remember, the patient twice ran away. The men stopped at [our]_p7796 gate to ask the porter [their]_p7797 way, as [they]_p7798 were strangers. [I]_p7799 was [myself]_p7800 looking out of the study window, having a smoke after dinner, and saw one of [them]_p7801 come up to the house. As [he]_p7802 passed the window of Renfield's room, the patient began to rate [him]_p7804 from within, and called [him]_p7805 all the foul names [he]_p7803 could lay [his]_p7806 tongue to. The man, who seemed a decent fellow enough, contented [himself]_p7807 by telling [him]_p7808 to "shut up for a foul-mouthed beggar," whereon [our]_p7813 man accused [him]_p7809 of robbing [him]_p7809 and wanting to murder [him]_p7810 and said that [he]_p7814 would hinder [him]_p7810 if [he]_p7815 were to swing for it.

[I]_p7816 opened the window and signed to the man not to notice, so [he]_p7818 contented [himself]_p7820 after looking the place over and making up [his]_p7821 mind as to what kind of a place [he]_p7819 had got to by saying: 'Lor' bless yer, sir, [I]_p7817 wouldn't mind what was said to [me]_p7822 in a bloomin' madhouse. [I]_p7823 pity [ye]_p7824 and the guv'nor for havin' to live in the house with a wild beast like that. ' Then [he]_p7825 asked [his]_p7827 way civilly enough, and [I]_p7828 told [him]_p7829 where the gate of the empty house was [he]_p7826 went away, followed by threats and curses and revilings from [our]_p7830 man. [I]_p7831 went down to see if [I]_p7832 could make out any cause for [his]_p7833 anger, since [he]_p7835 is usually such a well-behaved man, and except [his]_p7834 violent fits nothing of the kind had ever occurred. [I]_p7836 found him, to [my]_p7837 astonishment, quite composed and most genial in [his]_p7838 manner. [I]_p7839 tried to get [him]_p7841 to talk of the incident, but [he]_p7842 blandly asked [me]_p7844 questions as to what [I]_p7840 meant, and led [me]_p7845 to believe that [he]_p7843 was completely oblivious of the affair. [It]_p7846 was, [I]_p7847 am sorry to say, however, only another instance of [his]_p7849 cunning, for within half an hour [I]_p7848 heard of [him]_p7850 again. This time [he]_p7851 had broken out through the window of [his]_p7852 room, and was running down the avenue. [I]_p7853 called to the attendants to follow me, and ran after him, for [I]_p7854 feared [he]_p7855 was intent on some mischief. [My]_p7856 fear was justified when [I]_p7857 saw the same cart which had passed before coming down the road, having on [it]_p7858 some great wooden boxes.

The men were wiping [their]_p7859 foreheads, and were flushed in the face, as if with violent exercise. Before [I]_p7860 could get up to [him]_p7861 the patient rushed at them, and pulling one of [them]_p7862 off the cart, began to knock [his]_p7864 head against the ground. If [I]_p7865 had not seized [him]_p7867 just at the moment [I]_p7866 believe [he]_p7868 would have killed the man there and then. The other fellow jumped down and struck [him]_p7869 over the head with the butt-end of [his]_p7870 heavy whip. [It]_p7871 was a terrible blow but [he]_p7872 did not seem to mind it, but seized [him]_p7873 also, and struggled with the three of us, pulling [us]_p7874 to and fro as if [we]_p7876 were kittens. [You]_p7877 know [I]_p7878 am no light weight, and the others were both burly men. At first [he]_p7879 was silent in [his]_p7881 fighting but as [we]_p7882 began to master him, and the attendants were putting a strait-waistcoat on him, [he]_p7880 began to shout: 'I'll frustrate them! [They]_p7883 shan't rob me! [they]_p7886 shan't murder [me]_p7884 by inches! I'll fight for [my]_p7887 [Lord]_n874 and Master!' and all sorts of similar incoherent ravings. [It]_p7888 was with very considerable difficulty that [they]_p7889 got [him]_p7890 back to the house and put [him]_p7891 in the padded room. One of the attendants, Hardy, had a finger broken. However, [I]_p7892 set [it]_p7893 all right and [he]_p7894 is going on well.

"The two carriers were at first loud in [their]_p7895 threats of actions for damages, and promised to rain all the penalties of the law on us. [Their]_p7896 threats were, however, mingled with some sort of indirect apology for the defeat of the two of [them]_p7897 by a feeble madman. [They]_p7898 said that if [it]_p7899 had not been for the way [their]_p7900 strength had been spent in carrying and raising the heavy boxes to the cart [they]_p7901 would have made short work of him. [They]_p7902 gave as another reason for [their]_p7903 defeat the extraordinary state of drouth to which [they]_p7906 had been reduced by the dusty nature of [their]_p7904 occupation and the reprehensible distance from the scene of [their]_p7904 labours of any place of public entertainment. [I]_p7907 quite understood [their]_p7908 drift, and after a stiff glass of grog, or rather more of the same, and with each a sovereign in hand, [they]_p7909 made light of the attack, and swore that [they]_p7910 would encounter a worse madman any day for the pleasure of meeting so 'bloomin' good a bloke' as [your]_p7911 correspondent. [I]_p7912 took [their]_p7913 names and addresses, in case [they]_p7914 might be needed. [They]_p7915 are as follows:, Jack Smollet, of Dudding's Rents, King George's Road, Great Walworth, and Thomas Snelling, Peter [Farley]_n's875 Row, Guide Court, Bethnal Green. [They]_p7916 are both in the employment of Harris & Sons, Moving and Shipment Company, Orange Master's Yard, Soho. "   Letter, Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra. (Unopened by her. )  "18 September. "My dearest Lucy,,   "Such a sad blow has befallen us. Mr Hawkins has died very suddenly. [He]_p7934 says the amount of responsibility which [it]_p7935 puts upon [him]_p7936 makes [him]_p7937 nervous.

[He]_p7938 begins to doubt himself. [I]_p7939 try to cheer [him]_p7940 up, and [my]_p7943 belief in [him]_p7941 helps [him]_p7941 to have a belief in himself. But [it]_p7944 is here that the grave shock that [he]_p7945 experienced tells upon [him]_p7946 the most. Oh, [it]_p7947 is too hard that a sweet, simple, noble, strong nature such as his, a nature which enabled [him]_p7948 by [our]_p7949 [dear]_n,880 good friend's aid to rise from clerk to master in a few years, should be so injured that the very essence of [its]_p7950 strength is gone. Forgive me, [dear]_n,881 if [I]_p7951 worry [you]_p7955 with [my]_p7956 troubles in the midst of [your]_p7957 own happiness but, [Lucy]_n882 [dear]_n,883 [I]_p7952 must tell some one, for the strain of keeping up a brave and cheerful appearance to Jonathan tries me, and [I]_p7952 have no one here that [I]_p7953 can confide in. [I]_p7958 dread coming up to London, as [we]_p7959 must do the day after to-morrow for poor [Mr Hawkins]_n884 left in [his]_p7960 will that [he]_p7962 was to be buried in the grave with [his]_p7961 father. As there are no relations at all, Jonathan will have to be chief mourner. [I]_p7963 shall try to run over to see you, dearest, if only for a few minutes. Forgive [me]_p7964 for troubling you. With all blessings, "Your loving "[MINA HARKER]_n885.

" [Dr Seward]_n's886 [Diary]_n887. 20 September. , Only resolution and habit can let [me]_p7965 make an entry [to-night]_n888. [I]_p7999 could see that the [Professor]_n896 had carried out in this room, as in the other, [his]_p8000 purpose of using the garlic the whole of the window-sashes reeked with it, and round Lucy's neck, over the silk handkerchief which [Van Helsing]_n897 made [her]_p8001 keep on, was a rough chaplet of the same odorous flowers. " "The [Westminster Gazette]_n,"1040 25 September. A [HAMPSTEAD]_n1041 MYSTERY. The neighbourhood of Hampstead is just at present exercised with a series of events which seem to run on lines parallel to those of what was known to the writers of headlines as "The [Kensington]_n1042 Horror," or "The Stabbing Woman," or "The Woman in Black. " During the past two or three days several cases have occurred of [young]_n1043 children straying from home or neglecting to return from [their]_p9075 playing on the Heath. In all these cases the children were too [young]_n1044 to give any properly intelligible account of themselves, but the consensus of [their]_p9076 excuses is that [they]_p9077 had been with a "bloofer lady. " [It]_p9078 has always been late in the evening when [they]_p9079 have been missed, and on two occasions the children have not been found until early in the following morning.

[It]_p9080 is generally supposed in the neighbourhood that, as the first child missed gave as [his]_p9081 reason for being away that a "bloofer lady" had asked [him]_p9082 to come for a walk, the others had picked up the phrase and used [it]_p9083 as occasion served. This is the more natural as the favourite game of the little ones at present is luring each other away by wiles. A correspondent writes [us]_p9084 that to see some of the tiny tots pretending to be the "bloofer lady" is supremely funny. Some of [our]_p9085 caricaturists might, [he]_p9086 says, take a lesson in the irony of grotesque by comparing the reality and the picture. [It]_p9087 is only in accordance with general principles of human nature that the "bloofer lady" should be the popular r le at these al fresco performances. [Our]_p9088 correspondent na vely says that even [Ellen Terry]_n1045 could not be so winningly attractive as some of these grubby-faced little children pretend, and even imagine themselves, to be. There is, however, possibly a serious side to the question, for some of the children, indeed all who have been missed at night, have been slightly torn or wounded in the throat. The wounds seem such as might be made by a rat or a small dog, and although of not much importance individually, would tend to show that whatever animal inflicts [them]_p9089 has a system or method of [its]_p9090 own. The police of the division have been instructed to keep a sharp look-out for straying children, especially when very [young]_n,1046 in and around [Hampstead Heath]_n,1047 and for any stray dog which may be about. "[VAN]_n1228 HELSING. " [Dr Seward]_n's1229 [Diary]_n1230. 28 September. , [It]_p10599 is wonderful what a good night's sleep will do for one. " CHAPTER XVI [DR]_n1272. SEWARD'S DIARY, continued   [It]_p10840 was just a quarter before twelve o'clock when [we]_p10841 got into the churchyard over the low wall. The coffin was empty!  For several minutes no one spoke a word. The silence was broken by [Quincey]_n1283 Morris:, "[Professor]_n,1284 [I]_p10868 answered for you. "  "That night [we]_p10887 were just in time. One more so small child was missing, and [we]_p10888 find it, thank God, unharmed amongst the graves. So", here [he]_p10902 shut the dark slide of [his]_p10903 lantern, "now to the outside. [Arthur]_n1295 and [Quincey]_n1296 drew near also, as [they]_p10933 too were curious. [He]_p10934 answered:, "I am closing the tomb, so that the [Un-Dead]_n1297 may not enter. " "And is that stuff [you]_p10935 have put there going to do it?" asked [Quincey]_n1298. "[Great]_n1299 Scott! Is this a game?" "It is. " "What is that which [you]_p10936 are using?" " [It]_p10942 was an answer that appalled the most sceptical of us, and [we]_p10943 felt individually that in the presence of such earnest purpose as the [Professor]_n's,1303 a purpose which could thus use the to [him]_p10944 most sacred of things, [it]_p10945 was impossible to distrust. [Dr Seward]_n's1399 [Diary]_n1400. 29 September. , [I]_p11594 was so absorbed in that wonderful diary of Jonathan Harker and that other of [his]_p11596 wife that [I]_p11595 let the time run on without thinking.
