Then [he]_p13260 spoke:,   "My friends, [we]_p13261 are going into a terrible danger, and [we]_p13262 need arms of many kinds.

[Our]_p13263 enemy is not merely spiritual. Remember that [he]_p13264 has the strength of twenty men, and that, though [our]_p13265 necks or [our]_p13266 windpipes are of the common kind, and therefore breakable or crushable, [his]_p13267 are not amenable to mere strength. A stronger man, or a body of men more strong in all than him, can at certain times hold [him]_p13268 but [they]_p13272 cannot hurt [him]_p13269 as [we]_p13273 can be hurt by him. [We]_p13274 must, therefore, guard [ourselves]_p13275 from [his]_p13276 touch. Keep this near [your]_p13277 heart", as [he]_p13280 spoke [he]_p13281 lifted a little silver crucifix and held [it]_p13283 out to me, [I]_p13286 being nearest to him, "put these flowers round [your]_p13278 neck", here [he]_p13281 handed to [me]_p13284 a wreath of withered garlic blossoms, "for other enemies more mundane, this revolver and this knife and for aid in all, these so small electric lamps, which [you]_p13287 can fasten to [your]_p13278 breast and for all, and above all at the last, this, which [we]_p13288 must not desecrate needless. " This was a portion of Sacred Wafer, which [he]_p13289 put in an envelope and handed to me. Each of the others was similarly equipped. "Now," [he]_p13290 said, "friend John, where are the skeleton keys? If so that [we]_p13291 can open the door, [we]_p13292 need not break house by the window, as before at Miss Lucy's. " Dr [Seward]_n1590 tried one or two skeleton keys, [his]_p13293 mechanical dexterity as a surgeon standing [him]_p13294 in good stead. Presently [he]_p13295 got one to suit after a little play back and forward the bolt yielded, and, with a rusty clang, shot back.

[We]_p13296 pressed on the door, the rusty hinges creaked, and [it]_p13297 slowly opened. [It]_p13298 was startlingly like the image conveyed to [me]_p13299 in Dr [Seward]_n's1591 diary of the opening of Miss Westenra's tomb [I]_p13300 fancy that the same idea seemed to strike the others, for with one accord [they]_p13301 shrank back. The [Professor]_n1592 was the first to move forward, and stepped into the open door. "In manus tuas, Domine!" [he]_p13302 said, crossing [himself]_p13304 as [he]_p13303 passed over the threshold. [We]_p13305 closed the door behind us, lest when [we]_p13306 should have lit [our]_p13308 lamps [we]_p13307 should possibly attract attention from the road. The [Professor]_n1593 carefully tried the lock, lest [we]_p13309 might not be able to open [it]_p13311 from within should [we]_p13310 be in a hurry making [our]_p13312 exit. Then [we]_p13313 all lit [our]_p13314 lamps and proceeded on [our]_p13315 search. The light from the tiny lamps fell in all sorts of odd forms, as the rays crossed each other, or the opacity of [our]_p13316 bodies threw great shadows. [I]_p13317 could not for [my]_p13318 life get away from the feeling that there was some one else amongst us. [I]_p13319 suppose [it]_p13320 was the recollection, so powerfully brought home to [me]_p13321 by the grim surroundings, of that terrible experience in [Transylvania]_n1594.

[I]_p13322 think the feeling was common to [us]_p13325 all, for [I]_p13323 noticed that the others kept looking over [their]_p13326 shoulders at every sound and every new shadow, just as [I]_p13323 felt [myself]_p13327 doing. The whole place was thick with dust. The floor was seemingly inches deep, except where there were recent footsteps, in which on holding down [my]_p13328 lamp [I]_p13329 could see marks of hobnails where the dust was cracked. The walls were fluffy and heavy with dust, and in the corners were masses of spider's webs, whereon the dust had gathered till [they]_p13330 looked like old tattered rags as the weight had torn [them]_p13331 partly down. On a table in the hall was a great bunch of keys, with a time-yellowed label on each. [They]_p13332 had been used several times, for on the table were several similar rents in the blanket of dust, similar to that exposed when the [Professor]_n1595 lifted them. [He]_p13333 turned to [me]_p13334 and said:, "You know this place, [Jonathan]_n1596. [You]_p13335 have copied maps of it, and [you]_p13338 know [it]_p13336 at least more than [we]_p13339 do. Which is the way to the chapel?" [I]_p13340 had an idea of [its]_p13343 direction, though on [my]_p13344 former visit [I]_p13341 had not been able to get admission to [it]_p13345 so [I]_p13341 led the way, and after a few wrong turnings found [myself]_p13346 opposite a low, arched oaken door, ribbed with iron bands. "This is the spot," said the [Professor]_n1597 as [he]_p13347 turned [his]_p13348 lamp on a small map of the house, copied from the file of [my]_p13349 original correspondence regarding the purchase.

With a little trouble [we]_p13350 found the key on the bunch and opened the door. [We]_p13351 were prepared for some unpleasantness, for as [we]_p13352 were opening the door a faint, malodorous air seemed to exhale through the gaps, but none of [us]_p13354 ever expected such an odour as [we]_p13353 encountered. None of the others had met the Count at all at close quarters, and when [I]_p13355 had seen [him]_p13356 [he]_p13357 was either in the fasting stage of [his]_p13359 existence in [his]_p13360 rooms or, when [he]_p13358 was gloated with fresh blood, in a ruined building open to the air but here the place was small and close, and the long disuse had made the air stagnant and foul. There was an earthy smell, as of some dry miasma, which came through the fouler air. But as to the odour itself, how shall [I]_p13363 describe it? [It]_p13367 was not alone that [it]_p13364 was composed of all the ills of mortality and with the pungent, acrid smell of blood, but [it]_p13365 seemed as though corruption had become [itself]_p13361 corrupt. Faugh! [it]_p13368 sickens [me]_p13370 to think of it. Every breath exhaled by that monster seemed to have clung to the place and intensified [its]_p13371 loathsomeness. Under ordinary circumstances such a stench would have brought [our]_p13372 enterprise to an end but this was no ordinary case, and the high and terrible purpose in which [we]_p13373 were involved gave [us]_p13374 a strength which rose above merely physical considerations. After the involuntary shrinking consequent on the first nauseous whiff, [we]_p13375 one and all set about [our]_p13376 work as though that loathsome place were a garden of roses. [We]_p13377 made an accurate examination of the place, the [Professor]_n1598 saying as [we]_p13378 began:, "The first thing is to see how many of the boxes are left [we]_p13379 must then examine every hole and corner and cranny and see if [we]_p13379 cannot get some clue as to what has become of the rest.

" A glance was sufficient to show how many remained, for the great earth chests were bulky, and there was no mistaking them. There were only twenty-nine left out of the fifty! Once [I]_p13381 got a fright, for, seeing [Lord]_n1599 [Godalming]_n1600 suddenly turn and look out of the vaulted door into the dark passage beyond, [I]_p13382 looked too, and for an instant [my]_p13383 heart stood still. Somewhere, looking out from the shadow, [I]_p13384 seemed to see the high lights of the Count's evil face, the ridge of the nose, the red eyes, the red lips, the awful pallor. [It]_p13385 was only for a moment, for, as [Lord]_n1601 [Godalming]_n1602 said, "I thought [I]_p13386 saw a face, but [it]_p13389 was only the shadows," and resumed [his]_p13390 inquiry, [I]_p13387 turned [my]_p13391 lamp in the direction, and stepped into the passage. There was no sign of any one and as there were no corners, no doors, no aperture of any kind, but only the solid walls of the passage, there could be no hiding-place even for him. [I]_p13392 took [it]_p13393 that fear had helped imagination, and said nothing. A few minutes later [I]_p13394 saw Morris step suddenly back from a corner, which [he]_p13395 was examining. [We]_p13396 all followed [his]_p13397 movements with [our]_p13398 eyes, for undoubtedly some nervousness was growing on us, and [we]_p13399 saw a whole mass of phosphorescence, which twinkled like stars. [We]_p13400 all instinctively drew back. The whole place was becoming alive with rats.

For a moment or two [we]_p13401 stood appalled, all [save Lord Godalming]_n,1603 who was seemingly prepared for such an emergency. Rushing over to the great iron-bound oaken door, which Dr [Seward]_n1604 had described from the outside, and which [I]_p13402 had seen myself, [he]_p13403 turned the key in the lock, drew the huge bolts, and swung the door open. Then, taking [his]_p13404 little silver whistle from [his]_p13405 pocket, [he]_p13406 blew a low, shrill call. [It]_p13407 was answered from behind [Dr Seward]_n's1605 house by the yelping of dogs, and after about a minute three terriers came dashing round the corner of the house. Unconsciously [we]_p13408 had all moved towards the door, and as [we]_p13409 moved [I]_p13410 noticed that the dust had been much disturbed: the boxes which had been taken out had been brought this way. But even in the minute that had elapsed the number of the rats had vastly increased. [They]_p13411 seemed to swarm over the place all at once, till the lamplight, shining on [their]_p13412 moving dark bodies and glittering, baleful eyes, made the place look like a bank of earth set with fireflies. The dogs dashed on, but at the threshold suddenly stopped and snarled, and then, simultaneously lifting [their]_p13413 noses, began to howl in most lugubrious fashion. The rats were multiplying in thousands, and [we]_p13414 moved out. [Lord Godalming]_n1606 lifted one of the dogs, and carrying [him]_p13415 in, placed [him]_p13416 on the floor.

The instant [his]_p13417 feet touched the ground [he]_p13420 seemed to recover [his]_p13418 courage, and rushed at [his]_p13418 natural enemies. [They]_p13421 fled before [him]_p13422 so fast that before [he]_p13423 had shaken the life out of a score, the other dogs, who had by now been lifted in the same manner, had but small prey ere the whole mass had vanished. With [their]_p13424 going [it]_p13426 seemed as if some evil presence had departed, for the dogs frisked about and barked merrily as [they]_p13427 made sudden darts at [their]_p13425 prostrate foes, and turned [them]_p13428 over and over and tossed [them]_p13429 in the air with vicious shakes. [We]_p13430 all seemed to find [our]_p13431 spirits rise. Whether [it]_p13432 was the purifying of the deadly atmosphere by the opening of the chapel door, or the relief which [we]_p13433 experienced by finding [ourselves]_p13435 in the open [I]_p13436 know not but most certainly the shadow of dread seemed to slip from [us]_p13437 like a robe, and the occasion of [our]_p13438 coming lost something of [its]_p13440 grim significance, though [we]_p13434 did not slacken a whit in [our]_p13439 resolution. [We]_p13441 closed the outer door and barred and locked it, and bringing the dogs with us, began [our]_p13442 search of the house. [We]_p13443 found nothing throughout except dust in extraordinary proportions, and all untouched save for [my]_p13444 own footsteps when [I]_p13446 had made [my]_p13445 first visit. Never once did the dogs exhibit any symptom of uneasiness, and even when [we]_p13447 returned to the chapel [they]_p13448 frisked about as though [they]_p13449 had been rabbit-hunting in a summer wood. The morning was quickening in the east when [we]_p13450 emerged from the front. Dr [Van Helsing]_n1607 had taken the key of the hall-door from the bunch, and locked the door in orthodox fashion, putting the key into [his]_p13451 pocket when [he]_p13452 had done.

"So far," [he]_p13453 said, "our night has been eminently successful. No harm has come to [us]_p13454 such as [I]_p13455 feared might be and yet [we]_p13456 have ascertained how many boxes are missing. More than all do [I]_p13457 rejoice that this, [our]_p13458 first, and perhaps [our]_p13459 most difficult and dangerous, step has been accomplished without the bringing thereinto [our]_p13459 most sweet [Madam]_n1608 Mina or troubling [her]_p13461 waking or sleeping thoughts with sights and sounds and smells of horror which [she]_p13462 might never forget. One lesson, too, [we]_p13463 have learned, if [it]_p13464 be allowable to argue a particulari: that the brute beasts which are to the Count's command are yet [themselves]_p13465 not amenable to [his]_p13466 spiritual power for look, these rats that would come to [his]_p13467 call, just as from [his]_p13467 castle top [he]_p13469 summon the wolves to [your]_p13470 going and to that poor mother's cry, though [they]_p13471 come to him, [they]_p13472 run pell-mell from the so little dogs of [my]_p13473 friend Arthur. [We]_p13474 have other matters before us, other dangers, other fears and that monster, [he]_p13475 has not used [his]_p13476 power over the brute world for the only or the last time [to-night]_n1609. So be [it]_p13477 that [he]_p13478 has gone elsewhere. Good! [It]_p13479 has given [us]_p13480 opportunity to cry 'check' in some ways in this chess game, which [we]_p13481 play for the stake of human souls. And now let [us]_p13482 go home. The dawn is close at hand, and [we]_p13483 have reason to be content with [our]_p13484 first night's work. [It]_p13485 may be ordained that [we]_p13486 have many nights and days to follow, if full of peril  but [we]_p13487 must go on, and from no danger shall [we]_p13487 shrink.

"  The house was silent when [we]_p13489 got back, save for some poor creature who was screaming away in one of the distant wards, and a low, moaning sound from Renfield's room. The poor wretch was doubtless torturing himself, after the manner of the insane, with needless thoughts of pain. [I]_p13490 came tiptoe into [our]_p13492 own room, and found [Mina]_n1610 asleep, breathing so softly that [I]_p13491 had to put [my]_p13493 ear down to hear it. [She]_p13494 looks paler than usual. [I]_p13495 hope the meeting [to-night]_n1611 has not upset her. [I]_p13496 am truly thankful that [she]_p13497 is to be left out of [our]_p13498 future work, and even of [our]_p13499 deliberations. [It]_p13500 is too great a strain for a woman to bear. [I]_p13501 did not think so at first, but [I]_p13502 know better now. Therefore [I]_p13503 am glad that [it]_p13504 is settled. There may be things which would frighten [her]_p13505 to hear and yet to conceal [them]_p13508 from [her]_p13506 might be worse than to tell [her]_p13506 if once [she]_p13509 suspected that there was any concealment.

Henceforth [our]_p13510 work is to be a sealed book to her, till at least such time as [we]_p13513 can tell [her]_p13511 that all is finished, and the earth free from a monster of the nether world. [I]_p13514 daresay [it]_p13517 will be difficult to begin to keep silence after such confidence as ours but [I]_p13515 must be resolute, and to-morrow [I]_p13515 shall keep dark over [to-night]_n's1612 doings, and shall refuse to speak of anything that has happened. [I]_p13518 [rest]_n1613 on the sofa, so as not to disturb her. * * * * *  1 October, later. , [I]_p13519 suppose [it]_p13520 was natural that [we]_p13521 should have all overslept ourselves, for the day was a busy one, and the night had no [rest]_n1614 at all. Even Mina must have felt [its]_p13522 exhaustion, for though [I]_p13523 slept till the sun was high, [I]_p13524 was awake before her, and had to call two or three times before [she]_p13525 awoke. Indeed, [she]_p13526 was so sound asleep that for a few seconds [she]_p13527 did not recognize me, but looked at [me]_p13528 with a sort of blank terror, as one looks who has been waked out of a bad dream. [She]_p13530 complained a little of being tired, and [I]_p13531 let [her]_p13532 rest till later in the day. [We]_p13533 now know of twenty-one boxes having been removed, and if [it]_p13534 be that several were taken in any of these removals [we]_p13535 may be able to trace [them]_p13536 all. Such will, of course, immensely simplify [our]_p13537 labour, and the sooner the matter is attended to the better.

[I]_p13538 shall look up [Thomas Snelling]_n1615 to-day. [Dr Seward]_n's1616 [Diary]_n1617. 1 October. , [It]_p13539 was towards noon when [I]_p13540 was awakened by the [Professor]_n1618 walking into [my]_p13541 room. [He]_p13542 was more jolly and cheerful than usual, and [it]_p13543 is quite evident that last night's work has helped to take some of the brooding weight off [his]_p13544 mind. After going over the adventure of the night [he]_p13545 suddenly said:,   "Your patient interests [me]_p13546 much. May [it]_p13547 be that with [you]_p13549 [I]_p13551 visit [him]_p13553 this morning? Or if that [you]_p13550 are too occupy, [I]_p13552 can go alone if [it]_p13548 may be. [It]_p13554 is a new experience to [me]_p13555 to find a lunatic who talk philosophy, and reason so sound. " [I]_p13556 had some work to do which pressed, so [I]_p13557 told [him]_p13561 that if [he]_p13564 would go alone [I]_p13557 would be glad, as then [I]_p13558 should not have to keep [him]_p13562 waiting so [I]_p13558 called an attendant and gave [him]_p13562 the necessary instructions. Before the [Professor]_n1619 left the room [I]_p13565 cautioned [him]_p13566 against getting any false impression from [my]_p13567 patient.

"But," [he]_p13568 answered, "I want [him]_p13569 to talk of [himself]_p13570 and of [his]_p13571 delusion as to consuming live things. [He]_p13572 said to [Madam Mina]_n,1620 as [I]_p13573 see in [your]_p13574 diary of yesterday, that [he]_p13575 had once had such a belief. Why do [you]_p13576 smile, friend John?"  "Excuse me," [I]_p13577 said, "but the answer is here. " [I]_p13578 laid [my]_p13579 hand on the type-written matter. "When [our]_p13580 sane and learned lunatic made that very statement of how [he]_p13581 used to consume life, [his]_p13583 mouth was actually nauseous with the flies and spiders which [he]_p13582 had eaten just before Mrs Harker entered the room. " [Van Helsing]_n1621 smiled in turn. "[Good]_n!"1622 [he]_p13584 said. "Your memory is true, friend John. [I]_p13585 should have remembered. And yet [it]_p13586 is this very obliquity of thought and memory which makes mental disease such a fascinating study.

Perhaps [I]_p13587 may gain more knowledge out of the folly of this madman than [I]_p13588 shall from the teaching of the most wise. Who knows?" [I]_p13589 went on with [my]_p13590 work, and before long was through that in hand. [It]_p13591 seemed that the time had been very short indeed, but there was [Van Helsing]_n1623 back in the study. "Do [I]_p13592 interrupt?" [he]_p13593 asked politely as [he]_p13594 stood at the door. "Not at all," [I]_p13595 answered. "Come in. [My]_p13596 work is finished, and [I]_p13597 am free. [I]_p13598 can go with [you]_p13599 now, if [you]_p13600 like. "It is needless [I]_p13601 have seen him!"  "Well?"  "I fear that [he]_p13603 does not appraise [me]_p13604 at much. [Our]_p13605 interview was short.

When [I]_p13606 entered [his]_p13607 room [he]_p13611 was sitting on a stool in the centre, with [his]_p13608 elbows on [his]_p13608 knees, and [his]_p13609 face was the picture of sullen discontent. [I]_p13612 spoke to [him]_p13615 as cheerfully as [I]_p13613 could, and with such a measure of respect as [I]_p13613 could assume. [He]_p13616 made no reply whatever. "Don't [you]_p13617 know me?" [I]_p13618 asked. [His]_p13619 answer was not reassuring: "I know [you]_p13620 well enough [you]_p13621 are the old fool [Van Helsing]_n1624. [I]_p13622 wish [you]_p13623 would take [yourself]_p13624 and [your]_p13625 idiotic brain theories somewhere else. Damn all thick-headed Dutchmen!" Not a word more would [he]_p13626 say, but sat in [his]_p13627 implacable sullenness as indifferent to [me]_p13628 as though [I]_p13629 had not been in the room at all. Thus departed for this time [my]_p13630 chance of much learning from this so clever lunatic so [I]_p13631 shall go, if [I]_p13632 may, and cheer [myself]_p13633 with a few happy words with that sweet soul [Madam Mina]_n1625. [Friend John]_n,1626 [it]_p13634 does rejoice [me]_p13635 unspeakable that [she]_p13636 is no more to be pained, no more to be worried with [our]_p13637 terrible things. Though [we]_p13638 shall much miss [her]_p13639 help, [it]_p13640 is better so.

"  "I agree with [you]_p13644 with all [my]_p13645 heart," [I]_p13641 answered earnestly, for [I]_p13642 did not want [him]_p13646 to weaken in this matter. "[Mrs Harker]_n1627 is better out of it. Things are quite bad enough for us, all men of the world, and who have been in many tight places in [our]_p13647 time but [it]_p13648 is no place for a woman, and if [she]_p13650 had remained in touch with the affair, [it]_p13649 would in time infallibly have wrecked her. " So [Van Helsing]_n1628 has gone to confer with [Mrs Harker]_n1629 and [Harker Quincey]_n1630 and Art are all out following up the clues as to the earth-boxes. [I]_p13651 shall finish [my]_p13652 round of work and [we]_p13653 shall meet [to-night]_n1631. Mina Harker's [Journal]_n1632. 1 October. , [It]_p13654 is strange to [me]_p13655 to be kept in the dark as [I]_p13656 am to-day  after Jonathan's full confidence for so many years, to see [him]_p13657 manifestly avoid certain matters, and those the most vital of all. This morning [I]_p13658 slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though [Jonathan]_n1633 was late too, [he]_p13659 was the earlier. [He]_p13660 spoke to [me]_p13661 before [he]_p13662 went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but [he]_p13663 never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Count's house.

And yet [he]_p13664 must have known how terribly anxious [I]_p13665 was. [Poor]_n1634 [dear]_n1635 fellow! [I]_p13666 suppose [it]_p13667 must have distressed [him]_p13669 even more than [it]_p13668 did me. [They]_p13670 all agreed that [it]_p13671 was best that [I]_p13672 should not be drawn further into this awful work, and [I]_p13673 acquiesced. But to think that [he]_p13674 keeps anything from me! And now [I]_p13675 am crying like a silly fool, when [I]_p13676 know [it]_p13677 comes from [my]_p13678 husband's great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men. That has done [me]_p13679 good. Well, some day Jonathan will tell [me]_p13680 all and lest [it]_p13681 should ever be that [he]_p13682 should think for a moment that [I]_p13683 kept anything from him, [I]_p13684 still keep [my]_p13685 journal as usual. Then if [he]_p13686 has feared of [my]_p13687 trust [I]_p13689 shall show [it]_p13690 to him, with every thought of [my]_p13688 heart put down for [his]_p13691 [dear]_n1636 eyes to read. [I]_p13692 feel strangely sad and low-spirited [to-day]_n1637. [I]_p13693 suppose [it]_p13694 is the reaction from the terrible excitement. Last night [I]_p13695 went to bed when the men had gone, simply because [they]_p13696 told [me]_p13697 to.

[I]_p13698 didn't feel sleepy, and [I]_p13699 did feel full of devouring anxiety. [I]_p13700 kept thinking over everything that has been ever since Jonathan came to see [me]_p13701 in London, and [it]_p13702 all seems like a horrible tragedy, with fate pressing on relentlessly to some destined end. Everything that one does seems, no matter how right [it]_p13703 may be, to bring on the very thing which is most to be deplored. If [I]_p13704 hadn't gone to [Whitby]_n,1638 perhaps poor [dear]_n1639 [Lucy]_n1640 would be with [us]_p13705 now. [She]_p13706 hadn't taken to visiting the churchyard till [I]_p13707 came, and if [she]_p13708 hadn't come there in the day-time with [me]_p13711 [she]_p13709 wouldn't have walked there in [her]_p13712 sleep and if [she]_p13709 hadn't gone there at night and asleep, that monster couldn't have destroyed [her]_p13713 as [he]_p13714 did. Oh, why did [I]_p13715 ever go to [Whitby]_n?1641 There now, crying again! [I]_p13716 wonder what has come over [me]_p13717 to-day. [I]_p13718 must hide [it]_p13721 from Jonathan, for if [he]_p13722 knew that [I]_p13719 had been crying twice in one morning, I, who never cried on [my]_p13724 own account, and whom [he]_p13723 has never caused to shed a tear, the [dear]_n1642 fellow would fret [his]_p13725 heart out. [I]_p13726 shall put a bold face on, and if [I]_p13727 do feel weepy, [he]_p13728 shall never see it. [I]_p13729 suppose [it]_p13730 is one of the lessons that [we]_p13731 poor women have to learn. [I]_p13732 can't quite remember how [I]_p13733 fell asleep last night.

[I]_p13734 remember hearing the sudden barking of the dogs and a lot of queer sounds, like praying on a very tumultuous scale, from [Mr Renfield]_n's1643 room, which is somewhere under this. And then there was silence over everything, silence so profound that [it]_p13735 startled me, and [I]_p13736 got up and looked out of the window. All was dark and silent, the black shadows thrown by the moonlight seeming full of a silent mystery of [their]_p13737 own. Not a thing seemed to be stirring, but all to be grim and fixed as death or fate so that a thin streak of white mist, that crept with almost imperceptible slowness across the grass towards the house, seemed to have a sentience and a vitality of [its]_p13738 own. [I]_p13739 think that the digression of [my]_p13742 thoughts must have done [me]_p13743 good, for when [I]_p13740 got back to bed [I]_p13740 found a lethargy creeping over me. [I]_p13745 lay a while, but could not quite sleep, so [I]_p13746 got out and looked out of the window again. The mist was spreading, and was now close up to the house, so that [I]_p13747 could see [it]_p13748 lying thick against the wall, as though [it]_p13749 were stealing up to the windows. The poor man was more loud than ever, and though [I]_p13750 could not distinguish a word [he]_p13752 said, [I]_p13751 could in some way recognise in [his]_p13753 tones some passionate entreaty on [his]_p13754 part. Then there was the sound of a struggle, and [I]_p13755 knew that the attendants were dealing with him. [I]_p13756 was so frightened that [I]_p13757 crept into bed, and pulled the clothes over [my]_p13758 head, putting [my]_p13759 fingers in [my]_p13759 ears.

[I]_p13761 was not then a bit sleepy, at least so [I]_p13762 thought but [I]_p13762 must have fallen asleep, for, except dreams, [I]_p13763 do not remember anything until the morning, when Jonathan woke me. [My]_p13771 dream was very peculiar, and was almost typical of the way that waking thoughts become merged in, or continued in, dreams. And so [I]_p13779 slept uneasily and thought. Then [it]_p13780 began to dawn upon [me]_p13781 that the air was heavy, and dank, and cold. [I]_p13782 put back the clothes from [my]_p13783 face, and found, to [my]_p13784 surprise, that all was dim around. The gaslight which [I]_p13785 had left lit for Jonathan, but turned down, came only like a tiny red spark through the fog, which had evidently grown thicker and poured into the room. Then [it]_p13786 occurred to [me]_p13787 that [I]_p13788 had shut the window before [I]_p13789 had come to bed.

[I]_p13790 would have got out to make certain on the point, but some leaden lethargy seemed to chain [my]_p13791 limbs and even [my]_p13792 will. [I]_p13793 lay still and endured that was all. [I]_p13794 closed [my]_p13795 eyes, but could still see through [my]_p13796 eyelids. (It is wonderful what tricks [our]_p13797 dreams play us, and how conveniently [we]_p13798 can imagine. ) The mist grew thicker and thicker and [I]_p13799 could see now how [it]_p13801 came in, for [I]_p13800 could see [it]_p13802 like smoke, or with the white energy of boiling water, pouring in, not through the window, but through the joinings of the door. [It]_p13803 got thicker and thicker, till [it]_p13804 seemed as if [it]_p13805 became concentrated into a sort of pillar of cloud in the room, through the top of which [I]_p13806 could see the light of the gas shining like a red eye. Things began to whirl through [my]_p13807 brain just as the cloudy column was now whirling in the room, and through [it]_p13808 all came the scriptural words "a pillar of cloud by day and of fire by night. " Was [it]_p13809 indeed some such spiritual guidance that was coming to [me]_p13810 in [my]_p13814 sleep? But the pillar was composed of both the day and the night-guiding, for the fire was in the red eye, which at the thought got a new fascination for [me]_p13811 till, as [I]_p13815 looked, the fire divided, and seemed to shine on [me]_p13811 through the fog like two red eyes, such as Lucy told [me]_p13812 of in [her]_p13816 momentary mental wandering when, on the cliff, the dying sunlight struck the windows of [St]_n1645. Mary's [Church]_n1646. Suddenly the horror burst upon [me]_p13817 that [it]_p13818 was thus that Jonathan had seen those awful women growing into reality through the whirling mist in the moonlight, and in [my]_p13819 dream [I]_p13820 must have fainted, for all became black darkness.

The last conscious effort which imagination made was to show [me]_p13821 a livid white face bending over [me]_p13822 out of the mist. [I]_p13823 must be careful of such dreams, for [they]_p13824 would unseat one's reason if there were too much of them. [I]_p13825 would get [Dr Van Helsing]_n1647 or [Dr Seward]_n1648 to prescribe something for [me]_p13827 which would make [me]_p13828 sleep, only that [I]_p13826 fear to alarm them. Such a dream at the present time would become woven into [their]_p13829 fears for me. To-night [I]_p13830 shall strive hard to sleep naturally. If [I]_p13831 do not, [I]_p13832 shall to-morrow night get [them]_p13833 to give [me]_p13834 a dose of chloral that cannot hurt [me]_p13835 for once, and [it]_p13837 will give [me]_p13835 a good night's sleep. Last night tired [me]_p13838 more than if [I]_p13839 had not slept at all. * * * * *  2 October 10 p. m. , Last night [I]_p13840 slept, but did not dream.

[I]_p13841 must have slept soundly, for [I]_p13842 was not waked by [Jonathan]_n1649 coming to bed but the sleep has not refreshed me, for to-day [I]_p13842 feel terribly weak and spiritless. [I]_p13844 spent all yesterday trying to read, or lying down dozing. In the afternoon [Mr Renfield]_n1650 asked if [he]_p13845 might see me. [Poor]_n1651 man, [he]_p13846 was very gentle, and when [I]_p13848 came away [he]_p13847 kissed [my]_p13849 hand and bade God bless me. Some way [it]_p13850 affected [me]_p13851 much [I]_p13852 am crying when [I]_p13853 think of him. This is a new weakness, of which [I]_p13854 must be careful. Jonathan would be miserable if [he]_p13855 knew [I]_p13856 had been crying. [He]_p13857 and the others were out till dinner-time, and [they]_p13858 all came in tired. [I]_p13859 did what [I]_p13860 could to brighten [them]_p13864 up, and [I]_p13860 suppose that the effort did [me]_p13865 good, for [I]_p13861 forgot how tired [I]_p13861 was. After dinner [they]_p13866 sent [me]_p13869 to bed, and all went off to smoke together, as [they]_p13867 said, but [I]_p13870 knew that [they]_p13867 wanted to tell each other of what had occurred to each during the day [I]_p13871 could see from Jonathan's manner that [he]_p13872 had something important to communicate.

[I]_p13873 was not so sleepy as [I]_p13874 should have been so before [they]_p13877 went [I]_p13874 asked Dr [Seward]_n1652 to give [me]_p13878 a little opiate of some kind, as [I]_p13875 had not slept well the night before. [He]_p13879 very kindly made [me]_p13880 up a sleeping draught, which [he]_p13884 gave to me, telling [me]_p13881 that [it]_p13885 would do [me]_p13881 no harm, as [it]_p13886 was very mild. [I]_p13887 have taken it, and am waiting for sleep, which still keeps aloof. [I]_p13888 hope [I]_p13889 have not done wrong, for as sleep begins to flirt with me, a new fear comes: that [I]_p13889 may have been foolish in thus depriving [myself]_p13891 of the power of waking. [I]_p13892 might want it. Here comes sleep. [Good-night]_n1653. CHAPTER XX JONATHAN [HARKER]_n'S1654 JOURNAL 1 October, evening. , [I]_p13893 found [Thomas Snelling]_n1655 in [his]_p13894 house at Bethnal [Green]_n,1656 but unhappily [he]_p13895 was not in a condition to remember anything. The very prospect of beer which [my]_p13896 expected coming had opened to [him]_p13897 had proved too much, and [he]_p13898 had begun too early on [his]_p13899 expected debauch.

[I]_p13900 learned, however, from [his]_p13901 wife, who seemed a decent, poor soul, that [he]_p13902 was only the assistant to [Smollet]_n,1657 who of the two mates was the responsible person. So off [I]_p13903 drove to [Walworth]_n,1658 and found [Mr Joseph Smollet]_n1659 at home and in [his]_p13904 shirtsleeves, taking a late tea out of a saucer. [He]_p13905 is a decent, intelligent fellow, distinctly a good, reliable type of workman, and with a headpiece of [his]_p13906 own. [He]_p13907 remembered all about the incident of the boxes, and from a wonderful dog's-eared notebook, which [he]_p13908 produced from some mysterious receptacle about the seat of [his]_p13910 trousers, and which had hieroglyphical entries in thick, half-obliterated pencil, [he]_p13909 gave [me]_p13911 the destinations of the boxes. There were, [he]_p13912 said, six in the cartload which [he]_p13913 took from Carfax and left at 197, Chicksand Street, Mile End New Town, and another six which [he]_p13913 deposited at [Jamaica Lane]_n,1660 Bermondsey. [I]_p13923 went back to [Smollet]_n,1662 and asked [him]_p13924 if [he]_p13925 could tell [us]_p13926 if any other boxes had been taken from Carfax.

[He]_p13927 replied:,   "Well, guv'nor, you've treated [me]_p13928 wery 'an'some", [I]_p13929 had given [him]_p13932 half a sovereign, "an' I'll tell [yer]_p13933 all [I]_p13930 know. [I]_p13934 heard a man by the name of Bloxam say four nights ago in the 'Are an' 'Ounds, in Pincher's Alley, as 'ow [he]_p13935 an' [his]_p13936 mate 'ad 'ad a rare dusty job in a old 'ouse at Purfect. There ain't a-many such jobs as this 'ere, an' I'm thinkin' that maybe [Sam Bloxam]_n1663 could tell [ye]_p13937 summut. " [I]_p13938 asked if [he]_p13939 could tell [me]_p13940 where to find him. So [he]_p13947 gulped down the rest of [his]_p13949 tea and stood up, saying that [he]_p13948 was going to begin the search then and there. [I]_p13953 may find [Sam]_n1664 soon, or [I]_p13954 mayn't but anyhow [he]_p13955 ain't like to be in a way to tell [ye]_p13956 much [to-night]_n1665. [Sam]_n1666 is a rare one when [he]_p13957 starts on the booze. But ye'd better be up arter 'im soon in the mornin', or maybe [ye]_p13965 won't ketch 'im for [Sam]_n1669 gets off main early, never mind the booze the night afore. "  This was all practical, so one of the children went off with a penny to buy an envelope and a sheet of paper, and to keep the change. We're on the track anyhow. [I]_p13971 am tired [to-night]_n,1671 and want sleep. Mina is fast asleep, and looks a little too pale [her]_p13972 eyes look as though [she]_p13973 had been crying. [Poor]_n1672 [dear]_n,1673 I've no doubt [it]_p13974 frets [her]_p13976 to be kept in the dark, and [it]_p13975 may make [her]_p13977 doubly anxious about [me]_p13978 and the others. [I]_p14004 think [she]_p14005 would be happier in [our]_p14006 own home, with [her]_p14007 daily tasks to interest her, than in being here amongst [us]_p14009 and in ignorance. [I]_p14010 only saw Dr [Seward]_n1676 for a moment, and told [him]_p14013 where [I]_p14011 was off to, promising to come back and tell the rest so soon as [I]_p14011 should have found out anything. "  "How did [you]_p14072 get into the houses if [they]_p14073 were both empty?"  "There was the old party what engaged [me]_p14074 a-waitin' in the 'ouse at Purfleet. "Yus [it]_p14101 was a big 'all, an' there was nothin' else in it. " [I]_p14103 made one more attempt to further matters:,   "You didn't have any key?"  "Never used no key nor nothink. The mews were active, the [Piccadilly]_n1684 houses being mostly in occupation. Having once told [me]_p14165 that the [Piccadilly]_n1686 house, which throughout [our]_p14166 interview [he]_p14167 called a "mansion", was sold, [he]_p14168 considered [my]_p14169 business as concluded. When [I]_p14170 asked who had purchased it, [he]_p14171 opened [his]_p14172 eyes a thought wider, and paused a few seconds before replying:,   "It is sold, sir. "  "Pardon me," [I]_p14173 said, with equal politeness, "but [I]_p14174 have a special reason for wishing to know who purchased it. [I]_p14189 am [myself]_p14190 a professional man. " Here [I]_p14191 handed [him]_p14192 [my]_p14193 card. "In this instance [I]_p14194 am not prompted by curiosity [I]_p14195 act on the part of [Lord Godalming]_n,1687 who wishes to know something of the property which was, [he]_p14196 understood, lately for sale. " These words put a different complexion on affairs. [He]_p14197 said:, "I would like to oblige [you]_p14201 if [I]_p14198 could, [Mr Harker]_n,1688 and especially would [I]_p14199 like to oblige [his]_p14202 lordship. " [I]_p14215 wanted to secure a friend, and not to make an enemy, so [I]_p14216 thanked him, gave the address at Dr [Seward]_n's1692 and came away. [It]_p14217 was now dark, and [I]_p14218 was tired and hungry.

[I]_p14219 got a cup of tea at the A rated Bread Company and came down to Purfleet by the next train. [I]_p14220 found all the others at home. Mina was looking tired and pale, but [she]_p14221 made a gallant effort to be bright and cheerful, [it]_p14222 wrung [my]_p14223 heart to think that [I]_p14224 had had to keep anything from [her]_p14225 and so caused [her]_p14226 inquietude. [I]_p14241 could not tell the others of the day's discovery till [we]_p14243 were alone  so after dinner, followed by a little music to save appearances even amongst ourselves, [I]_p14242 took Mina to [her]_p14244 room and left [her]_p14245 to go to bed. When [I]_p14251 came down again [I]_p14252 found the others all gathered round the fire in the study. Doubtless [we]_p14260 are on the track of the missing boxes. If [we]_p14261 find [them]_p14262 all in that house, then [our]_p14263 work is near the end. But if there be some missing, [we]_p14264 must search until [we]_p14265 find them. Then shall [we]_p14266 make [our]_p14267 final coup, and hunt the wretch to [his]_p14268 real death. " [We]_p14269 all sat silent awhile and all at once Mr Morris spoke:, "Say! how are [we]_p14271 going to get into that house?" "We got into the other," answered [Lord]_n1695 [Godalming]_n1696 quickly. "But, Art, this is different. [We]_p14272 broke house at Carfax, but [we]_p14273 had night and a walled park to protect us. [It]_p14274 will be a mighty different thing to commit burglary in [Piccadilly]_n,1697 either by day or night.

[I]_p14275 confess [I]_p14276 don't see how [we]_p14277 are going to get in unless that agency duck can find [us]_p14279 a key of some sort perhaps [we]_p14278 shall know when [you]_p14280 get [his]_p14281 letter in the morning. " [Lord Godalming]_n's1698 brows contracted, and [he]_p14282 stood up and walked about the room. By-and-by [he]_p14283 stopped and said, turning from one to another of us:, "[Quincey]_n's1699 head is level. This burglary business is getting serious [we]_p14284 got off once all right but [we]_p14285 have now a rare job on hand, unless [we]_p14285 can find the Count's key basket. " As nothing could well be done before morning, and as [it]_p14287 would be at least advisable to wait till [Lord Godalming]_n1700 should hear from Mitchell's, [we]_p14288 decided not to take any active step before breakfast time. For a good while [we]_p14289 sat and smoked, discussing the matter in [its]_p14290 various lights and bearings [I]_p14291 took the opportunity of bringing this diary right up to the moment. [I]_p14292 am very sleepy and shall go to bed. Just a line. [Mina]_n1701 sleeps soundly and [her]_p14293 breathing is regular. [Her]_p14294 forehead is puckered up into little wrinkles, as though [she]_p14295 thinks even in [her]_p14296 sleep.

[She]_p14297 is still too pale, but does not look so haggard as [she]_p14298 did this morning. To-morrow will, [I]_p14299 hope, mend all this [she]_p14300 will be [herself]_p14301 at home in [Exeter]_n1702. Oh, but [I]_p14302 am sleepy! [Dr Seward]_n's1703 [Diary]_n1704. 1 October. , [I]_p14303 am puzzled afresh about Renfield. [His]_p14304 moods change so rapidly that [I]_p14305 find [it]_p14306 difficult to keep touch of them, and as [they]_p14307 always mean something more than [his]_p14309 own well-being, [they]_p14308 form a more than interesting study. This morning, when [I]_p14310 went to see [him]_p14311 after [his]_p14312 repulse of [Van Helsing]_n,1705 [his]_p14313 manner was that of a man commanding destiny. [He]_p14314 was, in fact, commanding destiny, subjectively. [He]_p14315 did not really care for any of the things of mere earth [he]_p14316 was in the clouds and looked down on all the weaknesses and wants of [us]_p14317 poor mortals. [I]_p14318 thought [I]_p14319 would improve the occasion and learn something, so [I]_p14319 asked him:, "What about the flies these times?" [He]_p14321 smiled on [me]_p14322 in quite a superior sort of way, such a smile as would have become the face of Malvolio, as [he]_p14324 answered me:, "The fly, [my]_p14325 [dear]_n1706 sir, has one striking feature [its]_p14326 wings are typical of the a rial powers of the psychic faculties.

The ancients did well when [they]_p14327 typified the soul as a butterfly!"  [I]_p14328 thought [I]_p14329 would push [his]_p14333 analogy to [its]_p14337 utmost logically, so [I]_p14329 said quickly:,   "Oh, [it]_p14338 is a soul [you]_p14340 are after now, is it?" [His]_p14341 madness foiled [his]_p14334 reason, and a puzzled look spread over [his]_p14334 face as, shaking [his]_p14335 head with a decision which [I]_p14330 had but seldom seen in him, [he]_p14342 said:,   "Oh, no, oh no! [I]_p14330 want no souls. Life is all [I]_p14343 want. " Here [he]_p14344 brightened up "I am pretty indifferent about [it]_p14345 at present. Life is all right [I]_p14346 have all [I]_p14347 want. [You]_p14348 must get a new patient, doctor, if [you]_p14349 wish to study zo phagy!"  This puzzled [me]_p14352 a little, so [I]_p14353 drew [him]_p14355 on:,   "Then [you]_p14350 command life [you]_p14350 are a god, [I]_p14354 suppose?" [He]_p14356 smiled with an ineffably benign superiority. "Oh no! Far be [it]_p14357 from [me]_p14358 to arrogate to [myself]_p14359 the attributes of the Deity. [I]_p14360 am not even concerned in [His]_p14361 especially spiritual doings. If [I]_p14362 may state [my]_p14364 intellectual position [I]_p14363 am, so far as concerns things purely terrestrial, somewhat in the position which Enoch occupied spiritually!" This was a poser to me. [I]_p14365 could not at the moment recall Enoch's appositeness so [I]_p14366 had to ask a simple question, though [I]_p14366 felt that by so doing [I]_p14367 was lowering [myself]_p14369 in the eyes of the lunatic:,   "And why with Enoch?"  "Because [he]_p14370 walked with God. " [I]_p14371 could not see the analogy, but did not like to admit [it]_p14373 so [I]_p14372 harked back to what [he]_p14374 had denied:,   "So [you]_p14375 don't care about life and [you]_p14376 don't want souls.

Why not?" [I]_p14377 put [my]_p14378 question quickly and somewhat sternly, on purpose to disconcert him. The effort succeeded for an instant [he]_p14379 unconsciously relapsed into [his]_p14381 old servile manner, bent low before me, and actually fawned upon [me]_p14382 as [he]_p14380 replied:,   "I don't want any souls, indeed, indeed! [I]_p14384 don't. [I]_p14386 couldn't use [them]_p14388 if [I]_p14387 had [them]_p14389 [they]_p14390 would be no manner of use to me. [I]_p14391 couldn't eat [them]_p14392 or, , " [He]_p14393 suddenly stopped and the old cunning look spread over [his]_p14394 face, like a wind-sweep on the surface of the water. "And doctor, as to life, what is [it]_p14395 after all? When you've got all [you]_p14396 require, and [you]_p14397 know that [you]_p14397 will never want, that is all. [I]_p14400 have friends, good friends, like you, Dr [Seward]_n"1707 this was said with a leer of inexpressible cunning. "I know that [I]_p14401 shall never lack the means of life!"  [I]_p14402 think that through the cloudiness of [his]_p14404 insanity [he]_p14405 saw some antagonism in me, for [he]_p14406 at once fell back on the last refuge of such as he, a dogged silence. After a short time [I]_p14408 saw that for the present [it]_p14409 was useless to speak to him. [He]_p14410 was sulky, and so [I]_p14411 came away. Later in the day [he]_p14412 sent for me.

Ordinarily [I]_p14413 would not have come without special reason, but just at present [I]_p14414 am so interested in [him]_p14416 that [I]_p14414 would gladly make an effort. Besides, [I]_p14417 am glad to have anything to help to pass the time. Harker is out, following up clues and so are [Lord Godalming]_n1708 and [Quincey]_n1709. [Van Helsing]_n1710 sits in [my]_p14418 study poring over the record prepared by the Harkers [he]_p14419 seems to think that by accurate knowledge of all details [he]_p14420 will light upon some clue. [He]_p14421 does not wish to be disturbed in the work, without cause. [I]_p14422 would have taken [him]_p14424 with [me]_p14425 to see the patient, only [I]_p14423 thought that after [his]_p14426 last repulse [he]_p14427 might not care to go again. There was also another reason: Renfield might not speak so freely before a third person as when [he]_p14428 and [I]_p14429 were alone. [I]_p14430 found [him]_p14431 sitting out in the middle of the floor on [his]_p14432 stool, a pose which is generally indicative of some mental energy on [his]_p14433 part. When [I]_p14434 came in, [he]_p14435 said at once, as though the question had been waiting on [his]_p14436 lips:,   "What about souls?" [It]_p14437 was evident then that [my]_p14438 surmise had been correct. Unconscious cerebration was doing [its]_p14439 work, even with the lunatic.

[I]_p14440 determined to have the matter out. "What about [them]_p14441 yourself?" [I]_p14442 asked. [He]_p14443 did not reply for a moment but looked all round him, and up and down, as though [he]_p14444 expected to find some inspiration for an answer. "I don't want any souls!" [he]_p14445 said in a feeble, apologetic way. The matter seemed preying on [his]_p14446 mind, and so [I]_p14447 determined to use it, to "be cruel only to be kind. " So [I]_p14448 said:,   "You like life, and [you]_p14451 want life?"  "Oh yes! but that is all right [you]_p14452 needn't worry about that!"  "But," [I]_p14449 asked, "how are [we]_p14456 to get the life without getting the soul also?" This seemed to puzzle him, so [I]_p14449 followed [it]_p14457 up:,   "A nice time you'll have some time when you're flying out there, with the souls of thousands of flies and spiders and birds and cats buzzing and twittering and miauing all round you. You've got [their]_p14458 lives, [you]_p14460 know, and [you]_p14461 must put up with [their]_p14459 souls!" Something seemed to affect [his]_p14462 imagination, for [he]_p14467 put [his]_p14463 fingers to [his]_p14463 ears and shut [his]_p14464 eyes, screwing [them]_p14468 up tightly just as a small boy does when [his]_p14464 face is being soaped. There was something pathetic in [it]_p14469 that touched [me]_p14472 [it]_p14470 also gave [me]_p14473 a lesson, for [it]_p14470 seemed that before [me]_p14473 was a child, only a child, though the features were worn, and the stubble on the jaws was white. [It]_p14475 was evident that [he]_p14476 was undergoing some process of mental disturbance, and, knowing how [his]_p14477 past moods had interpreted things seemingly foreign to himself, [I]_p14479 thought [I]_p14480 would enter into [his]_p14478 mind as well as [I]_p14480 could and go with him. The first step was to restore confidence, so [I]_p14482 asked him, speaking pretty loud so that [he]_p14483 would hear [me]_p14484 through [his]_p14485 closed ears:,   "Would [you]_p14487 like some sugar to get [your]_p14488 flies round again?" [He]_p14489 seemed to wake up all at once, and shook [his]_p14486 head.

With a laugh [he]_p14490 replied:,   "Not much! flies are poor things, after all!" After a pause [he]_p14491 added, "But [I]_p14492 don't want [their]_p14493 souls buzzing round me, all the same. "  "Or spiders?" [I]_p14494 went on. "Blow spiders! What's the use of spiders? There isn't anything in [them]_p14495 to eat or", [he]_p14496 stopped suddenly, as though reminded of a forbidden topic. "So, so!" [I]_p14497 thought to myself, "this is the second time [he]_p14499 has suddenly stopped at the word 'drink' what does [it]_p14501 mean?" Renfield seemed [himself]_p14503 aware of having made a lapse, for [he]_p14500 hurried on, as though to distract [my]_p14504 attention from it:,   "I don't take any stock at all in such matters. 'Rats and mice and such small deer,' as Shakespeare has it, 'chicken-feed of the larder' [they]_p14505 might be called. I'm past all that sort of nonsense. [You]_p14506 might as well ask a man to eat molecules with a pair of chop-sticks, as to try to interest [me]_p14507 about the lesser carnivora, when [I]_p14509 know of what is before me. "  "I see," [I]_p14510 said. "You want big things that [you]_p14512 can make [your]_p14515 teeth meet in? How would [you]_p14513 like to breakfast on elephant?"  "What ridiculous nonsense [you]_p14513 are talking!" [He]_p14516 was getting too wide awake, so [I]_p14517 thought [I]_p14518 would press [him]_p14519 hard. "I wonder," [I]_p14520 said reflectively, "what an elephant's soul is like!"  The effect [I]_p14521 desired was obtained, for [he]_p14523 at once fell from [his]_p14524 high-horse and became a child again.

"I don't want an elephant's soul, or any soul at all!" [he]_p14525 said. For a few moments [he]_p14526 sat despondently. Suddenly [he]_p14527 jumped to [his]_p14528 feet, with [his]_p14529 eyes blazing and all the signs of intense cerebral excitement. "To hell with [you]_p14530 and [your]_p14531 souls!" [he]_p14532 shouted. "Why do [you]_p14533 plague [me]_p14534 about souls? Haven't [I]_p14536 got enough to worry, and pain, and distract [me]_p14535 already, without thinking of souls!" [He]_p14539 looked so hostile that [I]_p14537 thought [he]_p14540 was in for another homicidal fit, so [I]_p14537 blew [my]_p14541 whistle. The instant, however, that [I]_p14542 did so [he]_p14544 became calm, and said apologetically:,   "Forgive me, Doctor [I]_p14543 forgot myself. [You]_p14545 do not need any help. [I]_p14546 am so worried in [my]_p14548 mind that [I]_p14547 am apt to be irritable. If [you]_p14549 only knew the problem [I]_p14551 have to face, and that [I]_p14552 am working out, [you]_p14550 would pity, and tolerate, and pardon me. Pray do not put [me]_p14553 in a strait-waistcoat.

[I]_p14554 want to think and [I]_p14555 cannot think freely when [my]_p14556 body is confined. [I]_p14557 am sure [you]_p14559 will understand!" [He]_p14560 had evidently self-control so when the attendants came [I]_p14558 told [them]_p14561 not to mind, and [they]_p14562 withdrew. Renfield watched [them]_p14563 go when the door was closed [he]_p14564 said, with considerable dignity and sweetness:, "Dr [Seward]_n,1711 [you]_p14565 have been very considerate towards me. Believe [me]_p14566 that [I]_p14567 am very, very grateful to you!" [I]_p14568 thought [it]_p14570 well to leave [him]_p14571 in this mood, and so [I]_p14568 came away. There is certainly something to ponder over in this man's state. Several points seem to make what the American interviewer calls "a story," if [one]_p14572 could only get [them]_p14573 in proper order. Here [they]_p14574 are:,   Will not mention "drinking. "  Fears the thought of being burdened with the "soul" of anything. Has no dread of wanting "life" in the future. Despises the meaner forms of life altogether, though [he]_p14575 dreads being haunted by [their]_p14576 souls.

Logically all these things point one way! [he]_p14577 has assurance of some kind that [he]_p14578 will acquire some higher life. [He]_p14579 dreads the consequence, the burden of a soul. Then [it]_p14580 is a human life [he]_p14581 looks to!  And the assurance, ?  Merciful God! the Count has been to him, and there is some new scheme of terror afoot!  * * * * *  Later. , [I]_p14582 went after [my]_p14583 round to [Van Helsing]_n1712 and told [him]_p14585 [my]_p14584 suspicion. [He]_p14586 grew very grave and, after thinking the matter over for a while asked [me]_p14587 to take [him]_p14588 to Renfield. [I]_p14589 did so. As [we]_p14590 came to the door [we]_p14591 heard the lunatic within singing gaily, as [he]_p14592 used to do in the time which now seems so long ago. When [we]_p14593 entered [we]_p14594 saw with amazement that [he]_p14595 had spread out [his]_p14596 sugar as of old the flies, lethargic with the autumn, were beginning to buzz into the room. [We]_p14597 tried to make [him]_p14598 talk of the subject of [our]_p14599 previous conversation, but [he]_p14600 would not attend. [He]_p14601 went on with [his]_p14602 singing, just as though [we]_p14603 had not been present.

[He]_p14604 had got a scrap of paper and was folding [it]_p14605 into a note-book. [We]_p14606 had to come away as ignorant as [we]_p14607 went in. [His]_p14608 is a curious case indeed [we]_p14609 must watch [him]_p14610 [to-night]_n1713. [Letter]_n,1714 Mitchell, Sons and Candy to [Lord Godalming]_n1715. "1 October. "My [Lord]_n,1716 "We are at all times only too happy to meet [your]_p14611 wishes. [We]_p14612 beg, with regard to the desire of [your]_p14613 Lordship, expressed by Mr Harker on [your]_p14614 behalf, to supply the following information concerning the sale and purchase of No. 347, [Piccadilly]_n1717. The original vendors are the executors of the late Mr Archibald Winter-Suffield. The purchaser is a foreign nobleman, Count de Ville, who effected the purchase [himself]_p14615 paying the purchase money in notes 'over the counter,' if [your]_p14616 Lordship will pardon [us]_p14617 using so vulgar an expression.

Beyond this [we]_p14618 know nothing whatever of him. "We are, [my]_p14619 [Lord]_n,1718 "Your [Lordship]_n's1719 humble servants, "MITCHELL, SONS & CANDY. " [Dr Seward]_n's1720 [Diary]_n1721. 2 October. , [I]_p14620 placed a man in the corridor last night, and told [him]_p14621 to make an accurate note of any sound [he]_p14623 might hear from Renfield's room, and gave [him]_p14622 instructions that if there should be anything strange [he]_p14624 was to call me. After dinner, when [we]_p14625 had all gathered round the fire in the study, Mrs Harker having gone to bed, [we]_p14626 discussed the attempts and discoveries of the day. Harker was the only one who had any result, and [we]_p14627 are in great hopes that [his]_p14628 clue may be an important one. Before going to bed [I]_p14629 went round to the patient's room and looked in through the observation trap. [He]_p14630 was sleeping soundly, and [his]_p14631 heart rose and fell with regular respiration. This morning the man on duty reported to [me]_p14632 that a little after midnight [he]_p14633 was restless and kept saying [his]_p14634 prayers somewhat loudly.

[I]_p14635 asked [him]_p14636 if that was all [he]_p14637 replied that [it]_p14639 was all [he]_p14638 heard. There was something about [his]_p14640 manner so suspicious that [I]_p14641 asked [him]_p14642 point blank if [he]_p14643 had been asleep. [He]_p14644 denied sleep, but admitted to having "dozed" for a while. [It]_p14645 is too bad that men cannot be trusted unless [they]_p14646 are watched. [To-day Harker]_n1722 is out following up [his]_p14647 clue, and Art and [Quincey]_n1723 are looking after horses. [Godalming]_n1724 thinks that [it]_p14648 will be well to have horses always in readiness, for when [we]_p14649 get the information which [we]_p14650 seek there will be no time to lose. [We]_p14651 must sterilise all the imported earth between sunrise and sunset [we]_p14652 shall thus catch the Count at [his]_p14653 weakest, and without a refuge to fly to. [Van Helsing]_n1725 is off to the [British]_n1726 Museum looking up some authorities on ancient medicine. The old physicians took account of things which [their]_p14654 followers do not accept, and the [Professor]_n1727 is searching for witch and demon cures which may be useful to [us]_p14655 later. [I]_p14656 sometimes think [we]_p14657 must be all mad and that [we]_p14658 shall wake to sanity in strait-waistcoats.

* * * * *  Later. , [We]_p14659 have met again. [We]_p14660 seem at last to be on the track, and [our]_p14661 work of to-morrow may be the beginning of the end. [I]_p14662 wonder if Renfield's quiet has anything to do with this. [His]_p14663 moods have so followed the doings of the Count, that the coming destruction of the monster may be carried to [him]_p14664 in some subtle way. If [we]_p14665 could only get some hint as to what passed in [his]_p14666 mind, between the time of [my]_p14668 argument with [him]_p14669 to-day and [his]_p14667 resumption of fly-catching, [it]_p14670 might afford [us]_p14671 a valuable clue. [He]_p14672 is now seemingly quiet for a spell. Is he?, , That wild yell seemed to come from [his]_p14673 room. * * * * *  The attendant came bursting into [my]_p14674 room and told [me]_p14675 that Renfield had somehow met with some accident. [He]_p14676 had heard [him]_p14677 yell and when [he]_p14680 went to [him]_p14678 found [him]_p14678 lying on [his]_p14681 face on the floor, all covered with blood.

[I]_p14682 must go at once. CHAPTER XXI [DR]_n1728. SEWARD'S [DIARY]_n1729 3 October. , Let [me]_p14683 put down with exactness all that happened, as well as [I]_p14684 can remember it, since last [I]_p14685 made an entry. Not a detail that [I]_p14686 can recall must be forgotten in all calmness [I]_p14687 must proceed. When [I]_p14688 came to Renfield's room [I]_p14689 found [him]_p14690 lying on the floor on [his]_p14691 left side in a glittering pool of blood. When [I]_p14692 went to move him, [it]_p14693 became at once apparent that [he]_p14694 had received some terrible injuries  there seemed none of that unity of purpose between the parts of the body which marks even lethargic sanity. As the face was exposed [I]_p14695 could see that [it]_p14696 was horribly bruised, as though [it]_p14697 had been beaten against the floor, indeed [it]_p14697 was from the face wounds that the pool of blood originated. The attendant who was kneeling beside the body said to [me]_p14699 as [we]_p14700 turned [him]_p14701 over:,   "I think, sir, [his]_p14702 back is broken. See, both [his]_p14703 right arm and leg and the whole side of [his]_p14704 face are paralysed.

" How such a thing could have happened puzzled the attendant beyond measure. [He]_p14705 seemed quite bewildered, and [his]_p14706 brows were gathered in as [he]_p14707 said:,   "I can't understand the two things. [He]_p14708 could mark [his]_p14709 face like that by beating [his]_p14710 own head on the floor. [I]_p14711 saw a [young]_n1730 woman do [it]_p14712 once at the [Eversfield Asylum]_n1731 before anyone could lay hands on her. And [I]_p14713 suppose [he]_p14714 might have broke [his]_p14716 neck by falling out of bed, if [he]_p14715 got in an awkward kink. But for the life of [me]_p14717 [I]_p14718 can't imagine how the two things occurred. If [his]_p14719 back was broke, [he]_p14722 couldn't beat [his]_p14720 head and if [his]_p14720 face was like that before the fall out of bed, there would be marks of it. " [I]_p14723 said to him:, "Go to [Dr Van Helsing]_n,1732 and ask [him]_p14724 to kindly come here at once. [I]_p14726 want [him]_p14727 without an instant's delay. " The man ran off, and within a few minutes the [Professor]_n,1733 in [his]_p14728 dressing gown and slippers, appeared.

When [he]_p14729 saw Renfield on the ground, [he]_p14730 looked keenly at [him]_p14731 a moment, and then turned to me. [I]_p14732 think [he]_p14733 recognised [my]_p14735 thought in [my]_p14736 eyes, for [he]_p14734 said very quietly, manifestly for the ears of the attendant:,   "Ah, a sad accident! [He]_p14737 will need very careful watching, and much attention. [I]_p14738 shall stay with [you]_p14740 [myself]_p14741 but [I]_p14739 shall first dress myself. If [you]_p14743 will remain [I]_p14745 shall in a few minutes join you. "  The patient was now breathing stertorously and [it]_p14746 was easy to see that [he]_p14747 had suffered some terrible injury. [Van Helsing]_n1734 returned with extraordinary celerity, bearing with [him]_p14748 a surgical case. [He]_p14749 had evidently been thinking and had [his]_p14750 mind made up for, almost before [he]_p14751 looked at the patient, [he]_p14752 whispered to me:,   "Send the attendant away. [We]_p14753 must be alone with [him]_p14754 when [he]_p14755 becomes conscious, after the operation. " So [I]_p14756 said:,   "I think that will do now, Simmons. [We]_p14758 have done all that [we]_p14759 can at present.

[You]_p14760 had better go [your]_p14761 round, and Dr [Van Helsing]_n1735 will operate. Let [me]_p14762 know instantly if there be anything unusual anywhere. "  The man withdrew, and [we]_p14763 went into a strict examination of the patient. The wounds of the face was superficial the real injury was a depressed fracture of the skull, extending right up through the motor area. The [Professor]_n1736 thought a moment and said:, "We must reduce the pressure and get back to normal conditions, as far as can be the rapidity of the suffusion shows the terrible nature of [his]_p14764 injury. The whole motor area seems affected. The suffusion of the brain will increase quickly, so [we]_p14765 must trephine at once or [it]_p14766 may be too late. " As [he]_p14767 was speaking there was a soft tapping at the door. [I]_p14768 went over and opened [it]_p14770 and found in the corridor without, [Arthur]_n1737 and [Quincey]_n1738 in pajamas and slippers: the former spoke:, "I heard [your]_p14771 man call up Dr [Van Helsing]_n1739 and tell [him]_p14772 of an accident. So [I]_p14773 woke [Quincey]_n1740 or rather called for [him]_p14774 as [he]_p14775 was not asleep.

Things are moving too quickly and too strangely for sound sleep for any of [us]_p14776 these times. I've been thinking that to-morrow night will not see things as [they]_p14777 have been. We'll have to look back, and forward a little more than [we]_p14778 have done. May [we]_p14779 come in?" [I]_p14780 nodded, and held the door open till [they]_p14782 had entered then [I]_p14781 closed [it]_p14783 again. When [Quincey]_n1741 saw the attitude and state of the patient, and noted the horrible pool on the floor, [he]_p14784 said softly:, "My God! what has happened to him? [Poor]_n,1742 poor devil!" [I]_p14788 told [him]_p14786 briefly, and added that [we]_p14789 expected [he]_p14785 would recover consciousness after the operation, for a short time, at all events. [He]_p14790 went at once and sat down on the edge of the bed, with [Godalming]_n1743 beside [him]_p14791 [we]_p14792 all watched in patience. "We shall wait," said [Van Helsing]_n,1744 "just long enough to fix the best spot for trephining, so that [we]_p14793 may most quickly and perfectly remove the blood clot for [it]_p14794 is evident that the h morrhage is increasing. "  The minutes during which [we]_p14795 waited passed with fearful slowness. [I]_p14796 had a horrible sinking in [my]_p14798 heart, and from [Van Helsing]_n's1745 face [I]_p14797 gathered that [he]_p14799 felt some fear or apprehension as to what was to come. SEWARD'S DIARY 11 October, [Evening]_n2106. , Jonathan Harker has asked [me]_p17828 to note this, as [he]_p17829 says [he]_p17830 is hardly equal to the task, and [he]_p17830 wants an exact record kept.

[I]_p17832 think that none of [us]_p17833 were surprised when [we]_p17834 were asked to see Mrs Harker a little before the time of sunset. To-night, when [we]_p17840 met, [she]_p17841 was somewhat constrained, and bore all the signs of an internal struggle. A very few minutes, however, gave [her]_p17847 complete control of [herself]_p17850 then, motioning [her]_p17848 husband to sit beside [her]_p17848 on the sofa where [she]_p17851 was half reclining, [she]_p17852 made the rest of [us]_p17853 bring chairs up close. "What is that way, which [we]_p17886 must not, may not, take?"  "That [I]_p17887 may die now, either by [my]_p17888 own hand or that of another, before the greater evil is entirely wrought. [I]_p17889 know, and [you]_p17891 know, that were [I]_p17890 once dead [you]_p17892 could and would set free [my]_p17894 immortal spirit, even as [you]_p17892 did [my]_p17895 poor Lucy's. The faces of the others were set and Harker's grew ashen grey perhaps [he]_p17902 guessed better than any of [us]_p17903 what was coming. [She]_p17904 continued:,   "This is what [I]_p17905 can give into the hotch-pot. " [I]_p17906 could not but note the quaint legal phrase which [she]_p17907 used in such a place, and with all seriousness. "What will each of [you]_p17908 give? And [I]_p17950 promise you, too, that [I]_p17951 shall make all certain, for if [I]_p17951 am only doubtful [I]_p17952 shall take [it]_p17954 that the time has come!"  "My true friend!" was all [she]_p17955 could say amid [her]_p17957 fast-falling tears, as, bending over, [she]_p17956 kissed [his]_p17958 hand. "I swear the same, [my]_p17959 [dear Madam Mina]_n!"2115 said [Van Helsing]_n2116. "And I!" said [Lord Godalming]_n,2117 each of [them]_p17960 in turn kneeling to [her]_p17961 to take the oath. [I]_p17962 followed, myself. Then [her]_p17963 husband turned to [her]_p17964 wan-eyed and with a greenish pallor which subdued the snowy whiteness of [his]_p17966 hair, and asked:,   "And must I, too, make such a promise, oh, [my]_p17967 wife?"  "You too, [my]_p17968 dearest," [she]_p17969 said, with infinite yearning of pity in [her]_p17964 voice and eyes. "You must not shrink.

[You]_p17970 are nearest and dearest and all the world to [me]_p17971 [our]_p17972 souls are knit into one, for all life and all time. Think, [dear]_n,2118 that there have been times when brave men have killed [their]_p17973 wives and [their]_p17974 womenkind, to keep [them]_p17975 from falling into the hands of the enemy. [Their]_p17976 hands did not falter any the more because those that [they]_p17977 loved implored [them]_p17978 to slay them. [It]_p17980 is men's duty towards those whom [they]_p17981 love, in such times of sore trial! And oh, [my]_p17982 [dear]_n,2119 if [it]_p17983 is to be that [I]_p17985 must meet death at any hand, let [it]_p17984 be at the hand of [him]_p17986 that loves [me]_p17987 best. Dr [Van Helsing]_n,2120 [I]_p17988 have not forgotten [your]_p17989 mercy in poor Lucy's case to [him]_p17990 who loved", [she]_p17992 stopped with a flying blush, and changed [her]_p17993 phrase, "to [him]_p17991 who had best right to give [her]_p17994 peace. If that time shall come again, [I]_p17995 look to [you]_p17996 to make [it]_p17997 a happy memory of [my]_p17999 husband's life that [it]_p17998 was [his]_p18000 loving hand which set [me]_p18001 free from the awful thrall upon me. " "Again [I]_p18003 swear!" came the [Professor]_n's2121 resonant voice. [Mrs Harker]_n2122 smiled, positively smiled, as with a sigh of relief [she]_p18004 leaned back and said:, "And now one word of warning, a warning which [you]_p18005 must never forget: this time, if [it]_p18007 ever come, may come quickly and unexpectedly, and in such case [you]_p18006 must lose no time in using [your]_p18008 opportunity. At such a time [I]_p18009 [myself]_p18010 might be, nay! if the time ever comes, shall be, leagued with [your]_p18011 enemy against you. "  "One more request " [she]_p18012 became very solemn as [she]_p18013 said this, "it is not vital and necessary like the other, but [I]_p18014 want [you]_p18015 to do one thing for me, if [you]_p18016 will.

" [We]_p18017 all acquiesced, but no one spoke there was no need to speak:, "I want [you]_p18018 to read the [Burial]_n2123 Service. " [She]_p18019 was interrupted by a deep groan from [her]_p18020 husband taking [his]_p18022 hand in hers, [she]_p18023 held [it]_p18024 over [her]_p18021 heart, and continued: "You must read [it]_p18025 over [me]_p18026 some day. Whatever may be the issue of all this fearful state of things, [it]_p18027 will be a sweet thought to all or some of us. You, [my]_p18028 dearest, will [I]_p18031 hope read it, for then [it]_p18032 will be in [your]_p18034 voice in [my]_p18029 memory for ever, come what may!" "But oh, [my]_p18029 [dear]_n2124 one," [he]_p18035 pleaded, "death is afar off from you. " "[Nay]_n,"2125 [she]_p18036 said, holding up a warning hand. "I am deeper in death at this moment than if the weight of an earthly grave lay heavy upon me!"  "Oh, [my]_p18039 wife, must [I]_p18037 read it?" [he]_p18040 said, before [he]_p18041 began. "It would comfort me, [my]_p18042 husband!" was all [she]_p18043 said and [he]_p18045 began to read when [she]_p18044 had got the book ready. "How can I, how could any one, tell of that strange scene, [its]_p18046 solemnity, [its]_p18047 gloom, [its]_p18047 sadness, [its]_p18048 horror and, withal, [its]_p18048 sweetness. Even a sceptic, who can see nothing but a travesty of bitter truth in anything holy or emotional, would have been melted to the heart had [he]_p18051 seen that little group of loving and devoted friends kneeling round that stricken and sorrowing lady or heard the tender passion of [her]_p18054 husband's voice, as in tones so broken with emotion that often [he]_p18052 had to pause, [he]_p18052 read the simple and beautiful service from the Burial of the [Dead]_n2126. I, [I]_p18055 cannot go on, words, and, v-voice, f-fail m-me!"  * * * * *  [She]_p18057 was right in [her]_p18058 instinct.

Strange as [it]_p18059 all was, bizarre as [it]_p18060 may hereafter seem even to [us]_p18062 who felt [its]_p18065 potent influence at the time, [it]_p18060 comforted [us]_p18063 much and the silence, which showed Mrs Harker's coming relapse from [her]_p18066 freedom of soul, did not seem so full of despair to any of [us]_p18063 as [we]_p18067 had dreaded. Jonathan Harker's [Journal]_n2127. 15 October, [Varna]_n2128. , [We]_p18068 left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, got to Paris the same night, and took the places secured for [us]_p18069 in the Orient [Express]_n2129. [We]_p18070 travelled night and day, arriving here at about five o'clock. Lord Godalming went to the Consulate to see if any telegram had arrived for him, whilst the rest of [us]_p18071 came on to this hotel, "the Odessus. " The journey may have had incidents [I]_p18072 was, however, too eager to get on, to care for them. Until the [Czarina Catherine]_n2130 comes into port there will be no interest for [me]_p18073 in anything in the wide world. Thank God! [Mina]_n2131 is well, and looks to be getting stronger [her]_p18074 colour is coming back. [She]_p18075 sleeps a great deal throughout the journey [she]_p18076 slept nearly all the time.

Before sunrise and sunset, however, [she]_p18077 is very wakeful and alert and [it]_p18078 has become a habit for [Van Helsing]_n2132 to hypnotise [her]_p18079 at such times. At first, some effort was needed, and [he]_p18080 had to make many passes but now, [she]_p18081 seems to yield at once, as if by habit, and scarcely any action is needed. [He]_p18082 seems to have power at these particular moments to simply will, and [her]_p18083 thoughts obey him. [He]_p18084 always asks [her]_p18085 what [she]_p18086 can see and hear. [She]_p18087 answers to the first:,   "Nothing all is dark. " And to the second:,   "I can hear the waves lapping against the ship, and the water rushing by. Canvas and cordage strain and masts and yards creak. The wind is high, [I]_p18088 can hear [it]_p18089 in the shrouds, and the bow throws back the foam. " [It]_p18090 is evident that the [Czarina Catherine]_n2133 is still at sea, hastening on [her]_p18091 way to Varna. [Lord Godalming]_n2134 has just returned.

[He]_p18092 had four telegrams, one each day since [we]_p18093 started, and all to the same effect: that the [Czarina Catherine]_n2135 had not been reported to Lloyd's from anywhere. [He]_p18094 had arranged before leaving London that [his]_p18095 agent should send [him]_p18096 every day a telegram saying if the ship had been reported. [He]_p18097 was to have a message even if [she]_p18098 were not reported, so that [he]_p18099 might be sure that there was a watch being kept at the other end of the wire. [We]_p18100 had dinner and went to bed early. To-morrow [we]_p18101 are to see the Vice-Consul, and to arrange, if [we]_p18102 can, about getting on board the ship as soon as [she]_p18103 arrives. [Van Helsing]_n2136 says that [our]_p18104 chance will be to get on the boat between sunrise and sunset. The Count, even if [he]_p18105 takes the form of a bat, cannot cross the running water of [his]_p18106 own volition, and so cannot leave the ship. As [he]_p18107 dare not change to man's form without suspicion, which [he]_p18108 evidently wishes to avoid, [he]_p18108 must remain in the box. If, then, [we]_p18110 can come on board after sunrise, [he]_p18113 is at [our]_p18115 mercy  for [we]_p18111 can open the box and make sure of him, as [we]_p18111 did of poor Lucy, before [he]_p18114 wakes. What mercy [he]_p18116 shall get from [us]_p18117 will not count for much.

[We]_p18118 think that [we]_p18119 shall not have much trouble with officials or the seamen. Thank God! this is the country where bribery can do anything, and [we]_p18120 are well supplied with money. [We]_p18121 have only to make sure that the ship cannot come into port between sunset and sunrise without [our]_p18122 being warned, and [we]_p18123 shall be safe. Judge Moneybag will settle this case, [I]_p18124 think!  * * * * *  16 October. , Mina's report still the same: lapping waves and rushing water, darkness and favouring winds. [We]_p18125 are evidently in good time, and when [we]_p18126 hear of the [Czarina Catherine]_n2137 [we]_p18127 shall be ready. As [she]_p18128 must pass the Dardanelles [we]_p18129 are sure to have some report. * * * * *  17 October. , Everything is pretty well fixed now, [I]_p18130 think, to welcome the Count on [his]_p18131 return from [his]_p18132 tour. [Godalming]_n2138 told the shippers that [he]_p18133 fancied that the box sent aboard might contain something stolen from a friend of his, and got a half consent that [he]_p18134 might open [it]_p18137 at [his]_p18135 own risk.

The owner gave [him]_p18138 a paper telling the Captain to give [him]_p18139 every facility in doing whatever [he]_p18140 chose on board the ship, and also a similar authorisation to [his]_p18141 agent at Varna. [We]_p18142 have seen the agent, who was much impressed with [Godalming]_n's2139 kindly manner to him, and [we]_p18143 are all satisfied that whatever [he]_p18144 can do to aid [our]_p18145 wishes will be done. [We]_p18146 have already arranged what to do in case [we]_p18147 get the box open. If the Count is there, [Van Helsing]_n2140 and Seward will cut off [his]_p18148 head at once and drive a stake through [his]_p18149 heart. Morris and [Godalming]_n2141 and [I]_p18150 shall prevent interference, even if [we]_p18151 have to use the arms which [we]_p18152 shall have ready. The Professor says that if [we]_p18153 can so treat the Count's body, [it]_p18154 will soon after fall into dust. In such case there would be no evidence against us, in case any suspicion of murder were aroused. But even if [it]_p18155 were not, [we]_p18156 should stand or fall by [our]_p18157 act, and perhaps some day this very script may be evidence to come between some of [us]_p18158 and a rope. For myself, [I]_p18159 should take the chance only too thankfully if [it]_p18160 were to come. [We]_p18161 mean to leave no stone unturned to carry out [our]_p18162 intent.

[We]_p18163 have arranged with certain officials that the instant the [Czarina Catherine]_n2142 is seen, [we]_p18164 are to be informed by a special messenger. * * * * *  24 October. , A whole week of waiting. [Daily]_n2143 telegrams to [Godalming]_n,2144 but only the same story: "Not yet reported. " Mina's morning and evening hypnotic answer is unvaried: lapping waves, rushing water, and creaking masts. Telegram, October 24th. [Rufus Smith]_n,2145 Lloyd's, London, to [Lord Godalming]_n,2146 care of H. B. M. Vice-Consul, Varna.

"[Czarina Catherine]_n2147 reported this morning from Dardanelles. " [Dr Seward]_n's2148 [Diary]_n2149. 25 October. , How [I]_p18165 miss [my]_p18167 phonograph! To write diary with a pen is irksome to [me]_p18168 but [Van Helsing]_n2150 says [I]_p18166 must. [We]_p18169 were all wild with excitement yesterday when [Godalming]_n2151 got [his]_p18170 telegram from Lloyd's. [I]_p18171 know now what men feel in battle when the call to action is heard. [Mrs Harker]_n,2152 alone of [our]_p18172 party, did not show any signs of emotion. After all, [it]_p18173 is not strange that [she]_p18175 did not for [we]_p18176 took special care not to let [her]_p18179 know anything about it, and [we]_p18177 all tried not to show any excitement when [we]_p18177 were in [her]_p18180 presence. In old days [she]_p18181 would, [I]_p18183 am sure, have noticed, no matter how [we]_p18184 might have tried to conceal [it]_p18185 but in this way [she]_p18182 is greatly changed during the past three weeks. The lethargy grows upon her, and though [she]_p18188 seems strong and well, and is getting back some of [her]_p18186 colour, [Van Helsing]_n2153 and [I]_p18189 are not satisfied.

[We]_p18190 talk of [her]_p18191 often [we]_p18192 have not, however, said a word to the others. [It]_p18193 would break poor Harker's heart, certainly [his]_p18194 nerve, if [he]_p18195 knew that [we]_p18196 had even a suspicion on the subject. [Van Helsing]_n2154 examines, [he]_p18197 tells me, [her]_p18199 teeth very carefully, whilst [she]_p18201 is in the hypnotic condition, for [he]_p18198 says that so long as [they]_p18202 do not begin to sharpen there is no active danger of a change in her. If this change should come, [it]_p18203 would be necessary to take steps!. [We]_p18204 both know what those steps would have to be, though [we]_p18205 do not mention [our]_p18206 thoughts to each other. [We]_p18207 should neither of [us]_p18208 shrink from the task, awful though [it]_p18209 be to contemplate. "Euthanasia" is an excellent and a comforting word! [I]_p18210 am grateful to whoever invented it. [It]_p18211 is only about 24 hours' sail from the Dardanelles to here, at the rate the [Czarina Catherine]_n2155 has come from [London]_n2156. [She]_p18212 should therefore arrive some time in the morning but as [she]_p18213 cannot possibly get in before then, [we]_p18214 are all about to retire early. [We]_p18215 shall get up at one o'clock, so as to be ready.

* * * * *  25 October, Noon. , No news yet of the ship's arrival. Mrs Harker's hypnotic report this morning was the same as usual, so [it]_p18216 is possible that [we]_p18217 may get news at any moment. [We]_p18218 men are all in a fever of excitement, except Harker, who is calm [his]_p18219 hands are cold as ice, and an hour ago [I]_p18220 found [him]_p18221 whetting the edge of the great Ghoorka knife which [he]_p18223 now always carries with him. [It]_p18224 will be a bad lookout for the Count if the edge of that "Kukri" ever touches [his]_p18225 throat, driven by that stern, ice-cold hand! [Van Helsing]_n2157 and [I]_p18226 were a little alarmed about Mrs Harker to-day. About noon [she]_p18227 got into a sort of lethargy which [we]_p18228 did not like although [we]_p18229 kept silence to the others, [we]_p18229 were neither of [us]_p18231 happy about it.
