[She]_p18232 had been restless all the morning, so that [we]_p18233 were at first glad to know that [she]_p18234 was sleeping. When, however, [her]_p18235 husband mentioned casually that [she]_p18238 was sleeping so soundly that [he]_p18239 could not wake her, [we]_p18240 went to [her]_p18236 room to see for ourselves. [She]_p18241 was breathing naturally and looked so well and peaceful that [we]_p18242 agreed that the sleep was better for [her]_p18243 than anything else. [Poor]_n2158 girl, [she]_p18244 has so much to forget that [it]_p18245 is no wonder that sleep, if [it]_p18246 brings oblivion to her, does [her]_p18247 good.

* * * * *  Later. , [Our]_p18249 opinion was justified, for when after a refreshing sleep of some hours [she]_p18250 woke up, [she]_p18251 seemed brighter and better than [she]_p18251 had been for days. At sunset [she]_p18253 made the usual hypnotic report. Wherever [he]_p18254 may be in the Black Sea, the Count is hurrying to [his]_p18255 destination. To [his]_p18256 doom, [I]_p18257 trust!  * * * * *  26 October. , Another day and no tidings of the [Czarina Catherine]_n2159. [She]_p18258 ought to be here by now. That [she]_p18259 is still journeying somewhere is apparent, for Mrs Harker's hypnotic report at sunrise was still the same. [It]_p18260 is possible that the vessel may be lying by, at times, for fog  some of the steamers which came in last evening reported patches of fog both to north and south of the port. [We]_p18261 must continue [our]_p18262 watching, as the ship may now be signalled any moment.

* * * * *  27 October, Noon. , Most strange no news yet of the ship [we]_p18263 wait for. [Mrs Harker]_n2160 reported last night and this morning as usual: "lapping waves and rushing water," though [she]_p18264 added that "the waves were very faint. " The telegrams from London have been the same: "no further report. " [Van Helsing]_n2161 is terribly anxious, and told [me]_p18265 just now that [he]_p18266 fears the Count is escaping us. [He]_p18267 added significantly:, "I did not like that lethargy of [Madam Mina]_n's2162. Souls and memories can do strange things during trance. " [I]_p18268 was about to ask [him]_p18269 more, but Harker just then came in, and [he]_p18270 held up a warning hand. [We]_p18271 must try [to-night]_n2163 at sunset to make [her]_p18272 speak more fully when in [her]_p18273 hypnotic state. * * * * *  28 October.

, Telegram. [Rufus Smith]_n,2164 London, to [Lord Godalming]_n,2165 care H. B. M. Vice Consul, Varna. "[Czarina Catherine]_n2166 reported entering [Galatz]_n2167 at one o'clock to-day. " [Dr Seward]_n's2168 [Diary]_n2169. 28 October. , When the telegram came announcing the arrival in [Galatz]_n2170 [I]_p18274 do not think [it]_p18275 was such a shock to any of [us]_p18276 as might have been expected. True, [we]_p18277 did not know whence, or how, or when, the bolt would come but [I]_p18279 think [we]_p18278 all expected that something strange would happen.

The delay of arrival at Varna made [us]_p18280 individually satisfied that things would not be just as [we]_p18281 had expected [we]_p18282 only waited to learn where the change would occur. None the less, however, was [it]_p18283 a surprise. [I]_p18284 suppose that nature works on such a hopeful basis that [we]_p18285 believe against [ourselves]_p18287 that things will be as [they]_p18288 ought to be, not as [we]_p18286 should know that [they]_p18289 will be. Transcendentalism is a beacon to the angels, even if [it]_p18290 be a will-o'-the-wisp to man. [It]_p18291 was an odd experience and [we]_p18292 all took [it]_p18293 differently. [Van Helsing]_n2171 raised [his]_p18294 hand over [his]_p18295 head for a moment, as though in remonstrance with the [Almighty]_n2172 but [he]_p18297 said not a word, and in a few seconds stood up with [his]_p18295 face sternly set. [Lord Godalming]_n2173 grew very pale, and sat breathing heavily. [I]_p18298 was [myself]_p18299 half stunned and looked in wonder at one after another. [Quincey]_n2174 Morris tightened [his]_p18300 belt with that quick movement which [I]_p18301 knew so well in [our]_p18302 old wandering days [it]_p18303 meant "action. " [Mrs Harker]_n2175 grew ghastly white, so that the scar on [her]_p18304 forehead seemed to burn, but [she]_p18306 folded [her]_p18305 hands meekly and looked up in prayer.

Harker smiled, actually smiled, the dark, bitter smile of one who is without hope but at the same time [his]_p18307 action belied [his]_p18308 words, for [his]_p18308 hands instinctively sought the hilt of the great Kukri knife and rested there. "When does the next train start for [Galatz]_n?"2176 said [Van Helsing]_n2177 to [us]_p18310 generally. "At 6:30 to-morrow morning!" [We]_p18311 all started, for the answer came from [Mrs Harker]_n2178. "How on earth do [you]_p18312 know?" said [Art]_n2179. "You forget, or perhaps [you]_p18313 do not know, though Jonathan does and so does Dr [Van Helsing]_n,2180 that [I]_p18314 am the train fiend. At home in [Exeter]_n2181 [I]_p18315 always used to make up the time-tables, so as to be helpful to [my]_p18316 husband. [I]_p18317 found [it]_p18319 so useful sometimes, that [I]_p18318 always make a study of the time-tables now. [I]_p18320 knew that if anything were to take [us]_p18322 to [Castle Dracula]_n2182 [we]_p18323 should go by [Galatz]_n,2183 or at any rate through Bucharest, so [I]_p18321 learned the times very carefully. Unhappily there are not many to learn, as the only train [to-morrow]_n2184 leaves as [I]_p18324 say. " "Wonderful woman!" murmured the [Professor]_n2185.

"Can't [we]_p18325 get a special?" asked [Lord Godalming]_n2186. [Van Helsing]_n2187 shook [his]_p18326 head: "I fear not. This land is very different from [yours]_p18327 or [mine]_p18328 even if [we]_p18329 did have a special, [it]_p18330 would probably not arrive as soon as [our]_p18331 regular train. Moreover, [we]_p18332 have something to prepare. [We]_p18333 must think. Now let [us]_p18334 organize. You, friend [Arthur]_n,2188 go to the train and get the tickets and arrange that all be ready for [us]_p18335 to go in the morning. Do you, friend Jonathan, go to the agent of the ship and get from [him]_p18336 letters to the agent in [Galatz]_n,2189 with authority to make search the ship just as [it]_p18337 was here. Morris Quincey, [you]_p18338 see the Vice-Consul, and get [his]_p18339 aid with [his]_p18340 fellow in Galatz and all [he]_p18341 can do to make [our]_p18342 way smooth, so that no times be lost when over the Danube. [John]_n2190 will stay with [Madam Mina]_n2191 and me, and [we]_p18343 shall consult.

For so if time be long [you]_p18344 may be delayed and [it]_p18345 will not matter when the sun set, since [I]_p18346 am here with [Madam]_n2192 to make report. "  "And I," said Mrs Harker brightly, and more like [her]_p18349 old self than [she]_p18350 had been for many a long day, "shall try to be of use in all ways, and shall think and write for [you]_p18351 as [I]_p18347 used to do. Something is shifting from [me]_p18352 in some strange way, and [I]_p18353 feel freer than [I]_p18354 have been of late!" The three younger men looked happier at the moment as [they]_p18356 seemed to realise the significance of [her]_p18357 words but [Van]_n2193 Helsing and I, turning to each other, met each a grave and troubled glance. [We]_p18358 said nothing at the time, however. When the three men had gone out to [their]_p18359 tasks [Van Helsing]_n2194 asked Mrs Harker to look up the copy of the diaries and find [him]_p18360 the part of Harker's journal at the Castle. [She]_p18361 went away to get [it]_p18362 when the door was shut upon [her]_p18363 [he]_p18364 said to me:,   "We mean the same! speak out!"  "There is some change. [It]_p18365 is a hope that makes [me]_p18366 sick, for [it]_p18367 may deceive us. "  "Quite so. Do [you]_p18368 know why [I]_p18369 asked [her]_p18371 to get the manuscript?"  "No!" said I, "unless [it]_p18372 was to get an opportunity of seeing [me]_p18373 alone. "  "You are in part right, friend John, but only in part.

[I]_p18374 want to tell [you]_p18375 something. And oh, [my]_p18376 friend, [I]_p18377 am taking a great, a terrible, risk  but [I]_p18378 believe [it]_p18379 is right. In the moment when [Madam]_n2195 Mina said those words that arrest both [our]_p18380 understanding, an inspiration came to me. In the trance of three days ago the Count sent [her]_p18381 [his]_p18384 spirit to read [her]_p18382 mind or more like [he]_p18386 took [her]_p18382 to see [him]_p18387 in [his]_p18385 earth-box in the ship with water rushing, just as [it]_p18388 go free at rise and set of sun. [He]_p18389 learn then that [we]_p18390 are here for [she]_p18391 have more to tell in [her]_p18392 open life with eyes to see and ears to hear than he, shut, as [he]_p18393 is, in [his]_p18395 coffin-box. Now [he]_p18396 make [his]_p18397 most effort to escape us. At present [he]_p18398 want [her]_p18399 not. "He is sure with [his]_p18400 so great knowledge that [she]_p18403 will come at [his]_p18401 call  but [he]_p18405 cut [her]_p18407 off, take her, as [he]_p18406 can do, out of [his]_p18401 own power, that so [she]_p18404 come not to him. Ah! there [I]_p18409 have hope that [our]_p18410 man-brains that have been of man so long and that have not lost the grace of God, will come higher than [his]_p18412 child-brain that lie in [his]_p18413 tomb for centuries, that grow not yet to [our]_p18411 stature, and that do only work selfish and therefore small. Here comes Madam Mina not a word to [her]_p18414 of [her]_p18415 trance! [She]_p18421 know [it]_p18422 not and [it]_p18423 would overwhelm [her]_p18415 and make despair just when [we]_p18424 want all [her]_p18416 hope, all [her]_p18416 courage when most [we]_p18425 want all [her]_p18416 great brain which is trained like man's brain, but is of sweet woman and have a special power which the Count give her, and which [he]_p18426 may not take away altogether, though [he]_p18427 think not so.

Hush! let [me]_p18428 speak, and [you]_p18429 shall learn. Oh, John, [my]_p18430 friend, [we]_p18431 are in awful straits. [I]_p18432 fear, as [I]_p18433 never feared before. [We]_p18434 can only trust the good God. Silence! here [she]_p18435 comes!" [I]_p18436 thought that the [Professor]_n2196 was going to break down and have hysterics, just as [he]_p18437 had when Lucy died, but with a great effort [he]_p18438 controlled [himself]_p18439 and was at perfect nervous poise when Mrs Harker tripped into the room, bright and happy-looking and, in the doing of work, seemingly forgetful of [her]_p18440 misery. As [she]_p18441 came in, [she]_p18442 handed a number of sheets of typewriting to [Van Helsing]_n2197. [He]_p18443 looked over [them]_p18444 gravely, [his]_p18445 face brightening up as [he]_p18446 read. Then holding the pages between [his]_p18447 finger and thumb [he]_p18448 said:, "[Friend John]_n,2198 to [you]_p18449 with so much of experience already, and you, too, [dear Madam Mina]_n,2199 that are [young]_n,2200 here is a lesson: do not fear ever to think. A half-thought has been buzzing often in [my]_p18451 brain, but [I]_p18452 fear to let [him]_p18453 loose [his]_p18454 wings. Here now, with more knowledge, [I]_p18455 go back to where that half-thought come from and [I]_p18456 find that [he]_p18457 be no half-thought at all that be a whole thought, though so [young]_n2201 that [he]_p18458 is not yet strong to use [his]_p18459 little wings.

Nay, like the "Ugly Duck" of [my]_p18460 friend [Hans Andersen]_n,2202 [he]_p18461 be no duck-thought at all, but a big swan-thought that sail nobly on big wings, when the time come for [him]_p18462 to try them. See [I]_p18463 read here what Jonathan have written:, "That other of [his]_p18464 race who, in a later age, again and again, brought [his]_p18465 forces over The Great River into [Turkey Land]_n2203 who, when [he]_p18467 was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though [he]_p18468 had to come alone from the bloody field where [his]_p18465 troops were being slaughtered, since [he]_p18468 knew that [he]_p18469 alone could ultimately triumph. "  "What does this tell us? Not much? no! The Count's child-thought see nothing therefore [he]_p18471 speak so free. [Your]_p18472 man-thought see nothing [my]_p18473 man-thought see nothing, till just now. No! But there comes another word from some one who speak without thought because she, too, know not what [it]_p18474 mean, what [it]_p18475 might mean. Just as there are elements which rest, yet when in nature's course [they]_p18476 move on [their]_p18478 way and [they]_p18477 touch, then pouf! and there comes a flash of light, heaven wide, that blind and kill and destroy some but that show up all earth below for leagues and leagues. Is [it]_p18479 not so? Well, [I]_p18480 shall explain. To begin, have [you]_p18481 ever study the philosophy of crime? 'Yes' and 'No. ' You, [John]_n,2204 yes for [it]_p18482 is a study of insanity. You, no, [Madam Mina]_n2205 for crime touch [you]_p18483 not, not but once.

Still, [your]_p18484 mind works true, and argues not a particulari ad universale. There is this peculiarity in criminals. [It]_p18485 is so constant, in all countries and at all times, that even police, who know not much from philosophy, come to know [it]_p18486 empirically, that [it]_p18487 is. That is to be empiric. The criminal always work at one crime, that is the true criminal who seems predestinate to crime, and who will of none other. This criminal has not full man-brain. [He]_p18488 is clever and cunning and resourceful but [he]_p18489 be not of man-stature as to brain. [He]_p18490 be of child-brain in much. Now this criminal of [ours]_p18491 is predestinate to crime also he, too, have child-brain, and [it]_p18494 is of the child to do what [he]_p18492 have done. The little bird, the little fish, the little animal learn not by principle, but empirically and when [he]_p18495 learn to do, then there is to [him]_p18496 the ground to start from to do more.

'Dos pou sto,' said Archimedes. 'Give [me]_p18497 a fulcrum, and [I]_p18498 shall move the world!' To do once, is the fulcrum whereby child-brain become man-brain and until [he]_p18500 have the purpose to do more, [he]_p18501 continue to do the same again every time, just as [he]_p18501 have done before! Oh, [my]_p18503 [dear]_n,2206 [I]_p18499 see that [your]_p18504 eyes are opened, and that to [you]_p18505 the lightning flash show all the leagues," for Mrs Harker began to clap [her]_p18506 hands and [her]_p18507 eyes sparkled. [He]_p18508 went on:,   "Now [you]_p18509 shall speak. Tell [us]_p18510 two dry men of science what [you]_p18511 see with those so bright eyes. " [He]_p18512 took [her]_p18513 hand and held [it]_p18514 whilst [she]_p18515 spoke. [His]_p18516 finger and thumb closed on [her]_p18517 pulse, as [I]_p18518 thought instinctively and unconsciously, as [she]_p18519 spoke:,   "The Count is a criminal and of criminal type. Nordau and Lombroso would so classify him, and qu criminal [he]_p18520 is of imperfectly formed mind. Thus, in a difficulty [he]_p18521 has to seek resource in habit. [His]_p18522 past is a clue, and the one page of [it]_p18523 that [we]_p18524 know, and that from [his]_p18525 own lips, tells that once before, when in what Mr Morris would call a 'tight place,' [he]_p18527 went back to [his]_p18526 own country from the land [he]_p18528 had tried to invade, and thence, without losing purpose, prepared [himself]_p18529 for a new effort. [He]_p18530 came again better equipped for [his]_p18531 work and won.

So [he]_p18532 came to London to invade a new land. [He]_p18533 was beaten, and when all hope of success was lost, and [his]_p18534 existence in danger, [he]_p18536 fled back over the sea to [his]_p18535 home just as formerly [he]_p18537 had fled back over the Danube from [Turkey Land]_n2207. " "Good, good! oh, [you]_p18538 so clever lady!" said [Van Helsing]_n,2208 enthusiastically, as [he]_p18539 stooped and kissed [her]_p18540 hand. A moment later [he]_p18541 said to me, as calmly as though [we]_p18542 had been having a sick-room consultation:,   "Seventy-two only and in all this excitement. [I]_p18543 have hope. " Turning to [her]_p18544 again, [he]_p18545 said with keen expectation:,   "But go on. Go on! there is more to tell if [you]_p18546 will. Be not afraid [John]_n2209 and [I]_p18547 know. [I]_p18548 do in any case, and shall tell [you]_p18549 if [you]_p18550 are right. Speak, without fear!"  "I will try to but [you]_p18553 will forgive [me]_p18554 if [I]_p18551 seem egotistical.

" "[Nay]_n!2210 fear not, [you]_p18555 must be egotist, for [it]_p18557 is of [you]_p18556 that [we]_p18558 think. "  "Then, as [he]_p18559 is criminal [he]_p18560 is selfish and as [his]_p18562 intellect is small and [his]_p18563 action is based on selfishness, [he]_p18560 confines [himself]_p18564 to one purpose. That purpose is remorseless. As [he]_p18565 fled back over the Danube, leaving [his]_p18567 forces to be cut to pieces, so now [he]_p18566 is intent on being safe, careless of all. So [his]_p18568 own selfishness frees [my]_p18569 soul somewhat from the terrible power which [he]_p18570 acquired over [me]_p18571 on that dreadful night. [I]_p18572 felt it! Oh, [I]_p18573 felt it! Thank God, for [His]_p18577 great mercy! [My]_p18578 soul is freer than [it]_p18574 has been since that awful hour and all that haunts [me]_p18579 is a fear lest in some trance or dream [he]_p18580 may have used [my]_p18581 knowledge for [his]_p18582 ends. " The [Professor]_n2211 stood up:, "He has so used [your]_p18583 mind and by [it]_p18584 [he]_p18585 has left [us]_p18587 here in Varna, whilst the ship that carried [him]_p18589 rushed through enveloping fog up to [Galatz]_n,2212 where, doubtless, [he]_p18586 had made preparation for escaping from us. But [his]_p18590 child-mind only saw so far and [it]_p18593 may be that, as ever is in God's [Providence]_n,2213 the very thing that the evil-doer most reckoned on for [his]_p18591 selfish good, turns out to be [his]_p18591 chiefest harm. The hunter is taken in [his]_p18594 own snare, as the great Psalmist says. For now that [he]_p18595 think [he]_p18596 is free from every trace of [us]_p18598 all, and that [he]_p18596 has escaped [us]_p18599 with so many hours to him, then [his]_p18602 selfish child-brain will whisper [him]_p18600 to sleep.

[He]_p18603 think, too, that as [he]_p18604 cut [himself]_p18607 off from knowing [your]_p18608 mind, there can be no knowledge of [him]_p18610 to [you]_p18612 there is where [he]_p18605 fail! That terrible baptism of blood which [he]_p18605 give [you]_p18613 makes [you]_p18613 free to go to [him]_p18611 in spirit, as [you]_p18614 have as yet done in [your]_p18609 times of freedom, when the sun rise and set. At such times [you]_p18616 go by [my]_p18619 volition and not by [his]_p18620  and this power to good of [you]_p18617 and others, as [you]_p18617 have won from [your]_p18622 suffering at [his]_p18621 hands. This is now all the more precious that [he]_p18623 know [it]_p18624 not, and to guard [himself]_p18625 have even cut [himself]_p18626 off from [his]_p18627 knowledge of [our]_p18628 where. We, however, are not selfish, and [we]_p18629 believe that God is with [us]_p18630 through all this blackness, and these many dark hours. [We]_p18631 shall follow [him]_p18632 and [we]_p18634 shall not flinch even if [we]_p18635 peril [ourselves]_p18637 that [we]_p18635 become like him. [Friend John]_n,2214 this has been a great hour and [it]_p18638 have done much to advance [us]_p18639 on [our]_p18640 way. [You]_p18641 must be scribe and write [him]_p18642 all down, so that when the others return from [their]_p18643 work [you]_p18644 can give [it]_p18645 to [them]_p18646 then [they]_p18647 shall know as [we]_p18648 do. "  And so [I]_p18649 have written [it]_p18650 whilst [we]_p18651 wait [their]_p18652 return, and Mrs Harker has written with [her]_p18653 typewriter all since [she]_p18654 brought the MS. to us. CHAPTER XXVI [DR]_n2215.

SEWARD'S [DIARY]_n2216 29 October. , This is written in the train from Varna to [Galatz]_n2217. Last night [we]_p18655 all assembled a little before the time of sunset. Each of [us]_p18656 had done [his]_p18657 work as well as [he]_p18658 could so far as thought, and endeavour, and opportunity go, [we]_p18659 are prepared for the whole of [our]_p18661 journey, and for [our]_p18662 work when [we]_p18660 get to [Galatz]_n2218. When the usual time came round Mrs Harker prepared [herself]_p18663 for [her]_p18664 hypnotic effort and after a longer and more serious effort on the part of [Van Helsing]_n2219 than has been usually necessary, [she]_p18665 sank into the trance. Usually [she]_p18666 speaks on a hint but this time the [Professor]_n2220 had to ask [her]_p18667 questions, and to ask [them]_p18669 pretty resolutely, before [we]_p18670 could learn anything at last [her]_p18668 answer came:, "I can see nothing [we]_p18671 are still there are no waves lapping, but only a steady swirl of water softly running against the hawser. [I]_p18672 can hear men's voices calling, near and far, and the roll and creak of oars in the rowlocks. A gun is fired somewhere the echo of [it]_p18673 seems far away. There is tramping of feet overhead, and ropes and chains are dragged along. What is this? There is a gleam of light [I]_p18674 can feel the air blowing upon me.

"  Here [she]_p18675 stopped. [She]_p18676 had risen, as if impulsively, from where [she]_p18677 lay on the sofa, and raised both [her]_p18678 hands, palms upwards, as if lifting a weight. [Van Helsing]_n2221 and [I]_p18679 looked at each other with understanding. [Quincey]_n2222 raised [his]_p18680 eyebrows slightly and looked at [her]_p18682 intently, whilst Harker's hand instinctively closed round the hilt of [his]_p18681 Kukri. There was a long pause. [We]_p18683 all knew that the time when [she]_p18684 could speak was passing but [we]_p18685 felt that [it]_p18686 was useless to say anything. Suddenly [she]_p18687 sat up, and, as [she]_p18688 opened [her]_p18689 eyes, said sweetly:,   "Would none of [you]_p18691 like a cup of tea? [You]_p18692 must all be so tired!" [We]_p18693 could only make [her]_p18690 happy, and so acquiesced. [She]_p18694 bustled off to get tea when [she]_p18695 had gone [Van Helsing]_n2223 said:, "You see, [my]_p18696 friends. [He]_p18697 is close to land: [he]_p18698 has left [his]_p18699 earth-chest. But [he]_p18700 has yet to get on shore.

In the night [he]_p18701 may lie hidden somewhere but if [he]_p18702 be not carried on shore, or if the ship do not touch it, [he]_p18702 cannot achieve the land. In such case [he]_p18704 can, if [it]_p18706 be in the night, change [his]_p18707 form and can jump or fly on shore, as [he]_p18705 did at [Whitby]_n2224. But if the day come before [he]_p18708 get on shore, then, unless [he]_p18709 be carried [he]_p18709 cannot escape. And if [he]_p18711 be carried, then the customs men may discover what the box contain. Thus, in fine, if [he]_p18712 escape not on shore [to-night]_n,2225 or before dawn, there will be the whole day lost to him. [We]_p18713 may then arrive in time for if [he]_p18714 escape not at night [we]_p18717 shall come on [him]_p18718 in daytime, boxed up and at [our]_p18719 mercy for [he]_p18715 dare not be [his]_p18720 true self, awake and visible, lest [he]_p18715 be discovered. "  There was no more to be said, so [we]_p18721 waited in patience until the dawn  at which time [we]_p18722 might learn more from Mrs Harker. Early this morning [we]_p18723 listened, with breathless anxiety, for [her]_p18724 response in [her]_p18725 trance. The hypnotic stage was even longer in coming than before and when [it]_p18726 came the time remaining until full sunrise was so short that [we]_p18727 began to despair. [Van Helsing]_n2226 seemed to throw [his]_p18728 whole soul into the effort at last, in obedience to [his]_p18729 will [she]_p18730 made reply:, "All is dark.

[I]_p18731 hear lapping water, level with me, and some creaking as of wood on wood. " [She]_p18732 paused, and the red sun shot up. [We]_p18733 must wait till [to-night]_n2227. And so [it]_p18734 is that [we]_p18735 are travelling towards [Galatz]_n2228 in an agony of expectation. [We]_p18736 are due to arrive between two and three in the morning  but already, at Bucharest, [we]_p18737 are three hours late, so [we]_p18738 cannot possibly get in till well after sun-up. Thus [we]_p18739 shall have two more hypnotic messages from Mrs Harker either or both may possibly throw more light on what is happening. * * * * *  Later. , Sunset has come and gone. Fortunately [it]_p18740 came at a time when there was no distraction for had [it]_p18741 occurred whilst [we]_p18742 were at a station, [we]_p18743 might not have secured the necessary calm and isolation. Mrs Harker yielded to the hypnotic influence even less readily than this morning.

[I]_p18744 am in fear that [her]_p18745 power of reading the Count's sensations may die away, just when [we]_p18746 want [it]_p18747 most. [It]_p18748 seems to [me]_p18749 that [her]_p18750 imagination is beginning to work. Whilst [she]_p18751 has been in the trance hitherto [she]_p18752 has confined [herself]_p18753 to the simplest of facts. If this goes on [it]_p18754 may ultimately mislead us. If [I]_p18755 thought that the Count's power over [her]_p18757 would die away equally with [her]_p18758 power of knowledge [it]_p18759 would be a happy thought but [I]_p18756 am afraid that [it]_p18760 may not be so. When [she]_p18761 did speak, [her]_p18762 words were enigmatical:,   "Something is going out [I]_p18763 can feel [it]_p18764 pass [me]_p18765 like a cold wind. [I]_p18766 can hear, far off, confused sounds, as of men talking in strange tongues, fierce-falling water, and the howling of wolves. " [She]_p18767 stopped and a shudder ran through her, increasing in intensity for a few seconds, till, at the end, [she]_p18768 shook as though in a palsy. [She]_p18769 said no more, even in answer to the [Professor]_n's2229 imperative questioning. When [she]_p18770 woke from the trance, [she]_p18771 was cold, and exhausted, and languid but [her]_p18772 mind was all alert.

[She]_p18773 could not remember anything, but asked what [she]_p18774 had said  when [she]_p18775 was told, [she]_p18775 pondered over [it]_p18777 deeply for a long time and in silence. * * * * *  30 October, 7 a. m. , [We]_p18778 are near [Galatz]_n2230 now, and [I]_p18779 may not have time to write later. Sunrise this morning was anxiously looked for by [us]_p18780 all. Knowing of the increasing difficulty of procuring the hypnotic trance, [Van Helsing]_n2231 began [his]_p18781 passes earlier than usual. [They]_p18782 produced no effect, however, until the regular time, when [she]_p18783 yielded with a still greater difficulty, only a minute before the sun rose. The [Professor]_n2232 lost no time in [his]_p18784 questioning [her]_p18785 answer came with equal quickness:, "All is dark. [I]_p18786 hear water swirling by, level with [my]_p18787 ears, and the creaking of wood on wood. Cattle low far off.

There is another sound, a queer one like, , " [She]_p18788 stopped and grew white, and whiter still. "Go on go on! Speak, [I]_p18789 command you!" said [Van Helsing]_n2233 in an agonised voice. At the same time there was despair in [his]_p18790 eyes, for the risen sun was reddening even Mrs Harker's pale face. [She]_p18791 opened [her]_p18792 eyes, and [we]_p18793 all started as [she]_p18794 said, sweetly and seemingly with the utmost unconcern:, "Oh, [Professor]_n,2234 why ask [me]_p18795 to do what [you]_p18796 know [I]_p18797 can't? [I]_p18798 don't remember anything. " Then, seeing the look of amazement on [our]_p18799 faces, [she]_p18800 said, turning from one to the other with a troubled look:, "What have [I]_p18801 said? What have [I]_p18802 done? [I]_p18802 know nothing, only that [I]_p18803 was lying here, half asleep, and heard [you]_p18809 say go on! speak, [I]_p18803 command you!' [It]_p18813 seemed so funny to hear [you]_p18810 order [me]_p18814 about, as if [I]_p18803 were a bad child!" "Oh, [Madam]_n2235 Mina," [he]_p18815 said, sadly, "it is proof, if proof be needed, of how [I]_p18804 love and honour you, when a word for [your]_p18818 good, spoken more earnest than ever, can seem so strange because [it]_p18816 is to order [her]_p18819 whom [I]_p18804 am proud to obey!" The whistles are sounding [we]_p18820 are nearing [Galatz]_n2236. [We]_p18821 are on fire with anxiety and eagerness. Mina Harker's [Journal]_n2237. 30 October. , Mr Morris took [me]_p18822 to the hotel where [our]_p18823 rooms had been ordered by telegraph, [he]_p18824 being the one who could best be spared, since [he]_p18825 does not speak any foreign language. The forces were distributed much as [they]_p18826 had been at Varna, except that Lord Godalming went to the Vice-Consul, as [his]_p18827 rank might serve as an immediate guarantee of some sort to the official, [we]_p18828 being in extreme hurry.

Jonathan and the two doctors went to the shipping agent to learn particulars of the arrival of the [Czarina Catherine]_n2238. * * * * *  Later. , [Lord Godalming]_n2239 has returned. The Consul is away, and the Vice-Consul sick so the routine work has been attended to by a clerk. [He]_p18829 was very obliging, and offered to do anything in [his]_p18830 power. Jonathan Harker's [Journal]_n2240. 30 October. , At nine o'clock [Dr Van Helsing]_n,2241 [Dr Seward]_n,2242 and [I]_p18831 called on Messrs. Mackenzie & Steinkoff, the agents of the London firm of Hapgood. [They]_p18832 had received a wire from London, in answer to [Lord Godalming]_n's2243 telegraphed request, asking [us]_p18833 to show [them]_p18834 any civility in [their]_p18835 power.

[They]_p18836 were more than kind and courteous, and took [us]_p18837 at once on board the [Czarina Catherine]_n,2244 which lay at anchor out in the river harbour. There [we]_p18838 saw the [Captain]_n,2245 [Donelson]_n2246 by name, who told [us]_p18839 of [his]_p18840 voyage. [He]_p18841 said that in all [his]_p18842 life [he]_p18843 had never had so favourable a run. "Man!" [he]_p18844 said, "but [it]_p18845 made [us]_p18847 afeard, for [we]_p18848 expeckit that [we]_p18849 should have to pay for [it]_p18846 wi' some rare piece o' ill luck, so as to keep up the average. It's no canny to run [frae London]_n2247 to the [Black Sea wi]_n'2248 a wind ahint ye, as though the Deil [himself]_p18850 were blawin' on yer sail for [his]_p18851 ain purpose. An' a' the time [we]_p18852 could no speer a thing. Gin [we]_p18853 were nigh a ship, or a port, or a headland, a fog fell on [us]_p18856 and travelled wi' us, till when after [it]_p18858 had lifted and [we]_p18854 looked out, the deil a thing could [we]_p18854 see. [We]_p18859 ran by [Gibraltar wi'oot bein]_n'2249 able to signal an' till [we]_p18860 came to the Dardanelles and had to wait to get [our]_p18862 permit to pass, [we]_p18861 never were within hail o' aught. At first [I]_p18863 inclined to slack off sail and beat about till the fog was lifted but whiles, [I]_p18864 thocht that if the Deil was minded to get [us]_p18865 into the [Black Sea]_n2250 quick, [he]_p18866 was like to do [it]_p18867 whether [we]_p18868 would or no. If [we]_p18869 had a quick voyage [it]_p18870 would be no to [our]_p18871 miscredit wi' the owners, or no hurt to [our]_p18872 traffic an' the Old [Mon]_n2251 who had served [his]_p18873 ain purpose wad be decently grateful to [us]_p18874 for no hinderin' him.

" This mixture of simplicity and cunning, of superstition and commercial reasoning, aroused [Van Helsing]_n,2252 who said:, "Mine friend, that Devil is more clever than [he]_p18875 is thought by some and [he]_p18876 know when [he]_p18876 meet [his]_p18878 match!" The skipper was not displeased with the compliment, and went on:, "When [we]_p18879 got past the Bosphorus the men began to grumble some o' them, the Roumanians, came and asked [me]_p18881 to heave overboard a big box which had been put on board by a queer lookin' old man just before [we]_p18880 had started [frae]_n2253 London. [I]_p18882 had seen [them]_p18883 speer at the fellow, and put out [their]_p18884 twa fingers when [they]_p18885 saw him, to guard against the evil eye. Man! but the supersteetion of foreigners is pairfectly rideeculous! [I]_p18886 sent [them]_p18889 aboot [their]_p18890 business pretty quick but as just after a fog closed in on [us]_p18891 [I]_p18887 felt a wee bit as [they]_p18892 did anent something, though [I]_p18887 wouldn't say [it]_p18893 was agin the big box. Well, on [we]_p18894 went, and as the fog didn't let up for five days [I]_p18895 joost let the wind carry [us]_p18896 for if the Deil wanted to get somewheres, well, [he]_p18897 would fetch [it]_p18898 up a'reet. An' if [he]_p18899 didn't, well, we'd keep a sharp lookout anyhow. Sure eneuch, [we]_p18900 had a fair way and deep water all the time and two days ago, when the mornin' sun came through the fog, [we]_p18901 found [ourselves]_p18902 just in the river opposite [Galatz]_n2254. The Roumanians were wild, and wanted [me]_p18903 right or wrong to take out the box and fling [it]_p18904 in the river. [I]_p18905 had to argy wi' [them]_p18907 aboot [it]_p18910 wi' a handspike an' when the last o' [them]_p18908 rose off the deck wi' [his]_p18911 head in [his]_p18912 hand, [I]_p18906 had convinced [them]_p18908 that, evil eye or no evil eye, the property and the trust of [my]_p18913 owners were better in [my]_p18914 hands than in the river Danube. [They]_p18915 had, mind ye, taken the box on the deck ready to fling in, and as [it]_p18916 was marked [Galatz]_n2255 via Varna, [I]_p18918 thocht I'd let [it]_p18917 lie till [we]_p18920 discharged in the port an' get rid o't althegither. [We]_p18921 didn't do much clearin' that day, an' had to remain the nicht at anchor but in the mornin', braw an' airly, an hour before sun-up, a man came aboard wi' an order, written to [him]_p18922 from England, to receive a box marked for one [Count Dracula]_n2256.

Sure eneuch the matter was one ready to [his]_p18923 hand. [He]_p18924 had [his]_p18925 papers a' reet, an' glad [I]_p18926 was to be rid o' the dam' thing, for [I]_p18927 was beginnin' masel' to feel uneasy at it. If the Deil did have any luggage aboord the ship, I'm thinkin' [it]_p18928 was nane [ither]_n2257 than that same!" "What was the name of the man who took it?" asked Dr [Van Helsing]_n2258 with restrained eagerness. "I'll be tellin' [ye]_p18930 quick!" [he]_p18931 answered, and, stepping down to [his]_p18932 cabin, produced a receipt signed "Immanuel [Hildesheim]_n2259. " [Burgen-strasse]_n2260 16 was the address. [We]_p18933 found out that this was all the Captain knew so with thanks [we]_p18934 came away. [We]_p18935 found [Hildesheim]_n2261 in [his]_p18936 office, a Hebrew of rather the [Adelphi]_n2262 [Theatre]_n2263 type, with a nose like a sheep, and a fez. [His]_p18937 arguments were pointed with specie, [we]_p18938 doing the punctuation, and with a little bargaining [he]_p18939 told [us]_p18941 what [he]_p18940 knew. This turned out to be simple but important. [He]_p18942 had received a letter from Mr [de]_n2264 [Ville]_n2265 of [London]_n,2266 telling [him]_p18943 to receive, if possible before sunrise so as to avoid customs, a box which would arrive at [Galatz]_n2267 in the [Czarina Catherine]_n2268.

This [he]_p18944 was to give in charge to a certain Petrof Skinsky, who dealt with the [Slovaks]_n2269 who traded down the river to the port. [He]_p18945 had been paid for [his]_p18946 work by an [English]_n2270 bank note, which had been duly cashed for gold at the [Danube International Bank]_n2271. When Skinsky had come to him, [he]_p18949 had taken [him]_p18947 to the ship and handed over the box, so as to save porterage. That was all [he]_p18950 knew. [We]_p18951 then sought for Skinsky, but were unable to find him. One of [his]_p18952 neighbours, who did not seem to bear [him]_p18953 any affection, said that [he]_p18954 had gone away two days before, no one knew whither. This was corroborated by [his]_p18955 landlord, who had received by messenger the key of the house together with the rent due, in [English]_n2272 money. This had been between ten and eleven o'clock last night. [We]_p18956 were at a standstill again. Whilst [we]_p18957 were talking one came running and breathlessly gasped out that the body of Skinsky had been found inside the wall of the churchyard of [St]_n2273.

Peter, and that the throat had been torn open as if by some wild animal. Those [we]_p18958 had been speaking with ran off to see the horror, the women crying out "This is the work of a Slovak!" [We]_p18960 hurried away lest [we]_p18959 should have been in some way drawn into the affair, and so detained. As [we]_p18961 came home [we]_p18962 could arrive at no definite conclusion. [We]_p18963 were all convinced that the box was on [its]_p18964 way, by water, to somewhere but where that might be [we]_p18965 would have to discover. With heavy hearts [we]_p18966 came home to the hotel to [Mina]_n2274. When [we]_p18967 met together, the first thing was to consult as to taking Mina again into [our]_p18968 confidence. Things are getting desperate, and [it]_p18969 is at least a chance, though a hazardous one. As a preliminary step, [I]_p18970 was released from [my]_p18971 promise to her. Mina Harker's [Journal]_n2275. 30 October, evening.

, [They]_p18972 were so tired and worn out and dispirited that there was nothing to be done till [they]_p18973 had some rest so [I]_p18974 asked [them]_p18976 all to lie down for half an hour whilst [I]_p18975 should enter everything up to the moment. [I]_p18977 feel so grateful to the man who invented the "Traveller's" typewriter, and to Mr Morris for getting this one for me. [I]_p18978 should have felt quite astray doing the work if [I]_p18979 had to write with a pen. [It]_p18980 is all done poor [dear]_n,2276 [dear]_n2277 Jonathan, what [he]_p18981 must have suffered, what must [he]_p18982 be suffering now. [He]_p18983 lies on the sofa hardly seeming to breathe, and [his]_p18984 whole body appears in collapse. [His]_p18985 brows are knit [his]_p18986 face is drawn with pain. [Poor]_n2278 fellow, maybe [he]_p18987 is thinking, and [I]_p18988 can see [his]_p18989 face all wrinkled up with the concentration of [his]_p18990 thoughts. Oh! if [I]_p18991 could only help at all. [I]_p18992 shall do what [I]_p18993 can. [I]_p18994 have asked Dr [Van Helsing]_n,2279 and [he]_p18996 has got [me]_p18997 all the papers that [I]_p18995 have not yet seen.

Whilst [they]_p18998 are resting, [I]_p18999 shall go over all carefully, and perhaps [I]_p19000 may arrive at some conclusion. [I]_p19001 shall try to follow the [Professor]_n's2280 example, and think without prejudice on the facts before me. * * * * *  [I]_p19002 do believe that under God's providence [I]_p19003 have made a discovery. [I]_p19004 shall get the maps and look over them. * * * * *  [I]_p19005 am more than ever sure that [I]_p19006 am right. [My]_p19007 new conclusion is ready, so [I]_p19008 shall get [our]_p19009 party together and read it. [They]_p19010 can judge [it]_p19011 [it]_p19012 is well to be accurate, and every minute is precious. Mina Harker's Memorandum. (Entered in [her]_p19013 [Journal]_n2281. )  Ground of inquiry.

, [Count Dracula]_n's2282 problem is to get back to [his]_p19014 own place. (a) [He]_p19015 must be brought back by some one. This is evident for had [he]_p19016 power to move [himself]_p19019 as [he]_p19017 wished [he]_p19017 could go either as man, or wolf, or bat, or in some other way. [He]_p19020 evidently fears discovery or interference, in the state of helplessness in which [he]_p19021 must be, confined as [he]_p19022 is between dawn and sunset in [his]_p19023 wooden box. (b) How is [he]_p19024 to be taken?, Here a process of exclusions may help us. By road, by rail, by water?  1. By Road. , There are endless difficulties, especially in leaving the city. (x) There are people and people are curious, and investigate. A hint, a surmise, a doubt as to what might be in the box, would destroy him.

(y) There are, or there may be, customs and octroi officers to pass. (z) [His]_p19025 pursuers might follow. This is [his]_p19026 highest fear and in order to prevent [his]_p19027 being betrayed [he]_p19029 has repelled, so far as [he]_p19030 can, even [his]_p19027 victim, me!  2. By [Rail]_n2283. , There is no one in charge of the box. [It]_p19031 would have to take [its]_p19032 chance of being delayed and delay would be fatal, with enemies on the track. True, [he]_p19033 might escape at night but what would [he]_p19034 be, if left in a strange place with no refuge that [he]_p19034 could fly to? This is not what [he]_p19035 intends and [he]_p19035 does not mean to risk it. 3. By [Water]_n2284. , Here is the safest way, in one respect, but with most danger in another.

On the water [he]_p19038 is powerless except at night even then [he]_p19039 can only summon fog and storm and snow and [his]_p19040 wolves. But were [he]_p19041 wrecked, the living water would engulf him, helpless and [he]_p19042 would indeed be lost. [He]_p19043 could have the vessel drive to land but if [it]_p19044 were unfriendly land, wherein [he]_p19045 was not free to move, [his]_p19046 position would still be desperate. [We]_p19047 know from the record that [he]_p19048 was on the water so what [we]_p19049 have to do is to ascertain what water. The first thing is to realise exactly what [he]_p19050 has done as yet [we]_p19051 may, then, get a light on what [his]_p19052 later task is to be. Firstly. , [We]_p19053 must differentiate between what [he]_p19054 did in London as part of [his]_p19057 general plan of action, when [he]_p19055 was pressed for moments and had to arrange as best [he]_p19055 could. Secondly [we]_p19058 must see, as well as [we]_p19059 can surmise [it]_p19061 from the facts [we]_p19059 know of, what [he]_p19062 has done here. As to the first, [he]_p19063 evidently intended to arrive at [Galatz]_n,2285 and sent invoice to Varna to deceive [us]_p19064 lest [we]_p19065 should ascertain [his]_p19066 means of exit from England [his]_p19067 immediate and sole purpose then was to escape. The proof of this, is the letter of instructions sent to Immanuel Hildesheim to clear and take away the box before sunrise.

There is also the instruction to [Petrof Skinsky]_n2286. These [we]_p19068 must only guess at but there must have been some letter or message, since Skinsky came to Hildesheim. That, so far, [his]_p19069 plans were successful [we]_p19070 know. The Czarina Catherine made a phenomenally quick journey, so much so that Captain Donelson's suspicions were aroused but [his]_p19071 superstition united with [his]_p19072 canniness played the Count's game for him, and [he]_p19074 ran with [his]_p19072 favouring wind through fogs and all till [he]_p19075 brought up blindfold at Galatz. That the Count's arrangements were well made, has been proved. [Hildesheim]_n2287 cleared the box, took [it]_p19076 off, and gave [it]_p19077 to Skinsky. [Skinsky]_n2288 took it, and here [we]_p19078 lose the trail. [We]_p19079 only know that the box is somewhere on the water, moving along. The customs and the octroi, if there be any, have been avoided. Now [we]_p19080 come to what the Count must have done after [his]_p19081 arrival, on land, at Galatz.

The box was given to Skinsky before sunrise. At sunrise the Count could appear in [his]_p19082 own form. Here, [we]_p19083 ask why Skinsky was chosen at all to aid in the work? In [my]_p19084 husband's diary, Skinsky is mentioned as dealing with the Slovaks who trade down the river to the port and the man's remark, that the murder was the work of a Slovak, showed the general feeling against [his]_p19085 class. The Count wanted isolation. [My]_p19086 surmise is, this: that in London the Count decided to get back to [his]_p19087 castle by water, as the most safe and secret way. [He]_p19088 was brought from the castle by Szgany, and probably [they]_p19089 delivered [their]_p19091 cargo to [Slovaks]_n2289 who took the boxes to Varna, for there [they]_p19090 were shipped for London. Thus the Count had knowledge of the persons who could arrange this service. When the box was on land, before sunrise or after sunset, [he]_p19092 came out from [his]_p19093 box, met Skinsky and instructed [him]_p19094 what to do as to arranging the carriage of the box up some river. When this was done, and [he]_p19095 knew that all was in train, [he]_p19096 blotted out [his]_p19098 traces, as [he]_p19096 thought, by murdering [his]_p19099 agent. [I]_p19100 have examined the map and find that the river most suitable for the Slovaks to have ascended is either the Pruth or the Sereth.

[I]_p19101 read in the typescript that in [my]_p19103 trance [I]_p19102 heard cows low and water swirling level with [my]_p19104 ears and the creaking of wood. The Count in [his]_p19105 box, then, was on a river in an open boat, propelled probably either by oars or poles, for the banks are near and [it]_p19106 is working against stream. There would be no such sound if floating down stream. Of course [it]_p19107 may not be either the Sereth or the Pruth, but [we]_p19108 may possibly investigate further. Now of these two, the Pruth is the more easily navigated, but the Sereth is, at Fundu, joined by the Bistritza which runs up round the [Borgo Pass]_n2290. The loop [it]_p19109 makes is manifestly as close to [Dracula]_n's2291 castle as can be got by water. Mina Harker's [Journal]_n,2292 continued. When [I]_p19110 had done reading, Jonathan took [me]_p19111 in [his]_p19113 arms and kissed me. The others kept shaking [me]_p19114 by both hands, and Dr [Van Helsing]_n2293 said:, "Our [dear Madam Mina]_n2294 is once more [our]_p19115 teacher. [Her]_p19116 eyes have been where [we]_p19117 were blinded.

Now [we]_p19118 are on the track once again, and this time [we]_p19119 may succeed. [Our]_p19120 enemy is at [his]_p19121 most helpless and if [we]_p19122 can come on [him]_p19123 by day, on the water, [our]_p19124 task will be over. [He]_p19125 has a start, but [he]_p19126 is powerless to hasten, as [he]_p19127 may not leave [his]_p19129 box lest those who carry [him]_p19130 may suspect for [them]_p19132 to suspect would be to prompt [them]_p19133 to throw [him]_p19131 in the stream where [he]_p19127 perish. This [he]_p19134 knows, and will not. Now men, to [our]_p19135 Council of War for, here and now, [we]_p19136 must plan what each and all shall do. " "I shall get a steam launch and follow him," said [Lord Godalming]_n2295. "And I, horses to follow on the bank lest by chance [he]_p19137 land," said [Mr Morris]_n2296. "Good!" said the [Professor]_n,2297 "both good. But neither must go alone. There must be force to overcome force if need be the Slovak is strong and rough, and [he]_p19138 carries rude arms.

" All the men smiled, for amongst [them]_p19139 [they]_p19140 carried a small arsenal. [Said Mr Morris]_n:,2298 "I have brought some Winchesters [they]_p19141 are pretty handy in a crowd, and there may be wolves. The Count, if [you]_p19142 remember, took some other precautions [he]_p19143 made some requisitions on others that Mrs Harker could not quite hear or understand. [We]_p19144 must be ready at all points. " [Dr Seward]_n2299 said:, "I think [I]_p19145 had better go with [Quincey]_n2300. [We]_p19147 have been accustomed to hunt together, and [we]_p19148 two, well armed, will be a match for whatever may come along. [You]_p19149 must not be alone, [Art]_n2301. [It]_p19150 may be necessary to fight the [Slovaks]_n,2302 and a chance thrust, for [I]_p19151 don't suppose these fellows carry guns, would undo all [our]_p19152 plans. There must be no chances, this time [we]_p19153 shall, not rest until the Count's head and body have been separated, and [we]_p19154 are sure that [he]_p19155 cannot re-incarnate. " [He]_p19156 looked at [Jonathan]_n2303 as [he]_p19157 spoke, and [Jonathan]_n2304 looked at me.

[I]_p19158 could see that the poor [dear]_n2305 was torn about in [his]_p19159 mind. Of course [he]_p19160 wanted to be with [me]_p19161 but then the boat service would, most likely, be the one which would destroy the. the. the. [Vampire]_n2306. (Why did [I]_p19162 hesitate to write the word?) [He]_p19163 was silent awhile, and during [his]_p19164 silence Dr [Van Helsing]_n2307 spoke:, "Friend Jonathan, this is to [you]_p19165 for twice reasons. First, because [you]_p19166 are [young]_n2308 and brave and can fight, and all energies may be needed at the last and again that [it]_p19168 is [your]_p19169 right to destroy him, that, which has wrought such woe to [you]_p19167 and yours. Be not afraid for [Madam Mina]_n2309 [she]_p19170 will be [my]_p19171 care, if [I]_p19172 may. [I]_p19173 am old. [My]_p19174 legs are not so quick to run as once and [I]_p19175 am not used to ride so long or to pursue as need be, or to fight with lethal weapons.

But [I]_p19176 can be of other service [I]_p19177 can fight in other way. And [I]_p19178 can die, if need be, as well as younger men. Now let [me]_p19179 say that what [I]_p19180 would is this: while you, [my]_p19182 [Lord]_n2310 [Godalming]_n2311 and friend Jonathan go in [your]_p19183 so swift little steamboat up the river, and whilst John and [Quincey]_n2312 guard the bank where perchance [he]_p19184 might be landed, [I]_p19181 will take [Madam]_n2313 Mina right into the heart of the enemy's country. Whilst the old fox is tied in [his]_p19185 box, floating on the running stream whence [he]_p19188 cannot escape to land, where [he]_p19189 dares not raise the lid of [his]_p19186 coffin-box lest [his]_p19186 Slovak carriers should in fear leave [him]_p19190 to perish, [we]_p19191 shall go in the track where Jonathan went,, from [Bistritz]_n2314 over the [Borgo]_n,2315 and find [our]_p19192 way to the Castle of Dracula. Here, [Madam]_n2316 Mina's hypnotic power will surely help, and [we]_p19193 shall find [our]_p19195 way, all dark and unknown otherwise, after the first sunrise when [we]_p19194 are near that fateful place. There is much to be done, and other places to be made sanctify, so that that nest of vipers be obliterated. " Here Jonathan interrupted [him]_p19196 hotly:, "Do [you]_p19197 mean to say, [Professor]_n2317 [Van Helsing]_n,2318 that [you]_p19198 would bring Mina, in [her]_p19202 sad case and tainted as [she]_p19203 is with that devil's illness, right into the jaws of [his]_p19204 death-trap? Not for the world! Not for Heaven or Hell!" [He]_p19207 became almost speechless for a minute, and then went on:, "Do [you]_p19198 know what the place is? Have [you]_p19199 seen that awful den of hellish infamy, with the very moonlight alive with grisly shapes, and every speck of dust that whirls in the wind a devouring monster in embryo? Have [you]_p19199 felt the Vampire's lips upon [your]_p19208 throat?" Here [he]_p19209 turned to me, and as [his]_p19205 eyes lit on [my]_p19212 forehead [he]_p19210 threw up [his]_p19205 arms with a cry: "Oh, [my]_p19213 God, what have [we]_p19214 done to have this terror upon us!" and [he]_p19210 sank down on the sofa in a collapse of misery. The [Professor]_n's2319 voice, as [he]_p19215 spoke in clear, sweet tones, which seemed to vibrate in the air, calmed [us]_p19216 all:, "Oh, [my]_p19217 friend, [it]_p19218 is because [I]_p19219 would save [Madam]_n2320 Mina from that awful place that [I]_p19220 would go. God forbid that [I]_p19221 should take [her]_p19222 into that place. There is work, wild work, to be done there, that [her]_p19223 eyes may not see.

[We]_p19224 men here, all save Jonathan, have seen with [their]_p19225 own eyes what is to be done before that place can be purify. Remember that [we]_p19226 are in terrible straits. If the Count escape [us]_p19227 this time, and [he]_p19228 is strong and subtle and cunning, [he]_p19229 may choose to sleep [him]_p19231 for a century, and then in time [our]_p19234 [dear]_n2321 one", [he]_p19229 took [my]_p19235 hand, "would come to [him]_p19232 to keep [him]_p19232 company, and would be as those others that you, Jonathan, saw. [You]_p19236 have told [us]_p19237 of [their]_p19238 gloating lips [you]_p19240 heard [their]_p19239 ribald laugh as [they]_p19241 clutched the moving bag that the Count threw to them. [You]_p19242 shudder and well may [it]_p19243 be. Forgive [me]_p19244 that [I]_p19245 make [you]_p19246 so much pain, but [it]_p19247 is necessary. [My]_p19248 friend, is [it]_p19249 not a dire need for the which [I]_p19252 am giving, possibly [my]_p19254 life? If [it]_p19250 were that any one went into that place to stay, [it]_p19250 is [I]_p19253 who would have to go to keep [them]_p19255 company. "  "Do as [you]_p19256 will," said Jonathan, with a sob that shook [him]_p19257 all over, "we are in the hands of God!"  * * * * *  Later. , Oh, [it]_p19258 did [me]_p19259 good to see the way that these brave men worked. How can women help loving men when [they]_p19260 are so earnest, and so true, and so brave! And, too, [it]_p19261 made [me]_p19265 think of the wonderful power of money! What can [it]_p19262 not do when [it]_p19262 is properly applied and what might [it]_p19263 do when basely used.

[I]_p19266 felt so thankful that [Lord]_n2322 [Godalming]_n2323 is rich, and that both [he]_p19267 and Mr Morris, who also has plenty of money, are willing to spend [it]_p19268 so freely. For if [they]_p19269 did not, [our]_p19270 little expedition could not start, either so promptly or so well equipped, as [it]_p19271 will within another hour. [It]_p19272 is not three hours since [it]_p19273 was arranged what part each of [us]_p19274 was to do and now [Lord]_n2324 [Godalming]_n2325 and Jonathan have a lovely steam launch, with steam up ready to start at a moment's notice. Dr [Seward]_n2326 and Mr Morris have half a dozen good horses, well appointed. [We]_p19275 have all the maps and appliances of various kinds that can be had. [Professor]_n2327 [Van Helsing]_n2328 and [I]_p19276 are to leave by the 11:40 train [to-night]_n2329 for Veresti, where [we]_p19277 are to get a carriage to drive to the [Borgo Pass]_n2330. [We]_p19278 are bringing a good deal of ready money, as [we]_p19279 are to buy a carriage and horses. [We]_p19280 shall drive ourselves, for [we]_p19281 have no one whom [we]_p19282 can trust in the matter. The [Professor]_n2331 knows something of a great many languages, so [we]_p19283 shall get on all right. [We]_p19284 have all got arms, even for [me]_p19285 a large-bore revolver Jonathan would not be happy unless [I]_p19286 was armed like the rest.

Alas! [I]_p19287 cannot carry one arm that the [rest]_n2332 do the scar on [my]_p19288 forehead forbids that. [Dear Dr Van Helsing]_n2333 comforts [me]_p19289 by telling [me]_p19290 that [I]_p19291 am fully armed as there may be wolves the weather is getting colder every hour, and there are snow-flurries which come and go as warnings. * * * * *  Later. , [It]_p19292 took all [my]_p19293 courage to say good-bye to [my]_p19294 darling. [We]_p19295 may never meet again. Courage, Mina! the Professor is looking at [you]_p19296 keenly  [his]_p19297 look is a warning. There must be no tears now, unless [it]_p19298 may be that God will let [them]_p19299 fall in gladness. Jonathan Harker's [Journal]_n2334. October 30. Night.

, [I]_p19300 am writing this in the light from the furnace door of the steam launch: [Lord Godalming]_n2335 is firing up. [He]_p19301 is an experienced hand at the work, as [he]_p19302 has had for years a launch of [his]_p19303 own on the Thames, and another on the [Norfolk Broads]_n2336. Regarding [our]_p19304 plans, [we]_p19305 finally decided that Mina's guess was correct, and that if any waterway was chosen for the Count's escape back to [his]_p19306 Castle, the Sereth and then the Bistritza at [its]_p19307 junction, would be the one. [We]_p19308 took it, that somewhere about the 47th degree, north latitude, would be the place chosen for the crossing the country between the river and the Carpathians. [We]_p19309 have no fear in running at good speed up the river at night there is plenty of water, and the banks are wide enough apart to make steaming, even in the dark, easy enough. [Lord]_n2337 [Godalming]_n2338 tells [me]_p19310 to sleep for a while, as [it]_p19311 is enough for the present for one to be on watch. But [I]_p19312 cannot sleep, how can [I]_p19313 with the terrible danger hanging over [my]_p19314 darling, and [her]_p19315 going out into that awful place. [My]_p19316 only comfort is that [we]_p19317 are in the hands of God. Only for that faith [it]_p19318 would be easier to die than to live, and so be quit of all the trouble. Mr Morris and Dr [Seward]_n2339 were off on [their]_p19319 long ride before [we]_p19320 started [they]_p19321 are to keep up the right bank, far enough off to get on higher lands where [they]_p19322 can see a good stretch of river and avoid the following of [its]_p19323 curves.

[They]_p19324 have, for the first stages, two men to ride and lead [their]_p19325 spare horses, four in all, so as not to excite curiosity. When [they]_p19326 dismiss the men, which shall be shortly, [they]_p19327 shall [themselves]_p19328 look after the horses. [It]_p19329 may be necessary for [us]_p19330 to join forces if so [they]_p19331 can mount [our]_p19332 whole party. One of the saddles has a movable horn, and can be easily adapted for [Mina]_n,2340 if required. [It]_p19333 is a wild adventure [we]_p19334 are on. Here, as [we]_p19335 are rushing along through the darkness, with the cold from the river seeming to rise up and strike [us]_p19336 with all the mysterious voices of the night around us, [it]_p19338 all comes home. [We]_p19339 seem to be drifting into unknown places and unknown ways into a whole world of dark and dreadful things. [Godalming]_n2341 is shutting the furnace door. * * * * *  31 October. , Still hurrying along.

The day has come, and [Godalming]_n2342 is sleeping. [I]_p19340 am on watch. The morning is bitterly cold the furnace heat is grateful, though [we]_p19341 have heavy fur coats. As yet [we]_p19342 have passed only a few open boats, but none of [them]_p19344 had on board any box or package of anything like the size of the one [we]_p19343 seek. The men were scared every time [we]_p19345 turned [our]_p19346 electric lamp on them, and fell on [their]_p19347 knees and prayed. * * * * *  1 November, evening. , No news all day [we]_p19348 have found nothing of the kind [we]_p19349 seek. [We]_p19350 have now passed into the Bistritza and if [we]_p19351 are wrong in [our]_p19352 surmise [our]_p19353 chance is gone. [We]_p19354 have over-hauled every boat, big and little. Early this morning, one crew took [us]_p19355 for a Government boat, and treated [us]_p19356 accordingly.

[We]_p19357 saw in this a way of smoothing matters, so at Fundu, where the Bistritza runs into the Sereth, [we]_p19358 got a Roumanian flag which [we]_p19359 now fly conspicuously. With every boat which [we]_p19360 have over-hauled since then this trick has succeeded [we]_p19361 have had every deference shown to us, and not once any objection to whatever [we]_p19361 chose to ask or do. Some of the [Slovaks]_n2343 tell [us]_p19363 that a big boat passed them, going at more than usual speed as [she]_p19364 had a double crew on board. This was before [they]_p19365 came to Fundu, so [they]_p19366 could not tell [us]_p19367 whether the boat turned into the Bistritza or continued on up the Sereth. At Fundu [we]_p19368 could not hear of any such boat, so [she]_p19369 must have passed there in the night. [I]_p19370 am feeling very sleepy the cold is perhaps beginning to tell upon me, and nature must have [rest]_n2344 some time. [Godalming]_n2345 insists that [he]_p19371 shall keep the first watch. God bless [him]_p19372 for all [his]_p19373 goodness to poor [dear]_n2346 Mina and me. * * * * *  2 November, morning. , [It]_p19374 is broad daylight.

That good fellow would not wake me. [He]_p19375 says [it]_p19376 would have been a sin to, for [I]_p19377 slept peacefully and was forgetting [my]_p19378 trouble. [It]_p19379 seems brutally selfish to [me]_p19380 to have slept so long, and let [him]_p19381 watch all night but [he]_p19382 was quite right. [I]_p19383 am a new man this morning and, as [I]_p19384 sit here and watch [him]_p19386 sleeping, [I]_p19384 can do all that is necessary both as to minding the engine, steering, and keeping watch. [I]_p19387 can feel that [my]_p19388 strength and energy are coming back to me. [I]_p19389 wonder where Mina is now, and [Van Helsing]_n2347. [They]_p19390 should have got to [Veresti]_n2348 about noon on [Wednesday]_n2349. [It]_p19391 would take [them]_p19392 some time to get the carriage and horses so if [they]_p19393 had started and travelled hard, [they]_p19394 would be about now at the [Borgo Pass]_n2350. God guide and help them! [I]_p19395 am afraid to think what may happen. If [we]_p19396 could only go faster! but [we]_p19397 cannot the engines are throbbing and doing [their]_p19398 utmost.

[I]_p19399 wonder how Dr [Seward]_n2351 and [Mr Morris]_n2352 are getting on. There seem to be endless streams running down the mountains into this river, but as none of [them]_p19400 are very large, at present, at all events, though [they]_p19401 are terrible doubtless in winter and when the snow melts, the horsemen may not have met much obstruction. [I]_p19402 hope that before [we]_p19403 get to Strasba [we]_p19404 may see [them]_p19406 for if by that time [we]_p19404 have not overtaken the Count, [it]_p19407 may be necessary to take counsel together what to do next. [Dr Seward]_n's2353 [Diary]_n2354. 2 November. , Three days on the road. No news, and no time to write [it]_p19408 if there had been, for every moment is precious. [We]_p19409 have had only the rest needful for the horses but [we]_p19410 are both bearing [it]_p19411 wonderfully. Those adventurous days of [ours]_p19412 are turning up useful. [We]_p19413 must push on  [we]_p19414 shall never feel happy till [we]_p19415 get the launch in sight again.

* * * * *  3 November. , [We]_p19416 heard at Fundu that the launch had gone up the Bistritza. [I]_p19417 wish [it]_p19418 wasn't so cold. There are signs of snow coming and if [it]_p19419 falls heavy [it]_p19420 will stop us. In such case [we]_p19421 must get a sledge and go on, Russian fashion. * * * * *  4 November. , To-day [we]_p19422 heard of the launch having been detained by an accident when trying to force a way up the rapids. The Slovak boats get up all right, by aid of a rope and steering with knowledge. Some went up only a few hours before. [Godalming]_n2355 is an amateur fitter himself, and evidently [it]_p19423 was [he]_p19424 who put the launch in trim again.

Finally, [they]_p19425 got up the rapids all right, with local help, and are off on the chase afresh. [I]_p19426 fear that the boat is not any better for the accident the peasantry tell [us]_p19427 that after [she]_p19428 got upon smooth water again, [she]_p19429 kept stopping every now and again so long as [she]_p19429 was in sight. [We]_p19431 must push on harder than ever [our]_p19432 help may be wanted soon. Mina Harker's [Journal]_n2356. 31 October. , Arrived at [Veresti]_n2357 at noon. The [Professor]_n2358 tells [me]_p19433 that this morning at dawn [he]_p19435 could hardly hypnotise [me]_p19434 at all, and that all [I]_p19436 could say was: "dark and quiet. " [He]_p19437 is off now buying a carriage and horses. [He]_p19438 says that [he]_p19439 will later on try to buy additional horses, so that [we]_p19440 may be able to change [them]_p19441 on the way. [We]_p19442 have something more than 70 miles before us.

The country is lovely, and most interesting if only [we]_p19443 were under different conditions, how delightful [it]_p19444 would be to see [it]_p19445 all. If [Jonathan]_n2359 and [I]_p19446 were driving through [it]_p19447 alone what a pleasure [it]_p19448 would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of [their]_p19449 life, and to fill [our]_p19450 minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people! But, alas!,   * * * * *  Later. , [Dr Van Helsing]_n2360 has returned. [He]_p19451 has got the carriage and horses [we]_p19452 are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour. The landlady is putting [us]_p19453 up a huge basket of provisions [it]_p19454 seems enough for a company of soldiers. The [Professor]_n2361 encourages her, and whispers to [me]_p19455 that [it]_p19456 may be a week before [we]_p19457 can get any good food again. [He]_p19458 has been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats and wraps, and all sorts of warm things. There will not be any chance of [our]_p19459 being cold. * * * * *  [We]_p19460 shall soon be off.

[I]_p19461 am afraid to think what may happen to us. [We]_p19462 are truly in the hands of God. [He]_p19463 alone knows what may be, and [I]_p19465 pray [Him]_n,2362 with all the strength of [my]_p19468 sad and humble soul, that [He]_p19464 will watch over [my]_p19469 beloved husband that whatever may happen, Jonathan may know that [I]_p19466 loved [him]_p19471 and honoured [him]_p19472 more than [I]_p19466 can say, and that [my]_p19469 latest and truest thought will be always for him. CHAPTER [XXVII]_n2363 [MINA HARKER]_n'S2364 JOURNAL 1 November. , All day long [we]_p19474 have travelled, and at a good speed. The horses seem to know that [they]_p19475 are being kindly treated, for [they]_p19476 go willingly [their]_p19477 full stage at best speed. [We]_p19478 have now had so many changes and find the same thing so constantly that [we]_p19479 are encouraged to think that the journey will be an easy one. [Dr Van Helsing]_n2365 is laconic [he]_p19480 tells the farmers that [he]_p19481 is hurrying to [Bistritz]_n,2366 and pays [them]_p19482 well to make the exchange of horses. [We]_p19483 get hot soup, or coffee, or tea and off [we]_p19484 go. [It]_p19485 is a lovely country full of beauties of all imaginable kinds, and the people are brave, and strong, and simple, and seem full of nice qualities.

[They]_p19486 are very, very superstitious. In the first house where [we]_p19487 stopped, when the woman who served [us]_p19488 saw the scar on [my]_p19489 forehead, [she]_p19490 crossed [herself]_p19491 and put out two fingers towards me, to keep off the evil eye. [I]_p19492 believe [they]_p19494 went to the trouble of putting an extra amount of garlic into [our]_p19495 food and [I]_p19493 can't abide garlic. Ever since then [I]_p19496 have taken care not to take off [my]_p19497 hat or veil, and so have escaped [their]_p19498 suspicions. [We]_p19499 are travelling fast, and as [we]_p19500 have no driver with [us]_p19502 to carry tales, [we]_p19501 go ahead of scandal but [I]_p19504 daresay that fear of the evil eye will follow hard behind [us]_p19503 all the way. The [Professor]_n2367 seems tireless all day [he]_p19505 would not take any rest, though [he]_p19506 made [me]_p19507 sleep for a long spell. At sunset time [he]_p19508 hypnotised me, and [he]_p19509 says that [I]_p19510 answered as usual "darkness, lapping water and creaking wood" so [our]_p19511 enemy is still on the river. [I]_p19512 am afraid to think of [Jonathan]_n,2368 but somehow [I]_p19513 have now no fear for him, or for myself. [I]_p19514 write this whilst [we]_p19515 wait in a farmhouse for the horses to be got ready. Dr [Van Helsing]_n2369 is sleeping, [Poor]_n2370 [dear]_n,2371 [he]_p19516 looks very tired and old and grey, but [his]_p19518 mouth is set as firmly as a conqueror's even in [his]_p19519 sleep [he]_p19517 is instinct with resolution.

When [we]_p19520 have well started [I]_p19521 must make [him]_p19523 rest whilst [I]_p19522 drive. [I]_p19524 shall tell [him]_p19525 that [we]_p19526 have days before us, and [we]_p19527 must not break down when most of all [his]_p19528 strength will be needed. All is ready [we]_p19529 are off shortly. * * * * *  2 November, morning. , [I]_p19530 was successful, and [we]_p19531 took turns driving all night now the day is on us, bright though cold. There is a strange heaviness in the air, [I]_p19532 say heaviness for want of a better word [I]_p19533 mean that [it]_p19534 oppresses [us]_p19535 both. [It]_p19536 is very cold, and only [our]_p19537 warm furs keep [us]_p19538 comfortable. At dawn [Van Helsing]_n2372 hypnotised [me]_p19539 [he]_p19540 says [I]_p19541 answered "darkness, creaking wood and roaring water," so the river is changing as [they]_p19542 ascend. [I]_p19543 do hope that [my]_p19544 darling will not run any chance of danger, more than need be but [we]_p19545 are in God's hands. * * * * *  2 November, night.

, All day long driving. The country gets wilder as [we]_p19546 go, and the great spurs of the Carpathians, which at Veresti seemed so far from [us]_p19547 and so low on the horizon, now seem to gather round [us]_p19548 and tower in front. [We]_p19549 both seem in good spirits [I]_p19550 think [we]_p19551 make an effort each to cheer the other in the doing so [we]_p19552 cheer ourselves. [Dr Van Helsing]_n2373 says that by morning [we]_p19553 shall reach the [Borgo Pass]_n2374. The houses are very few here now, and the [Professor]_n2375 says that the last horse [we]_p19554 got will have to go on with us, as [we]_p19555 may not be able to change. [He]_p19556 got two in addition to the two [we]_p19557 changed, so that now [we]_p19558 have a rude four-in-hand. The [dear]_n2376 horses are patient and good, and [they]_p19559 give [us]_p19560 no trouble. [We]_p19561 are not worried with other travellers, and so even [I]_p19562 can drive. [We]_p19563 shall get to the [Pass]_n2377 in daylight [we]_p19564 do not want to arrive before. So [we]_p19565 take [it]_p19566 easy, and have each a long [rest]_n2378 in turn.

Oh, what will to-morrow bring to us? [We]_p19567 go to seek the place where [my]_p19568 poor darling suffered so much. God grant that [we]_p19569 may be guided aright, and that [He]_p19570 will deign to watch over [my]_p19571 husband and those [dear]_n2379 to [us]_p19572 both, and who are in such deadly peril. As for me, [I]_p19573 am not worthy in [His]_p19574 sight. Alas! [I]_p19575 am unclean to [His]_p19576 eyes, and shall be until [He]_p19579 may deign to let [me]_p19580 stand forth in [His]_p19577 sight as one of those who have not incurred [His]_p19577 wrath. Memorandum by [Abraham Van Helsing]_n2380. 4 November. , This to [my]_p19581 old and true friend John [Seward]_n,2381 M. D. , of Purfleet, [London]_n,2382 in case [I]_p19582 may not see him. [It]_p19583 may explain.

[It]_p19584 is morning, and [I]_p19585 write by a fire which all the night [I]_p19586 have kept alive, [Madam Mina]_n2383 aiding me. [It]_p19587 is cold, cold so cold that the grey heavy sky is full of snow, which when [it]_p19588 falls will settle for all winter as the ground is hardening to receive it. [It]_p19590 seems to have affected [Madam]_n2384 Mina [she]_p19591 has been so heavy of head all day that [she]_p19592 was not like herself. [She]_p19593 sleeps, and sleeps, and sleeps! [She]_p19594 who is usual so alert, have done literally nothing all the day [she]_p19595 even have lost [her]_p19596 appetite. [She]_p19597 make no entry into [her]_p19598 little diary, [she]_p19599 who write so faithful at every pause. Something whisper to [me]_p19600 that all is not well. However, [to-night]_n2385 [she]_p19601 is more vif. [Her]_p19602 long sleep all day have refresh and restore her, for now [she]_p19603 is all sweet and bright as ever. At sunset [I]_p19604 try to hypnotise her, but alas! with no effect the power has grown less and less with each day, and [to-night]_n2386 [it]_p19605 fail [me]_p19606 altogether. Well, God's will be done, whatever [it]_p19607 may be, and whithersoever [it]_p19608 may lead! Now to the historical, for as [Madam]_n2387 Mina write not in [her]_p19609 stenography, [I]_p19610 must, in [my]_p19611 cumbrous old fashion, that so each day of [us]_p19612 may not go unrecorded.

[We]_p19613 got to the [Borgo Pass]_n2388 just after sunrise yesterday morning. When [I]_p19614 saw the signs of the dawn [I]_p19615 got ready for the hypnotism. [We]_p19616 stopped [our]_p19617 carriage, and got down so that there might be no disturbance. [I]_p19618 made a couch with furs, and [Madam Mina]_n,2389 lying down, yield [herself]_p19619 as usual, but more slow and more short time than ever, to the hypnotic sleep. As before, came the answer: "darkness and the swirling of water. " Then [she]_p19620 woke, bright and radiant and [we]_p19621 go on [our]_p19622 way and soon reach the Pass. At this time and place, [she]_p19623 become all on fire with zeal some new guiding power be in [her]_p19625 manifested, for [she]_p19624 point to a road and say:,   "This is the way. "  "How know [you]_p19626 it?" [I]_p19627 ask. "Of course [I]_p19628 know it," [she]_p19633 answer, and with a pause, add: "Have not [my]_p19634 Jonathan travelled [it]_p19631 and wrote of [his]_p19635 travel?"  At first [I]_p19629 think somewhat strange, but soon [I]_p19629 see that there be only one such by-road. [It]_p19636 is used but little, and very different from the coach road from the [Bukovina]_n2390 to [Bistritz]_n,2391 which is more wide and hard, and more of use.

So [we]_p19637 came down this road when [we]_p19638 meet other ways, not always were [we]_p19638 sure that [they]_p19640 were roads at all, for [they]_p19641 be neglect and light snow have fallen, the horses know and [they]_p19641 only. [I]_p19643 give rein to them, and [they]_p19644 go on so patient. By-and-by [we]_p19645 find all the things which Jonathan have note in that wonderful diary of him. Then [we]_p19646 go on for long, long hours and hours. At the first, [I]_p19647 tell [Madam Mina]_n2392 to sleep [she]_p19648 try, and [she]_p19649 succeed. [She]_p19650 sleep all the time till at the last, [I]_p19651 feel [myself]_p19652 to suspicious grow, and attempt to wake her. But [she]_p19653 sleep on, and [I]_p19654 may not wake [her]_p19656 though [I]_p19655 try. [I]_p19657 do not wish to try too hard lest [I]_p19658 harm [her]_p19660 for [I]_p19658 know that [she]_p19662 have suffer much, and sleep at times be all-in-all to her. [I]_p19663 think [I]_p19664 drowse myself, for all of sudden [I]_p19664 feel guilt, as though [I]_p19665 have done something [I]_p19665 find [myself]_p19668 bolt up, with the reins in [my]_p19670 hand, and the good horses go along jog, jog, just as ever. [I]_p19671 look down and find [Madam Mina]_n2393 still sleep.

[It]_p19672 is now not far off sunset time, and over the snow the light of the sun flow in big yellow flood, so that [we]_p19673 throw great long shadow on where the mountain rise so steep. For [we]_p19674 are going up, and up and all is oh! so wild and rocky, as though [it]_p19675 were the end of the world. Then [I]_p19676 arouse [Madam]_n2394 Mina. This time [she]_p19677 wake with not much trouble, and then [I]_p19678 try to put [her]_p19679 to hypnotic sleep. But [she]_p19680 sleep not, being as though [I]_p19681 were not. Still [I]_p19682 try and try, till all at once [I]_p19683 find [her]_p19685 and [myself]_p19686 in dark so [I]_p19683 look round, and find that the sun have gone down. [Madam Mina]_n2395 laugh, and [I]_p19687 turn and look at her. [She]_p19688 is now quite awake, and look so well as [I]_p19689 never saw [her]_p19690 since that night at Carfax when [we]_p19691 first enter the Count's house. [I]_p19692 am amaze, and not at ease then but [she]_p19694 is so bright and tender and thoughtful for [me]_p19695 that [I]_p19693 forget all fear. [I]_p19696 light a fire, for [we]_p19698 have brought supply of wood with us, and [she]_p19699 prepare food while [I]_p19697 undo the horses and set them, tethered in shelter, to feed.

Then when [I]_p19700 return to the fire [she]_p19701 have [my]_p19702 supper ready. [I]_p19703 go to help [her]_p19704 but [she]_p19705 smile, and tell [me]_p19709 that [she]_p19706 have eat already, that [she]_p19706 was so hungry that [she]_p19707 would not wait. [I]_p19710 like [it]_p19714 not, and [I]_p19711 have grave doubts but [I]_p19711 fear to affright her, and so [I]_p19712 am silent of it. [She]_p19716 help [me]_p19717 and [I]_p19718 eat alone and then [we]_p19721 wrap in fur and lie beside the fire, and [I]_p19719 tell [her]_p19722 to sleep while [I]_p19719 watch. But presently [I]_p19723 forget all of watching and when [I]_p19724 sudden remember that [I]_p19724 watch, [I]_p19725 find [her]_p19727 lying quiet, but awake, and looking at [me]_p19728 with so bright eyes. Once, twice more the same occur, and [I]_p19729 get much sleep till before morning. When [I]_p19730 wake [I]_p19731 try to hypnotise [her]_p19732 but alas! though [she]_p19734 shut [her]_p19733 eyes obedient, [she]_p19735 may not sleep. The sun rise up, and up, and up and then sleep come to [her]_p19736 too late, but so heavy that [she]_p19737 will not wake. [I]_p19738 have to lift [her]_p19740 up, and place [her]_p19741 sleeping in the carriage when [I]_p19739 have harnessed the horses and made all ready. [Madam]_n2396 still sleep, and [she]_p19742 look in [her]_p19743 sleep more healthy and more redder than before.

And [I]_p19744 like [it]_p19745 not. And [I]_p19746 am afraid, afraid, afraid!, [I]_p19747 am afraid of all things, even to think but [I]_p19747 must go on [my]_p19749 way. The stake [we]_p19750 play for is life and death, or more than these, and [we]_p19751 must not flinch. * * * * *  5 November, morning. , Let [me]_p19752 be accurate in everything, for though [you]_p19753 and [I]_p19755 have seen some strange things together, [you]_p19754 may at the first think that I, [Van Helsing]_n,2397 am mad, that the many horrors and the so long strain on nerves has at the last turn [my]_p19757 brain. All yesterday [we]_p19758 travel, ever getting closer to the mountains, and moving into a more and more wild and desert land. There are great, frowning precipices and much falling water, and [Nature]_n2398 seem to have held sometime [her]_p19759 carnival. [Madam]_n2399 Mina still sleep and sleep and though [I]_p19760 did have hunger and appeased it, [I]_p19761 could not waken her, even for food. [I]_p19762 began to fear that the fatal spell of the place was upon her, tainted as [she]_p19763 is with that [Vampire]_n2400 baptism. "Well," said [I]_p19764 to myself, "if [it]_p19766 be that [she]_p19768 sleep all the day, [it]_p19767 shall also be that [I]_p19765 do not sleep at night.

" As [we]_p19769 travel on the rough road, for a road of an ancient and imperfect kind there was, [I]_p19770 held down [my]_p19771 head and slept. Again [I]_p19772 waked with a sense of guilt and of time passed, and found [Madam]_n2401 Mina still sleeping, and the sun low down. But all was indeed changed the frowning mountains seemed further away, and [we]_p19773 were near the top of a steep-rising hill, on summit of which was such a castle as Jonathan tell of in [his]_p19774 diary. At once [I]_p19775 exulted and feared for now, for good or ill, the end was near. [I]_p19776 woke [Madam Mina]_n,2402 and again tried to hypnotise [her]_p19777 but alas! unavailing till too late. Then, ere the great dark came upon us, for even after down-sun the heavens reflected the gone sun on the snow, and all was for a time in a great twilight, [I]_p19778 took out the horses and fed [them]_p19780 in what shelter [I]_p19779 could. Then [I]_p19781 make a fire and near [it]_p19783 [I]_p19782 make [Madam]_n2403 Mina, now awake and more charming than ever, sit comfortable amid [her]_p19784 rugs.
